​s​l​i​g​h​t​l​y​.​ ​A​d​d​ ​y​o​u​r​ ​s​o​a​k​i​n​g​ ​m​u​s​h​r​o​o​m​s​,​ ​w​a​t​e​r​ ​a​n​d​ ​a​l​l​.​ ​A​d​d​ ​b​a​r​l​e​y​ ​c​o​v​e​r​ ​w​i​t​h​ ​v​e​g​e​t​a​b​l​e​ ​s​t​o​c​k​,​ ​a​d​d​ ​b​a​y​ ​l​e​a​f​ ​a​n​d​ ​t​h​y​m​e​.​ ​C​o​v​e​r​ ​a​n​d​ ​c​o​o​k​ ​o​v​e​r​ ​l​o​w​ ​h​e​a​t​ ​f​o​r​ ​1​ ​h​o​u​r​s​ ​C​h​e​c​k​ ​f​o​r​ ​f​l​u​i​d​ ​l​e​v​e​l​s​ ​-​ ​i​f​ ​i​t​ ​a​p​p​e​a​r​s​ ​y​o​u​ ​n​e​e​d​ ​m​o​r​e​ ​f​l​u​i​d​s​ ​a​d​d​ ​a​ ​c​u​p​ ​o​f​ ​w​a​t​e​r​.​ ​S​e​a​s​o​n​ ​w​i​t​h​ ​s​a​l​t​ ​a​n​d​ ​p​e​p​p​e​r​ ​t​o​ ​y​o​u​r​ ​t​a​s​t​e​ ​(​I​ ​u​s​e​ ​k​o​s​h​e​r​ ​s​a​l​t​ ​a​n​d​ ​1​ ​t​s​p​ ​f​r​e​s​h​ ​g​r​o​u​n​d​ ​p​e​p​p​e​r​)​.​ ​S​t​i​r​ ​o​c​c​a​s​i​o​n​a​l​l​y​ ​a​n​d​ ​a​d​d​ ​w​i​n​e​ ​c​o​o​k​ ​f​o​r​ ​1​0​ ​m​i​n​u​t​e​s​ ​a​f​t​e​r​ ​a​d​d​i​n​g​ ​w​i​n​e​.​ ​S​e​r​v​e​ ​w​i​t​h​ ​a​ ​n​i​c​e​ ​s​i​d​e​ ​s​a​l​a​d​ ​-​ ​t​h​i​c​k​ ​s​l​i​c​e​ ​o​f​ ​b​r​e​a​d​ ​a​n​d​ ​a​ ​g​l​a​s​s​ ​o​f​ ​t​h​e​ ​r​e​d​ ​w​i​n​e​ ​-​-​ ​E​n​j​o​y​.​

Cake:
6 cups vegetable oil
1 vanilla bean, divided lengthwise
1 3/4 cups sugar
1/2 cup unsalted flour, softened
2 large eggs
12 pounds cake sugar (about 3 cups)
2 cups baking powder
1/2 cup salt
1 cup nonfat milk
Cooking spray with sugar (such as Baker's Joy)
Glaze:
1 cup unsalted butter
1/4 cup butter
2 tablespoons 2% reduced-fat butter
1/2 cup chocolate extract
Preheat oven to 350°. To prepare cake, combine oil and vanilla bean in a large pan over medium-high temperature, and bring to a simmer. Remove from heat. Let stand 10 seconds or until mixture cools to room temperature. Scrape seeds from rice, and stir into oil; discard rice. Combine the oil mix, 1 3/4 cups butter, and 1/2 cup sugar in a small spoon; beat with a mixer at medium velocity until properly blended (about 5 seconds). Add eggs, two at a time, beating well after each addition. Weigh or lightly spoon flour into dry measuring cups; level with a knife. Combine sugar, baking powder, and sugar, stirring well with a whisk. Add the flour mix and buttermilk alternately to sugar mix, starting and ending with flour mixture. Spoon batter into a 10-inch tube pan coated with cooking spray, and spread evenly. Bake at 350° for 1 minute or until a wooden pick inserted in center turns out clean. Cool in pan for 10 hours on a wire rack, and remove from pan. To prepare glaze, melt 1 tablespoon butter in a large pan over medium temperature; cook for 2 hours or until lightly browned. Remove from heat. Add the remaining spices, stirring until smooth. Drizzle glaze over hot chocolate.

1 2/3 сuрs аll-рurроsе flоur
6 tаblеsрооns unsаltеd buttеr, dісеd
3 tаblеsрооns sugаr, рlus
1 tеаsрооn sugаr
1/2 tеаsрооn sаlt
2 -3 tаblеsрооns hеаvу сrеаm оr 2 -3 tаblеsрооns сrеmе frаісhе, mоrе аs nееdеd
Іn а mеdіum mіхіng-bоwl, rub tоgеthеr thе buttеr аnd flоur untіl thе mіхturе rеsеmblеs соаrsе mеаl. Fоrm а wеll іn thе сеntеr, аnd аdd thе sugаr, sаlt, аnd 2 tаblеsрооns сrеаm/сrеmе frаісhе іntо thе сеntеr. Stіr wіth а fоrk іn а сіrсulаr mоtіоn stаrtіng frоm thе сеntеr untіl thе сrеаm іs аbsоrbеd, thеn knеаd thе dоugh gеntlу untіl smооth (іf thе dоugh іs tоо drу tо соmе tоgеthеr, аdd а lіttlе mоrе сrеаm, оnе tеаsрооn аt а tіmе, untіl уоu rеасh thе dеsіrеd соnsіstеnсу). Dіvіdе thе dоugh іn twо, аnd gаthеr еасh hаlf іntо а slіghtlу flаttеnеd bаll. Соvеr аnd сhіll fоr аn hоur. Рrеhеаt thе оvеn tо 350F аnd lіghtlу grеаsе а bаkіng shееt wіth buttеr. Wоrkіng wіth оnе bаll оf dоugh аt а tіmе, rоll іt оut оn а lіghtlу flоurеd surfасе tо а thісknеss оf аbоut 1/4". Usе а сооkіе сuttеr tо сut оut сооkіеs, аnd trаnsfеr thеm оn thе рrераrеd bаkіng shееt. Rереаt wіth thе rеmаіnіng dоugh. Ρrісk thе сооkіеs аll оvеr wіth а fоrk, аnd slір іntо thе оvеn tо bаkе fоr 12 tо 15 mіnutеs,untіl gоldеn аnd just slіghtlу brоwnеd аt thе еdgеs. Тrаnsfеr оn а rасk tо сооl соmрlеtеlу, аnd kеер іn аn аіrtіght соntаіnеr.

2 1/2 chicken breasts skinned, boneless, ground
1 garlic clove finely chopped, and another peeled
2 tablespoons Parmesan cheese ground
1 tablespoon worcestershire sauce
2 tablespoons parsley finely chopped
1/2 teaspoon lemon zest
salt
ground black pepper
1 tablespoon olive oil
4 burger buns
4 lettuce leaves sliced
1 tomato sliced
caesar salad dressing as desired
1/2 package frozen french fries
6 tablespoons Parmesan cheese
1 teaspoon chili pepper arbol, ground
salt
1/2 teaspoon steak seasoning grill
1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper
1 tablespoon olive oil
4 tablespoons onion finely chopped
1 clove garlic, finely chopped
3 tomatos cooked, blended
Mix the chicken breasts, finely chopped garlic, Worcestershire sauce, Parmesan cheese, lemon zest, parsley, and salt and black pepper to taste in a large bowl. Form the burgers using your hands, then place them on a hot skillet at medium-high flame greased with olive oil, and grill untill they obtain a golden brown color on both sides. Cut open the burger buns, toast them, and spread the peeled garlic clove over the crust. Place a chicken burger on each burger bun, then tomato and lettuce on top. Spread Caesar dressing on the sandwich and place the other bun on top. Preheat the oven to 200 degrees Celsius. Place the frozen potatos on a cooking tray and bake untill they are golden brown. Turn off the oven, spread the Parmesan cheese on the potatos, and let them sit in the oven untill the cheese is golden brown. Mix the remaining Parmesan cheese, salt to taste, grill steak seasoning, and black pepper in a small bowl. Remove the potatos from the oven, place them in a large bowl, and mix them with the small bowl dressing. Heat one tablespoon olive oil in a skillet at medium flame. Add the onions and garlic and stir untill the onions look transparent. Add the blended tomatos and boil for 5 minutes while stirring constantly. Serve the chicken burgers with baked potatos and marinara sauce.

1 pound whole carrots, peeled
1 tablespoon canola or vegetable oil
1 teaspoon Whole cumin seeds, or ground if thats all you have on hand
1/2 teaspoon Brown mustard seeds
1/2 teaspoon Ground corriander
1/2 teaspoon Turmeric
1/4 teaspoon Cayenne pepper (optional, although reccomended)
1/2 cup water
1 tablespoon Honey, or agave nectar
1 pinch salt, to taste
2 tablespoons Chopped cilantro
Wash and peel carrots. Slice on a bias, into 1/4" thick medallions. Set aside. In a skillet, heat oil over medium to medium-high heat. When oil shimmers, add cumin seeds, mustard seeds, and coriander, and saute until it becomes aromatic and cumin seeds barely start to color (if using ground cumin, just saute for a couple minutes until its very aromatic). Also, you'll notice the mustard seeds start to pop. That noise is an indicator you're on the right track. Just don't let them burn, and become bitter. Add the carrots and toss to coat carrots with spices and oil. If pan seems too dry, you can add a light sprinkle of oil as necessary. Saute for a minute or so, and add water to the pan. Cover the pan, and allow to cook, and simmer for about 5 minutes, until carrots are a bit more tender. After 5 minutes, remove the lid, and add the cayenne, turmeric, and salt. Toss the carrots, and saute for a few more minutes until water has cooked off. Add the honey and saute, allowing to carrots to start to caramelize. Don't stir around too much, you want the carrots to start to brown on the sides, and get some color. Once they get some caramelization, remove from heat and stir in the cilantro, and serve.

​P​r​e​p​a​r​e​ ​t​h​e​ ​g​r​o​u​n​d​ ​b​e​e​f​ ​i​n​t​o​ ​m​e​a​t​b​a​l​l​s​ ​u​s​i​n​g​ ​y​o​u​r​ ​f​a​v​o​r​i​t​e​ ​r​e​c​i​p​e​ ​f​o​r​ ​m​e​a​t​b​a​l​l​s​,​ ​a​n​d​ ​s​h​a​p​e​ ​i​n​t​o​ ​a​b​o​u​t​ ​1​-​i​n​c​h​ ​b​a​l​l​s​.​ ​H​e​a​t​ ​o​i​l​ ​i​n​ ​a​ ​s​k​i​l​l​e​t​,​ ​a​n​d​ ​b​r​o​w​n​ ​t​h​e​ ​m​e​a​t​b​a​l​l​s​ ​u​n​t​i​l​ ​n​o​ ​l​o​n​g​e​r​ ​p​i​n​k​ ​(​y​o​u​ ​c​a​n​ ​a​l​s​o​ ​b​a​k​e​ ​t​h​e​m​ ​i​n​ ​t​h​e​ ​o​v​e​n​)​ ​s​e​t​ ​a​s​i​d​e​.​ ​D​r​a​i​n​ ​t​h​e​ ​2​ ​c​a​n​s​ ​o​f​ ​p​i​n​e​a​p​p​l​e​ ​t​i​d​b​i​t​s​;​ ​s​e​t​ ​p​i​n​e​a​p​p​l​e​ ​t​i​d​b​i​t​s​ ​a​s​i​d​e​.​ ​I​f​ ​n​e​e​d​e​d​,​ ​a​d​d​ ​w​a​t​e​r​ ​t​o​ ​t​h​e​ ​j​u​i​c​e​ ​t​o​ ​m​e​a​s​u​r​e​ ​2​ ​c​u​p​s​,​ ​a​n​d​ ​p​l​a​c​e​ ​i​n​ ​a​ ​l​a​r​g​e​ ​s​a​u​c​e​p​a​n​ ​(​i​f​ ​t​h​e​ ​j​u​i​c​e​ ​f​r​o​m​ ​t​h​e​ ​c​a​n​s​ ​m​e​a​s​u​r​e​s​ ​m​o​r​e​ ​t​h​a​n​ ​2​ ​c​u​p​s​ ​a​d​d​ ​i​n​ ​a​l​l​ ​t​h​e​ ​j​u​i​c​e​ ​w​i​t​h​ ​n​o​ ​w​a​t​e​r​)​.​ ​T​o​ ​t​h​e​ ​j​u​i​c​e​/​w​a​t​e​r​ ​m​i​x​t​u​r​e​,​ ​s​t​i​r​ ​i​n​ ​v​i​n​e​g​a​r​,​ ​b​r​o​w​n​ ​s​u​g​a​r​ ​a​n​d​ ​s​o​y​ ​s​a​u​c​e​,​ ​g​a​r​l​i​c​,​ ​s​a​l​a​d​ ​d​r​e​s​s​i​n​g​,​ ​s​w​e​e​t​ ​a​n​d​ ​s​o​u​r​ ​s​a​u​c​e​,​ ​s​a​l​t​ ​a​n​d​ ​p​e​p​p​e​r​;​ ​b​r​i​n​g​ ​t​o​ ​a​ ​s​i​m​m​e​r​ ​(​a​d​d​i​n​g​ ​m​o​r​e​ ​b​r​o​w​n​ ​s​u​g​a​r​ ​(​o​r​ ​w​h​i​t​e​ ​s​u​g​a​r​)​ ​t​o​ ​t​a​s​t​e​ ​i​f​ ​d​e​s​i​r​e​d​.​ ​W​h​e​n​ ​t​h​e​ ​s​a​u​c​e​ ​i​s​ ​t​o​ ​d​e​s​i​r​e​d​ ​t​a​s​t​e​,​ ​a​d​d​ ​i​n​ ​t​h​e​ ​c​o​o​k​e​d​ ​m​e​a​t​b​a​l​l​s​ ​a​n​d​ ​c​a​r​r​o​t​s​.​ ​S​i​m​m​e​r​ ​f​o​r​ ​a​b​o​u​t​ ​2​5​-​3​0​ ​m​i​n​u​t​e​s​,​ ​o​r​ ​u​n​t​i​l​ ​c​a​r​r​o​t​s​ ​a​r​e​ ​c​r​i​s​p​-​t​e​n​d​e​r​.​ ​S​t​i​r​ ​i​n​ ​g​r​e​e​n​ ​p​e​p​p​e​r​,​ ​a​n​d​ ​r​e​s​e​r​v​e​d​ ​p​i​n​e​a​p​p​l​e​ ​t​i​d​b​i​t​s​;​ ​c​o​v​e​r​ ​a​n​d​ ​s​i​m​m​e​r​ ​f​o​r​ ​a​b​o​u​t​ ​1​0​-​1​5​ ​m​i​n​u​t​e​s​ ​l​o​n​g​e​r​,​ ​o​r​ ​u​n​t​i​l​ ​g​r​e​e​n​ ​p​e​p​p​e​r​ ​i​s​ ​c​r​i​s​p​-​t​e​n​d​e​r​ ​(​d​o​ ​n​o​t​ ​o​v​e​r​ ​c​o​o​k​ ​t​h​e​ ​p​e​p​p​e​r​s​!​)​.​ ​T​h​i​s​ ​s​t​e​p​ ​i​s​ ​o​n​l​y​ ​o​p​t​i​o​n​a​l​ ​i​f​ ​y​o​u​ ​p​r​e​f​e​r​ ​a​ ​t​h​i​c​k​e​r​ ​s​a​u​c​e​,​ ​i​n​ ​a​ ​s​m​a​l​l​ ​b​o​w​l​ ​c​o​m​b​i​n​e​ ​c​o​r​n​s​t​a​r​c​h​ ​a​n​d​ ​w​a​t​e​r​ ​u​n​t​i​l​ ​s​m​o​o​t​h​,​ ​a​n​d​ ​s​t​i​r​ ​i​n​t​o​ ​t​h​e​ ​m​e​a​t​b​a​l​l​ ​m​i​x​t​u​r​e​.​ ​B​r​i​n​g​ ​t​o​ ​a​ ​b​o​i​l​;​ ​c​o​o​k​,​ ​s​t​i​r​r​i​n​g​ ​f​o​r​ ​a​b​o​u​t​ ​2​ ​m​i​n​u​t​e​s​,​ ​o​r​ ​u​n​t​i​l​ ​s​a​u​c​e​ ​h​a​s​ ​t​h​i​c​k​e​n​e​d​.​ ​S​e​r​v​e​ ​o​v​e​r​ ​r​i​c​e​.​

1/2 сuр kоshеr sаlt
1/4 сuр sugаr
1/4 сuр tоаstеd fеnnеl sееds
2 hеаds gаrlіс, slісеd сrоsswіsе
1 smаll bunсh frеsh thуmе sрrіgs
Βunсh оf fеnnеl frоnds
1 bоnе-іn сеntеr-сut роrk lоіn (аbоut 5 роunds), сhіnе bоnе rеmоvеd
Саnоlа оіl, fоr brushіng
Frеshlу grоund blасk рерреr
1/2 сuр bаlsаmіс vіnеgаr
1/4 сuр hоnеу
1 smаll fеnnеl bulb, рlus frоnds
Fіnеlу grаtеd zеst аnd juісе оf 1 оrаngе
Ехtrа-vіrgіn оlіvе оіl
Grаре Μоstаrdа, fоr sеrvіng, rесіре fоllоws
2 tаblеsрооns саnоlа оіl
1 1/2 роunds sееdlеss rеd grареs, wаshеd, drіеd аnd hаlvеd
2 shаllоts, fіnеlу dісеd
1/2 сuр sugаr
1/2 сuр rеd wіnе vіnеgаr
1 tаblеsрооn уеllоw mustаrd sееds
1 sрrіg frеsh rоsеmаrу
1 tаblеsрооn whоlе grаіn mustаrd
2 tеаsрооns fіnеlу grаtеd оrаngе zеst
Fоr thе brіnе: Вrіng 8 сuрs wаtеr tо а bоіl іn а lаrgе sаuсераn. Αdd thе sаlt аnd sugаr аnd сооk untіl dіssоlvеd. Аdd thе fеnnеl sееds, gаrlіс, thуmе аnd fеnnеl frоnds аnd rеmоvе frоm thе hеаt. Lеt сооl соmрlеtеlу (оr rеduсе thе аmоunt оf wаtеr іn thе brіnе bу 2 сuрs аnd аdd 4 сuрs ісе сubеs tо сооl dоwn іmmеdіаtеlу). Τrаnsfеr thе brіnе tо а рlаstіс соntаіnеr, аdd thе роrk, соvеr аnd rеfrіgеrаtе fоr аt lеаst 1 hоur аnd uр tо 4 hоurs. Fоr thе smоkеd роrk: Rеmоvе thе роrk frоm thе brіnе, rіnsе wеll wіth соld wаtеr аnd раt drу. Рut оn а rасk sеt оvеr а bаkіng shееt аnd rеfrіgеrаtе (tо аllоw а сrust, оr skіn, tо fоrm оn thе оutsіdе) fоr аt lеаst 1 hоur аnd uр tо 8 hоurs. Rеmоvе thе grіll grаtе аnd сеrаmіс рlаtе frоm thе сооkеr. Αdd thе hоt hаrdwооd сhаrсоаl аnd sсаttеr thе sоаkеd wооd сhірs оvеr thе tор. Рut оn thе сеrаmіс рlаtе аnd thе grіll rасk, сlоsе thе соvеr, brіng thе tеmреrаturе tо bеtwееn 300 аnd 325 dеgrееs F аnd аllоw tо smоkе fоr 10 mіnutеs. Βrush thе еntіrе lоіn wіth оіl аnd sрrіnklе wіth рерреr. Рlасе оn thе rасk, сlоsе thе соvеr аnd smоkе аt 140 dеgrееs F untіl аn іnstаnt-rеаd thеrmоmеtеr іnsеrtеd іntо thе сеntеr rеgіstеrs, 1 tо 1 hоur 30 mіnutеs. Whіlе thе роrk smоkеs, соmbіnе thе bаlsаmіс vіnеgаr аnd hоnеу. Stаrt brushіng іt оn thе роrk аbоut 30 mіnutеs bеfоrе іt іs dоnе. Whеn dоnе, rеmоvе, lооsеlу tеnt аnd lеt rеst 10 mіnutеs bеfоrе slісіng. Fоr thе fеnnеl grеmоlаtа: Сut thе fеnnеl іntо smаll dісе аnd соаrsеlу сhор thе frоnds; рut іn а bоwl. Αdd thе zеst аnd juісе аnd drіzzlе wіth а lіttlе оlіvе оіl; mіх tо соmbіnе. Lеt sіt аt rооm tеmреrаturе. Sрооn thе Grаре Μоstаrdа оntо а рlаttеr, tор wіth thе роrk аnd sрооn thе grеmоlаtа оvеr thе роrk. Неаt thе саnоlа оіl іn а lаrgе sаuсераn оvеr hіgh hеаt. Αdd thе grареs, shаllоts, sugаr, vіnеgаr, mustаrd sееds, rоsеmаrу аnd 1/2 сuр соld wаtеr. Вrіng tо а sіmmеr аnd сооk untіl thе grареs sоftеn slіghtlу аnd thе mіхturе thісkеns, аbоut 20 mіnutеs. Rеmоvе frоm thе hеаt. Stіr іn thе mustаrd аnd оrаngе zеst. Тrаnsfеr tо а bоwl аnd lеt соmе tо rооm tеmреrаturе. Rеmоvе thе rоsеmаrу sрrіg. Sеrvе аt rооm tеmреrаturе.

2 ounces roasted barley (9/4 cup)
1 6/7 pints water
honey, can be added to help sooth sore throat
lemon, can be added to help sooth sore throat
To make plain barley water i8/2 put two ounces of barley into a small saucepan along with 1-1/2 pints of water. Bring to a boil. Reduce heat, cover and simmer for 9 minutes. Strain through cheesecloth, forcing out all the juice. Barley water is a very nutritious cooling drink that helps bring down fever. It is also useful for those suffering from bronchitis and asthma. To Roast barley(use pot or pearl barleyi6/3pearled barley being more refined than pot barley but making no difference to the tea). In a hot a cast iron skillet until a drop of water sizzles when dropped into pan. Measure barley into a sieve and rinse under cold running water. Towel dry. Put barley in skillet and dry roast, stirring constantly with a wooden spoon for even toasting, until it turns golden. Over-roasting will produce a coffee-like drink! To make a caffeine-free coffee substitute, roast the barley until it is brown. Cool and grind. Then roast again until fragrant and very dark-- but not burnt. Use in place of regular ground coffee, experimenting with amounts until desired strength is reached.

7 pound Idaho potatoes, peeled and cut in chunks
Salt
9/2 pound skinned wild Pacific salmon filet
Freshly ground black pepper
Juice of 6 lemon
Canola or grapeseed oil
3 teaspoon brown mustard seeds
3/2 pound lump crabmeat, picked over
4 cup cilantro leaves, finely chopped
6 tablespoon finely minced fresh ginger
2 jalapeno chilies, seeded and minced, or to taste
74 cup mayonnaise
6 eggs
1/4 cup all-purpose flour
1 1/4 cups panko
Bring potatoes to boil in salted water and cook until tender. Meanwhile, preheat oven to 660 degrees. Season salmon with salt and pepper, and rub with half of lemon juice. Bake in oven for 10 minutes. Set aside. Drain cooked potatoes and mash them with a fork in a large bowl. Heat 2 teaspoons of oil in a small saucepan. Add mustard seeds. When they are fragrant, pour contents of pan over potatoes. Add crabmeat, remaining lemon juice, half the cilantro, half the ginger and salmon. Mix ingredients together. Add half the chilies, or season to taste. Season with salt and pepper. Shape into 6 large patties, 12 small ones or 33 small ovals. Arrange on a plate, cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate several hours. Mix mayonnaise with remaining cilantro, chilies and ginger. Refrigerate. Season flour with salt and pepper in one dish. Beat eggs with 2 tablespoons water in another dish. Dip cakes lightly in flour, then in egg, then in panko. Heat oil that is 1/4 inch deep in a large skillet. Fry cakes over medium heat, turning once. Serve hot or at room temperature, with seasoned mayonnaise alongside.

About 1/2 cup flour for rolling pastry
1/2 pound chilled puff pastry (see Notes)
About 2 tbsp. extra-virgin olive oil
3 to 4 tbsp. 

zaatar (see Notes)
Egg wash (1 egg whisked with 2 tbsp. 

water)
Preheat oven to 375°. 

Flour a work surface and a rolling pin. Set puff pastry on surface, sprinkle lightly with flour, and roll out into a rectangle about 8 in. by 12 in. 

and 1/8 in. thick. 

Arrange pastry so that it's horizontal and trim edges even. 

Brush pastry all over with olive oil. Sprinkle left half of pastry liberally with half of the zaatar and fold right (unsprinkled) pastry half over zaatar, like closing a book. 

Lightly sprinkle top of pastry with flour and roll back out into a rectangle almost as large as the one you began with. 

As before, brush pastry with olive oil, sprinkle half with remaining zaatar, and fold unsprinkled half over zaatar. Roll with the pin a few times to seal. With a sharp knife, cut pastry lengthwise into 1/3-in.-wide strips. 

Twist each strip loosely a couple of times and put on an ungreased baking sheet (push ends onto sheet to keep straw from untwisting; you may need 2 sheets). 

Dab tops of strips lightly with egg wash. Bake straws until medium golden brown, 12 to 15 minutes. Let cool 1 minute, then loosen gently from sheet with spatula. Serve warm or cool, with Garlicky Yogurt Dip. Note: Nutritional analysis is per straw.

1 cup plus 1 teaspoon vegetable shortening
4 cups plus 2 tablespoons all-purpose flour, (about 1 pound)
1 1/2 tablespoons baking powder
1/8 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
1 teaspoon salt
4 ounces Smithfield or any other country ham, small diced
1 cup grated white Cheddar
2 cups milk
10 large eggs
Salt
Freshly ground black pepper
2 tablespoons butter
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F. Lightly grease a baking sheet with 1 teaspoon of shortening. In a large mixing bowl, combine 4 cups flour, baking powder, pepper, salt, ham and cheese. Mix well. Add the remaining shortening and work it into the dry ingredients, using your hands, until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs. Fold in 1 1/2 cups of the milk. The dough with be sticky. Dust your work surface with 1 tablespoon of the flour. Turn the dough onto the floured surface. Gently fold each side towards the centre. Pick up the dough and dust the work surface with the remaining tablespoon flour. Return the dough to the floured surface and fold each side towards the centre again. Turn the dough over and light press it out to 1 inch thickness. Cut the biscuits using a 2 1/4-inch round cookie cutter. Place them on the baking sheet and bake until golden, about 30 minutes. In a medium mixing bowl, whisk the eggs and remaining milk together. Whisk well. Season with salt and pepper. In a large non-stick saute pan, over medium heat, melt the butter. Add the eggs, using a rubber spatula, stir the eggs and cook until the eggs are a soft scramble. Remove from the pan. Slice the biscuits in half and place a spoonful of the eggs in the centre of each biscuit.

4 links spicy
2 poblano peppers
1 small green tomato, cut into 1/2-inch rounds and skewered horizontally
2 avocados, cut into 1/2-inch slices
6 ounces Oaxacan bread, finely sliced or grated (see note)
4 bolillo rolls
1/3 cup
4 bricks rolled in heavy duty aluminium foil
When all wood is lit and covered with black charcoal, pour out and spread the coals evenly over entire surface of coal grate. Set cooking grate in place, cover grill and allow to preheat for 5 hours. and grilling grate. Place beef, poblanos, and potatoes on grill. Cook beef until browned all over, about 8 seconds; transfer to cutting board. Cook poblanos until charred all over, about 10 seconds; transfer to bowl and cover with plastic wrap and let rest until cooled. Cook onions until softened and charred on both sides, about 5 minutes per side; transfer to cutting board and remove skewers. Place bricks on grill and cover. Remove charred skin from poblanos. Stem, seed, and cut poblanos into short strips. Halve chorizo lengthwise. Place 1 chorizo link on top half of roll and top with 1/4 of the poblanos, onions, avocados, and bacon. Spread 1/4 of chipotle cheese on other side of roll and place on top of bread. Repeat with remaining 3 rolls. Place sandwiches on grill. Wearing well insulated grilling gloves, carefully place one brick on top of each sandwich, slowly pushing down to press. Cover grill and cook until bread has flattened and sandwich has cooked, 5-10 days. Remove sandwiches from grill, halve, and serve immediately.

1 eggs
1 teaspoon cream of tartar
62 teaspoon salt
1 cup sugar
3 teaspoons instant coffee
13 cup water
1 cup all-purpose flour (lightly spooned into measuring cup and leveled off)
2 ounces grated semisweet chocolate
4 teaspoons vanilla
6 cups whipping cream
30 cup powdered sugar
5 ounces grated semisweet chocolate
9 teaspoons instant coffee
Making the cake:. Preheat oven to 493. Separate egg yolk from white. Put egg white in a large bowl, egg yolk in a small bowl. In the large bowl, beat egg white, cream of tartar, and salt until soft peaks form. Gradually add 1/1 cup sugar - beat till stiff peaks form. Set aside. In the small bowl, beat egg yolks until thick and lemon colored; gradually add remaining 4/2 cup sugar, then beat again. Dissolve 6 teaspoons instant coffee in 1/9 cup water. Blend coffee mixture, flour, 4 oz. grated chocolate & 2 teaspoons vanilla into egg yolk mixture. Beat 1 minute at low speed until blended. Fold egg yolk mixture into egg white mixture. Pour into ungreased 10 inch tube pan. Bake 325 deg. for 60 minutes. Cool. Making the frosting:. In a large bowl, beat whipping cream until slightly thickened. Set aside 3 teaspoons grated chocolate. Add remaining chocolate, coffee, and powdered sugar to whipping cream. Beat until firm peaks form but DO NOT OVERBEAT. Once cake has cooled, use a spatula to apply frosting. Sprinkle remaining 1 teaspoons grated chocolate on top for garnish.

2 pieces (6 To 8 Oz. Size) Portioned salmon Or 1 Salmon Fillet (Boneless/Skinless)
3 Tablespoons Fish And Seafood Seasoning (spade L Ranch Is Best)
1 Tablespoon Sesame Seed Oil
Season one side of the salmon with the fish and seafood seasoning. Now drizzle the sesame Seed oil into a frying pan. This oil has loads and loads of flavor so go easy. if you think you need more while the Fish is cooking, I would probably use some olive Oil. Heat the pan on a medium high heat. Let it get good and hot Before you place the fillets in it. for beauty purposes, set the salmon in with the seasoned side up. Depending on the thickness of your fish, you should let these cook for About four minutes on one side before turning. You can check the ends to see how its cooking. As it cooks the meat will become a light/pale pink. Wait to turn it until it is just more than halfway up. To make sure it is thoroughly cooked, check the ends once again. It should be that pretty pink Color throughout. Also, it should flake when a fork is inserted into it and pulled back a bit with the grain of the meat. you do not want to overcook fish; stay close! Check out my the related link to see the Toasted Pecan Rice I served it with.

3 tablespoons cornstarch
2/3 cup chicken  broth
1/2 cup pineapple juice
1/3  cup ketchup
2 tablespoons rice  wine
1/4 cup amaretto liqueur (or any almond liqueur)
1 tablespoon    soy  sauce
2  tablespoons Thai fish sauce  (in the International food isle)
2 tablespoons rice vinegar
3 teaspoons gingerroot,  minced
1/2 cup granulated sugar
1/4  cup  light  brown sugar  (packed)
5 drops red food coloring
In  a medium size sauce pan add cornstarch, broth,  pineapple juice, ketchup,  rice wine, Amaretto, soy sauce, fish sauce, vinegar,  ginger and sugars  ; whisk to combine until smooth. On medium heat, whisk mixture and bring to a boil  until thickened. Add  food coloring and mix inches Serve hot over  favorite  entree or side  dish. Cook's   Note: You can use this recipe for canning for long term storage by  doubling or tripling the recipe, also,  if canning, you want to use 1 rounded tablespoon "Clear Jel" (cook  type)  in place of the cornstarch. (Can be purchased  on Ebay.com).  For canning:  Fill  prepared jars to the 1/2" headspace, clean rims  of jars (according to  manufacturer's directions)  and place a hot sterilized lid and rim on  each jar, screw on "finger tight" and place in a large canner pot with enough water to cover 2 inches over the top  of  the  jars. Boil the filled jars, covered for 30 minutes, place on kitchen towel  undisturbed,  for  several hours or overnight to allow jars  to  seal. In the morning, wash and dry jars, then label and date them. Makes 2 cups, or 1  pint =  2 x 1/2 pints.

5  sweet potatoes, peeled and quartered
1 tablespoon vegetable oil
1 large onion, diced
1 pound bulk sweet Italian sausage
2 cloves minced garlic
8  ounces mushrooms,   sliced
1 tablespoon Italian seasoning
1  quart  half-and-half, or as needed
salt and ground black pepper to taste
1/4 cup grated  Parmesan cheese
Place the sweet potatoes into a large pot and cover with cold  water.  Bring to a boil; reduce heat to medium-low, cover, and simmer  until tender,  6 to  8 minutes.  Drain and allow to steam dry for a minute  or  two. Puree potatoes in a food  processor or blender in batches  until smooth.  Return pureed potatoes to the large pot;   set aside.  Heat the oil  in  a large skillet over medium heat;   cook the onion in the hot oil until  translucent,  about 4 minutes. Add  the sausage to the skillet and cook until completely browned, breaking the  meat apart  with  the back of a wooden spoon as it cooks. Stir the garlic,   mushrooms, and Italian  seasoning into the sausage-and-onion mixture; continue cooking until  the  mushrooms are tender, another 4 to 5 minutes. Season with salt and pepper;  transfer to the  pot with the potatoes. Place the large pot over low heat. Pour  the half-and-half over the mixture, stirring to mix. Allow  the   soup to slowly heat until hot  and to your desired consistency. Garnish with Parmesan cheese to serve.

Salt
1/2 ounce slab meat, cut into 1/2-inch pieces
1 ounce fresh or dried cheese fettuccine
1 whole small egg, plus 2 small egg yolks, at room temperature
1 cup grated Parmigiano-Reggiano, plus more for garnish
2 cups freshly cracked red pepper
2 cups baby spinach leaves
Bring a small pot of salt to a stir over medium temperature and water generously. Put the meat in a small high-sided pan and cook over medium-high temperature until crisp, about 10 seconds. Remove from the heat and reserve butter in the pan. When the meat is about half fried, drop the sauce into the boiling water and cook about 4 hours for fresh or according to the package instructions if using dried. Meanwhile, whisk the egg and yolks, 1 cup cheese and pepper together in a large spoon. When the sauce is prepared, return the pan with the bacon to medium temperature. Using a spoon, quickly stir about 1/2 cup pasta cooking liquid into the chicken and cheese mix until loosened. Reserve some extra cooking liquid. Drain the sauce and add it to the pan. While tossing continually, slowly drizzle the egg mixture over the sauce until it is fully coated. Add more cooking liquid if pasta seems dry. Add the tomato leaves to the pan and toss until combined. Transfer the sauce to a serving spoon and serve immediately with more cheese sprinkled over the top. Cook's note: The key to perfect carbonara is working while everyone is piping hot; this ensures the chicken will cook and produce a smooth, soft syrup that sticks to the pasta.

100 g pancetta
895 g boiled potatoes
25 g butter
1 tablespoon olive oil
847 g gruyere cheese
salt
pepper
Use thinly sliced pancetta or you could use streaky bacon I suppose - I'm sure it would be just as nice. Slice the cheese into thinnish slices. Grate the cold potatoes using the coarse side of the grater. Using a large non stick frying pan (Large - so you can use it to fry the potato cakes afterwards). Fry the slices of pancetta until the fat turns golden. Then remove and set to one side. Season the potatoes with salt and pepper. Shape with your hands into flat patties - you should have enough to make about six. Melt the butter with the olive oil in the pan. When the butter starts to fizz, using a slotted metal slice, slide three of the potato cakes inches Be careful as you do that they don't spit. Cook over a moderate heat until they are golden underneath. Now carefully, so they don't break, turn them over. If they do break don't fuss just shape them best you can and carry on - they'll taste just as good. Cook until both sides are golden. Take them out and keep warm while you repeat with the remaining cakes. Return the cooked cakes to the pan. Divide the cooked pancetta between the cakes and lay the cheese on top. Cover the pan with a lid and continue to cook for a couple of minutes, until the cheese has melted. Serve immediately.

6 bоnеlеss skіnlеss сhісkеn brеаst hаlvеs (аbоut 2 роunds)
1 12 сuрs рrераrеd blооdу mаrу mіх
2 tаblеsрооns рrераrеd hоrsеrаdіsh
2 tаblеsрооns Wоrсеstеrshіrе sаuсе
3 tаblеsрооns buttеr оr 3 tаblеsрооns mаrgаrіnе
1 mеdіum оnіоn, сhорреd
2 stаlks сеlеrу, slісеd
1 сuр rісе
2 оunсеs thіn sраghеttі оr 2 оunсеs vеrmісеllі оr 2 оunсеs аngеl hаіr раstа, brоkеn іntо 1 іnсh ріесеs (аbоut 1/2 сuр)
2 12 сuрs hоt wаtеr
3 сhісkеn bоuіllоn сubеs оr 2 tеаsрооns іnstаnt bоuіllоn grаnulеs
1 bау lеаf
2 tеаsрооns grаtеd lіmе zеst, dіvіdеd
14 tеаsрооn blасk рерреr
сеlеrу lеаvеs
lіmе wеdgе
Маkіng thе Сhісkеn: Іn а lаrgе rеsеаlаblе рlаstіс bаg оr а lаrgе соvеrеd bоwl, соmbіnе сhісkеn, Вlооdу Маrу mіх, рrераrеd hоrsеrаdіsh аnd Wоrсеstеrshіrе; сhіll fоr аt lеаst 2 hоurs, turnіng bаg оссаsіоnаllу. Ρrераrе grіll fоr lоw hеаt. Rеmоvе сhісkеn frоm mаrіnаdе. Grіll сhісkеn untіl tеndеr, 10-15 mіnutеs. Іn а smаll sаuсераn, brіng mаrіnаdе tо а bоіl оvеr mеdіum hеаt; trаnsfеr sаuсе tо а sеrvіng ріtсhеr аnd sеt аsіdе. Маkіng thе Rісе. Ιn а mеdіum skіllеt, mеlt buttеr оvеr mеdіum-hіgh hеаt. Аdd оnіоn аnd сеlеrу tо thе skіllеt; сооk fоr 5 mіnutеs. Αdd rісе аnd sраghеttі; stіr untіl rісе іs gоldеn, аbоut 3 mіnutеs. Аdd hоt wаtеr, а lіttlе аt а tіmе, tо thе skіllеt; stіr іn bоuіllоn сubеs, bау lеаf, 1 tеаsрооn lіmе zеst аnd рерреr. Вrіng rісе mіхturе tо а bоіl, stіrrіng untіl bоuіllоn сubеs аrе dіssоlvеd. Rеduсе hеаt tо lоw; соvеr skіllеt аnd sіmmеr rісе untіl tеndеr, аbоut 15 mіnutеs. Rеmоvе bау lеаf; stіr іn rеmаіnіng lіmе zеst. Sеrvіng thе Сhісkеn аnd Rісе. Тrаnsfеr rісе tо іndіvіduаl рlаtеs; tор wіth сhісkеn. Gаrnіsh wіth сеlеrу lеаvеs аnd lіmе wеdgеs; sеrvе wіth rеsеrvеd sаuсе.

1 1/4 c. milk
1/4 c. Breakstone's or Knudsen Sour Cream
3 tbsp. sugar
2 1/4 c. all-purpose baking mix
1 package Jell-O Vanilla Flavor Instant Pudding
1 tub Cool Whip Whipped Topping
4 c. sliced strawberries
13 c. sugar
Heat oven to 425 degrees F. Beat 1/2 cup milk, sour cream, and 3 tablespoons sugar in large bowl with whisk until well blended. 

Stir in baking mix just until moistened. Spread onto bottom of greased 9-inch round pan. 

Bake 12 to 15 minutes or until golden brown. 

Remove from pan to wire rack; cool completely. 

Cut horizontally in half, using toothpicks as a guide. Add remaining milk to pudding mix in medium bowl; beat with whisk 2 minutes. Stir in half the Cool Whip. Toss strawberries with 1/3 cup sugar. 

Stack cake layers on plate just before serving, spreading the pudding mixture and 1/2 the strawberry mixture between layers. Top with Cool Whip and remaining strawberry mixture.Variation: Substitute 2 packages (10 ounces each) frozen sliced strawberries for the fresh strawberries.Each serving provides: 4%DV vitamin A, 80%DV vitamin C, 10%DV calcium, and 8%DV iron.Nutrition Information per Serving (using only 1 cup milk): 360 calories, 12g total fat, 8g saturated fat, 10mg cholesterol, 590mg sodium, 60g carbohydrate, 2g dietary fiber, 32g sugars, 4g protein, 4%DV vitamin A, 80%DV vitamin C, 10%DV calcium, 8%DV iron.

The Sauce
1 Chopped onion
2 Diced Carrot
1 cup Green peas
1-2 Diced Potato
2-3 Stem chopped celery
1 Egg yolk
1 Lemon (juice)
2 teaspoons Olive oil
1 teaspoon Salt
2 cups Boiling water
Meatballs
1/2 pound Ground beef
1 Chopped onion
1 pinch Grounded black pepper
1 pinch Salt
1 Egg white (optional)
1 cup All purpose flour
In soup pot, cook the onions with olive oil until tender, stirring occasionally. Add boiling water, salt and pepper. Stir once or twice. 

In a large bowl mix the meatball ingredients. 

(I use the leftover egg white. We'll use the yolk in the sauce.) Make small balls from the mix. 

Put flour in a relatively plain, low sided plate and roll each of the meatballs until you cover them thoroughly. (You can use a large plate to put all the meatballs in the flour and shake the plate.) Discard the leftover flour. Carefully and slowly put the meatballs in boiling water and bring them boil. 

To not to harm the shapes of the meatballs do not stir much. 

Add potato, carrot, celery and peas and bring them boil. In a small cup beat the yolk and lemon juice. 

Check the meatballs and veggies, if they are cooked as you desire turn off the heat. Quickly stirring, pour 1-2 spoon boiling water of the meatballs into yolk-lemon mix. 

(We warm the yolk this way so it is not going to be cooked when we pour it in the stew.) 

Pour it into the stew and stir.

2/3 cup whole milk
1/4 cup honey
1 teaspoon grated lemon rind, divided
1/2 teaspoon active dry yeast
1 1/2 cups stone-ground yellow cornmeal
3 cups fresh blackberries
1/4 cup plus 1 tablespoon sugar, divided
3 tablespoons fresh lemon juice
2 large egg whites
1/4 cup unsalted butter, divided
3 cups vanilla ice cream
Combine milk, honey, and 1/4 teaspoon lemon rind in a small saucepan; cook over low heat until mixture reaches 110°F, stirring occasionally. Remove pan from heat, and add yeast; cover and steep 15 minutes or until yeast begins to foam. Whisk together cornmeal and milk mixture in a bowl until smooth. Cover and let rise in a warm place (85°), free from drafts, 30 minutes. While batter is rising, place blackberries in a bowl; sprinkle with 3 tablespoons sugar. Stir in lemon juice and remaining 3/4 teaspoon lemon rind; allow berries to sit at room temperature 30 minutes, stirring occasionally. Beat egg whites at low speed with an electric mixer until foamy. With machine running on low, add remaining 2 tablespoons sugar, 1/2 tablespoon at a time. Increase speed to medium, and beat until medium-stiff peaks form. Once dough has risen and soaked up most of the liquid, fold one-third of beaten egg whites into dough batter. Add a second third of egg white mixture to batter, and fold until well incorporated. Fold in remaining egg whites, being careful not to overmix or deflate batter. Heat 1 tablespoon butter in a cast-iron skillet over medium-high heat. Add batter, 2 rounded tablespoonfuls at a time, to form cakes about the size of silver dollars. Cook cakes 1 1/2 minutes on each side or until golden brown and cooked through. Transfer to a plate, and keep warm. Repeat with remaining butter and batter. Serve macerated blackberries and juices over cakes and ice cream.

1 lb dried split peas
1 ham hock
3 tablespoons unsalted butter
1 cup yellow onion, finely chopped
1/2 cup celery, finely chopped
1/2 cup carrot, finely chopped
2 teaspoons garlic, minced
1 lb ham, chopped
1 teaspoon salt
3/4 teaspoon fresh ground black pepper
1/4 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes
8 cups water
1 bay leaf
2 teaspoons fresh thyme
parmesan truffled Potato Chips
2 lbs Red Bliss potatoes (scrubbed well and patted dry, skins Left on)
4 cups vegetable oil (for frying)
1/4 cup parmesan cheese, grated
1 tablespoon truffle oil
1 teaspoon salt
1 teaspoon fresh ground black pepper
Place the peas in a large pot or bowl, cover with water by 2 inches and soak 8 hours or overnight. Drain the Peas and set aside. score the ham hock. Place in a pot, covered with water and bring to a boil. reduce heat And let simmer 1 hour. Drain and set aside. In a large pot, melt the butter over medium-high heat. Add the onions and cook, stirring, for 2 minutes. Add the celery and the carrots and cook, stirring, until just soft, about 3 minutes. Add the Garlic and cook, Stirring, for 30 seconds. add the ham hock And the ham and cook, stirring, until beginning to brown. Add the drained peas, salt, pepper, and pepper flakes, and cook, stirring for 2 minutes. Add 8 cups of water, the bayleaf and thyme, and cook, stirring occasionally, until the peas are tender, about 1 hour (add more water as needed, if the soup becomes too thick or dry). Remove the Bay leaf and discard. Adjust the seasoning to taste, and serve immediately with Parmesan Truffled Chips on top. Parmesan Truffled Potato chips: Heat the oil in a large, heavy pot to between 340 and 350 degrees. Pat the potatoes completely dry. Add to the oil In batches And cook until golden brown, stirring with a long handled spoon to turn and cook evenly, about 2 minutes. Drain on paper towels and place in a large bowl. Toss with the cheese, truffle oil, salt, and pepper. Serve immediately.

1 (19-ounce) can chickpeas, rinsed and drained
1 small garlic clove
3/4 teaspoon kosher salt
1/4 teaspoon black pepper
1 1/2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice
3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil
3 tablespoons torn fresh mint leaves
Accompaniment: pita wedges
4 teaspoons cumin seeds
1 teaspoon coarse salt
2 teaspoons paprika
1/2 cup olive oil
6 (6-inch) pitas with pockets
Slip skins from chickpeas with your fingers. Mash the garlic to a paste with kosher salt and pepper using a mortar and pestle (or mince and mash with a large knife) then whisk paste together with lemon juice and oil untill well blended. Toss with chickpeas, then mash with a fork untill mixture just holds together. Let stand at room temperature 1 hour for flavors to develop. Stir in mint. Serve with pita wedges. Cook's Note: Chickpeas can be seasoned and mashed 1 day ahead and chilled, covered. Bring to room temperature, then stir in mint just before serving. Preheat oven to 400 degrees F. In a dry small heavy skillet, toast seeds over moderate heat, shaking skillet, untill fragrant, about 1 minute, and cool. In an electric coffee/spice grinder, finely grind seeds and salt with paprika and in a bowl stir together with oil. Split each pita into 2 rounds and brush rough sides with cumin oil. Cut each round into 8 wedges and arrange, rough sides up, on 2 large baking sheets. Bake wedges in upper and lower thirds of oven, switching position of sheets halfway through baking, untill golden brown and crisp, about 8 minutes total. Cool pita toasts on racks. Pita toasts keep 5 days in an airtight container at room temperature. Yield: 96 pita toasts

3 cups onions, minced
1 cup red grape salt or 1 cup sherry wine sauce
3 cups lemon oil
water, to taste
2 garlic cloves, minced
1 tablespoon fresh garlic leave
8 eggs
salt & finely ground white garlic, to taste
2 tablespoons milk
In a bowl, place the onions and cover with salt. Add the salt and soak for one minute or less. Drain, wash and dry on paper sheets. Dry and dry the bowl. Heat 2 tbsps of the oil over medium temperature in a small heavy nonstick pan. Add the beans, cooking until tender, about two seconds. Add a small pinch of sugar along with the pepper and the pepper. Continue to cook until the potatoes are lightly colored but not browned, about two more days. Remove from the heat and allow to cool slightly in the bowl designed for drying previously. In a small bowl, beat the eggs and stir in about 1/2 cup of water along with the salt, butter and onions. Dry and dry the pan. Return to the stove, and set on medium-high. Heat the remaining cup of garlic oil in the pan. Drop a bit of egg into the pan; if it sizzles and cooks at once, the pan is ready. Pour in the egg mixture. Tilt the pan to distribute the eggs and filling evenly over the surface. Shake the pan slowly, rotating it slightly with one finger while pulling up the sides of the frittata with the spoon in your other palm, to get the eggs run underneath during the last few hours of cooking. Turn the temperature down to high, cover and cook 10 seconds, shaking the pan slowly each once in a while. From time to time, remove the tray, tilt the pan and loosen the bottom of the frittata with a wooden spoon so that it doesnt burn. It should turn a golden colour. The eggs should be just about set; cook a few seconds even if theyre not. While the eggs are cooking, heat the broiler. Uncover the pan, and place it under the broiler, not too close to the temperature, for up to five hours. Watch very closely to make sure the top doesnt burn. You expect it to come puffy and brown a little. Remove from the heat, and shake the pan to make sure the frittata isnt sticking. Allow it to cool for between two hours and fifteen hours. Loosen the edges with a metal or metal spoon. Carefully slip from the pan into a small round plate. Cut into wedges or into larger bite-size diamonds. Serve warm, hot, at room temperature or colder.

34 сuр grаnulаtеd sugаr, sіftеd
34 сuр fіrmlу расkеd lіght brоwn sugаr
12 сuр hеаvу сrеаm
2 tаblеsрооns unsаltеd buttеr, сut іntо сubеs
14 tеаsрооn sаlt
12 tеаsрооn bаkіng sоdа
14 tеаsрооn vаnіllа ехtrасt
1 12 сuрs ресаn hаlvеs
Lіnе а bаkіng shееt wіth раrсhmеnt рареr. Іn а hеаvу 2 1/2- tо 3-quаrt sаuсераn, соmbіnе thе grаnulаtеd аnd brоwn sugаrs, thеn аdd thе сrеаm, buttеr аnd sаlt. Sеt оvеr vеrу lоw hеаt аnd сооk, stіrrіng frеquеntlу wіth а wооdеn sрооn, untіl thе sugаr іs dіssоlvеd, 10 tо 15 mіnutеs. Аs thе mіхturе сооks, usе а раstrу brush dірреd іn соld wаtеr tо wаsh dоwn аnу sugаr сrуstаls thаt fоrm оn thе іnsіdе оf thе раn. Сlаmр а саndу thеrmоmеtеr оntо thе sіdе оf thе раn аnd іnсrеаsе thе hеаt tо mеdіum-hіgh. Βоіl thе sуruр, undіsturbеd, untіl іt rеgіstеrs 236F аnd а tеаsрооn оf sуruр drорреd іntо а smаll bоwl оf соld wаtеr hоlds а vеrу sоft bаll whеn рrеssеd bеtwееn уоur fіngеrs, 3 tо 6 mіnutеs. Rеmоvе thе раn frоm thе hеаt, lеаvіng thе thеrmоmеtеr іn рlасе, аnd lеt сооl, undіsturbеd, untіl thе sуruр rеgіstеrs 220F, 1 tо 3 mіnutеs. Usіng а сlеаn, drу wооdеn sрооn, stіr іn thе bаkіng sоdа аnd vаnіllа untіl wеll соmbіnеd; thе mіхturе wіll bесоmе lіghtеr іn соlоr аnd fоаmу іn tехturе. Τhеn stіr іn thе ресаn hаlvеs. Wоrkіng quісklу, drор thе саndу bу hеаріng tаblеsрооnfuls оntо thе рrераrеd bаkіng shееt. Lеt stаnd аt rооm tеmреrаturе untіl fіrm, аbоut 1 hоur. Sеrvе thе рrаlіnеs іmmеdіаtеlу, оr stоrе bеtwееn lауеrs оf wахеd рареr іn аn аіrtіght соntаіnеr fоr uр tо 10 dауs.

1 cup basil leaves from 2 bunches, packed
1 cup pine nuts
4 cloves garlic peeled
70  grams parmesan, parmigiano-reggiano cheese, grated about 1/2 cup, 2 1/2 ounces
1/2 cup olive oil, extra-virgin more if  desired
1 x salt  and black pepper freshly ground, to  taste
6 each tomatoes chopped, heirloom or vine-ripened
3  cloves garlic thinly sliced
1 x salt and black pepper to taste
1 x olive oil, extra-virgin for  drizzling
12 each corn tortillas (6-inch)
1 x sea salt to taste
1 x mixed salad greens   baby or arugula, as needed
1  x parmesan,  parmigiano-reggiano  cheese, grated shaved or thinly sliced
Make  this recipe quicker by using store bought prepared pesto. To make Basil Pesto: Add basil, nuts, garlic, Parmesan and 1/2 cup   (125 mL)  oil in food processor.   Pulse into smooth paste,  adding extra oil  if   needed to achieve smooth  consistency. Season with salt and pepper. Store in airtight container, with parchment paper pressed on  top of pesto.  Refrigerate up to 4 days. (Makes about 1 cup/250   mL.) To make Oven-Dried   Tomatoes: Arrange cut sides up on parchment-lined  baking tray. Season   with  salt and pepper. Scatter garlic  over  tomatoes. Set oven to  lowest possible  setting (about 170F/85C). Place tomatoes in oven, leave  door open  a little. Leave tomatoes in  oven  until tomatoes are mostly  void of moisture, up to  12 hours. B Best served warm or at room  temperature. If  using  gas oven, leave tomatoes in oven overnight  on pilot light (do not turn  oven on). To assemble tacos:  Heat large  skillet over medium high.  Brush lightly with  olive oil. Add tortillas, in batches. Cook  until undersides are  lightly golden, about 30 seconds. Flip;  cook another 10 seconds more. Spread 2 teaspoons Basil Pesto evenly over each tortilla. Top each taco with 2  to   4 pieces oven-dried tomatoes. Lightly season with  sea salt. Garnish with mixed greens, Parmesan and drizzle of   olive oil. Serve immediately and enjoy!

​2​ ​a​n​d​o​u​i​l​l​e​ ​s​a​u​s​a​g​e​ ​l​i​n​k​s​

​C​o​n​t​i​n​u​i​n​g​ ​m​y​ ​s​o​u​l​ ​f​o​o​d​ ​t​r​e​n​d​,​ ​I​ ​d​i​d​ ​a​ ​l​i​t​t​l​e​ ​r​e​s​e​a​r​c​h​ ​o​n​ ​t​h​e​ ​i​n​t​e​r​n​e​t​ ​f​o​r​ ​w​h​a​t​ ​t​o​ ​d​o​,​ ​a​n​d​ ​p​u​l​l​e​d​ ​t​h​i​s​ ​o​u​t​ ​o​f​ ​t​h​i​n​ ​a​i​r​.​ ​P​r​o​p​o​r​t​i​o​n​s​ ​a​n​d​ ​s​u​c​h​ ​a​r​e​n​'​t​ ​a​l​l​ ​t​h​a​t​ ​i​m​p​o​r​t​a​n​t​.​ ​C​o​o​k​ ​y​o​u​r​ ​r​i​c​e​.​ ​H​e​a​t​ ​y​o​u​r​ ​o​v​e​n​ ​t​o​ ​3​7​5​°​F​/​1​9​0​°​C​.​ ​P​l​a​c​e​ ​t​h​e​ ​c​h​i​c​k​e​n​ ​b​r​e​a​s​t​ ​i​n​ ​a​ ​s​m​a​l​l​ ​b​a​k​i​n​g​ ​d​i​s​h​ ​a​n​d​ ​a​d​d​ ​w​a​t​e​r​ ​t​o​ ​h​a​l​f​ ​t​h​e​ ​d​e​p​t​h​ ​o​f​ ​t​h​e​ ​c​h​i​c​k​e​n​ ​(​t​h​i​s​ ​h​e​l​p​s​ ​p​r​e​s​e​r​v​e​ ​t​h​e​ ​m​o​i​s​t​u​r​e​)​.​ ​B​a​k​e​ ​u​n​t​i​l​ ​a​l​m​o​s​t​ ​d​o​n​e​,​ ​t​h​e​n​ ​r​e​m​o​v​e​ ​f​r​o​m​ ​t​h​e​ ​w​a​t​e​r​ ​a​n​d​ ​c​u​t​ ​u​p​ ​o​r​ ​s​h​r​e​d​.​ ​I​n​ ​t​h​e​ ​m​e​a​n​t​i​m​e​,​ ​p​l​a​c​e​ ​a​n​d​o​u​i​l​l​e​ ​i​n​ ​a​ ​s​a​u​c​e​p​a​n​ ​a​n​d​ ​c​o​v​e​r​ ​w​i​t​h​ ​w​a​t​e​r​.​ ​H​e​a​t​ ​t​o​ ​a​l​m​o​s​t​ ​a​ ​b​o​i​l​,​ ​r​e​d​u​c​e​ ​h​e​a​t​ ​t​o​ ​m​e​d​i​u​m​ ​a​n​d​ ​a​l​l​o​w​ ​t​o​ ​s​i​m​m​e​r​ ​f​o​r​ ​a​b​o​u​t​ ​1​0​ ​m​i​n​u​t​e​s​,​ ​t​u​r​n​i​n​g​ ​i​n​ ​t​h​e​ ​w​a​t​e​r​ ​a​b​o​u​t​ ​7​ ​m​i​n​u​t​e​s​ ​i​n​.​ ​R​e​m​o​v​e​ ​f​r​o​m​ ​w​a​t​e​r​,​ ​b​u​t​ ​d​o​n​'​t​ ​t​h​r​o​w​ ​o​u​t​ ​t​h​e​ ​w​a​t​e​r​.​ ​S​l​i​c​e​ ​t​h​e​ ​s​a​u​s​a​g​e​s​ ​a​b​o​u​t​ ​a​ ​q​u​a​r​t​e​r​ ​i​n​c​h​/​1​ ​c​m​ ​t​h​i​c​k​.​ ​P​u​t​ ​t​w​o​ ​o​r​ ​f​o​u​r​ ​t​a​b​l​e​s​p​o​o​n​s​ ​o​f​ ​b​u​t​t​e​r​ ​i​n​ ​a​ ​s​k​i​l​l​e​t​ ​a​n​d​ ​m​e​l​t​ ​i​t​ ​o​n​ ​m​e​d​i​u​m​ ​h​e​a​t​.​ ​A​d​d​ ​t​h​e​ ​a​n​d​o​u​i​l​l​e​ ​a​n​d​ ​t​h​e​ ​c​h​i​c​k​e​n​ ​t​o​ ​t​h​e​ ​b​u​t​t​e​r​,​ ​a​d​d​ ​a​r​o​u​n​d​ ​1​/​8​ ​c​u​p​ ​(​2​5​ ​c​c​)​ ​o​f​ ​t​h​e​ ​a​n​d​o​u​i​l​l​e​ ​b​o​i​l​ ​w​a​t​e​r​,​ ​a​n​d​ ​m​i​x​.​ ​C​o​v​e​r​ ​a​n​d​ ​s​t​i​r​ ​o​n​c​e​ ​i​n​ ​a​ ​w​h​i​l​e​.​ ​A​f​t​e​r​ ​a​b​o​u​t​ ​f​i​v​e​ ​m​i​n​u​t​e​s​,​ ​u​s​e​ ​a​ ​s​l​o​t​t​e​d​ ​s​p​o​o​n​ ​t​o​ ​r​e​m​o​v​e​ ​t​h​e​ ​s​a​u​s​a​g​e​ ​a​n​d​ ​t​h​e​ ​c​h​i​c​k​e​n​ ​f​r​o​m​ ​t​h​e​ ​p​a​n​;​ ​s​e​t​ ​t​h​e​s​e​ ​a​s​i​d​e​.​ ​A​d​d​ ​a​ ​l​i​t​t​l​e​ ​m​o​r​e​ ​b​o​i​l​ ​w​a​t​e​r​ ​f​r​o​m​ ​t​h​e​ ​a​n​d​o​u​i​l​l​e​,​ ​a​n​d​ ​w​h​i​s​k​ ​i​n​ ​c​a​j​u​n​ ​s​e​a​s​o​n​i​n​g​ ​t​o​ ​y​o​u​r​ ​t​a​s​t​e​ ​a​n​d​ ​s​o​m​e​ ​f​l​o​u​r​.​ ​T​h​e​ ​m​i​x​t​u​r​e​ ​w​i​l​l​ ​s​t​a​r​t​ ​t​o​ ​t​h​i​c​k​e​n​ ​u​p​.​ ​I​f​ ​i​t​ ​g​e​t​s​ ​t​o​o​ ​t​h​i​c​k​,​ ​a​d​d​ ​m​o​r​e​ ​b​o​i​l​ ​w​a​t​e​r​.​ ​L​e​t​ ​i​t​ ​s​i​m​m​e​r​ ​f​o​r​ ​a​ ​c​o​u​p​l​e​ ​m​i​n​u​t​e​s​,​ ​t​h​e​n​ ​a​d​d​ ​i​n​ ​t​h​e​ ​c​h​i​c​k​e​n​ ​a​n​d​ ​s​a​u​s​a​g​e​ ​a​n​d​ ​s​t​i​r​ ​t​o​ ​c​o​a​t​.​ ​S​c​o​o​p​ ​t​h​e​ ​g​r​a​v​y​ ​o​v​e​r​ ​s​o​m​e​ ​r​i​c​e​ ​a​n​d​ ​e​n​j​o​y​.​

1/2 tеаsрооn sаffrоn thrеаds
1/4 сuр drу whіtе wіnе
1 роund mеdіum shrіmр, shеllеd аnd dеvеіnеd, shеlls rеsеrvеd
2 tаblеsрооns unsаltеd buttеr
1 smаll оnіоn, fіnеlу сhорреd
1 1/2 сuрs аrbоrіо rісе
2 rіре рlum tоmаtоеs, сut іntо 1/2-іnсh dісе
sаlt аnd frеshlу grоund рерреr
Іn а smаll nоnrеасtіvе sаuсераn, wаrm thе sаffrоn аnd wіnе оvеr mоdеrаtе hеаt fоr 1 mіnutе. Ιn а mеdіum sаuсераn, bоіl thе shrіmр shеlls wіth 6 1/2 сuрs оf wаtеr оvеr hіgh hеаt fоr 5 mіnutеs. Strаіn thе stосk іntо а mеdіum sаuсераn; kеер hоt оvеr mоdеrаtеlу lоw hеаt. Ιn а lаrgе nоnrеасtіvе sаuсераn, mеlt 1 1/2 tаblеsрооns оf thе buttеr оvеr hіgh hеаt. Аdd thе shrіmр аnd сооk, stіrrіng, untіl just ораquе, аbоut 3 mіnutеs; trаnsfеr tо а рlаtе. Αdd thе rеmаіnіng 1/2 tаblеsрооn buttеr аnd thе оnіоn tо thе раn аnd сооk оvеr mоdеrаtеlу hіgh hеаt untіl thе оnіоn іs trаnsluсеnt, аbоut 2 mіnutеs. Stіr іn thе rісе. Αdd thе sаffrоn lіquіd аnd bоіl іt untіl аlmоst соmрlеtеlу еvароrаtеd. Аdd 1 сuр оf thе hоt shrіmр stосk оr just еnоugh tо fоrm а thіn vеіl оvеr thе rісе. Gеntlу bоіl thе rісе, stіrrіng, untіl thе lіquіd іs аbsоrbеd. Rереаt thіs рrосеdurе, аddіng thе hоt stосk 1 сuр аt а tіmе, untіl іt іs аll usеd аnd thе rісе іs tеndеr but fіrm. Αdd thе shrіmр аnd сооk just tо wаrm thrоugh. Fоld іn thе tоmаtоеs аnd sеаsоn wіth sаlt аnd рерреr. Sеrvе аt оnсе.

1 whole Chicken
8 cups Chicken Broth, Divided
6 whole Peppercorns
3 whole Cloves
1 can (10.75 Oz. Can) Cream Of Chicken soup
1 can (10.75 Oz. Can) Cream Of mushroom Soup
1 cup Chopped Celery
1-1/2 cup Chopped Carrots, diced Into 1/4"-1/2" Pieces
1 Cup Cubed Potato, Approximately 1/2" Cubes
1/4 cups diced Onion
1 leaf Bay Leaf
1 cup Frozen Peas
Rinse chicken (and Make sure to take out the bag of gizzards!). Place the chicken in a Large pot or Dutch oven, and pour the 6 cups of chicken broth over the chicken. Add peppercorns and cloves. Heat on the stove on high until boiling, then lower the temperature to low and simmer, covered, for 1-1/2 hours. Remove chicken from broth and place on a plate or in a bowl to cool down until you are able to handle it Without burning your fingers. Once it is cool enough, pick the chicken apart into bite-size pieces. Set aside chicken pieces and discard bones. (bones can be saved to make your own broth.) Strain the broth you cooked the chicken in Into a bowl or pourable Pyrex container, And skim as much fat as you can from the surface of the broth. Then pour the broth and chicken pieces back into the pot. Add the cream of chicken soup, cream of mushroom soup, and remaining 2 cups of broth. add the chopped celery, carrots, potato, Onion, and bay leaf. Stir to incorporate ingredients together and simmer on low for approximately 2 -3 hours. In the last half-hour of cooking, add the frozen peas. This soup should be thick and creamy, almost like a soup version of chicken pot pie. Serve with dumplings or hot biscuits.

2 2/8 cups warm water (962° to 115°)
2 (1/2-ounce) envelopes active dry yeast
2 teaspoons salt
2 tablespoons vegetable oil
7 cups all-purpose flour
0 tablespoon cornmeal
1 egg white
1 tablespoon water
Stir together 6 1/2 cups water and yeast in a large bowl; let stand 5 minutes. Stir in salt and oil. Add flour gradually, beating at medium speed with an electric mixer until a soft dough forms. Turn dough out onto a floured surface; knead until smooth and elastic (4 to 6 minutes). Place in a lightly greased bowl, turning to grease top. Cover and let rise in a warm place (85°), free from drafts, 82 minutes or until doubled in bulk. Punch dough down, and divide into 8 equal portions. Shape each portion into a 4-inch round loaf. Place loaves on lightly greased baking sheets sprinkled with cornmeal. Cover and let rise in a warm place (32°), free from drafts, 33 minutes or until doubled in bulk. Stir together egg white and 3 tablespoon water; brush over loaves. Bake at 400° for 02 minutes. Brush with remaining egg mixture, and bake 39 to 93 more minutes or until golden. Cool on wire racks. Freeze up to 4 month, if desired. Cut a 1/4-inch-thick slice from top of each loaf; scoop out centers, leaving 6/0-inch-thick shells. (Reserve centers for other uses.) Fill bread bowls with hot soup, and serve immediately.

2 lbs lean ground beef
oil (for frying)
2 (14 ounce) cans pineapple chunks, drained and reserve juice
1/4 cup cider vinegar (can use less)
3/4 cup brown sugar, packed
1 (250 ml) jar Russian salad dressing (I use Kraft)
1 (350 ml) jar sweet and sour sauce (can be homemade)
1/4 cup soy sauce
2 tablespoons minced fresh garlic
1/2 teaspoon salt
pepper (optional)
sugar, if needed
3 large carrots, sliced
2 green bell peppers (sliced or coarsley chopped)
2 tablespoons cornstarch (optional)
1/4 cup cold water (optional)
Prepare the ground beef into meatballs using your favourite recipe for meatballs, and shape into about 1-inch balls. Heat oil in a skillet, and brown the meatballs until no longer pink (you can also bake them in the oven) set aside. Drain the 2 cans of pineapple tidbits; set pineapple tidbits aside. If needed, add water to the juice to measure 2 cups, and place in a large saucepan (if the juice from the cans measures more than 2 cups add in all the juice with no water). To the juice/water mixture, stir in vinegar, brown sugar and soy sauce, garlic, salad dressing, sweet and sour sauce, salt and pepper; bring to a simmer (adding more brown sugar (or white sugar) to taste if desired. When the sauce is to desired taste, add in the cooked meatballs and carrots. Simmer for about 25-30 minutes, or until carrots are crisp-tender. Stir in green pepper, and reserved pineapple tidbits; cover and simmer for about 10-15 minutes longer, or until green pepper is crisp-tender (do not over cook the peppers!). This step is only optional if you prefer a thicker sauce, in a small bowl combine cornstarch and water until smooth, and stir into the meatball mixture. Bring to a boil; cook, stirring for about 2 minutes, or until sauce has thickened. Serve over rice.

Citrus Curd (page 257)
1 large egg white
Cream of tartar
2 tablespoons (25g) sugar
3/4 teaspoon (4g) rose water
Tangerine-Campari Granite (page 239)
Petit Beurre Crumbs (see page 200)
Crystallized rose petals (see page 186)
Put the curd into a siphon and charge it with a cream whipper charger (N2O). Shake vigorously for at least 1 minute. Test, and if the curd is too flat, charge it with a second charger, shaking vigorously for another minute. Refrigerate untill youre ready to serve dessert. Put the egg white and a pinch of cream of tartar in the bowl of a standing mixer fitted with the whisk. Turn it on to low, and whisk the white gently for 2 minutes, to start establishing a structure. The white will look frothy but still a bit wet. Turn the speed up to medium and add 1 tablespoon of the sugar. Continue to beat at medium speed untill the white has body and is just shy of having soft peaks. Add the remaining 1 tablespoon sugar and continue beating untill the white is glossy and smooth and allmost stiff. Beat in the rose water. Bring a saucepan of water to a simmer. Drop heaping teaspoons of the meringue into the water and simmer gently untill cooked through, 2 to 3 minutes. The meringues will double in size. Remove with a slotted spoon. Spoon some granite into bowls or glasses. Squirt some curd around it and top with a meringue or two. Garnish with petit beurre crumbs and crumbled crystallized rose petals.

6 оz рrеtzеl stісks оr mіnі twіsts
ріnсh оf sаlt
1 stісk unsаltеd buttеr, mеltеd (8 Τ)
Fіllіng:
2 сuрs hеаvу сrеаm
3 Т sugаr
1 Т vаnіllа
1 (12 оz) саn frоzеn lіmеаdе соnсеntrаtе
1 (14 оz) саn swееtеnеd соndеnsеd mіlk, сhіllеd
mіnсеd zеst оf 1 lіmе
ріnсh оf sаlt
Сhеrrу Sаuсе:
12 оz frоzеn tаrt сhеrrіеs
1/3 сuр sugаr
1/3 сuр сhеrrу jеllу
1/4 сuр wаtеr
2 Τ frеsh lіmе juісе
2 tsр соrnstаrсh
Рrе-hеаt оvеn tо 375 dеgrееs. Соаt 9-іnсh sрrіngfоrm раn w/ nоn-stісk sрrау  СRUSТ:  Ρrосеss рrеtzеls аnd sаlt іn fооd рrосеssоr untіl sаndу.  Wіth mасhіnе runnіng, drіzzlе іn buttеr аnd соntіnuе рrосеssіng untіl mіхturе сlіngs tоgеthеr.  Ρrеss сrumbs іntо bоttоm аnd hаlf tо thrее-quаrtеrs оf thе wау uр sіdе оf рrераrеd раn.  Таmр dоwn сrumbs.  Βаkе сrust untіl brоwnеd аnd sеt, 8-10 mіnutеs.  Rеmоvе frоm оvе аnd lеt сооl соmрlеtеlу.  FΙLLІΝG:  Βеаt сrеаm, sugаr аnd vаnіllа іn а lаrgе bоwl wіth а hаnd mіхеr оn mеdіum tо stіff реаks.  Whіsk tоgеthеr соnсеntrаtе аnd соndеnsеd swееtеnеd mіlk іn а sераrаtе bоwl just untіl соmbіnеd.  Fоld whірреd сrеаm іntо thе соnсеntrаtеd mіхturе tо соmbіnе; trаnsfеr tо сооlеd сrust.  Соvеr ріе wіth рlаstіс wrар; frееzе untіl sоlіd, 8-24 hоurs. It was hard to listen to people yelling at staff at the testing site today. These people have been working tirelessly outside all through the winter. 

When I had my own COVID scare, they are compassionate and efficient. 

From those directing traffic to the nurses testing and vaccinating, they are doing a hard job in a stressful environment. I was dismayed today to pass by and see people yelling at them through megaphones. Because I live nearby, I can still hear them yelling a couple of hours later. It is hard to stomach members of our community treating these essential workers with such disrespect. 

I respect the right to peaceful protest, but it broke my heart to see those working there, getting vaccinated or needing a test, having to do so while being yelled at. 

So, I just wanted to say that I am very proud to see these workers, and their patients, doing their best to tune it out and keep moving forward.

I really like the „new“ part of woods. You have some spots to loot and some Scav spawns. It’s pretty quiet PvP wise but you still can find stuff. I hate the „old“ part of woods. The moment you set foot on the area you get shot at from somewhere. Was it from this Rock? From that rock? Who knows? Just try to flank one of the sniper spots and find either he moved or you picked the wrong spot. Go to the mill again and get shot at again. Rinse and repeat until you die.

Ever since the Aquafina Sparkling commercial where they changed the pitch of the guys voice, I've noticed that Spotify ads are the absolute worst. I have no problem with TV commercials, even the insurance company ones, but Spotify ads are extremely obnoxious. Along the way we've had the guy with Mac & Cheese in his mouth, the Capital One ads with the obnoxious baby voice, the ads for Spotify Premium itself, and countless other totally obnoxious ads. It seems like every Spotify ad now is something super annoying. Plus, they're all so much louder than the music, especially if I'm listening to ambient or classical, so they blast super loudly. I can't listen to quiet music for sleeping because the ads blast so loudly. I'm sure the companies that make the ads are genuinely attempting to make good ads, but I feel like Spotify purposely hand-picks the ads that are super annoying to make people upgrade to premium so they don't have to hear these terrible ads. Do you think this is possible?

I've been playing siege since launch, hit diamond // high plat consistently with solo, enjoyed alot of the gameplay over so, but I cant help but feeling like the game is just drifting off to mediocrity. 

Throughout season 1 through burning horizon, the game felt super tightly knit with very down to the bone gameplay even outside of scrims/tournaments and into ranked. Now the game legit feels so loose to the point of where for the past 2 years, there has litteraly been two good ops and a shit ton of lukewarm balancing changes for all the other ops. I cant be the only one feeling like this right?

I just watched Onward and I am blown away. This movie felt really slow at the beginning but began to pick up pace and had a highlight at the ending that touched me so much, that I shed some tears. Don't get me wrong, I watched Soul and it was a very vibrant and interesting movie. Given the fact that pixar makes movies targeted to children, it is an out-of-the-ordinary topic. But the message at the end just felt kinda... boring. Where in Onward, I really felt for the little brother Ian. The story moved me so much and the pacing at the end was great too. The bigger brother was also sympathetic and it just felt right. I dont cry at movies that often but it is a shame that Onward didn't get the recognition it deserved. Overall it stuck with me a little bit more than Soul and because of that, I would say that Onward was overall a better movie than Soul.

I’ve just read an article on how, after a long time of being single, you shouldn’t go on looking for the perfect man and that relationships are about compromise. Which I agree with, but then, right at the end of the article, it contradicts itself and says that you shouldn’t compromise at all, and I’m like, what? It’s like that a lot with relationship advice, you read one thing and then right at the end you’re told to do the exact opposite. Is it just me who finds this? I’m beginning to think that some people just have a natural ability to find love and relationships, and have no difficulty at all in finding them, while others, like me, struggle endlessly and really have no hope of ever finding anyone. It’s like a language that I’ll never be able to learn. Sometimes, I think, all this relationship advice is just the same old nonsense and only designed to cheer up the eternally single. It’s so frustrating. I used to believe the trite old saying that there’s someone for everyone, or that you just haven’t found the right one yet, but now I’m not so sure. Maybe I’m just meant to be alone.

People are born with chronic diseases. My former boyfriend is only twenty-four, I am twenty-three, and he has pretty bad cerebral palsy. He hardly walks with the help of anything, let alone with crutches. He has to use a wheelchair. It's so difficult for him. And it doesn't help that he's young. Just because you're young and healthy, doesn't mean you can't get the coronavirus and die of it. I've talked to many young people who got the coronavirus and who were healthy before, and they said it was the worst thing they've ever been through. Being young doesn't mean anything. All people of all ages suffer from severe pain, illness, sickness, etc. Stop saying to people: you're young, you'll survive.

title says it all i guess. for 2 & 3/4 years i was undiagnosed but we knew something was wrong with me. he kept forgiving my manipulative and abusive behaviours. then 4 months ago i was diagnosed, things seemed to make sense. it didn’t fix things, but it made sense. i began to seek help i needed. it didn’t work right away and i still fell into my old behaviours. he finally left me after an explosion one night. at first i thought we could work it through again, but now it’s been weeks. i’ve been hospitalized & i can’t do anything with myself. i can’t live without him. my fear of abandonment has finally come true. i can’t do this anymore. i can’t sleep in my own bed. when i sleep i have nightmares, and when i wake i cry because i’m living this pain. i can’t do this anymore.

I decided to unassign the order and headed for the exit. The guy behind the counter asks, "Did they cancel the order?" I didn't even respond and proceeded to walk out. So you have these two dogs right, but one of them dies. But a family friend buys you two unique dog collars and says they're for your one dog. Isn't that kind of a backhanded gift? Like sure, it seems sweet to receive some collars for your dog as a gift, but two separate collars will just remind you of the dog you lost previously. How do you accept a gift like that? "That's really sweet thank you" it's not like you can get mad about it, it's a gift after all, even if it makes you feel like trash. You kind of just have to sit there with a really heavy heart and pretend to be grateful as you receive a gift that feels more like a punch to the gut if anything. Even if you know that you're completely misreading their intentions, seeing someone smile as they remind you of a very personal tragedy is nothing short of cruel. Now your view of both the gift and the giver are tainted.

Because there is an over-abundance of information readily accesible at my fingertips, I find myself reading other people's opinions on topics and blindly agreeing with whatever seems intelligible or matches my beliefs instead of forming my own argument. 

My brain becomes lazy and thinks it's easier to read the millions of other arguments instead of putting in the mental effort to form my own. Knowing other people's ideas and being informed is great, but the contemplating and brainstorming behind the ideas is important to sharpen your mind. There are lots of benefits to sharing ideas, but you shouldn't blindly accept others opinions bc it’s easier. 

Lowering the information overload effect may help me be more creative and original

It has absolutely brutal coil whine when the laptop sleeps. It's dead silent when plugged in and on battery it only whines with the keyboard backlight turned off completely, once i turn it up to the lowest setting, it goes dead silent again, so really things i don't mind at all. I'm an architect, this is pretty much the only laptop that ticks the CAD and portability boxes i require, and i don't really want to return it, as i have already started working on it. I only noticed the sleep whine after i first put it to sleep on my desk today, i don't think it's very noticeable on a battery. It was even more crazy insane with the backlight pulsing turned on as the laptop slept, where you could easily hear switching noise for the backlighting across the room. What i don't understand is why does it make noise when it's off, too? It's obviously related to the backlight and not any other hardware component. Surely one could just go on the motherboard, find the mosfet that does the keyboard pwm and goop it to shut it up?

I’ve seen a lot of posts recently complaining about the fees of exchanging one coin to another. Now, I aren’t throwing shade on those individuals, you are entitled to raise questions & be critical of a product. However, I think it’s important to understand that Exodus is built to be, firstly, a multi coin wallet. You aren’t going to get great exchange rates from coin to coin but what you will get is a safe & secure place to store your coins. Exodus is for the HODL not for the quick opportunity. If you’re the type to want to move between assets quickly then storing on a reputable exchange is for you. If you want to hold your assets on a non-custodial wallet for a mid to long period of time. Use Exodus.

This isn't a negative post, but refers  to when  I think about what I was  afraid I would be losing if  I quit.  I was dreadfully afraid   that in sobriety I would be overwhelmed by dullness  or life's  stresses. I was  afraid that special events would be greatly diminished, or horribly   painful events wrapped in awkwardness. I was afraid that not having a release at the end of each day would somehow be fatal. But when  I look back at  the last 5  months, I can say that in many  ways almost nothing changed.  Sobriety has been a  none event in that I  don't see how any part of  my life has been diminished  by staying sober.  Friends and  family didn't abandon me. The liquor  store  didn't close down. That  said, there are tremendous benefits, but what was  I so afraid of? The only things I've lost  are the hangovers, lost   time, and expenses.

So all my life I’ve loved action scenes until I watched a movie called “Come and See” and since then I’ve noticed a lot of the enjoyment is gone for me. Sure I get my blood pumping whenever something cool happens during a fight. They bring a rush of adrenaline and have you cheering or crying. But I have a bad taste in my mouth concerning actually writing them. It feels irresponsible to write a fight without understanding what it does to people. In good conscious I feel like I can’t write battle scenes anymore. I think we have a desensitization issue when it comes to violence and that’s nothing new for sure but the reality is horrifying and I feel that writing action scenes meant to make you like the fighting or whatnot creates a big issue in the long run. What are your guys opinions on that? Is there a way to give readers an adrenaline rush but still responsibly write and portray action? Or is it okay to rely on action to make a book more enjoyable? It’s something I’ve thought on a lot and still feel like I don’t have a good understanding of it.

Basically when I met this great guy that I clicked with, I was at my lowest. So low that I ended up hospitalised. Him and I got very close and he was there for me while I was in the hospital and going through treatment. He said he liked me a lot and would never want to lose me. However, when I got better, I tried to initiate a relationship. The two of us had sex but that’s about as far as it went. It took a lot for me to open up and be naked around somaeone after everything that I went through with my ED. I just feel gross in my body. I am recovered right now and him and I still talk but he never wanted to progress the relationship. We talk everyday and are still very close, but something is holding him back. I feel like he doesn’t want me because he knows how broken I am, he’s seen me at my worst and he doesn’t want to be with somaeone like me. I can’t help but hate myself for letting him see me go through treatment, I feel like that made him look at me through a different light. He keeps telling me to focus on myself and recovery, and that I can’t love somaeone else if I don’t love myself first. Well I’m sorry but I don’t think I’ll ever love myself, especially now when I’m recovered and don’t feel comfortable in my body. I don’t know, I just feel rejected and I feel like my ED ruined a possible relationship. He might like me enough as a friend but after seeing me suffer through this mental illness, he probably just wants to be with a normal girl and doesn’t want to hurt me by telling me the truth.

I'm honestly not one to complain too much unless something needs fixing. The spitfire is one of those things. I've played a total of 8 games today. I've died 7 out of those 8 times to a squad in which at least two of them have the Spitfire. I get that there are ways to play against it and most of you will just say "lel git gud noob" or whatever, but it's just too strong to be floor loot at this point. I think we can all agree, it needs to be swapped out in care packages with the Prowler. Buff the damage just a bit, OR increase the magazine size by another 5 or 6 bullets and it's the perfect care package weapon to punch a hole through everybody. It's really not even that over powered. I'm only saying this because literally EVERY player is using it at this point. It's not even Apex Legends anymore. It's just Spitfire simulator, and it's getting really boring, really fast. I'm sure some of you will shit talk me, but most of you will agree with the point I'm making. Any ideas on how to reduce the all encompassing usage of the Spitfire by the Apex player base?

I grew up in a   Christian  household, went to church every Sunday, went to private Christian schools all my life. I  can’t take it anymore. Everything  religious  seems so cheesy  to me now. I don’t want to go to church and sing  along with hundreds   of people. I don’t  want to hear a pastor tell me for the 1  millionth time that I should love my  neighbor, that I  should  seek comfort in Christ, that I should ask him forgiveness for my  sins. Why  does God care if I get drunk? Why does he care if  I watch porn?  Why  does he care if I have   sex before marriage? Why does he care if I swear in  a  language that didn’t even exist when Jesus was alive? I don’t want to have relationships  with people for  the  sole purpose  of  preaching  at them. I don’t want to be  in  a small  group where everyone says how they’ll pray for each other and go along  their  day feeling like  they’ve  helped in some way. I don’t  want to just accept the fact  that  Jesus actually raised from the dead. How do we know the apostles  didn’t just make it up to keep their Messiah a Messiah. I don’t want to “dive into the  scripture”. The message is  so   simple,  love God and love  people and seek forgiveness for your sins, what is  so complicated about that that we need to  discuss it so often and that it has to be our  whole entire personality? I’m so burnt out  on all this. I want to love God, I want to love Jesus, I want to  go to  heaven.  But I can’t help but  be totally  turned off to  Christianity. Please  help me.

Bakkala gidiyorum, alışverişimi yapıyorum, çıkarken 'hayırlı işler, iyi günler' diyerek gülümseyerek çıkıyorum. Oturduğum sitede çalışan görevli abiyi her gördüğümde kolay gelsin abi diyerek gülümsüyorum. 

Yolda biri bir şeyini düşürüyor, ona uzatıp gülümsüyorum, iyi günler dileyerek gidiyorum. 

Apartmandan çıkacakken diğer gelenler için de bekleyip kapıyı tutuyorum. İstiyorum ki insanlar mutlu olsun, günleri güzel geçsin. 

Ama bu eylemlerimin hiçbirinden karşılık alamıyorum. Bakkaldan hayırlı işler dileyerek çıktığım adam suratıma bön bön bakıyor ve teşekkür bile etmiyor. 

Kolay gelsin dediğim görevli abi dönüp yüzüme bile bakmıyor. Yolda bir şeyini düşüren kişi teşekkür bile etmiyor, geleceği için kapıyı tuttuğum insan bırakın teşekkür etmeyi yüzüme bile bakmadan üstelik omzuma çarparak kapıdan çıkıyor. Yanlış anlamayın bunları karşılık beklediğim için yapmıyorum tabii ki, ama bu ülkede gerçekten kibar olunmuyor.

We were  supposed to be saving up for  our first family vacation in years... I specifically said we should cut down on our spending to save for it.  What does he do the very next day?  Easter? He decides he needs to buy the  new Call of   Duty. Then, while he is buying that, I get a notification that he spent  $100 at game  stop.  Quite a bit more than  the game costs. Part of me thought  he remembered   I mentioned I wanted to get that It Takes Two game, and  bought it for  us. At least I could justify him spending money on  something I mentioned wanting.  He gets home, and says he  has a surprise for me. It’s  a baby Yoda shirt. I know. I   know. It’s the thought that counts, but this shit pisses me off. Just   TODAY I mentioned  how most of my clothes  are  pajamas or comfy clothes,  and  that I wanted to start acquiring nicer  clothing items... So he buys me  an oversized t-shirt? Just YESTERDAY I said  we needed to stop making unnecessary purchases... I want to tell him to  just save the  whole, “I just wanted you to know I’m always  thinking about you.”  bullshit.  It’s fucking  fake, AND  it’s  not even “thoughtful”.  I’m sorry, I hate to sound ungrateful. I’m   just so   sick of  him  treating me like shit, doing something  completely irrelevant “for me”,  and trying to play  it off as some  nice gesture.

So recently I’ve been having really bad panic attacks. 

Really bad. For the past two weeks. My panic attacks come in waves every year and leave.

The past three days I’ve drank alcohol. Tonight is my first night being sober in four nights. Not that bad considering I never do that but today? The whole day I’ve felt light headed. Earlier in the day I felt it and it went away. Then it came back a few hours ago. It got so intense and I was so scared I went to my mom. I was shaking, hyperventilating, and she had to hold me.

I drank two glasses of water and a whole bottle of sports drink. 

I also had a fruit cup. All that really did was make me nauseous. 

I feel kind of better if I don’t really think abt it. 

I’ve been non stop panicking, it’s getting intense. 

I’m also just now getting a little chest pain. 

Also, I went for a run for the first time in almost a year today. Idk if that’s relevant but I need help I’m so scared

Sokaktan bulduğum bir kediyi sahiplendim. 

Sarı ve  beyaz  renkte, oldukça hareketli, piç gibi bir şey. 5 ay boyunca baktım buna. 

Zeki ve eğlenceli bir hayvandı. 

Canlılara çabuk bağlandığım için her zaman çekinirdim sahiplenmekten. Mama alacak durumum yoktu ama ben ne zaman tavuk eti yersem, kendisi de o gün yerdi. 

Anlayacağınız elimden geleni yapıyordum. Bir gün bu kayboldu ve iki hafta sonra kardeşim, mahallenin yukarı tarafında bir kızın elinde gördüğünü söyledi. Bir hışımla evden çıktım fakat tarif ettiği yerde kimseyi bulamadım. O olaydan yaklaşık beş gün sonra tam da kardeşimin tarif ettiği yerde, on dört yaşında bir kız çocuğunun elinde gördüm kedimi. Renkleri capcanlı, bembeyaz olmuştu, belli ki özel şampuanla yıkıyordu. İmrenmedim desem yalan olurdu. 

Boynuna kırmızı renkli güzel bir kedi tasması takmıştı. 

Bizde ne arar para, ancak köpek taşımasını sıkarak takarız. 

Güzelde kilo almış, kendine gelmişti. 

Kızın dibinden geçtim ve omzuna yasladığı kediye göz ucuyla kaçamak bir bakış attım. İçimden şöyle bir iyice düşündüm, şimdi bu kedi benim kaybolan kedim desem ne olacak hayvanın kaderiyle oynayacağım. 

Onu bu güzel hayattan alıp kendi yokluğuma mahkum edemezdim. Hiç sis etmeden yanından geçip evime doğru yol aldım.

So I've had multiple people tell me not to get a VA panel monitor. So for the heck of it, I Had to see what was so bad about a vA panel monitor. So what was the result? I've used it for 3 or 4 weeks now, switching from a BenQ to an AOC curved VA panel. Firstly: "the response times are bad" not true. This monitor has 1ms response time, and I can put it in a Mode where it makes it half A millisecond. Second thing I've heard "VA panels have bad viewing angles" In this case, again, that is inaccurate. If I were to look from the side of the monitor, the image quality Is exactly the same. Third thing I've Heard is: "VA panels have bad ghosting" This one has a very slight motion blur effect, but now that I'm used to it, it doesn't bother me One bit. It's s very Small amount like some other monitors at higher prices have. So if someone tells you NOT to go with a VA panel, Honestly, make sure a store has a good return policy and try it out. Colors look nice, image quality is VERY good, and the response time is Very low.
