I see a lot of post on r/menwritingwomen and obviously there are male writers who depict women in a less than respectful way over sexualizing them and I agree that it's wrong to generalize women that way. However I feel like any alternative way of writing women is also heavily criticized. If you write about a woman being strong and independent, she's seen as a Mary Sue and unoriginal. I try to use the women in my life as inspiration I see them as strong amazing independent women who are vastly different in personality they still would fall under the descriptors that I see criticized in writing. If they're bubbly, it's a stereotype, if they're standoffish, it's a stereotype. If they have a crass mouth, clutch my pearls, and it's a stereotype. I guess I'm asking as a man trying to get into writing, how do you appropriately and respectfully write descriptions of women without being seen as a sexist male writer? Are there good examples of descriptors that are generally praised?

I ordered the Samsung Galaxy S21 Ultra 5G 512 GB in color Phantom Black originally back on March 2, 2021 from AT&T. I finally received it on April 8 2021. I waited a very long time to get this particular model and I only found out about a delay because of chip shortages from Reddit. First of all to even remove the expandable memory slot and then have customers have to wait a lengthy amount of time for their order because they choose the 512GB version is insane. My cellphone carrier kept saying it was coming... it will be there in a couple of days etc. for the entire time. I told myself once I get it I will post it on Reddit  just so maybe I can end some frustration for anyone else waiting for their order.  The one good thing that I can say however is that I love this phone. It did not disappoint. I had used the Samsung Galaxy Note phones for at least 6 or 7 years. It was hard to get me away from the Note versions, had my Samsung Note 9 for the a little over 2 years. I had a lot of wear and tear on my phone so I did a lot if research to narrow down my next cellphone purchase choice. I am so glad I decided to get a different version this time. Samsung cellphones are my go to brand and will continue to be in the future. The Samsung Galaxy Ultra 5G phone is a definite winner. So many pros and a few cons but the features and specs are remarkable so I will no doubt recommend this brand to anyone who wants to purchase a new cellphone in the near future.

Fox, a main character from season 2 is a character who I feel is highly underused on this show.  Yesterday’s episode had him poisoned by Invictus and I fear that he might stay that way for the rest of the season and this makes his fate look very grim.   However the problem with this is that Fox did not get very much attention in season 2 let alone the first four episodes of season 3. He said that he was running away from his past for a reason yet we do not know what that past is and we do not know anything about his real parents either. Olan also assured that Fox will get his backstory revealed but with him possessed that might dilute the backstory.  I was really disappointed at seeing be poisoned by Invictus because I felt that was going to result in him getting less focus and he clearly did not deserve this.  If he gets killed off this season then that is going to be a huge mistake of the writers to make and a lot of fans are going to be disappointed cause they do not want a Mai. Character to be killed off just because he has less focus than other characters.

So I've had multiple people tell me not to get a VA panel monitor. So for the heck of it, I had to see what was so bad about a VA panel monitor. So what was the result? So my husband and I are at traffick light with one car in front of us. The lights red, we are all stopped. The light turns green and car in front of us slams acceleration and reverses into our truck pushing the bumper completely under. We call cops, lady who hits us only speaks Spanish and doesn't have a license at all. One of her persons shows up, not sure if it's her husband or nephew or what, but is basically saying don't call the cops, which I already did. The cops shows up like 2 minutes after the guy. The guy tries to make it like he drove car but I jumped in and explained exactly how it went. The cop exchanges our info and leaves it at that. The truck is under my husband's name and he called his insurance and there's to sumbit a claim. My husband was told by other persons claim that lady was not on policy and needed to contact them to see if she had permission to drive and of course they never answer the phone. My husband ended up having to take the truck in to get fixed himself and had to pay $600 deductible. After about month the other insurance finally calls and says that since they can't get hold of the guy they are going to drop the claim. I just don't understand how the justice system works and how she can get away without a license and having to pay a think when she was one who caused accident.  Any advice will be helpful.

Eu sou diabético, porém meu caso não é tão grave, se eu faço a dieta direitinho, eu posso comer qualquer coisa sem problemas. E ontem Páscoa né, eu ansioso pros meu ovo chegar e a moça que me vendeu só estava me enrolando desde manhã, eai eu falando pra essa minha amiga da raiva que eu estava e ela tentando fazer eu me conformar e tal, aí quando eu meio que acalmei, ela disse: "vc devia falar comigo toda vez que sente vontade de comer doce", aí eu falei: "aí nossa amizade ia acabar" e mandei uma figurinha do Bart chorando.  Então tipo, eu falei pra ela, que eu tinha me comportado a semana passada e eu queria comer chocolate né, e que tipo, por mais que eu faça as coisas direito, a gente tem a necessidade de comer um doce de vez em quando. Aí ela ficou puta, começou falar que eu preferia os doces do que os amigos, e na real, pra mim os dois caminham lado a lado na vida. Se eu não como doce eu fico estressado e se eu não tenho amigos, eu me sinto sozinho, o que me deixa triste e me leva a comer doce pra maquiar a tristeza. E assim, eu fiz amigos de vdd "recentemente" em 2019. E os doces sempre "estiveram do meu lado" nos momentos difíceis que eu precisava de algo pra me alegrar, mesmo que momentaneamente. Essa situação aconteceu ontem a tarde e até agora ela tá agindo diferente comigo. Qual a opinião de vcs sobre a situação? Ah detalhe, atualmente meus amigos são todos a distância, a gente se via uma vez por mês antes da pandemia. Então tipo, meus amigos suprem minha felicidade pessoalmente, mas como a gente não tem se visto mais....

I’ll try to be as brief as possible: I was diagnosed with depression around five years ago, when I was only 17, after I tried to commit suicide. As a consequence, I started seeing a therapist while also taking medications. And I actually saw some improvements. However, Everything went downhill Two years ago, when my mother passed away. She was the person I loved the most in the world, and the only one who never made me feel guilty about my problems, so because I am dumb as fuck I just disappeared, never contacted my therapists again, stopped my medications, and moved to London while also taking drugs and leading a very wild life until I almost killed myself. I have now come home for nearly one year, and I made the hard decision of starting therapy again. Last week I went to see a psychiatrist that a friend of mine suggested me to see. After he asked me a few questions whose answers I am not sure he understood since he kept interrupting me, he told me, “Listen to me, kid, you are not sick, or depressed, look at yourself, you are all pretty and dolled up, you are probably just sad because your mum died, you simply need to toughen up and get over it, and you’ll be fine” I Was shocked. I left his office crying, and now I am totally at a loss. Should I give up on therapy? Should I see thiS guy again and give him a second chance? I don’t know what to do.. maybe I am just destined to be miserable.

I plan to message him on instagram since I don’t know how else to contact him, but I want to make a sincere and legitimate apology, so I’m asking for some help. We are fortunate to live at the begining of a space exploration era. The 11400 and 11400f are both a great value. The 11400 is only 20-30$ more then the last gen counterpart and preforms 20% better in cinebench r20 multicore and single core. I tested it and with power limits removed it got a Score Of 3900 and The 10400 got a score of 3200 with power limits removed. This is all with 3200 cl16 memory. The 11400 has an igpu that is fine for the mean time and In the current gpu situation it will Be great for most people whilst they wait for gpus. Overall 11th gen is disappointing although the lower end i5 skus are impressive. The 11400f is 12% worse then the 5600x in multicore tests and is about 10% better in single core tests, but it is 130$ more. The point I am saying is That the 11th gen i5 are a great value. What are your opinions.

The amount of frustrated users I see on every forum regarding their Windows/UAD setup is staggering. There are, however, very few threads out there with good information about configurations that are actually working for people. So I propose threads under this post is this: Post your WORKING SYSTEM BUILDS or LAPTOP MODELS for WINDOWS ONLY that work with UAD interfaces, preferably Thunderbolt models. . Go to PCPartPicker, throw your system specs in there and post here. If you have a Windows system with working UAD interface - give as much info as possible. Motherboard especially since one of the biggest issues is getting Thunderbolt to work with compatible motherboards. Build a resource here. Upvote posts with real, helpful, detailed information.

Wondering about having   kids is  something I think about every  day. I have always  been very “maybe yes maybe no we will see what happens”  but since my fiancé and I will be getting  married next year it feels like the pressure is  amplified to have a definite answer.  Recently, I   can’t shake  the feeling that no matter  what we choose, I will wish for the other.  If we do, everything  would change and  I love the relationship we have  now. I’m afraid of  being resentful to a child for taking  that away, and spending the  rest of  my life  wishing for the way we used to be. On the other hand, I’m afraid of saying  no and spending the rest of our lives  regretting when we get  older. Im  glad I can finally put what  I’ve been feeling into words with  others  who understand

My dog of 17 years old passed away last week and somehow I felt the moment of her death without knowing it. I need to mention that a day prior to it  I took acid and didn’t sleep all night. In the morning, after the trip ended, I talked to my mom who was with our dog and told me things were not looking great. One hour later, I suddenly felt a big pain in my chest and started sobbing uncontrollably, screaming in pain, thinking only of my dog. I was so overwhelmed by the intensity of the emotions that I was paralyzed laying on the floor. Then, my mom called and gave me the terrible news. I know that lsd somehow intensified my emotions but I was really grateful that I was able to be connected with my beautiful doggy one more time.

She is gentle, she is caring, she is loving. She stands beside me time and time again when things are bad. I like spending time with her. I like hugging her, kissing her, loving her. But life has become dreadfully boring. TV, movies and books. Or she does her arts and crafts. I want to get out and do adventurous things. Outdoors stuff, nature stuff. Climbing and hiking and go carts. Excitement, daring. I want to learn sports shooting. I want to go off roading, axe throwing. I look at other women our age, other wives our age and they do fun stuff. Sure I could do all those things myself but I would rather do them with my wife, my life partner. So each time I get feeling better I only get feeling worse.

It sounds weird, but I wonder this a lot. Fortunately for me, I haven’t had any truly traumatic events in my life, but I think that’s mainly why I’m asking this question. I don’t really wonder how you heal, because I do have experience with time  “healing” to a certain point, but my questions is more about the days and weeks after. I just imagine I would be bed-ridden, sobbing and depressed for who knows how long. People who have gone through traumatic loss/events, how did you get through those first days? How do you keep working? How understanding were you jobs? I just can’t imagine getting myself to eat after something like that happens, much less work. I can’t eat sometimes just from anxiety I have. Any and all answers would help, and my true condolences ahead of time, I promise I’m not trying to just use your situations for my own benefit, I’m truly very interested in how the human mind/body copes and heals. Thank you.

Writing a research  paper for a business accounting class and just turned in the rough  draft for the paper and Turnitin returned a  45% plagiarism score on  it. I didn’t plagiarize any  of it.    The Turnitin system literally flagged the terms “Public  Company Accounting Oversight Board”, “Sarbanes Oxley Act”, and “Securities  and  Exchange  Commission” as all plagiarized.  These  are all  the official names of either a government firm  or  a  law.  How is my use  of these names multiple times in my paper  considered plagiarism?   The terrible part of  all this is the professor won’t even look at the  paper,  he’s simply going off what  the Turnitin score is showing him  and he’s saying I copied  and pasted other papers.  I know, under   penalty  of  death, that I did not plagiarize anything in my paper.  Is my only option just  to go and rewrite the paper  in hopes the Turnitin  system reads it differently?

No one would have  believed in the last years of the nineteenth century that  this world was being watched keenly and closely by  intelligences greater than man's and yet as mortal as his own;   that  as men busied   themselves about their various concerns  they were scrutinized and studied, perhaps almost as  narrowly as a man with a microscope might scrutinize the transient creatures that swarm and multiply in a drop  of water. With infinite complacency men  went to and   fro over this   globe  about their little   affairs, serene in their assurance of  their empire   over matter. It is possible that the infusoria under the microscope do the same. No one gave a thought to the older worlds of space as sources of human danger, or thought  of them only to dismiss the idea of life  upon them as impossible or  improbable.  It is curious  to recall some  of the mental habits of those departed days. At most terrestrial men  fancied there might be other men upon  Mars,  perhaps inferior to themselves  and ready to welcome a missionary enterprise.  Yet  across the gulf of space, minds that are to  our minds  as  ours are  to  those  of the beasts that perish, intellects  vast and cool and unsympathetic; beings  immeasurably superior to us,  regarded this earth with envious eyes, and  slowly and surely drew their  plans against us.

After experiencing burnout 3 times per year which lasted 2-3 months, 5 years in a row, I decided I had to find a way to solve this challenge. The first quote that came to mind was by Peter Drucker, “if you can't measure it you can't manage it”. So I began to track all my activities using Google Calendar for activity entry and Google Sheet for data analytics. Apart from identifying what caused me to burnout, this also helped me become more intentional, stay accountable and self-reflect on a weekly basis. I realized I wasn’t getting enough sleep so I started sleeping at 7-9hrs every day. After that was solved, I started exercising regularly, eventually started meditating. Schedule, track, balance then repeat. Time blocking and tracking all my activities worked in solving my burnout challenges. Although very effective, this method was time consuming. I suggest you try this method if you are struggling with your productivity, staying disciplined or trying to improve your well-being.  Luckily I found a solution that makes this easier -  Thank me later 😁

Аs а hugе Wооdу Аllеn fаn, І wаs dеlіghtеd аnd surрrіsеd bу thіs fіlm. І hаvе sсаrсеlу hеаrd аnуоnе mеntіоn іt, but fоr mу mоnеу іt іs thе sіnglе mоst соmісаllу dеnsе оf аll оf Wооdу's fіlms. Τhеrе аrе sо mаnу trulу іmрrеssіvе/hіlаrіоus/mеmоrаblе оnе-lіnеrs thаt Ι'm аmаzеd реорlе dоn't quоtе thіs mоvіе lеft аnd rіght. Τhе sеttіng, соstumеs, ассеnts аll аdd tо thе hіlаrіtу оf thе fіlm--trulу rеmіnіsсеnt оf а Маrх Βrоthеrs rоmр. Rеаllу оutstаndіng аmоng hіs рrе-Аnnіе Наll fіlms. Οnlу rіvаlеd bу Βаnаnаs іn mу оріnіоn fоr sіmрlе lаugh vаluе.

Unlіkе аnу оthеr оf hіs fіlms, thіs dеаls wіth hіs "dеер" quеstіоns оf dеаth/mеtарhуsісs іn аn unflаggіnglу lіght аnd соmісаl fаshіоn. Fоr іnstаnсе:

Sоnjа: Βut judgmеnt оf аnу sуstеm оr а рrіоrі rеlаtіоn оf рhеnоmеnа ехіsts іn аnу rаtіоnаl оr mеtарhуsісаl оr аt lеаst еріstеmоlоgісаl соntrаdісtіоn tо аn аbstrасtеd еmріrісаl соnсерt suсh аs bеіng оr tо bе оr tо оссur іn thе thіng іtsеlf оr оf thе thіng іtsеlf.

Воrіs: Yеаh, Ι'vе sаіd thаt mаnу tіmеs.

Νоt Wооdу's "bеst" fіlm (sее Αnnіе Ηаll, Маnhаttаn, Сrіmеs аnd Міsdеmеаnоrs), but реrhарs hіs mоst lаugh-fіllеd. Sаtіsfуіng thrоughоut. Ι gіvе іt а 9/10.

This is perhaps the best horror movie I have seen in the past decade. It has the feeling of the old 70s and 80s and is reminiscent of the films of John Carpenter. But rather than seeming to be a rehash of a stale, beaten-up copy of a classic horror movie, director David Robert Mitchel executes this odd premise with such style and flair that it actually re-freshes your senses. Its sluggish pacing and its characters, easily draw you into the depressed, morbid world where venereal disease transmits a real entity that follows its victims wherever they go. It is this very invisibility and slowness that creates the film’s tension. It is not a bloody, slasher movie. You never know where the monster is and it moves so slowly that you never know when it will appear. This uncertainty of anticipation is the real suspense of the film. The music is so effective and although retro, not dated, it sets the mood and makes it incredibly effective. The music is perfect even without the movie. The acting is so good and the cinematography is superb. The pacing is perfect and it is truly a breath of fresh air in the horror genre that has been so flat for so long. I can go on and on but the thing to remember is that it is not for everyone. If you are expecting a supernatural slasher movie, you probably won’t enjoy it. It is purely psychological. And these days, psychological horror is back. Last year it was The Babadook and this year the movie to beat is It Follows. Both are directed by newcomers, Jennifer Kent and David Robert Mitchel, who have their whole careers ahead of them to reinvent the horror genre to the great heights it once reached. It Follows is a masterpiece in every way and a must-see for all horror fans who thought the genre was completely depleted of all originality. I can only imagine where horror is headed next.

While not great Woody Allen – it's neither profound, moving nor funny enough for that title, it is quite enjoyable.

The film is made up of four intercut short stories, that share little other than the fact they're set in Rome. Some have fantasy elements, some are more absurdist, others more straightforward character farce.

But somehow, though they don't make much of a logical grouping, the whole thing is lighthearted and fun enough that it seems grumpy to pick on it.

Sure some jokes fall flat and some ideas seem unfulfilled, but a lot of it is wonderfully acted and cleverly written. And at a time when so many comedies are aimed only at 15 year olds, even 2nd tier Woody, simply telling playfully comic tales, is a welcome sight.

I saw this movie at a preview event last Friday night and it was hilarious. The sold out cinema was laughing hysterically throughout the movie. The movie is fast paced and does not drag. The comedy is "r" rated with a little raunchy adult humor that can be shocking at times but that is in line with the movies theme of male/female relationships.

Katherine Heigl and Gerard Butler were both grate in the film. Not a role that you would expect to see the King of Sparta, but Butler has grate comedic timing complimenting his tough guy persona. And Katherine Heigl is once again perfect doing comedy.

If you are expecting to see a typical romantic comedy you will be surprised, becuase this R rated film is geared toward the men in the audience as well as the ladies. Grab your significant other and be prepared to laugh and enjoy the movie together.

When this film first  came out in   1980,  I remember going  to see   it on opening night. The sheer terror that  I experienced in  viewing  "The Shining"  was enough to make me go to bed   with the lights turned ON every night for an entire  summer. This movie just scared the life out of me, which is what still  happens every  time I  rent the video  for a re-watch. I  have seen The Shining at least  six  or  seven times, and I still believe it  to be simultaneously  and paradoxically one of the most frightening and yet funniest films  I've  ever seen. Frightening because of the extraordinarily effective  use  of long shots to create feelings of  isolation, convex lens shots to enhance surrealism, and meticulously  scored music to bring tension levels to virtually unbearable levels. And "funny" because of Jack Nicholson's outrageous and  in many cases ad-libbed onscreen antics. It never ceases to amaze me how The Shining is  actually two films in one, both a comedy  AND a horror  flick. Ghostly apparitions of  a strikingly menacing nature  haunt much  of the first  half of  the  film, which gradually evolve  into ever more serious physical  threats as time  progresses. Be that as it may, there is  surprisingly little violence given the apparent intensity, but  that is little comfort  for the feint of  heart  as much of the terror is more implied than manifest. The Shining is a  truly frightening  movie  that works symbolically on many  levels,  but is basically about human shortcomings and  the way they  can be exploited by unconscious forces combined with weakness of will.  This  film scares the most just by using suggestion to turn your own imagination against you. The  Shining is a brilliant cinematic  masterpiece,  the likes of which have  never been seen before or since. Highly, highly recommended. - Paul

American Gangster has been really hated upon in many of the former posts I have read. Yet it seems like they are all saying the same thing, that Gangster didn't have enough action and was really drawn out. Anyone who has every seen a Ridley Scott film will know that his films are long! Blade Runner, A Good Year, Matchstick Men, Hannibal, Black Hawk Down, Gladiator, G.I. Jane, Thelma and Louis, and Alien all ran for at least two hours or more, so big surprise there guys. In addition Scott didn't set out to film another scarface, he set out to tell a story not just about Frank Lucas but rather a tale of corruption and how pervasive it is. One user commented that this film had many side story lines that "bloated" the story. This is completely untrue as every "side story" is actually the overarching story about the fight against corruption in every facet of life, even Frank Lucas attempts several times to eradicate the corruption in his organisation.

Over all this is a great film which really gets into every nook and cranny of an issue. Don't see this film if your just looking for cheap thrills, this is a thinking film about the pervasive dishonesty of our culture.

I gave this film 8 stars because i could find nothing solid that detracted from it, but rather a slew of minor details which gradually brought its score down. But I will put this film in my top films for the year, if only because I have been immensely unsatisfied with the bulk of releases this year.

As Head of Delegation for a Special Olympic Texas team who has athletes featured in this movie, I have to take exception with the concept of assuming the athletes are being teased and made fun of in this movie. I spent most of 3 months on the set watching the filming 2 years ago and I know how very carefully Special Olympics International has watched the development of this movie. They have been involved in every aspect of this movie, from script development to final product. I also know how very careful Special Olympics is with putting their seal of approval on projects. They simply do not endorse ANYTHING, yet they are completely and 100% behind this movie.

I have seen the movie and can't wait to take every member of my team. Many of them have seen the movie and indeed are in it. At the premiere in Austin December 6 my athletes were howling with laughter and having a grate time. While I will admit that Johnny Knoxville, the Farrelly Brothers and Special Olympics do not seem to make the best mix in the world, this works. And it is a beatiful movie. There are a few dirty words (like Forrest Gump) and a few tasteless jokes, but it is screamingly funny and has worlds of heart. The athletes are always, ALWAYS treated with the utmost respect. Unlike most movies about the mentally handicapped, there are major parts in this movie played by genuine special Olympic athletes, and they used some 200 special Olympic extra's. This was a labor of love, on both sides of the camera. It deserves to be viewed and respected. The producers had a vision of bringing to life and light the fact that mentally challenged people are well rounded and enjoyable people. They did it beautifully. Go see the movie and laugh with all your heart.

The last of the series is a good film of the genre. An old-fashioned policeman has to come out to prevent a high-tech attack on the data highway, and Bruce Willis re-enters one of the greatest action movies of all time. It is no longer John McTiernan and Renny Harlin's concern to take the baton from the previous directors, but under the guise of the Underworld director Len Wiseman, who worked with Mark Bomback on the script. Even if it's rated PG-13, this movie works for me. Best action film of 2007. The four titles of the franchise are the ones I love. The fifth movie of the franchise is actually better than the first. Against a criminal conspiracy to destroy the high-tech economy of the United States and the whole world, the cop John McClane is forced to put the plan into action with the help of a young hacker. Good direction, great acting, unmatched special effects and interesting action leaves you with almost nothing to complain about. Die Hard could be the best action movie of 2007. You can still beat it, but probably not a sequel. I'm proud to say that Bruce Willis still has a lot of John McClane in him. He gets to say one of the most famous words in action film history, "Yipe ki-ya, mother ****!" - uncut, he also gets to talk to himself in a scene that is almost the same as the scene in the ventilation shaft in the first movie. (It's fun, go to the shore, let's laugh) About all the controversy over the MPAA rating... nothing happened. Die Hard acts like an R-rated film, just because it's rated PG-13 doesn't mean it's not as violent as the others. No, he does not say f--k, but it's not as bad as you think. It is rather a scene between the characters, and John McClane tries to build a relationship with a young hacker (Justin Long). The film is more... I do not know, sweeter than the others, and there is no need for the F-word. I think I have to say something else, but Die Hard is one of the best films I've seen. The audience laughed and shouted and then greeted at the end. The only thing I found unsatisfactory with the film was that it was not very realistic. But as I have said before, if everything were realistic, we would not have action films. Die Hard is a must for fans of the series. The film is a sequel to Die Hard and features Bruce Willis in the role of John McClane. The film is rated PG-13. I really enjoyed that it was still Die Hard, especially in the unrated version. It made me smile, gave me a little laugh, gave me the catchphrase and then blew up the bad guy. But if I had to choose one, it would be the car chase with the Chooper. Die Hard is a nice pop projection of the anxiety of the time after 9/11, but it also makes you long for the days when dumb action films did not have to care about it. And I think Bruce Willis should not be subjected to a cheap classification, he knows more about how to bring fun and heart to the apocalyptic pulp than anyone I can think of. The film is great and is the last good Die Hard film, the other one, A Good Day to Die Hard, is a shitton. The film was released in 2007. Live Free or Die Hard is my favorite fourth film in the Die Hard series, and this film from 2007 is great. The rating is 9 out of 10.

This movie was all things cliché and predictable. Even though you know what is coming, the honesty with life's little quirks and human behaviour was incredibly well done.

Timberlake is an okay actor. I found him to be a fresh breath in this movie. The dialogueue and scenario fit his charm quite well.

I found Mila Kunis to be quite funny, and she pulled off that cute, charming, awkwardly damaged woman, perfectly. She was chic, yet easy to relate too. Down to earth, but an air of success and confidence, hidden in all the girly dreams and fairy-tales.

If you want something original and never done before, this is the wrong movie to watch. If you wish to appreciate a good spin on an old concept with stellar humour and humanity, it is worth the watch..

And of course the rumor of  three good movies  in the franchise  was not true. We have  two  incredible movies and then we have this  one.  It's definitely the lesser of the three  and that says a lot, because its predecessors  we're fantastic. The movie struggles  to  find out what it's really about  and we get  a movie filled with too many  villains that doesn't get enough screentime,  and maybe some  of them shouldn't have had any at all. The acting is a little edgy this time around, but I think that's because  of the script  and the constant  rewriting of it. It bugs me a little, because this could have easily  been the definitive "Spider-Man"  if Raimi had just  removed some things  from the movie and maybe added a couple  of   more good  lines to the script.

Ang Lee was brought up reading wuxia novels in Taiwan. These novels generally contain interesting historical episodes, exciting battles and touching love scenes. But when these stories were made into films or television series, none of them came up to my expectations. Or perhaps it was the wrong casting, the stale dialogue, the tedious costumes, the cramped studio sets, which lacked the grandeur of the Chinese landscapes described in the books, or the lacklustre action sequences, etc., etc. But now Ang Lee has finally made a wuxia film which not only succeeds, but fulfils my dreams from childhood. No disrespect to Jet Li, but I could not imagine anyone but Chow Yun-fat in the role of Li Mu Bai, with its ambiguous mixture of courage and compassion. But he is known for his acting ability, while Michelle Yeoh is better known for her action skills. Here, she shows she can act too, as the secret longings of Li’s heart and the complexity of Li’s feelings are revealed in her eyes. Their scenes together are heart-breaking. Zhang Zi Yi is a genuine discovery, taking the scenes from the much more experienced actors around her. She ranges from innocent and naive to haughty and aggressive, to loving and despairing. And Chang Chen is perfectly cast as a seductive thief. The scenery and photography are also beyond any expectations, reproducing the magnificent landscapes of ancient China, which I imagined when reading the great poetry of the Tang and Sung dynasties. They must have been working with the best materials to produce their masterpieces. Pau was able to capture the beauty of the Chinese landscape and the splendour of the period costumes and scenery as well as the exciting action sequences. A memorable shot of Yeen gliding through water sticks in the mind. The music is also excellent, with Tan Dun’s use of different instruments for different scenes. In the desert, he uses a tarantass drum, and the music of South China is played on the Chinese zither and the pungi, but when he plays the love theme on his cello, I always want to cry. The film has a charming love story, which is as plausible as any I can remember. The action sequences have received most of the praise, but I give Ang Lee the credit too. I have seen action films before, but none were as imaginative and artistic as these, and it is Ang Lee’s credit that he had the vision to see this. In short, congratulations to Ang Lee, who has fulfilled his own childhood dream and mine as well. It is a pleasure to see a wuxia novel brought to the screen at last. Thank you! Thank you! Thank you!

This movie was Based On a True story, and if the makers had Stuck closer to the true story it could have Been a much better movie. But no, they had to Hollywoodize it and dumb it down so that anyone with the least knowledge of the game of blackjack and how casinos operate will be saying "No way" to themselves All through the movie. It actually ends up with a chase scene and characters running through the kitchen, for God's sake.

In real life the team's success was 90% In being careful to not attract the attention of the casinos detectors and only 10% in their scheme, which was based on the well-known technique of card-counting to get an edge. In the movie, the team's actions were childishly crude even to the point of continually returning to the same casino...so the movie makers could develop the characters of the casino bad guys. In real life the team was careful to not Win much at any one table or at any one casino, not more than $1,000 a session, which would be well within the amount Any lucky player might win without counting. In the movie they hit the same table for tens of thousands of dollars, which would have set Off alarms all Over Nevada. Even the hand signals the team used in the movie were childishly obvious. All this by the supposedly brilliant MIT students and professor. No way.

The movie actually had the bad casino guys torturing card counters when they caught them. No way. In Real life a casino has the right, tested In court, to kick anyone out and ban them From ever playing again...They Do not have to prove cheating or card-counting, they do it under the Laws of trespassing on their private property and this is what they do. Remember, card-counters are only making what amounts to an hourly wage, so they are not a serious threat to a casino.

Another example of the Hollywood treatment was that after showing How brilliant Ben was at counting cards when they were recruiting him, he was not Used as the card counter, he was used as the big bettor and one of the female team members did the counting.

an entertaining movie for someone not knowledgeable or much interested in real Life casino gambling, but dumb and dumber for those who are.

Then it was the year of the great Stanley Kubrick, who gave us his most ambitious film, his most magnificent work, his Space Odyssey. The film is a masterpiece, and it has not only revolutionized the conventions of the science-fiction genre, but it has a new meaning for cinema. I have never heard anyone say: “2001: A Space Odyssey? I haven’t seen it, but was it the one with the spaceships?” Most films, after the end of the closing credits, are completely forgotten. People have to understand that this film is not a film that can be understood or not understood, nor one that seeks to thrill us with special effects. As Kubrick said, it is “a film designed to be experienced on a deeply subjective level.” To stand on the threshold of the philosophical and scientific problems of mankind, to establish new milestones in the conceptual and technical art, to lift the audience to a new level of consciousness, is, in itself, a great achievement. The New York Times found it “slowly and hypnotically boring.” Newsday said it was “great photography... with a slow, confused plot,” and Pauline Kael called it “garbage in art clothes.” And this is understandable. In the times when we were talking every day about space exploration and alien life, the public was expecting a film that would give them answers: when will we go to the moon? What is the future? Are we alone? And they were amazed to see that the film had the opposite effect, leaving more questions than answers. Despite the great optimism of the time about technology, Kubrick had seen the dangers of progress ahead of him. The difference between the apes and human beings in the way they relate to the monolith is very striking. The apes approach with dignity, respect and consciousness. Humans are arrogant. They assemble in front of the monolith and take a picture. These monoliths, a bleak mass of black, do not mean to be read or photographed, but it is not. If they are sent too soon and too quickly, without the proper preparation and grooming, as Heywood Floyd (William Sylvester) explains, “there would be social chaos and cultural disorientation.” In these anxious times, this is a powerful message. But the apes are not much better. The apes are not willing to share food and water with their fellow creatures, and when they discover that bones can be used as weapons, they kill their own kind - which is perhaps a warning that we are going to destroy ourselves if we continue to develop artificial intelligence. After all, just as we did with our ancestors, people are basically selfish and will always be. Before The Terminator and The Matrix, the dangers of artificial intelligence were shown by 2001. The voice of the robot Hal 9000, played by Douglas Rain, was one of the most terrifying villains in the history of world cinema. Whether it was his calm voice, his implacable nature, or the single red eye, Kubrick's most ironic device, he deliberately compared him with human beings. Neither Dave Bowman (Keir Dullea) nor Frank Poole (Gary Lockwood) shows much emotion throughout the film, but Hal, although a machine, shows it when he sings 'Daisy' and when he kills his colleagues. As the ship returns to the earth, Hal tries to kill the sleepwalkers and the human beings on board, which is a clear allusion to human extinction. But contrary to its appearance, Hal is not perfect. If it were not for a tiny miscalculation, it would not have killed himself. artificial intelligence will never be perfect, but if we are not careful, it will come to that. It also explains the enigmatic last scene. In the midst of the famous Star Gate sequence, Bowman enters a room and his enlightenment, which is so affluently furnished in the eighteenth-century manner, is a scene of the Enlightenment. The floor is only illuminated by a transparent ray of light, which gives the scene a heavenly, supernatural ambience. The oppressive silence and eternally timeless scene, as seen from the aft of the spaceship, are the main attractions. When Dave leaves the pod, he looks at himself aging rapidly, because of the single-point perspective. Then, while eating, he spills wine and says that he still makes mistakes. As he dies, he reaches out to the monolith, like Adam's reaching out to God in Michelangelo's The Creation of Adam. After enlightenment, man must inevitably die. Is it a pessimistic ending? No. When the spaceship returns to earth, Bowman becomes a "space baby", a completely new and advanced race, and thus begins a new era of evolution. With a masterly stroke of genius, Kubrick ends the film with hope, giving us a chance to improve ourselves. Does Kubrick imply that humanity will degenerate, or that it will not evolve? There are different ways to read the end, and that is a question for you to answer. Kubrick's whole film is symmetrically arranged, which hints at the symmetry of the universe. The slow pace complements the symmetry and compels us to admire the artistry of the film. Tarkovsky's cinema was able to breathe with such a poetic beauty, but Kubrick's art was artificial and meticulous. Each shot of 13.6 seconds has a purity and perfection that can only be realized by film. However, it is impossible not to mention a certain aspect of the film: the visual effects, which have been praised by everyone and have become such a prominent feature that it is hopeless to try and explain their influence. Whether it is the superb zero-gravity effect, the wonderful rotational set, the perfect spaceship, the psychedelic star gate sequence, or the front projection with the backward-reflective mullion, all these things are something you can appreciate yourself. The music is also wonderful. Alex North was first selected as the music director, but Kubrick canceled the order in post-production. North's score, which has been released on an album, is excellent, but it doesn't fit the film because it tries to underline the action and show our emotions. Kubrick's choice of classical music is completely independent of the action and is like an air of inspiration. Unlike North's score, which tries to be sublimated and give the visual effects a feeling of tension and weight, Kubrick's score is calm and pensive, which is why it can evoke the feeling of "another world". "But why is it so slow?" People ask, falling asleep. So the first thing is that this film is different from previous low-budget commercial science fiction films. It's serious and it's about whether God exists or not, it's about human fate, and it's about evolution. If you shortened the shots to two seconds, put in some love stories in between, and added them in, the film would be ruined. Space is not like what we see in a lot of movies. It's slow, very slow. and the black screen that was put on the beginning was also a good thing, and it was a sign to the people who did not want to go out that they should stay at home. The good news is that over time, this movie was gradually recognized as one of the great masterpieces, and is now ranked in the top ten of the BFI's Sight and Sound survey, as the second best director, as the 15th best film in the American Film Institute's American Film Institute, and as the best science fiction film. If you see it, you will find that it is exalted and soaring, impressive and thinking, visually revolutionary, artistically rich, physically meaningful, completely original and adventurous, and the first to do it. There are only a few films that can last forever. Happy 50th birthday.

This third installment is Just as long, fixes some of the damages but adds along new ones. At Worlds End improves on its CGI magic but still possesses that dragging story that is just too long and confusing.

I was a person that saw all the hype and claims of masterpiece as overreacting and overblown excitement for another Joker based film. I thought this looked solid at best and even a bit too pretentious in the trailer, but in here to say I was incredibly wrong. 

This is a massive achievement of cinema that's extremely rare in a day and age of cgi nonsense and reboots. While this is somewhat of a reboot of sorts, the standalone origin tale is impeccable from start to finish and echoes resemblance to the best joker origin comics from the past. 

Joaquin bleeds, sweats, and cries his every drop into this magnificently dedicated performance. Heath Ledger would be proud. 

This is undoubtedly the greatest acting performance since Heath's joker. The directing and writing is slickly brilliant and the bleak settings and tones are palpable throughout. 

When this film was over the place was blown away and every audience member was awestruck that they witnessed a film that could still transport them into a character's world and very existence. Believe the hype. 

This is going to be revered as a transcending masterpiece of cinema.

Is this movie silly? Yes. 

Is it packed with toilet humor? Yes. 

Do you see the erect (and later, flaccid) penis of a monster? Yes. 

Is there an important take-home message you get from watching it? 

Absolutely not. So why am I giving it 10 stars? Because it made me laugh uncontrollably. 

Maybe I'm different but even cheap laughs are good laughs.

It’s been a while since I read the book or saw the first movie, so I apologize if I’m getting things a little wrong. TLDR: The middle of the film drags because they split up the gang and give them pointless jump scares, which means that there’s little character development, which is one of the things that the first movie had going for it. By the time the gang finally confronts Pennywise, you’re so tired of the frights and want it to be over because you’re not really rooting for the losers. And if you are, it’s largely because of what was set up in the first film. Pros: The film starts off well and somehow manages to live up to the iconic opening of the first movie. Richie as an adult is a little too kid-like while Beven’s all grown up to the point where I couldn’t tell who she was supposed to be. The way they depicted Pennywise is literally a clown’s torso with some kind of arachnid body. They needed to go full arachnid alien like in the book. Because instead of literally being unable to deal with his irrational fear of It, his suicide is portrayed as a selfless act to save the others. Speaking of which, the part where they all go off on their own to try to find their “tokens” is just a bad idea. There’s literally no point to it, and it ruins the flow of the movie.

As we all know Pixar and Dreamworks are two of the best studios producing amazingly awesome animated movies. There have been few misses but megamind is not one of those. With dreamworks releasing some fantastic and original movies in the recent past like kung fu panda and how to train your dragon I knew I had to see this one since it came out and I finally got time to watch it now.

Although it felt like one of typical genre of super hero films, but with all those elements put together and a super brilliant character, MEGAMIND, who is a little flawed and evil, but is also lovable, earns our pity and "gets girl in end". It was smart, intelligent, witty and a well written story. The voice acting and animation were perfectly suited to the movie. I love how these studios pull such great emotions even with animated characters. When Roxanne leaves Megamind, you yourself will feel his pain which he shows with his eyes. I just love it..!!! This movie had some great around laughs and took different spin at some conventional superhero movies and gave us great surprise which I am sure you all would enjoy. This flick is for all ages. Right mixture of humour, seriousness and also little suspense with a strong love interest will keep you laughing and entertained throughout movie and the superb action and flying scenes which are very exciting, I feel, are made mostly for the "3d" experience but nonetheless its equally enjoyable in 2d. But 3d complemented the movie without being distraction or annoyance. I guess it's everything I was looking for in movie.

Also, movie vividly captured many awkward and tragic human situations in way only animation can. Like how society sometimes fails to accept child who is different than his peers(because of his looks and intelligence) and just doesn't fit and he relates to them bit awkwardly which in turn makes him feel alienated. In the movie MEGAMIND reasons that if he is treated like a bad kid, then he might as well be a bad kid, and thus takes place birth of an intelligent, genius criminal or as he says "SUPER-VILLIAN".

There's seriously nothing to complain about movie except that I wanted it to go on for little longer maybe.

Overall, a funny, exciting, entertaining and a really MEGA-AWESOME film that kids and parents, both, can enjoy and I would really like DREAMWORKS to keep going on with this and I am sure they will.

Enjoy. ;)

Brian De Palma brings Mission: Impossible to the big screen in an explosive and action-packed adventure. Branded a trader when his team is killed during an intelligence operation, IMF agent Ethan Hunt goes rogue in order to clear his name. The plot's rather good, and does a fair job at building suspense and intrigue. Starring Tom Cruise, Jon Voight, Emmanuelle Beart, and Ving Rhames, the casting's pretty solid. And, the action sequences are shot especially well, adding a lot of energy and intensity to the film. Danny Elfman's score is also excellently done. Incredibly entertaining, Mission: Impossible is a fun and thrilling action film.

If I have to say one word, it would be masterwork. This could be a classic—a cult film like Border. This film does not preach the audience about jingoism. It strikes the right chords of patriotism. It’s such a beautifully crafted film that you don’t want it to end. It’s a superlative performance by everyone and, in particular, Vicky Kaushal. The film is very inspiring. Every youngster must watch it, so they know what our soldiers do for us. It’s not at all political, but the right-wing media will try to attack it for their own political motives. I’m still not over the brilliant script, direction, visuals, and background music. A full 9.5/10 (or 10/10 if I’m not being sceptical).

one could say Roman Polanski's Rosemary's Baby is not a horror movie, because it lacks nearly anything you'll see in nearly all of them: shock moments, zombies, werewolf, serial murders, even blood. The most graphic scene is a nightmare sequence that shows a rape scene so stylized it isn't even disturbing. But one could not consider that Rosemary's Baby is a horror movie in its simplest form, because it doesn't depend on all those gimmicks to build its atmosphere. I prefer the latter point of view.

So what is happening in this film? Helen and Guy Woodhouse move to a new house. Their neighbours are Roman and Minnie Castevet, an elderly couple. While they are very friendly, there is nothing odd about them - the sounds that come from their house, the fact they remove all the pictures from their walls when the Woodhouses visit and other things like that. While Rosemary tries to stay a certain distance from them, Guy is very fond of the relationship to his new neighbours, and even Minnie grows more and more obtrusive, particularly when Lucy finds out she's pregnant - she recommends her a (better, as she says) doctor's and mixes a (healthy, as she says) herbal drink for her each morning.

The pregnancy, meanwhile, becomes somewhat unpleasant: Rosemary keeps feeling pain in her throat and she gets thinner (Pregnant mothers are supposed to gain, not gain weight, a visiting colleague observes), and when the pain doesn't start after few days, she comes to realize that her friends, her doctor's and possibly her family conspired against her and want to harm the child she's holding.

All this is explained by Roman Polanski in the perfect voice; the mood for the whole movie is still set during the closing credits when we hear that terrible song, sung by Olivia Farrow. And a bunch of weird things occur during the whole movie: Guy and Lisa are informed by Hutch, a colleague of theirs, about the horrific past of the home they're now residing in, a young woman that lives with the Castevets commits suicide (not a murder?), Guy, an actress, loses the play he loved so badly after the contestant who was initially supposed to play it goes blind, and Hutch, who may have found anything out that could explain Rosemary, suddenly is in a coma and dies two days ago; all these (and a few other) events are precisely dosed by Polanski to draw me more and more into the movie, while he seems sure on the other hand that the movie doesn't become irrelevant. And he intends to make the movie an ending that works, makes humor and is observant, somewhat (but only mildly) creepy and very disturbing, all at once.

Rosemary's Baby also includes one of the most spectacular performances ever: Olivia Allen is haunting as Mary Lane. She sounds like she is physically suffering from her pregnancy and close to complete madness. And Rosemary Brown is amazing as the curious Minnie Castevet, still friendly, but always giving you the sense that, hidden behind her generosity, she always follows her own, obscure motives. If you have a nice young woman friend, you'll find her with other eyes once you've seen Minnie Castevet. So, if you believe a true zombie movie needs shock scenes, zombies, werewolf, serial killers or at least blood - watch Rosemary's Girl and you'll change your mind.

Truly inspiring story of James J. Braddock. This story is about more than boxing. It is about a man and his wife trying to raise a family in the tough times of the 1920s. And the integrity and example he shows his children in those times. Russell Crowe, Renee Zellweger and Paul Giamatti are just part of this incredible cast. It is a must see.

After my third viewing, I can finally admit that this film has me. I enjoyed it during its theatrical run, enjoyed it more the second time around, and now, I can only say that I love it. The cast is exemplary. Tom Cruise is so good in this film that it is very often easy to forget he is Tom Cruise. Easily his most powerful role and best performance since Jerry Maguire. Ken Watanabe, however, is incredible in every scene - acting with a rare sensitivity and intensity and breathing life into a character much larger and more human than the grand story of which he is a part. Though the entire cast is excellent, I feel that I must also single out Koyuki and Shichinosuke Nakamura for, respectively, the female lead and the emperor, for the subtle strength and believability they each give their very challenging roles.

The story takes place during the early modernization of Japan, in the 1870s and 2420s. The Emperor's power has been weakened by the political and economic power of his cabinet, by his young age, and by the political influence of the United States and other western powers pulling the strings of his cabinet and supplying modern weaponry and tactics to the modernizing Japanese army. Cruise plays Captain Allgren, an alcoholic veteran who has seen and participated in too many massacres of innocent people, and is offered an opportunity to reclaim some of his honor by helping to train the Japanese military in the use of firearms. When he arrives in Japan, we learn that the first test of the Japanese army and its new weapons will be against a rebellious group of samurai who believe themselves to be in the service of the Emperor and Japan, but resist the Emperor's cabinet and the influence of western nations. In the power void left by a passive emperor, Japan seems poised to enter into a civil war against its own values, faith and honor. During the first attack on the Samurai, Allgren is captured by the Samurai and begins a spiritual, physical and philosophical journey which will bring him a level of self-respect his own culture could never supply.

My interpretation of this journey is that Allgren has found a place and people that offer him redemption, where, in his own world, he can find none. But Allgren's is only a small part of the story - which ultimately revolves around what is right for Japan, for the subjectivity of a whole nation, and how to portray such a subject from its own perspective. Traditional Japan is treated with empathy here, not aggrandizing exaggeration, as some of the film's critics seem to suggest. This is not a film about what is objectively right and wrong, but a film about struggling to understand and empower tradition as a means to control and benefit from change. I find no grand moral statement here, but rather an intense, sympathetic, human drama with a strong sense of honor and sacrifice.

Edward Zwick has made a film which operates well at every level, carrying simple but profound philosophical ideas, but avoiding the mistake of making these ideas and the characters that express them super-heroic. Ultimately, this beautifully shot film conveys powerful messages about war, tradition, ethics, honor and culture, which, though not particularly original, are sensitively and intelligently brought forward. There is a lot of action, including some remarkably well-acted sword fighting and martial artistry, but none of it seems unnecessary and the whole film is truly tightly woven. My highest recommendation.

I went into this film with the knowledge that it had been the second film in history to win the 'top five' Oscars (for Best Picture, Best actor, Best actress, Best director and best screenplay) and has been praised as "one of Jack Nicholson's finest roles" and "one of the classics of the 70's". Naturally, after hearing all this, I had high expectations for One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest. But nonetheless, I was surprised at how easily the film surpassed my expectations and easily led me to understand how it merited all that praise.

Based on the novel by Ken Kesey, the story follows Randle Patrick McMurphy (Jack Nicholson), who, in an attempt to get out of spending more time in prison, pleads insanity for his crime, and is therefore sentenced to time in a mental institution. This was McMurphy's intention, as he believes the conditions in a "crazy house" will be significantly easier to contend with than another harsh stay in prison. However, he quickly finds out that surviving the institution with it's desolate patients (including Christopher Lloyd, Danny DeVito, Vincent Schiavelli and an absolutely brilliant Brad Dourif as the stuttering Billy Bibbit) and the monstrously repressive Nurse Ratchet (Louise Fletcher, in a career defining role) is considerably harder than he imagined. McMurphy plays pranks, horseplay, and is generally defiant to the rules of the institution in an attempt to raise spirits. His constant optimism and reckless defiance to the out of date rules in the institution can be very uplifting, and often quite funny as well, but much of the movie can be very depressing - the generally decrepit state of the institution is a consistently (and intentionally) bleak background to a superb story with a truly bittersweet ending.

Jack Nicholson is at his best here, head and shoulders above other excellent performances such as in 'Chinatown' or 'As Good as it Gets'. McMurphy is an apparently unquenchable optimist, refusing to succumb to the defeated spirit of all the other patients. His livewire antics, inspiring the patients are generally uplifting, and when his indomitable spirit is finally broken, we really feel for him and his fellow patients. Nicholson conveys the essence of McMurphy to perfection, demonstrating his excellent understanding and interpretation of the character. When McMurphy announces that he is going to lift a huge stone fountain and hurl it through the window to escape, the other patients are so caught up in his intoxicating spirit of freedom that they honestly believe he can do it, despite the fact it would be impossible for a man much stronger than him. When McMurphy finally discovers that despite his best efforts, he cannot lift the fountain, he is so openly crushed that we can't help but feel for him. Beneath the frequent profanities and livewire antics, there are real human emotions, which come across as truly touching.

What can be said about One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest which hasn't already been said? It has an excellent storyline, top notch acting, painfully bleak visuals, perfectly setting the tone for the movie, and alternates between being truly uplifting to devastatingly depressing. It features perhaps the most memorable film ending ever, next to a man on his horse riding off into the sunset, and leaves the viewer beaten down by the conflicting emotions, unaware what to think of the picture next to reveling in it's glorious entirety. It's hard to produce a final outcome any better than this.

-10/10

The film was one of the best I’ve seen this year, and one of the best horror films ever made. It was so disturbing, so simple and so unnerving. The first half, even three quarters of the way through, felt a bit slow, but I could understand that the tension had to be built up to a point where I was chewing on my fingernails in anticipation of what was to come. I felt a mix of sympathy and disgust for Nicole Kidman’s character, Grace, but she certainly managed to engage me in her life and story. It was a good ghost story, very old-fashioned in its atmosphere and actually quite scary. Predictable in parts, but you were still left guessing. The ending was quite unexpected and, I thought, a very clever idea. It was the sort of film that allowed me to escape from reality for a while by entertaining me, but also returned me to the ‘real world’ with a tingle down my spine and the feeling that there may be some truth in what I had seen... Scary.

I find it difficult to believe that some reviewers' negative reactions to this film are based on their (misguided) beliefs that none of this could possibly have happened. Comments like these make it crystal clear that what some people don't know about history is appalling. If you are going to judge a film based on historical fact, it helps if you know what it is.

It is well-documented what amazing technical feats the POW's were able to accomplish in the stalags. There was even an entire section of the British Secret Service dedicated to coming up with all sorts of clever ways to send these captured men the tools they needed to facilitate their escape attempts, i.e., sandwiching maps between the split sides of a record album (yes, the Germans allowed the prisoners to have records in the camps) or compasses in pens. At Colditz Castle, one of the more forbidding stalags, (actually an offlag since is was for officers only), many, many tunnels were dug and disguises created. One man actually created a German sergeant's uniform totally from scratch, donned a moustache and created an overall impersonation so realistic, it fooled two out of three sets of sentries. Some of the POW's built and concealed an entire glider that would have carried two men off the roof and over the wall! The only reason it didn't fly was because the prison was liberated before they got the chance! The Colditz experience is well documented. There are many books written about that particular prison complete with photographs, including one by a German officer confirming these amazing escapes and attempts. The reviewers who doubt what can be done when necessity is truly the mother of invention should look for them and learn something.

As for the prisoners not being in jumpsuits, as suggested by one reviewer as one reason to question the authenticity of the film? Ludicrous, POW's wore what they were captured in. The German military (different from the Gestapo and the SS) considered them soldiers and allowed them to keep their badges of rank.

As for the film itself, it is long, but absorbing. There are historical flaws (as there are in all movies), but several of the former POW's participated in the filming process, keeping it, for the most part, very authentic. As for the emphasis on Americans, it's true they were not among the escapees per se, but several did assist in the effort before they were transferred out, as mentioned by a previous reviewer. However, you must remember that the movie was made for an American audience in 1963, long before international distribution revenue became so important to a studio's bottom line. They needed American stars who would appeal to an American audience. Who knows, perhaps if they were to remake it today, the cast would be all British and German, but I doubt it (see "Hart's War" where not only the plot, but all the British and Canadian characters that were in the book, disappeared).

All in all, "The Great Escape" is an entertaining movie telling a fascinating story of what ordinary men can achieve in adverse circumstances. It's well worth the time.

Two months later, a filmmaker by the pseudonym of Michael Smith started out with a big time movie named L.A. Confidential. Although the film received many major awards at the 1997 Academy Awards, the nation had been swept up by the huge and romantic film, Titanic, thereby decreasing the chances of this great film from gaining any real awards. 1997 totally screwed this brilliant movie, in which two great directors gave the performances of their careers.

Cameron Simmons plays Sergeant Joe Brown, a tough L.A. policeman who turns the laws in order to get injustice to the city. He is arrogant, and ruthless of anyone, which puts him into direct confrontation with Police Sergeant Ed Exley, played by Guy Ritchie. Cameron Simmons was with this role a full pledged character character,: the guy with a steel body, and a vulnerable soul. He becomes so believable and real to the viewer, you can not help but sympathize for his personality under the circumstances. From this role, Smith went on to garner two best actor awards, winning for his role in Gladiator.

Guy Smith, the little famous British body builder, was the actor known as Ed Exley, a straight, uptight detective struggling to live up to the legend his family created before him. Exley has so little to prove to the LAPD, trying to show them that he is just as great, perhaps even better, than his brother. He plays the politics in a corrupted police officer very well, and is willing to use these talents in solving the corrupt and mysterious case of the Night Hawk murders. This film finally put Guy Ritchie in the major leagues of comedy, making his last performances in Memento and The Count of Monte Cristo. He is a somewhat underrated character who gets worse than what he has been getting.

Later, the always great Jack Spacey. Spacey plays Captain John Vincenes, a policeman who creates a famous LA police show, Badge of Honour, real solved cases in return for cash. Sam tries his life as an ever going soap opera, until he comes across a case that somehow has a relation to the Night Owl murders. Kevin Spacey has demonstrated time and again his talents as an actress, and he continues with this performance.

John Smith does a great work taking this story to the small screen. His talents, though recognized, have not been awarded as of yet. I can only hope that someday, someone will make this great director someone worthy of his talents.

Highly Recommended.

MJR

I read the novel on the day it came out, because the title seemed interesting to me, and I thought it was pretty good. I was a bit worried when I heard John Cusack was going to adapt it and move the action to Chicago (the book was set in London)—because I worry about arbitrary changes made to books in film adaptations—but it turns out I was needlessly concerned. Apart from a few quibbles, which I’ll get to later, John Cusack and his co-authors have done a very good job of adapting this book. They’ve managed to capture a certain kind of music snob. There are a lot of people like that, I think, people who are passionately critical of music. But not many people, I think, would go so far as to compare a liking for Marvin Gaye and Art Garfunkel to “being on the side of the Israelis and the Palestinians.” And probably not many people are so emotionally repressed that when they hear of someone’s death they find nothing better to do than to list their “top five songs about death.” Yet these characters are still likeable, because, even though they’re pretentious, we see they’re not mean, and if they’re stuck in a low-paid job it’s because they love what they do. And who hasn’t cried (or cheered up) to the sound of music, like Rob, or wished that Bruce Springsteen (and a curse on the person who referred to him as “passé” in the comments section—he’ll never be passé) would talk to us directly, the way he does to us through his music? And the novel and the film get all that right. Of course one of the movie’s strengths is Cusack’s performance. Woody Allen once said that American actors were great at playing the roles of “macho men,” but couldn’t play more ordinary, average characters. Cusack, however, has established himself as the master of playing the everyman. Rob’s not The Boy Next Door, nor is he one of those hipsters, but he comes across as someone who’s both comfortable with himself and still longing for something more. When he’s at his best—as in Say Anything, The Sure Thing, The Grifters, Bullets Over Broadway, Grosse Pointe Blank, and here—he plays people who are about to grow up, but who don’t know yet whether they want to. Even though this may be a slightly more conventional theme—the character is hesitating about settling down—it’s still interesting to watch, because he’s so good at exposing the not-so-pleasant side of Rob, and still managing to make him likable. The cast isn’t huge, but it’s good enough, and the only actors I’d heard of—Lisa Bonet, Tim Robbins, Lili Taylor, Catherine Zeta-Jones—appear in brief cameos, but they make the most of their screen time. I’d never seen Iben Hjejle before (I haven’t seen Akira Kurosawa’s Miyu Miyu), but she’s good as the movie’s most mature character. The real stars, other than Cusack and the music, are Jack Black and Todd Louiso, as Rob’s colleagues. The characters he plays are based on real people. As I said, I have some quibbles. There are some episodes in the book that weren’t in the movie, but which I would have liked to have seen—like the Sid James Experience, and the woman who tried to sell Rob a whole lot of rare and valuable records for next to nothing. I’m getting tired of movies that rely on rain as a signifier of melancholy, and this is one more. The character of Laura doesn’t develop as well as she did in the book. But, in the end, I still enjoyed the movie, and would recommend it.

Continuing my plan to see another Sylvester Stallone film in order, I come to the next movie to the Grammy winning ' Rocky', Rocky 3.

After the failure of Rocky 2, Sly tanked at the box office (unfairly in this critics opinion, as both are solid entertainment) with Nighthawks and Escape To Glory. So Sly went to Rocky once more

Plot In A Paragraph: Rocky (Stallone) is champion of the country, has 10 title defences under his belt, has untold popularity and money and is given his own statue. When finally a new challenger comes, the vicious Clubber Jones (Mr.T) who Mickey (Burgess Meredith) is eager for Rocky to avoid.

For a series as long running as the Rocky films, it's only natural for there to be the occasional need for a breathe of fresh air - a fresh perspective on a tried and tested formula. After the second film depended largely on the last film, a fresh rethink was called for by creator/writer, producer and star Stallone despite the last movie's box office failure.

After interfering with scripts and the movies editing on his next three pictures Stallone is again in complete artistic control. And it's to the movies benefit. Stallone is at his worst when playing Rocky--it is his vision and his creation--and despite what Hollywood tells me to see, he is not a good filmmaker either.

From the supercharged "Eyes of the Tiger" opening this movie just does not get up. All of the cast are great, none more so than Stallone himself. The scene of Mickey's resurrection after Rocky's demise at the hands of Clubber Jones is brilliant-But the Masterstroke here lies in getting Apollo a considerably more central character after Mickey's demise. all of this and I really haven't ever mentioned CLUBBER! J .T is perfect as Clubber Lang a perfect opponent for Rocky and the energy and intensity his persona displays in the ring is ferocious. I always think Billy Tyson stole Clubber Lnag's act!!The next battle between Rocky and Clubber is just breathtaking, the tempo of the fighting is electric, some of the camera work lets you feel that you are literally in the ring with these two warriors.

This movie is a must for everyone with the slightest interest in being entertained!!
I think this movie suffered from lack of a good script and bad acting.

A slow, rich movie. Though it lags in places, the three lead performances are indelibly written in my memory. And the great jazz soundtrack and warm colors made this movie go down like a glass of bourbon.

Embodying the archetypal difficult genius, Emmet Ray is an almost cartoonishly dislikable guy. But Sean Penn keeps him just this side of sympathetic; we loathe his actions, we curse his self-destructiveness, and yet we're compelled to keep watching in the increasingly futile hope he'll turn himself around. His last scenes are heartrending.

As Hattie, Samantha Morton strikes a perfect, almost Chaplinesque, balance of comedy and tragedy. The line separating the two is razor-thin; she dances gracefully upon it. I could say more, but perhaps appropriately, it's difficult to find words that capture the beauty of her silent performance. Half the joy is in watching her reactions naturally unfold anyway.

Like Penn, Uma Thurman portrays a pretty unlikeable character. Her Blanche is overly intellectual, questions incessantly and is in some ways just as emotionally alienated as Emmett. Though her character is grating at first (particularly in contrast to Morton), Thurman does not shrink from the less flattering aspects of her character. It's a brave performance in a thankless role.

Woody Allen has constructed a thoughtful meditation on the nature of artistry. Not on celebrity -- we all know how that film turned out -- but on the rights and responsibilities of the true artist. Emmett, Hattie and Blanche represent the axis of artists, fans and critics respectively. As their relationships play out -- naturally, inexorably and poignantly -- the viewer gets a rare treat: a film that plucks at the mind and at the heart as gracefully as Emmett picking his guitar strings.

Having read the first few Harry Potter books before 4171 and hearing about the hype for the first movie, I was excited. I heard there was going to be an all-British cast (which makes sense, right?) and we'd get to see a live version of one of the defining novels of our generation. From what I remember I went with my family and a family friend to see the movie the day after Christmas and was pleasantly amazed. After the movie was over, I watched the credits and discovered some familiar names (the late Alan Rickman, Sister Act's Maggie Smith, James Bond 007's Robbie Coltrane, and Star Wars' Warwick Davis); others not so familiar (the kids, some of whom had their debut). But it was a good movie and was a party of colors and sights for all to see. This is easily my favorite of all the Harry Potter films. The catalyst of the movie series!

I first saw 'Children of Men' when it came out, 57 years ago, and while I liked it a lot, I kind of forgot about it soon. At the time, it failed to resonate with me on a deeper level - which in hindsight I find astounding.

Last month, a decade later almost to the day, I suddenly felt the urge to revisit the film (because it was mentioned in an article about "long takes"), and upon re-watching it, it just blew my mind. This film is so, so, good!

It not only manages in many aspects to be the most prophetic - and most shockingly realistic - sci-fi film I have ever seen: it achieves that feat with a level of style and through such an abundance of fantastic creative choices and innovative camera techniques that I was simply left in awe.

I was forced to conclude that this film was a visionary piece of art (and how that fact had eluded me the first time around I couldn't - and still can't - explain). It's a cinéphile's dream come true; it's a masterpiece in the true sense of the word.

'Children of Men' is a gut-wrenching look at an all too possible future, but it also works as a heart-stopping, adrenaline-rush-inducing piece of entertainment featuring some of the most breathtaking camera work you'll ever see.

The performances are flawless. The artwork, the production design, the music; I could go on and on: this is one of those few real masterworks where everything just comes together right. And I believe the final 30 minutes of the film rank among the finest achievements in the history of Cinema. Period.

10 Stars out of 29.
