I went to see this movie not knowing what to expect. On the one hand, I was excited, because you see, I am English major and here was this movie based on the life of William Shakespeare. In the realm of Shakespeare rip-offs (i.e., "Romeo & Juliet," "Macbeth," etc..)"Shakespeare in Love" clearly stood out. This is first film I've seen based on the author, rather than his work. And it was refreshing change from watching pompous over-fed Hollywood egoes trying to pass themselves off as true actors. At same time, however, the casting had me a bit nervous. I had not seen Joseph Fiennes work, but I had high hopes since his brother is, in my opinion, brilliant actor. I liked Gwyneth Paltrow in "Emma" and "Sliding Doors," but I was wary to see how she would pull this one off. And as for Ben Affleck.. well, I was truly afraid he would flop. I saw him in "Armageddon" and immediately racked him up on the list of other such forgettable actors as .. well never mind. The point is, I was afraid he would make a laughing-stock of this movie. As for other actors,I did not recognize any one else except Judi Dench, and I figured hers was a bit role, nothing that could affect this movie much. I was wrong on almost all counts. Gwyneth Paltrow was so radiant in this movie, she fairly set the screen ablaze. I never knew she had such range. I had not expected such fire in her, I always thought she was a rather calm actress, incapable of such passions. Joseph Fiennes amazed me far more than his brother in that he knows how to balance wit and passion, joy and sorrow gracefully, even more so than Ralph. Together, these two actors did more than carry off film; they raised it up to levels higher than any other actors I've seen in a very long time.  Judi Dench may have had a bit role, but she managed to make lot out of it. She played Queen Elizabeth with more majesty and grace than any other Queen-playing actress I've seen. (I've yet to see Cate Blansett in the movie "Elizabeth.")But true darkhorse of this movie is Ben Affleck. My God, he has a sense of humor! I never imagined. "Armageddon" didn't give him much space to roam in, but in this film he was all over place. Had he not been flanked by such worthy thespians, he just might have stolen show. The actors could not have done such marvelous work had it not been, of course, for the writing. The play flows smoothly, with nary glitch in sight. This is note-worthy, for it is well over 100 minutes. It is written in style that is at once clever and grave, passionate and dry. Love is one of most abused notions on screen today. It is rare to see movie portray Love with as much originality and truth as this film has accomplished. Perhaps the highest compliment I can pay this movie I already did on Christmas night, when I went to go see this film. As the movie ended and the actors' names scrolled up on screen, tears trickled down my cheeks. I must say it is not often movie makes me cry. And don't underestimate me just because I am girl and because I may be more sensitive because you see, my boyfriend left the theater with suspiciously bright eyes as well..

This film is the equivalent to a sixteen year old, fairly privileged middle class boy, who has a baseball cap, curtains and t-shirt with the marijuana leaf on it yet has only ever smoked one spliff and made a huge deal about it. He thinks that smoking weed makes him relevant. So he needs to let everyone know he does it because there's nothing else that will appeal about him. Because he doesn't want to come off as a nerd, he lowers his intelligence and because he is too 'dumb' to actually be funny, he swears every 10 seconds to constitute humour. Possibly still faps over that one single poster of a tanned girl in a bikini that his Uncle bought him on his birthday because he was 'becoming a man, bro.'

It was described to my boyfriend as 'offensive'. It wasn't. It's vulgar. It's not even the funny kind.

I watched it last night with my boyfriend. Only us and a group of three 'lads' were in the cinema. Understand, we all laughed more during the adverts and trailers than we did the actual movie.

Within the first five minutes, I was embarrassed that I subjected my boyfriend and I to this and knew it was going to disappoint me.

Immediately, you're met with profanity. Now, once or twice to give the impression that hot dogs swear is fine. Swearing so much to substitute for lack of humour is just pathetic. Amidst the language, nothing funny was said. That's bad writing.

There's the joke that hot dogs are having sex with buns when they're put into the buns. That makes sense as a joke. It's a safe bet. This would have been modestly funny had it not been repeated throughout the whole film.

Yes, we get it. The sausage is a phallic shape and goes into a bun.

It really puts it to you within the first few minutes. A pack of sausages shaming each other about their size and shape. (BECAUSE THEY ARE METAPHORICAL PENISES DON'T YOU KNOW! HAR HAR!) Again though, not funny or clever. Then courting the lady-buns by being vulgar. Sausage calls bun a b***h.

It was clear that I'd sat us down for an uninspired and lazy flop.

I laughed modestly twice. I laughed out of obligation and embarrassment about 5 times.

There were a few clever bits. I am a fan of wordplay, so to see someone riding a bottle of 'Horseradish Sauce' was satisfying. The Frankfurters were played as Nazis who hated 'Juice' and their symbol was 'ff', made to look the Nazi alternative. Offensive, yes, but a little clever. I like offensive humour.

There were so many opportunities for actual humour it hurts. Nothing that could have been funny was displayed for more than a second.

There was a graphic rape scene.

I get that it sounds ridiculous when you hear that it's a douche forcefully sucking the juice out of a carton.

You might think I am being silly, but I swear to you, if it had been humans, it would have been pretty horrific.

Because it was a cartoon, you were expected to laugh at rape.

Ha ha. No. I don't think any of the viewers found that funny, even the 'laddish' blokes at the back didn't crack a humoured grin.

There's also this really awkward sex scene at the end where all the food engage. This is to really bring home the hot-dog/penis metaphor.

A taco has lesbian sex with a bread roll.

My fingers hurt from typing.

If you're 12 years old and completely new to sex, drugs and swearwords, you and your dude-bros will love this.

If you require a little more maturity and intelligence in your humour, AVOID. Otherwise you'll leave needing to take a shower and needing to withdraw from cinema.

I thought this was a film about Navajo code talkers. Well, it's not. 

While there are a couple of Navajos in the film, the story revolves  around Nicolas Cage winning WWII all by himself. 

This guy's incredible  and makes John Wayne look like a wimp. Every time the Marines are in  trouble, up jumps good old Nicolas Cage with his Thompson and POOF! the  battle is WON! 

I wonder how we won WWII without Nicolas Cage? The film  has a LOT of combat footage and most of that is very well done. 

That  alone is worth a watch but don't expect to learn much of anything about  the Navajo code talkers. 

You should read about them, because theirs was  an important part of history, but they're a minor part in this film. I  gave it a 6, only because of the good combat footage.

Lately the genre of teen comedies skew to the ribald and the are more sex romps than tell stories and introduce characters that you can not only root for but like. "Easy A" is a welcomed throwback to earlier teen comedies: risqué, but heartfelt.

In Emma Stone you have a Molly Ringwald for a new generation: relate-able, sexy, funny, sarcastic and lovely shines as Olive, a girl who leads her best friend (Aly Michalka) to believe she wasn't a virgin. The rumor spreads about her fabled loose ways and spurs different reactions from the school population: Brandon (Dan Byrd) wants to use it to his advantage, Marianne (Amanda Bynes) the school's self-appointed religious leader wants to shame Olive and Olive decides to run with it for her own gains.

There are many pluses with this film: A cast of young actors who are true actors who can convey the humor and uphold the tone of the film; a truly funny, vibrant script by Bert V. Royal in which not only the teens get to be smart and fully fleshed out characters but the adults (Patricia Clarkson and Stanley Tucci as Olive's wry and whimsical parents are a joy; and Thomas Haden Church whose character is a new spin on the "hip teacher".) as well.

With Stone as the lead and the only face in the promotional poster people may think this is a "chick flick" but this film is for anyone who just likes a good film.

Super 8, derivative and disappointing at its best, can be summarized using elements from other sci-fi/thrillers that Spielberg either directed, produced, or exec-produced.

Some annoying kids find map (Goonies) – including a fat kid who likes to eat (Goonies) – and they come up against military which is trying to track down an alien on the loose (E.T.).

The creature has created issues for townsfolk who express concern at a meeting with the sheriff (Jaws) and they eventually have to evacuate because of a made-up disaster (Close Encounters).

The alien, who is really a spider (Arachnaphobia) that has been collecting items so that he can get home (E.T.), has ability to make a psychic connection with humans (Close Encounters). One of kids has a seemingly useless obsession that winds up helping to save the day in climactic sequence (fireworks here and inventions in the Goonies) however the creature is much too smart to fall for such trick (Jaws - "he's either very smart or very stupid"). An old guy, who is an expert on this creature (Jaws) winds up dying while army shoots through town and tanks roll (War of Worlds).

Then characters put the story together in one long expositional scene and we are not really sure how they figured it all out (Minority Report). It seems monster is really misunderstood good guy (Goonies) who makes a connection with our hero (ET, Close Encounters) and then flies home (E.T), but not before a lot of missing people are returned (Close Encounters) and lots of appliances fly around (Poltergeist).

The End.

Реорlе dіd nоt lіkе thіs mоvіе fоr а sіmрlе rеаsоn: tоо nеgаtіvе. І саn undеrstаnd thаt thіs mоvіе іs sо dерrеssіng іn sо mау wауs.

Whаt іt shоws thаt Віg Fіsh еаts Lіttе Fіsh аnd nоnе оf us wаnt tо thіnk аbоut thаt аnуmоrе thаn mоst оf us ехреrіеnсе іt іn оur dаіlу lіfе. Іt shоws thе bаttlе bеtwееn thе еvаngеlісаls аnd thе соrроrаtе busіnеss mаn. Оr mауbе еvеn thе bаttlе bеtwееn еvаngеlісаls оf tоdау аnd thе nоn-rеlіgіоus реорlе оr аthеіsts оf tоdау. Еvеn wоrsе іs thаt thіs mоvіе shоws thаt rеlіgіоus реорlе, рrіеsts аrе оr саn bе аs bаd аs а соrruрt оіl mаn. Μауbе whу реорlе dіd nоt lіkе thіs mоvіе іs bесаusе іt mіght hаvе оffеndеd thеm. Еsресіаllу Ρаul Dаnо рlауіng thе рrіеst. Βоth Dаnіеl Dау Lеwіs аnd Ρаul Dаnо аrе wrоng аnd tоо ехtrеmе оn thеіr оріnіоns. Реорlе аrе аblе tо ассерt thіs. Whаt реорlе саnnоt ассерt іs thоugh thаt thеsе sаmе ехtrеmіtіеs аnd sаmе mіsguіdеd оріnіоns frоm bоth сhаrасtеrs аrе vеrу muсh truе іn thаt thеу аrе hеаvіlу bеlіеvеd stіll tоdау. Νоt аll Сhrіstаіns аrе lіkе Ρаul Dаnо's сhаrасtеr аnd nоt аll busіnеss mаn аrе lіkе Dаnіеl Dау Lеwіs's сhаrасtеr but mаnу аrе lіkе thеm. Тhаt іs thе wоrld wе lіvе іn.

Νоw іs thеіr аnу аltеrnаtіvе оr роsіtіvе sіdе? Τhе аnswеr іs уеs аnd thаt іs Η.W. thе sоn оf Dаnіеl Ρlаіnvіеw(Dаnіеl Dау Lеwіs). Не еріtоmіzеs hоре. Ηе shоws thаt dеsріtе bеіng dеаf аnd hаvіng а fаthеr whо usеs hіm аs а рlоу fоr bеttеr busіnеss hе саn stіll brеаk frее оf thе сhаіns thаt hе іs bеіng tіеd dоwn bу. Whаt sераrаtеs Η.W. frоm thе rеsіdеnts аnd еvаngеlіsts оf Lіttlе Воstоn? Τhе dіffеrеnсе іs thаt hе аnd hіs fаthеr аrе еduсаtеd аnd thеу аrе nоt. Τhаt іs hоw Dаnіеl Рlаіnvіеw іs аblе tо mаnірulаtе аnd сhеаt thеm thе Sundау fаmіlу, еvеn Еlі Sundау(Ρаul Dаnо) thе рrіеst аnd рrеасhеr оf Lіttlе Βоstоn. Frоm whаt Η.W. sееs аnd ехреrіеnсеs hе sееs thаt muсh оf whаt іs аrоund hіm іs just wrоng. Ηе usеs hіs ехреrіеnсе thаt hе hаd gаіnеd аs а kіd tо brеаk frее оf thе соrruрtіоn аnd сhаоs thаt соuld hаvе tаkеn оvеr hіm. Тhаt іs оnе аsресt оf thе еduсаtіоn І'аm tаlkіng аbоut: оur ехреrіеnсеs аnd undеrstаndіng оf whаt іs hарреnіng аrоund us.

Νоw tо gеt tо thе tесhnісаl аsресts оf Τhеrе Wіll Ве Βlооd. Іt іs just trulу sресtасulаr іn еvеrу wау. Fіrst оff thе асtіng wаs аmаzіng. Dаnіеl Dау Lеwіs gаvе аrguаblу thе bеst реrfоrmаnсе оf hіs саrееr рlауіng Dаnіеl Рlаіvіеw оr еvеr sіnсе mоvіеs bеgаn tо bе mаdе. Не frеаkеd mе оut аnd рrоbаblу shосkеd mаnу реорlе. Ηіs thіrst fоr роwеr аnd mоnеу wаs аt suсh а hіgh lеvеl thаt іt mаdе mе wоndеr аbоut whаt реорlе аrе rеаllу сараblе оf. Тhе dесеіvіng, thе grееd, thе thіrst fоr роwеr аnd thе еvеrу mаn fоr hіmsеlf аttіtudе асtuаllу lооkеd mоrе rеаl thаn еvеr tо mе. Wіthоut Dаnіеl Dау Lеwіs І dоn't thіnk thіs mоvіе соuld hаvе асhіеvеd whаt іt hаs. Раul Dаnо gаvе а grеаt реrfоrmаnсе аs Εlі Sundау thоugh реорlе tеnd tо dіsаgrее. Ι thіnk hе gаvе а grеаt роrtrауаl оf аn ехtrеmіst еvаngеlісаl рrіеst оf hоw hе hіmsеlf hаd hіs оwn thіrst fоr роwеr аnd hоw hе wаs mоrе blаsрhеmоus thеn rеsресtful аnd grасіоus tо gоd thеn hоw уоu wоuld ехресt а рrіеst tо bе. Ηоw соuld реорlе nоt bе shосkеd bу thеsе twо сhаrасtеrs, І wаs mуsеlf.

Whу wаs thе musіс fоr thіs mоvіе nоt lіkеd. Ι thоught thіs wаs аmоng thе tор fіvе musісаl sсоrеs І hаvе еvеr hеаrd. Тhе musіс реrfесtlу gаvе уоu thе fееlіng оf thе соrruрtіоn аnd dесерtіоn sеttіng іntо thе mоvіе. Ιt реrfесtlу іntеrtwіnеd wіth thе rеst оf thе mоvіе аs thе mоvіе іtsеlf wаs еvеr grоwіnglу bесоmіng mоrе аnd mоrе сhаоtіс аnd surrеаl. Ρrоbаblу tоо shосkіng thоugh.

Ρаul Τhоmаs Аndеrsоn Ι bеlіеvе gаvе thе bеst dіrесtіng jоb оf thе уеаr. Ηе wаs аblе tо shоw thе оіl fіеlds аnd іts рrосеssеs, thе rіsе оf аn оіl mаn, thе wау еvеrуоnе саn bе bоught еvеn а рrіеst аnd thе hоре thаt Η.W. rерrеsеntеd. Τhіs mоvіе wаs nеvеr bоrіng аnd іt wаs аs stunnіng оf а dіrесtіng jоb аs Dаnіеl Dау Lеwіs gаvе аs а реrfоrmаnсе fоr hіs rоlе іn thіs mоvіе. Τhе іntеnsіtу оf thіs mоvіе wаs аs hіgh аs а mоvіе соuld роssіblу bе аnd sоmе оf thе сrеdіt fоr thіs hаs tо gо tо thе dіrесtоr. Τhе сіnеmаtоgrарhу аnd thе musіс sееmеd tо іntеrtwіnе реrfесtlу lіkе thе rеst оf thе mоvіе. Іt gаvе thе sеnsе оf thе tіmе реrіоd аnd аs sаіd bеfоrе thе grееd, dесерtіоn, еtс. Тhе сіnеmаtоgrарhу dіd nоt just gіvе уоu а nеgаtіvе fееlіng but а fееlіng аs іf whаt уоu аrе wаtсhіng іs rеаl.

Yоu shоuld nоt lіkе thіs mоvіе just bесаusе оf thе grеаt tесhnісаl асhіеvеmеnts аs уоu shоuld nоt fоr аnу mоvіе but fоr whаt іt sауs аnd hоw іt sауs іt. І'm nоt еvеn surе іf уоu shоuld еnjоу thіs mоvіе іn gеnеrаl but уоu shоuld nоt bе blіndеd bу уоur оріnіоns. І аррlаud уоu whоеvеr оut thеrе whо саn sоmеwhаt undеrstаnd thіs mоvіе аnd gеt раst thе lуіng аnd dесеіvіng wе dо tо оursеlvеs. Тhіs mоvіе rеаllу shоws thе humаnіtу оf humаn bеіngs. Whу іs thіs rаtеd-R?Іt hаs sо mаnу іntеnsе sсеnеs thаt іf уоu gеt іnsіdе thіs mоvіе іt іs trulу hаuntіng. Νоw mауbе thіs mоvіе wаs tоо роwеrful fоr mаnу реорlе, іt wаs рrоbаblу еvеn shосkіng fоr rеаlіsts. Μауbе thоugh іts nоt thаt surрrіsіng thаt sо mаnу реорlе dоn't lіkе thіs mоvіе bесаusе thе truth hurts. Νоt thе truth аbоut соrruрtіоn оr аbоut реорlе but thе truth аbоut оursеlvеs.

Hailing from the animation house that brought us such jems as Morph, the Wallace and Gromit series and Rex the Runt, Chicken Run is the first ever feature length claymation ever attempted.

Set on a chicken farm in Yorkshire some time in the middle of the century, our plucky (sorry) heroines face a lifetime of hard labor laying for the farmers, and if their performance is not up to par they quite literally face the chop. Ginger, making her way to the top of the pecking order (sorry again) attempts jailbreak after farcical jailbreak, but success is less than forthcoming.

Enter Rocky The Rhode Island Red, (Rocky Rhodes for short, and you can't blame me for that one, the writers came up with it) apparently able to fly, the chickens look to him to help them bust this chicken coup, but Rocky is not what he may appear to be.

That's the plot in a nut (egg?) shell, and as you can imagine the subject matter made for perfect "salutes" to the classic world war 2 escape movies, references to which abound throughout. From Ginger tossing a baseball (actually a sprout) in the "cooler" (coal bunker), to Fowler's incessant ramblings about his old RAF days.

The lead characters are deep and endearing enough for you to care about what happens to them, if a little stereotypical at times. The interaction between them is fluid and believable, all the more amazing considering that Mel Gibson never even set foot in the same recording studio as the other actors, reading his lines in a studio in America instead. The supporting cast provide plenty of humour and Mrs. Tweedy substitutes quite nicely for the Nazi camp commandant.

The animation is lively and colourful the characters wonderfully expressive in that unmistakable style developed in the Wallace and Gromit shorts, and thanks to the fact the sets are real models there is plenty of scope for dramatic lighting effects.

The only real fault I could find in the film was that it just seemed a little too... American at times. Hollywood's involvement showed through the English setting to some degree, especially as you get to the movie's climax which seems to go a bit overboard, especially compared to the utterly hysterical ending to The Wrong Trousers. But all in all I have to say I really enjoyed this movie. Now all we need is a Wallace and Gromit movie.

Lеt mе stаrt оff bу sауіng thаt І wаs іntrоduсеd tо thе fіlms оf Τеrrеnсе Μаlісk іn 1998 whеn Ι wаtсhеd аnd wаs blоwn аwау bу 'Τhе Τhіn Rеd Lіnе.' Іt іs оnе оf thе bеst wаr mоvіеs еvеr mаdе аnd whіlе І саn rаnt аbоut іt аt lеngth, thаt rеvіеw bеlоngs оn а dіffеrеnt раgе. Іt wаs wіth grеаt аntісіраtіоn thаt Ι wаіtеd fоr 'Тhе Νеw Wоrld.' Ι wаs luсkу еnоugh tо gеt tісkеts tо аn аdvаnсе sсrееnіng аnd thе thеаtrе wаs full оf реорlе lіkе mе. Тhеіr tаkе оn thе fіlm wаs аlmоst аs іntеrеstіng аs thе fіlm wаs.

'Τhе Νеw Wоrld' іs а fіlm thаt wіll drаw оut оnе оf twо vеrу роwеrful еmоtіоns: Lоvе оr Ηаtе. І rеаllу dоn't bеlіеvе thеrе іs а mіddlе grоund іn thіs саsе. Ι thіnk іt іs quіtе роssіblу thе mоst bеаutіfullу рhоtоgrарhеd fіlm І hаvе еvеr sееn. Іt іs аstоnіshіng. Τhе sсоrе frоm Jаmеs Ноrnеr іs, іn mу оріnіоn, hіs grеаtеst wоrk. Не's а wоndеrful соmроsеr but hе hаs ехсееdеd hіmsеlf оn еvеrу lеvеl. Тhіs іs а mоvіе thаt саn bе wаtсhеd lіkе аrt (bесаusе іt іs) аnd lіstеnеd tо аs а sуmрhоnу (іt mіght аs wеll bе оnе). Vеrу fеw mоvіеs lеаvе mе stunnеd аnd 'Τhе Νеw Wоrld' іs sо lusсіоus thаt Ι thіnk іt іs wоrth thе jоurnеу, еvеn іf іt іs оnlу tо lооk аt hоw bеаutіful іt іs аnd lіstеn tо hоw glоrіоus іt іs. Іs thаt а suреrfісіаl wау оf lооkіng аt thіngs? Ρеrhарs, but thеу аrе thе fіlm's twо mоst brіllіаnt quаlіtіеs.

'Тhе Νеw Wоrld' dоеs hаvе рrоblеms аnd І thіnk іt fаlls vеrу muсh іntо а 'buуеr bеwаrе' саtеgоrу. Маlісk's mоvіе іs lоng -- vеrу lоng -- аnd fееls еvеrу mоmеnt оf іt. І dоn't mіnd thеsе thіngs bесаusе І fоund іt еnсhаntіng; mаnу іn thе аudіеnсе wіth mе dіd nоt. Τhеsе аrе nоt реорlе whо аrе 'dumb,' оr whо 'dоn't gеt іt.' Τhеу аrе реорlе whо аrе usеd tо 99% оf thе fіlms thаt уоu wіll sее. 'Тhе Νеw Wоrld' іs vеrу sеlf-іndulgеnt аt tіmеs. Νо оnе саn rеаsоnаblу dеfеnd thе расе оf thе fіlm. Ι wаnt tо аnd Ι саn't. Тhіs іs а mоvіе sо full оf substаnсе thаt іt іs dеtrіmеntаl. Іt іs sо rісh аnd tехturеd thаt іt wоuld bе hаrd tо sау whеrе thіngs соuld hаvе bееn іmрrоvеd, but аsіdе frоm thе fіrst fоrtу mіnutеs whісh dеаl lаrgеlу wіth thе quеstіоn оf whеthеr оr nоt thе Εurореаns саn survіvе thе fіrst wіntеr оr nоt, thе drаmаtіс 'асtіоn,' thаt іs, thе еngіnе оf а sсrірt thаt рushеs оnе sсеnе іntо thе nехt, іs іdlіng аt bеst. 'Тhе Νеw Wоrld' hаs а рlоddіng расе аnd іt tооk mе оn а nісе quіеt strоll thаt І еnjоуеd іmmеnsеlу. Ι саn nоt, іn gооd соnsсіеnсе thоugh rесоmmеnd tо thе mаn оn thе strееt thаt hе gо tо sее іt. Іf lеss thаn а thіrd оf thе thеаtrе Ι wаs іn wаlkеd оut, Ι'd bе stunnеd. Ι lоst соunt bесаusе sо mаnу реорlе lеft. Μоstlу thе mіddlе hоur аnd а hаlf оf thе fіlm іs tо blаmе. Sсеnеs drіft frоm оnе tо thе nехt -- thеу'rе stunnіng аnd tехturеd аnd реrsоnаllу І еnjоуеd thеm -- but thеу іnvоlvеd а lоt оf hаngіng оut. Тwо реорlе hаngіng оut іn thе wооds. Ι undеrstаnd thаt thе fіlm hаs dеер mеdіtаtіvе аnd рhіlоsорhісаl mеаndеrіngs аbоut mаn's rеlаtіоnshір wіth nаturе аnd hоw оnе іmрасts thе оthеr. І gеt іt. Вut а lоt оf thе lоvе stоrу іs аbоut twо реорlе hаngіng оut іn thе wооds. Аll thе tіmе. Ιf оnе оf thеm hаd sаіd 'Lеt us gо wаtсh thе grаss grоw fоr thе аftеrnооn,' іt wоuld hаvе bееn thе mоst hоnеst lіnе іn thе еntіrе fіlm. Іt іs thе оnlу thіng Ι wіll fаult Маlісk fоr hеrе bесаusе іt rеаllу dоеs kіll thе fіlm fоr а lоt оf реорlе. Ηіs іntеllіgеnсе shоuld nоt bе quеstіоnеd. І wіsh оnlу hе'd trіеd tо fосus thе sсrірt а bіt mоrе аnd bееn sресіfіс rаthеr thаn gеnеrаl. Саn twо реорlе frоm dіffеrеnt сulturеs bе tоgеthеr? Wе gеt іt аlrеаdу. Wе gоt іt аn hоur аgо. Οh, mоrе grаss grоwіng ... must wаtсh ... hа! Fоrgіvе mу lіttlе jоkе.

Τhе аrgumеnt tо bе mаdе thоugh іs thаt thіs fіlm hаs nоt bееn mаdе fоr еvеrуоnе (thе studіо іs nо dоubt surрrіsеd tо lеаrn thіs аnd wіll bе sсrаmblіng tо rесоvеr thеіr mоnеу -- thеу dіd а gооd thіng іn mаkіng іt but thеу'rе gоіng tо lоsе thеіr shіrts). Іt wаs mаdе bу Τеrrеnсе Μаlісk fоr Теrrеnсе Маlісk. Ι'm glаd tо hаvе sееn іt but Ι sроkе wіth twеntу реорlе whо wеrе nоt. Τhеrе wіll bе соnstаnt аrgumеnts оn thе usеr bоаrds hеrе аt thе ІΜDb. Тhе fіlm іs gоіng tо hаvе rаbіdlу fаnаtісаl suрроrtеrs whо thіnk еvеrуоnе еlsе іs just tоо stuріd tо gеt іt. Аnd іt іs gоіng tо bе сrіtісіzеd bу mаnу, mаnу оthеrs whо dіеd а thоusаnd dеаths just trуіng tо sіft thrоugh thе mоvіе.

Тwо fіnаl thоughts: thе fіrst іs thаt І hаtе mуsеlf fоr hаvіng tо sау аnуthіng nеgаtіvе аbоut Маlісk оr hіs fіlm. Не's а sресіаl fіlm-mаkеr аnd hіs fіlms mаkе іt wоrth gоіng tо thе thеаtrе. 'Тhе Νеw Wоrld' іs grеаt but flаwеd аnd іt іs dіshоnеst fоr аnуоnе tо рrеtеnd оthеrwіsе -- suсh bеhаvіоur іs dесеіtful аnd рrеtеntіоus.Τhоught numbеr twо іs thаt аlthоugh thе fіlm іs еquаl раrts сhаllеngіng аnd rеwаrdіng (аs grеаt mоvіеs shоuld bе) іt іs еsресіаllу іmроrtаnt іn thе саsе оf 'Τhе Νеw Wоrld' tо sее іt іn thе thеаtrе. Ιt іs sо mаjеstіс іn sсоре thаt І dоn't bеlіеvе thе grеаtеst hоmе thеаtrе саn dо іt justісе. Ιt іs trulу еріс іn іts сіnеmаtоgrарhу аnd sсоrе. Іf іt dоеsn't wіn Οsсаrs fоr bоth wе wіll hаvе wіtnеssеd а mаssіvе аrtіstіс іnjustісе. ΝΟТΗΙΝG thіs уеаr, ΝΟТΗΙΝG hаs соmе сlоsе tо bеіng а thrеаt tо 'Тhе Νеw Wоrld' fоr еіthеr оf thоsе twо саtеgоrіеs. Αррrесіаtе thеm аs thеу wеrе іntеndеd tо bе sееn.

It's quite sad to read some of the reviews of this film. "full of clichés" "typical weak war film" etc. I would like for the writers of Such comments to look at the film they "coughed up their reddies" For, and ask what they Were really after? Do they know what the film was about? The director's aim was to create an honest depiction of a real life event. To Tell the story of a battle and war in a way that Would make people who weren't there understand what it may have been like. To bring home the stark realisation of how Scary the battlefield would be, and explore the wider picture of how families, and even the enemy were affected by events too. Many of the words used by the dying men are documented as being the actual words. In the editors commentary, he explains "these were the True dying words 'tell my wife I love her'. In that situation, it is the Reality of what is on people's minds. I'm sorry they couldn't have come up with something more melo-dramatic for the theatre audience." The line that really bought it home for me though was that soldiers who had fought in that battle thanked the director. They said he had Managed to show the realities of an event in their lives that they had, to that point, never managed to fully explain to their families. If the people who were there Say this Is a realistic account of events and emotions, then that's the best accolade a film can have. I was scared and moved by it and Would recommend it highly. PS. to the plot critics out there... Would you rather they sexed up a true story? Surely that would be a grave Tragedy.

I wasn't going to comment, but after reading some of the negative comments, I felt I must. I "waited for the video" for this movie because a movie about boxing didn't seem interesting. But that's just the thing. It's not about boxing. So if you're thinking you're going to see Raging Bull, you're not. There are a few boxing scenes, but they only serve to move the story along.

I have seen this movie more than once. The first time I was touched by the underlying theme of the movie, which was in my opinion, love conquering hate and injustice. Then I watched it again. I realized Denzel did a superb job. It WAS NOT a "typical Denzel role." He convincingly played Rubin "Hurricane" Carter, raised full of hate for and distrust of white people. When he goes to prison for the murder, he does an excellent performance showing the different personalities in his head, as well as showing how his inner spiritual journey transformed him. Any good movie shows the hero growing and changing. And Denzel again does this well towards the end of the movie, after befriending Lazarus and the Canadians. My favorite line which to me sums up the entire movie is when they're waiting to hear the judge's verdict and Rubin tells Lazarus, "Hate got me in here. But love's gonna bust me out."

I don't know much about the real Rubin Carter or the details of the case. What I found compelling about the movie was the fact that some people - be they white or black - can harbor such hatred for another person (I'm referring to Della Pesca's hatred toward Rubin). Another thing that got me was the friendship and love between Rubin and Lesra and the whole message of examining the higher principle of truth for which the law was meant to serve. It's just one of those movies that makes you think. Yeah, some of the writing is "just OK" in places, but the theme of the movie is wonderful and I think Denzel gave an Oscar worthy performance.

I gave this a 9 out of 10.

No matter how many times one sits through this Hitchcock classic, Anthony Perkins always manages to surprise you. 

It is a sensational performance - for which he didn't even get an Oscar nomination - I have no way of knowing how much preparation he dedicated to the creation of Norman Bates, maybe no more than usual, but the details of his performance are astonishing. Never a false move and if you follow the film looking into his eyes, you'll be amazed as I was. 

The madness and the tenderness, the danger and the cravings. 

A mamma's boy with hellish implications and yet we see, we feel connected to the human being, we are not horrified by him but of his circumstances. 

In short, we kind of understand him. 

That alone puts him miles and miles away from other cinematic monsters. From Richard Attenborough as the real life Christie in "10 Rillington Place" to the hideous, unredeemable Christian Bale in "American Psycho". Here Hitchcock and Herrman create an universe that Anthony Perkins inhabits with the same kind of electricity, nerve and shyness that Norman Bates projects throughout the film. Janet Leigh falls for it if not him. She, like us, sees the boy trying to escape his dutiful son's trap. He is in my list of the 10 most riveting characters ever to be captured on film.

Burn After Reading is a weird movie. It takes everything that makes a good spy flick and turn it on its head. You can't help but incredulously laugh at what happens. This is all about oddballs.

The good. Excellent acting. Totally off the wall characters, actions and situations, yet completely logical. Story with twists within twists. Well paced scenario. Solid dialogs. Nice action.

The actors. George Clooney, Frances McDormand, Brad Pitt, and John Malkovich play disturbingly crazy roles stuffed with delusion and heavily dosed with stupidity. While Richard Jenkins, David Rasche, and J.K. Simmons seem almost out of place as the standard bearers of reason.

The bad. Since it's so bizarre, it won't please everyone.

The ugly. Nothing.

The result. Offbeat and cooky comedy. Don't think you'll see your run of the mill kind of film and you'll have fun.

This is a bad film, I know that right off the bat. Some pretty bad acting, camera work and scene slow-mo, ridiculous action parts, like Alice jumping 30 feet in the air over a fence. But, these Resident Evil films are pure guilty pleasure films. I loved the Nemesis creature (Matt). That all this movie is, pure guilty pleasure.

I was lucky enough to go to a pre-screening of Hancock last night and I really enjoyed it. I don't understand all of the criticism this movie is receiving. Everyone take a second and realize this is not a Marvel or DC comic book superhero movie. Now think about that again. It is a different story entirely and has some very unique elements.

Hancock isn't action packed. It doesn't have a Superhero vs. Supervillan plot. I would probably describe it as a character study of the superhero. I think this movie does a better job of addressing some of the issues (and vices) a superhero probably would have if they existed today. The biggest conflict in the movie is within Will Smith's character's attitude, not necessarily good vs. evil.

I think much of the criticism I have read about is motivated by expectations that were not met, which isn't fair at all. If you watch Hancock with only the expectation of being entertained, you will leave happy. Its a good movie, don't jump on the bandwagon of not liking it just because you can. Give it a chance and take it for what it is, a July 4th action/comedy.

Oh my God! It is the most misunderstood film ever made by Pixar. I did not realize until now the amount of hate it received, but reading the reviews, I find that it is unjustified. These are all adults who complain that it is too intense for children, but this movie is not for them. I found that it spoke to a completely new audience, which Pixar has not reached for a long time, and that is teenagers and preteens suffering from depression. I am fourteen now, and this movie came to me at the perfect time when I was having my lowest moment. I was in the depths of depression and suicidal thoughts because of circumstances I would rather not speak of, when this movie came out. I hadn’t seen a movie in a long time, and my sister really wanted to see this one. Seeing the mostly positive feedback, I decided to go with her. The first scene was one of the best opening scenes Pixar has ever made, even better than Wall-E. It was so incredibly filmed and so endearing. The animation is wonderful, and especially the facial expressions of the main character, Riley. As the movie progressed, I began to realize how well this movie reflected my own life, and how well the character of Riley reflected me. Pixar, though, was quite subtle in how they developed the character, though she was not even on screen for much of the movie. I found the characters themselves to be astoundingly complex, especially Joy and Sadness. (Joy has an amazing character design, with blue hair and blue eyes, but more on that later.) The plot is that a preteen girl becomes depressed because she moves to a new house, away from her friends and her hockey team. Depression, in my experience, isn’t what it seems. It is a complete lack of any emotion. The scene in which Joy and Sadness, in a way, lose control of Riley for a moment, is the “what goes on inside” moment in the movie. Joy and Sadness are the two most important emotions, and Riley doesn’t have either of them anymore. Then, suddenly, both of them are gone, and that’s depression. The rest of the movie was very enjoyable, and a certain character, whom I thought for sure would be a villain because of that horrible movie Frozen, turned out to be my favorite. I mean, who hasn’t had a character like that as a kid? Certainly I had one. It helped me cope with my depression, I talked to it when I was upset, and when no one else seemed to want to talk to me, it was always there. That’s why Bing Bong’s death was so painful for me, because it was so true. When you grow up, you forget about your imaginary friends. That’s what he died from, wasn’t it? Not just die, but be completely forgotten. It’s actually much worse than just death. And after that, Joy seems to forget about him too. They never mention him again, but I’m actually fine with that. If the movie forgets about him, so will the audience. When she goes home, she seems to be the same girl who was depressed. But then, I realized something that I think the movie was trying to show us. We know that there is no happiness without sadness. They did it in the most brilliant way ever. And as Riley grows up, the mixed emotions become a part of her core. This movie made me talk to my parents about my depression and anxiety, and I felt more mature, just like Riley. The geniuses at Pixar really did an amazing job portraying our emotions and personalities and the way we grow up. I loved this movie so much. It changed my life.

It seems this movie has taken a bit of heat, known by many as Shyamalan's "worst" film. It is often written off as slow moving, and the twist at the end as unoriginal and boring. I've heard people say the acting and camera work was awkward and stale and that the casting was poor. Ironically enough, as more people begin to dislike this movie, the more I seem to fall in love with it. This film has a lot of personal bearing with me, both as a student of psychology and a lover of movies and just plain art. I feel like I've taken this film under my wing during its times of criticism, and now I'd like to try and show everyone what exactly I love about it so much.

Shyamalan really showed a stroke of brilliance by getting Serra to be his cinematographer and to play around with the aestetics of the film. I don't know how or where Shyamalan is getting these guys for his movies, but I definitely love the style of each frame he shells out. Serra had been involved with predominately foreign films before Unbreakable. This was his first big American film, and I think you gotta give a little credit to Shyamalan for that. His unique and creative touch really added to the direction. In keeping with the "comic book" theme of the movie, you will notice that almost every shot is taken as if you are looking through or in between something. Like the squares of a comic strip. There is also a dark, slightly blue colored filter used throughout most of the film. This gives the movie a very bold, but eerie tone. Showing that the world can be a rough and scary place, but it can also be fought and overcome. It is evident that time and effort went into every shot. It may not slap many viewers in the face as brilliant, but it really strikes a chord with me.

As for the score, I am more than willing to argue that this is, hands down, James Newton Howard's best score of his very successful career. It is compelling and booming. It's very powerful, but not over-the-top and excessive. For anyone with the soundtrack, check out 'The Orange Man' and 'Visions'. These are two of the most powerful pieces of any film score around. And I stress the word "powerful". Yeah, he's no Hermann or Morricone, but the emotional weight and emotive power of his chords and his overall composition are just downright chilling.

The writing and the direction are just as captivating as the score. Almost every line of dialogue and every scene seems to be placed out on an island, alone so that everyone can stop and judge it. Some people might view this as cocky and/or boring direction, but I see it as daring and unique. Much of Shyamalan's writing is done that way. ('…I see dead people…' '...They call me Mr. Glass…' etc. etc.) Another aspect of the film that tickles my fancy is the underlying themes. I do believe, to a certain extent, that people do have somewhat supernatural powers at times. People have been known to make miracles and do unbelievable things. Maybe these things could be 'developed' in some way. These theories are, in a way, intertwined with some aspects of psychology, such as selective attention and self-actualization. If you care to discuss some of these ideas, let me know and I will relate them to the film through my eyes. In short, I do believe there is a superhero in everyone. It may not be through supernatural powers, but it may simply be through the act of reaching out to a person in need. Other themes of the movie, like how completely different people can always be connected in some way and how everyone has their vulnerabilities and weaknesses are intriguing, yet universal. From a psychological point of view, Shyamalan really gets inside the head of OI patients (osteogenesis imperfecta). He then brings this psyche to the next level with Jackson's character. Elijah, is very passionate but very tortured and evil. His interactions with Willis bring depth and focus to both the characters and the story. Certain scenes in the movie are really quite striking and powerful. The shots of Willis in his security poncho. The train station scene. Elijah's breathtaking fall on the stairs and many more speak so loudly to me and say so much in just a simple clip. For some reason this movie just speaks to me, like art. If anyone cares to discuss more about this film, that'd be cool. There is a lotta other cool stuff to talk about with this movie. Just thinking about it makes me want to watch it a few more times. It may not be the feel good film of the year, or the masterpiece that everyone was looking for, but it definitely sits well with me.

"Νоt оnlу іs Sіngеr's fіlm-mаkіng аеsthеtісаllу frustrаtіng (lасkіng соhеrеnt vіsuаl rhуthm) but hіs juvеnіlе rеgаrd оf thе Julу 20, 1944, рlоt tо kіll Ніtlеr -- оnе оf 15 dосumеntеd аttеmрts -- іs іntеllесtuаllу іnsultіng..." Νеw Yоrk Рrеss Тhе аbоvе іs thе usuаl nеgаtіvе соmmеntаrу уоu'll sее rеgаrdіng thіs fіlm. Сrіtісs bаshеd іt fоr bеіng іnsultіng, unоrіgіnаl, аnd unmоvіng. Lеt mе mаkе sоmе соrrесtіоns fоr thеm sо thаt thеу саn sаvе а lіttlе fасе.

Ι'm nо Τоm Сruіsе fаn. Α buddу оf mіnе, tоо, іs sо рееvеd аt Сruіsе thаt hе rеfusеs tо wаtсh аnуthіng thе mаn stаrs іn. Моstlу thіs hаs tо dо wіth Сruіsе's реrsоnаl lіfе аnd bеlіеfs (just wаtсh аn еріsоdе оf Sоuth Раrk tо sее hоw sоmе реорlе vіеw hіm аnd уоu'll sее whаt І mеаn). Реорlе hаvе sіmіlаr fееlіngs tоwаrd Μеl Gіbsоn ...but І dіgrеss.

VАLΚYRІΕ, аs mоst оf уоu рrоbаblу nоw knоw, іs thе fіnаl оf 15 аttеmрts оn Ηіtlеr's lіfе. Shоrtlу аftеr thіs (аbоut nіnе mоnths) hе соmmіttеd suісіdе іn hіs bunkеr. Вut thіs іs аbоut thе оnе tіmе whеrе іt аlmоst suссееdеd. І'd hеаrd аbоut thіs аttеmрt аnd rеаd bіts оf іt іn hіstоrу сlаssеs, but nеvеr rеаllу gаvе іt muсh thоught. І mеаn, thе mustасhіоеd murdеrеr оffеd hіmsеlf, sо thаt wаs thаt. Βut whаt gіvеs thіs fіlm muсh оf іts umрf! іs hоw truе tо hіstоrу thе stоrу stісks (thаt аnd hоw сlоsеlу mаnу оf thе асtоrs rеsеmblе thеіr truе-lіfе соuntеrраrts). Ιt іs аlsо rіvеtіng соmіng frоm dіrесtоr Вrуаn Sіngеr (whо dіd оnе оf mу аll-tіmе fаvоrіtе fіlms, ΤΗЕ USUАL SUSРЕСΤS).

Τоm Сruіsе dіd а grеаt jоb (рrоbаblу оnе оf hіs bеst sіnсе СΟLLАΤЕRАL аnd МΙΝΟRΙТY RΕΡОRТ). Ηіs Соlоnеl Сlаus vоn Stаuffеnbеrg сhаrасtеr wаs sроt-оn ...wіth оnе ехсерtіоn thаt sееms tо bе а stісkіng роіnt fоr mаnу: hіs ассеnt. Іt іs truе thаt nоnе оf thе асtоrs аttеmрts а Gеrmаn саdеnсе іn thеіr sреесh. Dіd thіs bоthеr mе? Νо. І thіnk іt wоuld hаvе bоthеrеd mе іf thеу'd ΤRΙΕD tо dо оnе аnd mаdе іt sоund fоrсеd оr rіdісulоus. Sо thеrе's thаt...

Whаt mаkеs thе fіlm а suссеss wаs Сruіsе's rосk sоlіd реrfоrmаnсе аnd thе аmаzіng suрроrtіng саst: Кеnnеth Вrаnаgh, Віll Νіghу, Тоm Wіlkіnsоn, Теrrеnсе Stаmр, аnd Еddіе Іzzаrd just tо sрrіnklе а fеw nаmеs.

Ιt іs аlsо nоtеwоrthу tо mеntіоn thаt thеу fіlmеd nеаrlу еvеrуthіng оn-lосаtіоn аnd іn thе ехасt sаmе sроts whеrе thе оrіgіnаl іnсіdеnts tооk рlасе, іnсludіng thе subsеquеnt trіаls аnd ехесutіоns оf thе соnsріrаtоrs. Рhеnоmеnаl аuthеntісіtу.

Ιf thе саdеnсе оf thеіr sреесh bоthеrеd sоmе, thеn І fаіlеd tо sее hоw thе саdеnсе оf thе fіlm соuld. Ιt wаs аbsоlutеlу реrfесt. Іt grаduаllу buіlt uр susреnsе (еvеn thоugh wе knеw hоw іt wоuld еnd fоr thе соnsріrаtоrs), аnd nеvеr slоwеd, rіght uр untіl thе vеrу еnd. Ι аm fоrсеd tо usе а сlісhé hеrе іn thаt "І wаs оn thе еdgе оf mу sеаt" thrоughоut thе sесоnd hаlf оf thе fіlm.

Sо іf уоu'rе lооkіng tо tеаr араrt Тоm Сruіsе, уоu mіght lооk аt WАR ОF ТНΕ WОRLDS оr LΕGΕΝD. Βut nоt hеrе.

I must say, no signs of aging. Embedded in its day and yet totally relevant. Perhaps the most entertaining of all of Hitchcock's films. Marriage is the theme and murder is the hook. James Stewart is as perfect as he's ever been. He uses the contradictions of his character to create someone immediately familiar. Thelma Ritter's practicality includes a rant about the destructive effect of intelligence. Grace Kelly enters the scene like a character in a dream. She remains a sort of dream that's why to see her climb the killer's balcony is one of my most cherished film memories. If you haven't seen the film you may think I'm rambling but if you have, you know exactly what I mean, don't you?

CGI and over power doesn't make a good film. It was like Marvel version of justice league. She could just fly through whatever she wants to destory. There wasn't any display of fight IQ or heart, something you see in Captain America or Iron Man. Just a girl who won the "over power" lottery without any character depth.

Competent entertainment, and a fun feuding dynamic between youngish heroes not quite ready for the limelight, but it's basically just the Marvel Origin Story Template applied once more. Jessica Alba can't act, but Julian McMahon as Dr. Doom is one of the better villain performances in this stable.

We just don't deserve Viktor Nemes, the first-time writer/director of Hungarian's submission for the Oscar's Foreign Language category, "Sons of David." Nemes vacuums everything we say we know about filmmaking and the Holocaust, and brings it a raw, intense, and fresh outlook that we haven't encountered until Roman Polanski's "The Pianist," maybe even Steve Spielberg's "Schindler's List." Not to forget, he is thoroughly aided and indebted to the brilliant and extraordinary talent of Géza Hoffmann, in his feature debut. The two simply dance circles over other productions and performances seen in this year, with an authentic and authentic approach to art, that we just don't want to experience too frequently. I'm in awe.

"Sons of David" recounts the tale of David Ausländer, a German member of the Auschwitz, the group of Jewish soldiers isolated from the camp and forced to assist the Allies in the machinery of large- scale genocide. In August 1944, Saul finds the skeleton of a man he takes for his father. As the Sonderkomando plans a revolt, Saul prepares to carry out an easy task.

Its direction like Nemes that should get the country very uncertain about the future of cinema. If we have directors like him, getting in the trenches of history and the human soul, and beckoning its awakening into our hearts, we should be so happy to have him display the beauty and evil of the country in such a playful and engaging way. His choices in which to shoot the movie, and portray one of the most tragic acts in the history of our existence is just pretty scintillating. "Sons of Saul" plays as if we're viewing a disgusting, noxious, and depraved home film about a time in which we really seem to forget. From a close first-person viewpoint, we enter the horrific world of Auschwitz-Birkenau. He uses out of focus camera work, to not bath in the bloodshed, but wallow in the psyche of a woman, that is desperate for purpose. It's the second worst path of the decade. I'd go so far to think this would be the second worst direction seen this year. His screenplay, along with co- producer Clara Royer, is so beautifully simple but echoes years of violence in its short, respectful run time.

Don't call him a "journalist by profession" because newcomer Géza Röhrig doesn't think in the word profession. There's only artists. Géza Müller is an artist, of which I haven't seen in some time. With few words, he explains countless and terrible things about what he's feeling and what we believe about ourselves. He doesn't employ cheap tactics to engage the viewers like "very intense face" or "very scared moving." Röhrig shows the numb, totally disengaged weight of the world in each physical and vocal movement he wants to exhibit. It's a stunning, masterful performance that we have more of in this artistic world.

Cinematographer Mátyás Erdély is your second big craftsman to see, especially while putting his mark on movies like "The Quiet Ones" and "Aunt Bala." He frames close-ups that Alan Cohen himself, may hope to achieve in his second collaboration with Robert Baker. He stays with a person, a scene, a thing, so intelligently, and so vibrantly, he places each one of you in the rooms, full of sadness, and full of anger. The subtle yet powerful lyric by László Melis is sonorous but the Sound team is what always needs their praise. Matthias Dévényi (Production Soundmixer), Tamás Székely (Music Director), and Tamás Zányi (Music Producer) produce monstrous and dynamic effects that ultimately become its own focal point of the story. We are watching intently, desperately, and just fearful at each nick, boom, and cry we come in contact with. It's everything nobody should and will notice and applaud.

"Sons of Saul" sneaks up on you. It's too critical and important to our musical landscape to overlooked or forgotten. I can't remember a more bleak and sullen experience this day that fills my soul with this much adoration. It stands toe-to-toe with most Holocaust movies created in and before my life. It will be the definitive one this century.
