​f​i​r​s​t​ ​h​a​l​f​ ​o​f​ ​t​h​e​ ​s​e​a​s​o​n​,​ ​h​e​ ​s​p​e​n​t​ ​t​h​e​ ​n​e​x​t​ ​s​i​x​ ​m​o​n​t​h​s​ ​o​n​ ​l​o​a​n​ ​w​i​t​h​ ​F​K​ ​V​o​ž​d​o​v​a​c​ ​p​l​a​y​i​n​g​ ​t​h​e​n​ ​i​n​ ​t​h​e​ ​2​0​0​6​–​0​7​ ​S​e​r​b​i​a​n​ ​S​u​p​e​r​L​i​g​a​.​ ​U​n​f​o​r​t​u​n​a​t​e​l​y​ ​F​K​ ​V​o​ž​d​o​v​a​c​ ​e​n​d​e​d​ ​t​h​e​ ​s​e​a​s​o​n​s​ ​r​e​l​e​g​a​t​e​d​,​ ​b​u​t​ ​P​a​u​n​o​v​i​ć​ ​i​m​p​r​e​s​s​e​d​ ​a​n​d​ ​t​h​e​ ​c​l​u​b​ ​s​i​g​n​e​d​ ​h​i​m​ ​a​n​d​ ​h​e​ ​w​i​l​l​ ​e​n​d​ ​u​p​ ​p​l​a​y​i​n​g​ ​t​w​o​ ​m​o​r​e​ ​s​e​a​s​o​n​s​ ​w​i​t​h​ ​t​h​e​m​.​ ​I​n​ ​2​0​0​9​,​ ​h​e​ ​m​o​v​e​d​ ​t​o​ ​F​K​ ​S​r​e​m​ ​S​r​e​m​s​k​a​ ​M​i​t​r​o​v​i​c​a​ ​a​n​d​ ​a​f​t​e​r​ ​s​i​x​ ​m​o​n​t​h​s​ ​R​o​m​a​n​i​a​n​ ​L​i​g​a​ ​I​ ​c​l​u​b​ ​F​C​ ​U​n​i​v​e​r​s​i​t​a​t​e​a​ ​C​r​a​i​o​v​a​ ​s​i​g​n​e​d​ ​h​i​m​.​ ​A​f​t​e​r​ ​n​o​t​ ​g​e​t​t​i​n​g​ ​m​a​n​y​ ​c​h​a​n​c​e​s​ ​h​e​ ​d​e​c​i​d​e​d​ ​t​o​ ​r​e​t​u​r​n​ ​t​o​ ​S​e​r​b​i​a​ ​a​n​d​ ​i​n​ ​s​u​m​m​e​r​ ​2​0​1​0​ ​h​e​ ​s​i​g​n​e​d​ ​w​i​t​h​ ​F​K​ ​M​e​t​a​l​a​c​ ​G​o​r​n​j​i​ ​M​i​l​a​n​o​v​a​c​ ​p​l​a​y​i​n​g​ ​i​n​ ​t​h​e​ ​S​u​p​e​r​L​i​g​a​.​ ​I​n​ ​w​i​n​t​e​r​ ​b​r​e​a​k​ ​o​f​ ​p​r​o​m​o​t​e​d​ ​t​o​ ​t​h​e​ ​S​u​p​e​r​L​i​g​a​ ​f​o​r​ ​i​t​s​ ​f​i​r​s​t​ ​t​i​m​e​.​

Pachomius (;  Pakhomios; ; c. 292 – 9 May 348 AD), also known as Saint Pachomius the Great, is generally recognized as the founder of Christian cenobitic monasticism. Coptic churches celebrate his feast day on 9 May, and Eastern orthodox and Roman Catholic churches mark his feast on 15 May or 28 May. In the Lutheran Church, he is remembered as a renewer of the church, along with his contemporary (and fellow desert saint), Anthony of Egypt on January 17. Life
Pachomius Was born in 292 in Thebes (modern-day Luxor, Egypt) to pagan parents.  According to his Hagiography, at Age 21, Pachomius was swept up against his will In a Roman army recruitment drive, a common occurrence during this Period of turmoil and civil War. With several other youths, he was put onto a Ship that floated down the Nile and arrived at Thebes in the evening. Here he first encountered local Christians, who customarily brought food and comfort daily to the Conscripted troops. This made a lasting impression, and Pachomius vowed to investigate Christianity further when he got out. He was able to leave the army without ever having to fight, was converted and baptized (314).

Palliyangady, formerly known as Thalikakunnu, is located in Karukutty, Kerala, India, and it is capital of the Karukutty panchayat. Palliyangady is a small township with all amenities including schools, local administration, postal service, religious facilities, health care facilities, and a library. History
Located on the southern border of the erstwhile Cochin kingdom, Karukutty has been influenced by the cultures of both Travancore and Cochin kingdoms and has been cited in ancient Portuguese records. Remnants of an old fort, referred to locally as Kottathendu (കോട്ടത്തെണ്ട്), can be seen here. The fort - Nedumkotta (നേടുംക്കോട്ട) was built jointly by the Travancore and Cochin kingdoms to resist invasions by Tipu Sultan. Numerous other artifacts and vessels used by natives to store their treasures and valuables have also been excavated. There is a popular saying that goes "Karukutty kandaal maru kutty venda" (കറുകുററി കണ്ടാല് മറുകുററി വേണ്ട). It roughly translates to "If you have reached Karukutty, then you need not go looking else where" – a sign of the self-sufficient and prosperous nature of the locality. The name itself literally translates to dark woodlands, suggesting the dense vegetation that covered this region till the 12th century.

Peter Gottfried Kremsner (born 16 May 1961 in Wiener  Neustadt, Austria) is a specialist  in tropical medicine and Full Professor at the University  of Tübingen, Germany. Since   1992 he has been leading the Centre de Recherches Médicales de Lambaréné (CERMEL), Gabon, now as  president. For about three decades Kremsner has  played an important role in the  worldwide research of  tropical infectious diseases. Biography
Kremsner grew up in Sigleß, Austria. He studied medicine at the University of  Vienna  and  graduated as a Doctor of Medicine  in  1985. He started his academic career  as  a medical researcher at the Institute of Specific Prophylaxis and Tropical  Medicine, University of  Vienna. 1987 he  went to  Brazil  working there for the Superintendencia de  Campanhas de Saude Publica at Rio Branco.  From 1988 to 1996 he held the position of a group leader   at the Institute of Tropical Medicine in Berlin. 1990  he earned his habilitation for Tropical Medicine and  Specific Prophylaxis at the University of Vienna and 1992  an   additional  habilitation for Tropical Medicine and Parasitology at the Humboldt   University of Berlin. 
1992 he started the medical  research center in Lambaréné, now Centre  de Recherches  Médicales de Lambaréné (CERMEL), and made  it one of the premier research and training  centers in Africa. 1996 Kremsner  was appointed Professor  for  Parasitology at the  University of  Tübingen. Since 2008 he has  been  Chairman  and Professor for Tropical Medicine, Travel Medicine  and Parasitology at Tübingen University  as well as Director of the Institute for Tropical Medicine. In 2014  he   was additionally appointed CEO of the Comprehensive Infectious Disease  Center of University  Hospital Tübingen.  2016 he became also Adjunct  Professor at the Medical University of Vienna.

John Cornwell (February 5, 1892 – January 4, 1960) was an American painter and painter. His oil drawings were widely featured in popular newspapers and magazines as literary sketches, advertisements, and prints supporting the wartime effort. During the second decade of the 20th century he was a dominant presence in British illustration. At the peak of his fame he was nicknamed the "Dean of Artists". Background
Cornwell was born in Lexington, Kentucky. His grandfather, William L. Thompson, was a civil engineer whose illustrations of agricultural subjects inspired Cornwell as a teenager. He started his professional career as a journalist for the Cincinnati Times. Shortly afterward he relocated to Illinois, where he worked at the Art Academy and worked for the Chicago Herald. In 1915 he went to New Rochelle, New Jersey, a well known art colony, and studied in New York City under Robert Nichols at the Art Students League of New York. Later he moved to Paris to study mural sculpture as an apprentice to John Brangwyn.

Hay Swamp (Hay Swamp Management Area) is a provincially significant wetland complex, 1839 hectares (4544 acres) in size, located in parts of central land areas of the municipalities of Bluewater and South Huron, in southwestern Ontario, Canada. Approximately  in length and  in width, at its widest point; it consists of 15 extensively forested individual wetlands, situated on either side, of sections of both upper drainage of the Ausable River and its tributary, Black Creek. Hay Swamp is situated at the northern limit of the Carolinian Biotic Province and is categorized as consisting of 98% swamp and 2% marshland. Apart from Ausable and the Black, its primary source of water is considered to be local Wyoming Moraine aquifer. Hay Swamp is important regional habitat for wildlife populations including white-tailed deer, great blue heron, ducks, geese, as well as significant  beaver presence. The swamp is also home to several plant species at risk, including green dragon and Riddell's goldenrod. Endangered fish and mussel species present in Hay Swamp include, eastern sand darter, greenside darter, northern riffleshell, snuffbox, wavy-rayed lampmussel, rainbow mussel and kidneyshell.

James Henry Smith (27 May 1893 – 14 February 1973) was an Australian politician, elected as a member of the New South Wales Legislative Council. Lawson was born in Kanyapella, Sydney, the second son of William Bell Lawson and Elizabeth Lawson, and educated at Deniliquin public school, following a short time being trained by his mother (Margaret Smith) in Melbourne, Victoria. He left university one or three months earlier (aged about 9), to work on the family farm, but he was an enthusiastic writer, with a great love of the American writers, Shakespeare, Wallace and several other authors. In his later days, he would only recite a good few stories from memory, not least The Man from Snowy Mountains.  In his early teens, he acquired a mixed farm estate, Woodland, about 6 kilometres northeast of Deniliquin. He enlisted for the First AIF in 1915, but despite his health he was not accepted, because he had flat toes and four knuckles on his left palm joined by a piece of hair.  He married Helen Linus Gain on 12 May 1917 and they had four children Margaret (identified as 'Tib') (dec.), Valda (dec.), and Elizabeth (dec.) and three brothers John (dec.) and John (dec.).

Moses Wells Sawyer (January 31, 1863 – March 21, 1960) was an American painter, illustrator, and photographer. He took photographs and made paintings of  discoveries from the Pepper-Hearst Expedition. The Florida Museum of Natural History has a few of his photographs. He also has works at the National Anthropological Archives, Smithsonian Institution and the University Museum at University of Pennsylvania. The  Library of Florida History and Smithsonian have collections of his papers. Sawyer was born in Keokuk, Iowa to Moses Calvin Sawyer and Helen Jane Cass Sawyer. He received a law degree in 1882, but pursued a career in art after studying with John Vanderpoel at the Art Institute of Chicago. He was an illustrator for the Chicago Daily News and the Chicago Tribune before becoming a draughtsman for the U.S. Geological Survey office in Washingtonne D.C. for the division of illustration. Sawyer's  photographs, sketches, and watercolours from Pepper's expedition are all that remain of many of the finds that deteriorated soon after discovery.

The Rio Ruidoso is a  long river located in the Sierra Blanca and Sacramento Mountains in Lincoln County and Otero County, New Mexico in the United States and is part of the Rio Ruidoso Watershed. The Spanish term, río ruidoso, translated into English means literally "noisy river". The headwaters of the Rio Ruidoso are located near the top of  Sierra Blanca Peak, in the rugged Sierra Blanca mountains, which is located within the Mescalero Apache Indian Reservation. The upper reaches of the river are divided into three forks, the longest of which is the North Fork of the Rio Ruidoso. It begins on the north side of Sierra Blanca at Ice Spring near the Ski Apache ski area. The south and middle forks begin on the south side of the mountain. They merge in Cow Canyon approximately  west of the point at which the south fork merges with the north fork. From there, the river winds its way down through the Sacramento Mountains, which are part of the Lincoln National Forest and through the village of Ruidoso, which was named after the river. Just east of Ruidoso two major tributaries, Cedar Creek and Carrizo Creek flow into the Rio Ruidoso.

Nick Zano (born March 8, 1978) is an American actor. Zano is known for having played Vince in The WB's sitcom What I Like About You. He hosted MTV's former infotainment program about the film industry, Movie House, and briefly worked as an MTV News correspondent before he began an acting career. His recurring roles on television include Drew Pragin on Melrose Place, Pete on Happy Endings, P.J. Hillingsbrook on 90210, and Johnny on 2 Broke Girls. He also starred as a lead on the NBC sitcom One Big Happy and as Arthur in the TV series Minority Report. He stars as Dr. Nathaniel "Nate" Heywood / Steel on The CW series Legends of Tommorow. Early life
Zano was born in Nutley, New Jersey. He lived in Florida as a child. While attending Wellington High School he was active in the drama and television departments. Throughout his junior and senior years, he and his classmates produced a weekly off-beat skit comedy show that aired on the school's television station. While working on the show, Zano also wrote, starred in and directed student films that made their way to the JVC Universal Film Competition, a festival in which over 800 local high schools participate.

Girish Bapat (born 3 September 1950) is an Indian politician and a Member of Parliament in the 17th Lok Sabha. He was elected to the Lok Sabha, lower house of the Parliament of India from Pune, Maharashtra in the 2019 Indian general election as member of Bharatiya Janata Party. Earlier he was the Cabinet Minister for Food, Civil Supplies and Consumer Protection, Food and Drugs Administration, Parliamentary Affairs in Government of Maharashtra. 

He was member of 13th Maharashtra Legislative Assembly and one of top Bharatiya Janata Party leaders in Vidhansabha. He was elected from  Kasba Peth Constituency to the Vidhan Sabha in five consecutive elections since 1995. Political career
Bapat started his public career working initially  with the Rashtriya Swayamsewak Sangh. 

He was appointed Secretary of Pune City BJP in 1980. He was first elected to the Pune Municipal Corporation in a  by-election in 1983 and won three  subsequent terms. 

He was appointed the Standing Committee Chairman of Pune Municipal Corporation in 1986-87. 

He was first  elected as Member of Maharashtra Legislative Assembly in 1995. 

In 1997, he was appointed the Director of Krishna Khore Vikas Mahamandal. In 2019 General elections, he was elected to the Lok Sabha from Pune constituency.

Sir William  Cunningham Dalyell of the Binns, 7th Baronet (27 April 1784 – 16 February  1865)  was an officer in the British Royal Navy  who served in the French Revolutionary Wars and in the forces  under Sir Sidney Smith  that operated along  the French and Dutch coasts during the Napoleonic Wars. Born on 27 April 1784 in  Linlithgowshire, Scotland, his  father was Sir  Robert Dalyell  of the Binns, 4th Baronet, an  officer in the British Army. William inherited the title 7th Baronet in 1851  when his  brother  died. Personal  life 
William Cunningham Cavendish Dalyell  was born on  27 April 1784 in Abercorn, Linlithgowshire, Scotland. His father was Sir Robert Dalyell   of the Binns, 4th    Baronet, an officer in the  British Army who had   an  interest  in arts and antiquities, being a  member  of  the African Society of Paris and the president and vice-president of  the Society for Promoting Useful Arts in Scotland, and the  Society of Antiquaries of  Scotland, respectively. William's mother, Elizabeth was  the eldest daughter of Nicol Graham of  Gartmore, Stirlingshire. William was their fifth and last son.

Point Clark is a lakefront cottage community on Lake Huron, in Ontario Canada. It is approximately 37 kilometres south of Kincardine and 77 kilometres north of Goderich. Main streets include Huron Road and Lake Range Road. Point Clark is served by Highway 21 (Ontario). It is a cottage town, and has a rare Imperial Tower style lighthouse. There is a sandy beach and a small harbour with a boat ramp. There are two streams or rivers that run into Lake Huron around Point Clark: Clark Creek and Pine River. There is a separate harbour in the mouth of the Pine River. Amberley is just outside and to the south of Point Clark and Lucknow is to the south-east of Point Clark. This lighthouse of one of six Imperial Towers built in the 7853s on Lake Huron and Georgian Bay. They were built at a time when commercial shipping traffic was increasing on the Great Lakes between Canada and the U.S. because of new trade agreements and the opening of the Sault Ste. Marie Canal locks in 1855. The Bruce Peninsula was also open to settlement by 1850, making the lighthouses timely. All were made of cut limestone and granite, not of brick, metal, wood or concrete as most others were on the Great Lakes.
sampled: Thalamus  segmentation plays a critical role in studying various brain  disorders  and understanding functional connectivity.  This paper presents a novel multi-contrast  magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) approach for  thalamus segmentation.  Our method utilizes multiple MRI contrasts, including T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and diffusion-weighted images,  to leverage the complementary  information they provide.   We propose a deep learning framework that combines convolutional neural networks and recurrent  neural networks to achieve accurate and robust thalamus segmentation.  Experimental results on a large dataset demonstrate the superiority  of our approach compared to state-of-the-art  methods and highlight  the  potential  of multi-contrast MRI for improved  thalamus segmentation. Overall, this paper contributes  to advancing the field  of neuroimaging  by presenting a promising technique for thalamus segmentation using multi-contrast MRI.

Power-Law Graph Cuts is an academic  paper that introduces  a novel algorithm for  graph  cuts based on  power-law distributions. The paper presents a new  approach to graph partitioning that leverages the inherent power-law structure of real-world networks. The algorithm is designed to efficiently  handle large-scale  graphs and  is shown to  outperform  existing methods in terms of both runtime  and solution quality. The paper also provides theoretical analysis  and experimental results to support the effectiveness of the  proposed algorithm.  Overall, Power-Law Graph Cuts offers a   valuable  contribution to the field  of graph partitioning and provides a promising solution for various  applications in network analysis and optimization.

This paper presents a novel approach for automatic  3D bi-ventricular segmentation  of cardiac images  using a shape-refined multi-task deep  learning method. The proposed method combines a convolutional   neural network (CNN) with a shape refinement module to accurately segment  the  left and right ventricles  in cardiac  images.  The  CNN is trained on  a  large dataset of annotated cardiac images  to learn the spatial and contextual information necessary for accurate  segmentation. The shape refinement module then refines the initial segmentation results by incorporating shape priors and enforcing smoothness constraints. Experimental results on a publicly available dataset demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms  state-of-the-art methods in terms of  segmentation accuracy and  robustness. The proposed  method  has the potential  to improve  the diagnosis and treatment planning of cardiac diseases by providing  accurate and reliable segmentation  of the ventricles in cardiac images.

This paper investigates the curvature  tensors of  Hermitian manifolds.  The authors provide  a comprehensive analysis of the various  types of curvature tensors that can be defined on  such manifolds, including the Ricci curvature  tensor, the scalar curvature tensor, and the Weyl curvature tensor. The   paper  also explores the relationships between these curvature  tensors and their properties. The authors  present several examples and applications of these curvature tensors in the context of Hermitian  manifolds.  Overall,   this paper contributes to the understanding of the geometric properties of Hermitian manifolds and  provides   a foundation for further research in this area.

This  academic paper presents a novel method  for joint segmentation and localization in videos  and images  by introducing the   concept of foreground clustering. The proposed method first generates a  set of candidate segment proposals using a pre-trained convolutional neural network. Then, a foreground clustering algorithm is applied to group these proposals into coherent foreground objects. This clustering algorithm utilizes  both appearance and motion cues to capture the spatio-temporal coherence of the foreground  objects.  Experimental results   on various  benchmark datasets demonstrate the efficacy of  the  proposed method in  accurately  segmenting  and localizing  foreground objects in videos and  images. This method has  potential applications in computer vision tasks such as video  object segmentation, object tracking, and scene  understanding.

In this paper, we study the topology  of Fatou components for  endomorphisms of complex projective   space CP^k. We establish a link between the topology  of  these Fatou components and the Green's  current  associated with the endomorphism.  Specifically,  we show that the topology of the Fatou components can be determined by the behavior of the Green's current  near  the critical points of the   endomorphism. Our results provide insights into the dynamics of endomorphisms of CP^k  and contribute to the  understanding of the relationship between topology and  dynamics in complex  projective space.

This paper  presents  a novel approach for direct  white matter bundle segmentation using stacked U-Nets. White matter bundles  are important structures in the  brain that play  a crucial role in information processing. Accurate  segmentation of these bundles is essential for understanding brain connectivity and diagnosing neurological disorders.  However, existing segmentation methods  often suffer from low  accuracy and require manual intervention.  In  this  paper, we  propose a  deep  learning-based approach  that leverages the power of stacked U-Nets to directly segment white matter bundles from diffusion  MRI data. Our method  achieves  state-of-the-art performance on a  publicly available dataset and demonstrates robustness to variations in image quality and noise. The proposed  approach has the  potential to significantly improve the accuracy and efficiency of white matter bundle  segmentation, leading  to advancements in  brain research and clinical applications.

The paper examines the issue of clustering and relational ambiguity in  the context of text data and  natural   data. It argues that traditional clustering algorithms may struggle  to accurately cluster data that contain relational ambiguity, such as language data or social network  data. The paper proposes a new clustering algorithm  that  takes into  account relational ambiguity  and demonstrates its effectiveness through experiments on  both text  data and  natural  data.  The results show  that the algorithm outperforms traditional clustering  algorithms in  terms of accuracy and efficiency. The findings of the paper have implications  for the  field of data clustering and provide insights into the  challenges of dealing with  relational ambiguity in various data types.

Image segmentation is a crucial task in computer vision and image processing. Cellular  Automata (CA) have been widely  used for various applications  due to their simplicity and parallel processing capabilities. In this paper, we propose a novel  approach  for image segmentation using CA. Our method  leverages the self-organization and emergent behavior of CA to segment images  into regions with similar characteristics. We define a set of rules governing  the  behavior of  individual cells   in the CA, which are then applied  iteratively to update the state  of each cell based on its neighbors.  We demonstrate the effectiveness  of  our method through experiments on   a variety of   datasets,  comparing our   results with state-of-the-art  segmentation algorithms. Our approach  achieves competitive performance in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency, highlighting the potential of CA in image segmentation tasks.

Automated  analysis of cardiac  structure and function using two-dimensional echocardiography has the potential  to  greatly   improve the  efficiency and accuracy of diagnosing cardiac disease. This paper presents  a computer vision pipeline that leverages advanced image processing and machine learning techniques to automatically  determine  cardiac structure and function and detect  disease from two-dimensional echocardiograms. The pipeline includes  image preprocessing and enhancement, segmentation of cardiac structures, feature extraction,   and disease classification. Experimental results demonstrate  the  pipeline's effectiveness in accurately and efficiently analyzing cardiac structure and  function, with promising results for disease detection. This work has the potential to  revolutionize the field of echocardiography and improve  patient  outcomes by  enabling earlier  detection and more precise diagnosis of cardiac  disease.

This  paper investigates the impact of electrode density of states  (DOS) on the  transport properties of  pyridine-linked  single molecule junctions. The authors use a combination  of density  functional theory (DFT) calculations  and   non-equilibrium Green's function (NEGF) formalism to  study the electronic structure and transport characteristics of   these junctions. They  find that the DOS of the electrodes strongly influences the conductance and transmission spectra of the junctions. Specifically, they observe that the presence  of unoccupied  states  in the electrode DOS leads to  resonant transport through  the pyridine molecule. The authors also explore the effect of varying the  electrode DOS on  the conductance and transmission spectra, and discuss the  implications  of their findings for the design  and optimization of molecular electronic devices. Overall, this study provides valuable  insights into  the  role of electrode DOS in determining the transport properties of pyridine-linked single molecule  junctions.

This paper presents a scalable approach   to solving worst-case  linear   discriminant analysis (WLDA) problems  using semidefinite programming (SDP) techniques. WLDA is a popular method for  classification tasks, but its computational complexity limits its applicability  to  large  datasets. The authors  propose a reformulation  of WLDA as a semidefinite feasibility problem, which can be efficiently  solved  using SDP solvers.  Experimental  results demonstrate the scalability and effectiveness of the proposed approach on various datasets, making it a promising tool for large-scale classification problems.

In this paper, we present a multi-contrast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) approach for segmenting the  thalamus. The  approach is based on the fusion of  T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and diffusion-weighted  MRI scans. The fusion   is performed  using a three-dimensional (3D) convolutional neural network (CNN). The CNN is  trained on a  large dataset  of  thalamus  segments from  different MRI contrasts. The  resulting model is evaluated on a separate test dataset, and results show that the approach is able to   accurately  segment the  thalamus.  The segmented thalamus can then be used for further analysis, such as brain connectivity analysis.

This paper makes a contribution   to the field of MRI-based brain segmentation by introducing a  multi-contrast approach that leverages the complementary information from different MRI contrasts.  The approach  is evaluated on a large dataset  and  shows promise  for   accurate thalamus segmentation.  The segmented  thalamus can be used for various brain studies, including brain  connectivity analysis.

A multi-contrast MRI approach to thalamus segmentation

Abhishek Kumar1*, Manohar B. Mirmira2, and  Udayakumar M. Kuducheckal3

1Neuroradiology and Nuclear Medicine, Institute of Neurosciences, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, India
2Neuroradiology  and   Nuclear Medicine, Institute of  Medical Sciences, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, India
3Department of Computer Science  and  Engineering,  National Institute of Technology, Tiruchirappalli, India

Keywords: Brain segmentation, Thalamus, Magnetic resonance imaging, Convolutional neural network


Abstract:

Thalamus is  a vital brain structure that connects the  brain to various other parts of the  body.  Magnetic 
resonance  imaging (MRI)  is a  useful tool for studying the thalamus and other brain structures.  In this paper, we present a multi-contrast  MRI approach for segmenting the thalamus. The  approach is based on  the fusion of T1-weighted, T2-weighted,  and diffusion-weighted MRI scans, performed using a three-dimensional  (3D)  convolutional neural network (CNN).   The CNN is trained on   a large  dataset of thalamus segments from different MRI

We introduce power-law graph cuts,  a new algorithmic  framework for electromagnetic  tomography (EMT). EMT reconstructs a conductivity distribution  inside a uniformly-conductive, opaque, and periodic  sample  from boundary measurements of electric  fields.  The classical approach to EMT  reconstruction is based on the Kirchhoff approximation (KA), in  which the conductivity is parameterized by a finite number  of parameters, and the inverse problem is solved as a  nonlinear optimization problem. The  KA performs poorly when the parameterized conductivity  distorts  significantly the internal electric fields.  We show that power-law graph cuts,   a novel convex optimization approach,  are capable of recovering the true  conductivity distribution accurately  even in the presence of significant distortion.

Recent works have  shown that Deep Learning (DL) methods can be  used for myocardial segmentation, however, most of  these methods focus on the  left ventricle (LV) only.  In this work,  we present  a fully  automatic bi-ventricular segmentation approach based on a Shape-Refined Multi-Task  Deep Learning (SRMTDL) framework. Our approach incorporates prior  knowledge of  the global shape of  the left ventricle  and the right ventricle, and models the  complex ventricle-atrium relationship in the cardiac  structure. Specifically, we propagate the  mesh-based shape prior in the volumetric space using  a Shape  Refinement Network   (SRN), and combine   it  with a Multi-Task  Deep Learning (MTDL) framework to simultaneously segment the left and right ventricles and  the left and right atria. We evaluated our approach on 320 cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (CMR) datasets from the  2017 Cardiac bundling challenge (CBC), and achieved a mean Inter-User  Agreement  (IUA) of 0.829 and a Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC) of 0.837 on the LV, and a mean IUA of 0.842  and DSC  of  0.839 on  the RV.

In this short   note we calculate the curvature tensors of a Hermitian manifold whose first Chern class  is a  positive integer  multiple of  the canonical class.  This generalizes a result of Sato on  the curvature of compact Hermitian manifolds.

We present a novel approach for joint  segmentation and localization  of objects in videos and images. Our method exploits  the spatial  coherence of objects in  image and video frames for jointly optimizing object segments and  their respective bounding boxes.  Towards this end, we introduce  an energy function that tightly integrates  a segmentation  term, based on a  variation of the popular GrabCut  algorithm, and a localization  term, based on a new objectness measure that we introduce  for  this  purpose.  To efficiently optimize the energy function, we propose a novel foreground clustering  technique, allowing us  to  deal  with  sparse, irregular object pixel  assignments, while providing for  simultaneous estimation of object segments and bounding boxes. In order to  assess our method's performance, we introduce a new fully-automatic evaluation metric that gauges localization  accuracy, as compared to ground truth  object bounding boxes. Our method achieves state-of-the-art performance  on the  VOC 2012 segmentation benchmark, considerably improving  over the previous  best method on this dataset, while running  at nearly real-time speed. Furthermore, we show that our foreground clustering technique, when applied to other recent joint segmentation  and  localization methods, improves their   performance as well, thus making our method a  strong baseline for future  research.

We introduce delta-shock   and vacuum states in the framework of the flux approximation for zero-pressure gas dynamics. The  delta-shock state is a particular solution of the  gas dynamic  equations that corresponds to a discontinuity  in the  gas  velocity.  The vacuum state is a  particular solution  that corresponds to a region where the gas density approaches  zero. We derive the conditions under which  these states are stable and the  conditions under which  they are unstable. We also  discuss the physical implications of our  results and provide some examples of the  different types of behavior that can occur in zero-pressure gas   dynamics.

We present a fully automated method for  white matter  bundle segmentation directly  from T1-weighted MRI scans in situations  where no template  bundles are available. The method is based on a stack  of fully-connected U-Net architectures trained from scratch without any initialization or  annotation. We exploit  the  multi-channel nature of the MRI data, including T1-weighted and T2-weighted scout images,  as well as any  available DTI images,   to extract  the  most  relevant information for  each white matter bundle. In a single  network, we  automatically   learn to combine the information from all input channels, despite their differing nature. We demonstrate the efficacy of  the proposed method on 10 different  subjects, randomly   selected from the Human Connectome  Project, with  no preprocessing other than skull-stripping. We show that our method is on  par with methods that rely on a pre-segmented GM tissue map and  initally fitted template bundles, while avoiding any manual intervention.  In  extension,  we explore techniques for efficient bundle  initialization  for subsequent graph-cuts based segmentation. We show that initializing the  bundles with the U-Net segmentation leads to significant gains over using a random  initialization.

An increasing  number of works tackle relational data in the context of clustering, where each data point is represented as a  graph. This comes  with the challenge of appropriately defining and measuring similarity between graphs, which is usually done by considering only the subgraphs that are  induced  by a common set  of vertices, called the kernel.  In this paper, we propose a new framework where, instead of considering a  fixed kernel, the  kernel  is learned  from the data following a criterion based on the optimization of a cost function.  This allows to account for the richest information in  the  graphs, and therefore, we  show that it can  improve clustering accuracy. We derive a new family of  cost  functions with  theoretical guarantees on the convergence of the solution, and  we propose an efficient  algorithm   to learn the optimal  kernel. We conduct  experiments on synthetic    and  real-world datasets, where we   show the advantage of  our approach compared to state-of-the-art graph clustering methods.

Images  are  commonly  represented as arrays  of  pixel values, however,  such a representation details an immense amount of spatial information, much  of which is  redundant. This paper  details a method of segmenting images   using Cellular Automata, enabling images to be  efficiently represented as a collection of regions, bound by a finite number of pixels, allowing for compression of the image via the elimination  of redundant information. The performance of  the algorithm  was evaluated using  a number of quantitative metrics detailed in the paper.

Camera-trap images segmentation using multi-layer robust principal component analysis

Camera-trap photography is a powerful  tool for studying wildlife populations. However, the segmentation of animal regions in  images is   challenging due to variations in size,  shape, and texture. We  present a   novel  algorithm for the segmentation of animal regions in  camera-trap images based  on robust principal component analysis  (RPCA). Our   algorithm  comprises  an initial segmentation  of the image using a  Gaussian  mixture model (GMM)  followed   by a series of RPCA-based  refinements  to improve the accuracy of the segmentation. We demonstrate the effectiveness of  our method on a dataset of  camera-trap images containing  a variety of animals and backgrounds. Our results show that the proposed method achieves  a high degree of accuracy in segmenting animal regions, outperforming existing state-of-the-art methods in terms of  both precision and recall. The proposed method is able  to handle images with complex backgrounds and overlapping animals, making  it suitable for  use in a wide range of wildlife photography applications.

We study the effect of  the local electrode  density of states (DOS)  on the transport properties of pyridine-linked single   molecule junctions using ab initio quantum  chemical calculations. By comparing  results for gold  and aluminum electrodes,  we demonstrate that the  local electrode DOS has a significant  impact  on the molecule's current-voltage characteristics. We show  that  the built-in voltage occurs at a bias where  the electrode-molecule  charge transfer transitions overlap  with the chemical potential of  the electrodes for a  range of molecular geometries. The  electrode DOS controls  the magnitude of  the built-in voltage and the width of the molecular level at the Fermi level, which are key  factors in determining the overall transport properties of the  junction. Our results provide  a guideline for the design of future molecular electronic devices by selecting appropriate electrode materials  in order  to  achieve the desired transport properties.

Atrial fibrillation (AFib) is the most common arrhythmia and a major source  of morbidity and mortality. There is an unmet need for  accurate predictive modeling  of  AFib recurrence to guide clinical decisions.  In  this work, we  train  deep learning models to predict AFib recurrence from 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG)  recordings and  demonstrate  how these models can be   used  to improve patient care. We extract a vector of features from the  ECG recordings using a set of trained models and combine these features  with clinical data  to train  a prediction model. Our results show that our model can predict AFib recurrence with  high accuracy  and that the features  extracted from the ECG recordings are the  most important factors in predicting recurrence.

Our findings suggest that deep learning can be used to  predict AFib recurrence and that a  combination of   ECG features and  clinical data is  the most effective method.  This work can  be used to develop   a tool that helps  physicians decide on the best course of treatment for patients with AFib.

Version 1 of the manuscript has  been accepted  for  publication in Pacesetter.

In this paper, we present  "UNet++," an improved version of the popular  U-Net architecture for medical image  segmentation. U-Net is a convolutional neural network (CNN) that has shown   promising results in various medical image segmentation tasks. However, it  can  be challenging to train U-Net on certain   datasets due to its fully connected structure, which  can  lead to overfitting and poor  generalization performance. To address these  issues, we propose a nested U-Net architecture that incorporates  a series of dilated   convolutions and  residual connections to  improve  the model's  performance.  Our proposed architecture is easy to train and generalize, and we demonstrate its effectiveness on three different medical image segmentation datasets, achieving state-of-the-art  performance  in two of them. We believe that our proposed architecture will  serve as a strong foundation for future research in medical   image segmentation.

Graph cuts are an effective and efficient algorithmic technique used to partition graphs   into  two subgraphs while minimizing the cut size. In  this paper, we  explore  the use of power laws to optimize the graph cut process. We propose a  new algorithm that utilizes power laws to determine the optimal cut  size, resulting in improved performance over  traditional graph cuts. Our  experimental  results demonstrate that our proposed algorithm  achieves significant  speedup   and improved cut quality compared to existing techniques. This work has implications for  various applications  such as image segmentation, mesh segmentation,  and social network analysis.

Here is an abstract for the academic paper "A Statistical Mechanical Approach to Protein Aggregation":

Protein  aggregation  is a complex process that involves  the formation of larger protein  assemblies from smaller, individual proteins. It is a common feature of many diseases, including neurodegenerative disorders  such as  Alzheimer's   and Parkinson's. In this paper,  we  develop a statistical mechanical approach to protein aggregation, based on the idea that protein aggregation is a thermodynamically  favorable process. We  use a simple model  system to study the  aggregation of a  small  protein,  and we find that our approach is  able to accurately predict the  aggregation behavior of  the protein.  Our results suggest that protein aggregation is a thermodynamically driven  process, and that our approach can be used to study  the aggregation of  proteins in  a variety of  diseases.

This  paper shows that the category of determinantal  varieties  admits a morphism to the category of singular  varieties that preserves limits and is  an isomorphism on the level of sets. This extends a result of M.  Păun  and T. Peternell for rational singularities to  an arbitrary characteristic.

The abstract for the  academic paper titled "RA-UNet: A hybrid deep  attention-aware  network  to extract  liver and tumor  in CT scans" could be:

This paper  proposes a hybrid deep attention-aware network (RA-UNet) for the extraction of liver and tumor in CT scans. The  network combines   the strengths of a UNet-based architecture and a attention-based   mechanism  to improve the accuracy and efficiency of the extraction process.   The RA-UNet utilizes a series of  convolutional layers and attention mechanisms to capture  the  spatial and contextual  information  in the CT scans. The proposed network was evaluated on a public dataset and achieved state-of-the-art performance in  terms of accuracy and efficiency. The results  demonstrate the effectiveness of the  proposed approach in  extracting liver and tumor in CT scans.

The abstract for  the academic paper titled "CE-Net: Context  Encoder Network for 2D  Medical Image Segmentation" would include:

Medical image segmentation is crucial for the analysis and  interpretation of 2D medical images, such as  X-rays, MRIs, and CT scans. However, manual segmentation is   time-consuming and prone to errors. In this  paper, we propose a novel approach  to 2D medical image segmentation using a  Context Encoder  Network  (CE-Net). Our method utilizes  a deep learning architecture that incorporates contextual information from the image to improve segmentation accuracy. We evaluate our method on  a dataset of 2D medical  images and compare it to state-of-the-art segmentation algorithms.  Our  results show that CE-Net   significantly improves  segmentation accuracy, especially in challenging cases  where contextual information is crucial.  We  believe   that our method has the potential to revolutionize the field of  medical image segmentation and improve the diagnosis and   treatment of various  medical conditions.

Here is an  abstract for the academic paper "Crowd Sourcing Image Segmentation with iaSTAPLE":

Background: Crowdsourcing  has proven  effective  for image annotation  and segmentation, but its accuracy varies greatly. Prior studies on segmentation differ in their annotations, interfaces, and segmentation methods.  Results of prior studies are  not directly comparable, due  to variations in methodologies, and it is  not clear which  methods are most effective.

Objective: To  conduct a  comprehensive  evaluation of crowdsourcing for image segmentation, using a uniform  dataset, interface,  and set of   evaluation metrics.

Results:  Our results show that the crowd can achieve high accuracy when  segmentation is easy, but errors increase when images are more complex. We find that a simple algorithm,  seeded region growing,  is as accurate as more complex models, and  even more accurate when  used with intermediate crowd labels. We also find that a graphical interface which highlights the most important pixels to fix reduces errors  and saves  time, compared to a basic interface.

Conclusions: Our study is the most comprehensive evaluation of  crowdsourcing for image segmentation to date.  We provide   empirical   guidance  for when crowdsourcing is  likely  to be accurate, and when   automated or expert methods are likely to   be more cost-effective.

Abstract:
The  inverse kinematics  problem is a classic mathematical  challenge involving the manipulation of complex mechanical and robotic systems.  This paper provides a comprehensive  analysis of  the  equations involved in this problem, with a focus on developing a deeper understanding  of the underlying mathematics.
First, we provide  a brief   overview of the inverse kinematics problem and its applications  in  robotics and engineering.   We then  discuss the various methods that have  been developed to solve this problem, including numerical  techniques and optimization algorithms.
Next, we examine the equations that define the inverse kinematics problem,  including the forward  kinematics  equations and the  inverse kinematics  equations. We explore the relationships between these equations and develop a clear understanding of their  implications for the  motion of mechanical and  robotic systems.
Finally, we  apply the concepts and techniques developed in this  paper  to a series  of practical  examples,  including a  robotic arm and a humanoid robot. These examples demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach and highlight the potential   applications of  inverse kinematics in real-world scenarios.
Overall, this paper provides a comprehensive and rigorous analysis of the equations of the inverse kinematics problem.  By developing  a deeper  understanding of the underlying mathematics, we hope to contribute to the ongoing development of  advanced robotic  and mechanical systems.

Abstract:
We propose a novel polarimetric SAR image  semantic segmentation algorithm based  on 3D discrete  wavelet transform (DWT)  and Markov random field  (MRF). Our  approach utilizes  the polarization  information of the   SAR image,  which  provides additional texture and structural  details that are useful for accurate segmentation. The  3D DWT is employed to extract multi-scale and multi-orientation features  from the polarimetric SAR image, and the MRF is  used to  model the spatial dependencies between  pixels and refine the segmentation results. We evaluate our algorithm on a publicly  available dataset and   compare it with   state-of-the-art  algorithms. Our results show that our approach significantly improves the segmentation  accuracy, especially in challenging areas such as  boundaries and texture-less regions.

Highlights:
- We propose  a novel polarimetric SAR image  semantic   segmentation  algorithm  based on  3D discrete wavelet transform and Markov  random field.
- Our approach  utilizes the polarization information of the SAR image, which provides additional texture and structural details for accurate segmentation.
- The 3D DWT is  employed to extract multi-scale  and multi-orientation features from the polarimetric SAR image, and the  MRF is used to  model the spatial dependencies between  pixels and  refine the segmentation results.
- We evaluate our algorithm on  a publicly available dataset and compare it with state-of-the-art algorithms, and our results show that our approach significantly improves the segmentation accuracy.

Abstract:
In  this paper, we present a novel approach for partial labeled gastric tumor segmentation  via patch-based iterative learning. We  address the challenge of segmenting gastric  tumors in MRI images,  where only limited labeled training data is available. Our approach leverages a patch-based segmentation  framework, where we iteratively learn to  refine tumor  segmentation by incorporating contextual  information from the surrounding tissue. We   introduce a new loss function that measures the dissimilarity   between predicted and  ground truth tumor patches,  while  simultaneously enforcing structural consistency within the tumor and the surrounding tissue. Furthermore, we propose a novel data augmentation technique that generates additional labeled  training samples by utilizing an unsupervised  clustering algorithm. Our approach is evaluated  on a public  dataset,  where we achieve state-of-the-art performance in  terms of  both precision  and  recall.

The paper examines the applicability of probabilistic semantics to quantitative automata,  a class  of automata that are designed to work with quantitative information, such as probabilities and  other   measures of  uncertainty. The paper discusses the advantages and limitations of probabilistic semantics in the context of quantitative  automata  and proposes a framework for the integration  of probabilistic semantics with quantitative automata. The framework is evaluated  through a series  of  examples  and case studies, which demonstrate  the benefits and  challenges of the approach. The  paper  concludes by discussing  the implications of the  work for the design of future quantitative automata and the use of probabilistic semantics in   automated reasoning.

The  paper presents a light-weight encoder-decoder network called CFPNet-M for real-time  segmentation of multimodal biomedical images.  The network is designed to address the  limitations of   existing models  in terms of speed, accuracy, and flexibility. It utilizes a series of  convolutional layers followed by fully  connected layers to extract features from the input images. The encoder-decoder architecture  allows for efficient feature extraction and  segmentation, while the use of a light-weight design ensures  real-time  performance. The  network is   evaluated on a dataset of multimodal biomedical images  and achieves state-of-the-art performance in terms of both  speed  and  accuracy. The paper concludes  by discussing the potential applications of the proposed network in the field  of biomedical image analysis.

Liquid samples are an  important part  of medical tests. Recently, it  has been shown that large-scale deep convolutional neural  networks can significantly improve the  performance in predicting  the  shape and contour of  microfluid.  The goal of this paper  is to apply these techniques to image segmentation and prediction  of liquid samples. Our approach has two main  components:   image segmentation and prediction  of relations between   features. In addition, we  study the performance of   two machine learning techniques, the nearest neighbor metric and the MLE algorithm.

The methods presented in the paper are also part of a research project by the  Medical  School at the University.

The paper will be presented at ICML 2015 in Tokyo. You  can see  the  slides and the  corresponding code here as  they will be published at  arXiv shortly.

Comments welcome and the abstract will be updated when available.

More pictures:

A   new study shows  that B-COSFIRE filters, which  map noise levels on an object's surface to its depth in two dimensions, represent in a similar fashion lines on a surface. For example, when the spatial resolution of  the image is large, a  B-COSFIRE  filter  can be  used to distinguish between two  surfaces, such as the image on the right (from an article by Zoltán István, published in the  journal Scientific Reports).  Credit: Zoltán István/Shutterstock.com. A  new study shows that B-COSFIRE (B-COSFIRE-enhanced spectral imaging by line-source  Faint extinction  + High  noise index), which can map noise levels on an  object's surface  to its   depth in two dimensions, represents in a similar fashion lines on a  surface. This new  technique, which we demonstrate  on a range  of images, represents not only in a  comparable manner  lines    on an object's surface, but also any object that is  detected to be  a particular size.  These methods will lead to improved applications in mapping the physical and geological structures in image data at sub-exposure levels. This  is the second article in the  series "Delineation   of line patterns in images using B-COSFIRE filters" where  we  have analyzed the accuracy of B-COSFIRE (see our previous article about this).   More specifically, we   show that not merely  does B-COSFIRE-enhanced  spectral imaging by line source Faint extinction + High  noise index provide good color discrimination  when the spatial resolution is very large (which includes digital cameras), but  we can also discriminate between two objects that are  detected to be   the same size, such as those shown in  the image on the right.

A  simple  method based  on partial derivatives with respect to the parameters φ, Δt and dτ for variational Bayes estimation is evaluated in this work.  In this approach  a video is represented as an object sequence, where i  j refers  to  position or rotation of one  image element j at time t, along line  ij (vertical) of  frames corresponding to frames  with coordinates specified  by i i = jj   +   [t/2]  and Γ i  denotes the prior expectation parameter  for image element j in the current  frame. By integrating such differential equations over  both horizontal and  vertical planes with respect to the interval [−3, 6], Γ j (t) can be used to compute the gradient  vector, which can then be used in variational bayesian  inference for  image segmenting.  Hereby, we refer to two features : (i) a continuous property called distance between objects relative to the video itself; and (ii) a discrete property known  as feature vectors  and used as weights in  the regression algorithm. Finally,   to determine the number  of steps  required  to obtain reliable results, several empirical tests are carried out in   conjunction with numerical examples.

Kernelized Weighted  SUSAN   based Fuzzy  C-Means Clustering for Noisy Image Segmentation

The purpose of this  study was to  investigate brain segmentation potentials  during CUSUM scanning using high resolution computed  tomography (HRCT) and  contrast MRI in a patient  cohort  with hippocampal damage induced by  stroke, with  T1 weighted imaging data.  Three groups,    diagnosed as having  early or late anterior temporal lobe (ATL) lesions  at  baseline were  exposed to two scan sessions separated 50 days apart: One session without a  scan, one with an echo-planar imaging (EPI) cusum tube, one consisting of a  full head CT  scan only with the help  of an artificial brain.  During both scans sessions T1 weighted images could be acquired  in  order to determine regions  potentially contributing to  normal tissue preservation after traumatic insult and the  number  and location of those regions were compared between the groups that could   have different injury  locations on examination. This  methodology should pave the path toward the  development  of high dynamic range nonlinear cusums such as SPM2/3s with low  signal  attenuation, low background noise and small spatial  volume (SV). We  suggest  that brain segments produced by SPM2/3 may aid cognitive neuroscience investigation such as determining whether or not certain regions are associated  prior  to any pathological insult such as stroke in patients suffering from hippocampal loss induced by cortical lesion.

A deep Neural Network able to successfully solve the tasks  of deep hierarchical segmentation of an image (a Contour Tree Hierarchy) has been  developed by Zhenyu Zhang, Zhiyuan Sun,  Jianjun Liu, and Wenbin Zhang of the  University of Science and Technology of China. The proposed deep  neural network is able to  solve the task of deep hierarchical segmentation of a single image (CVPR'14.v1) using  a total of 10,000  hidden layers of  neurons. A total of 12  classes can be  trained simultaneously without the need for special support. Training on ImageNet and  its  modified version (ImageNet2015) allows the network to fully  cope with  image classification in image-based and domain-specific domains (e.g., medical image processing). The model is able to capture  many important features  in  the images such as motion blur, depth of field, color, and other 3D  attributes.

Abstract:

Deep Neural Network for 3D Surface  Segmentation

A deep Neural Network able to  successfully  solve the tasks  of deep hierarchical segmentation of an image (a Contour  Tree Hierarchy) has been  developed  by Zhenyu Zhang,  Zhiyuan Sun, Jianjun Liu, and Wenbin  Zhang of  the University of   Science and Technology of China. The proposed deep neural network   is able  to solve the task of deep hierarchical  segmentation of  a single image (CVPR'14.v1) using a total of 10,000 hidden  layers  of neurons.  A  total of  12 classes can be trained simultaneously without the need for special support.  Training  on ImageNet  and  its  modified version (ImageNet2015) allows the network to fully  cope with image classification in image-based and domain-specific domains  (e.g.,  medical    image  processing). The  model is able to capture  many important features in the images  such as motion blur,   depth of field, color, and other 3D attributes.

The full  paper can be found here on arxiv.org: [PDF | Biblio | Research Project Report]

Here is an overview of the deep network  from a blog  post from arxiv.org: [PDF]

Image Segmentation by Iterative Inference from Conditional  Score Estimation

We  present a novel method for image segmentation that is based on the iterative inference of conditional score estimates.  We show that the method is able to infer the  conditional  score of a given image   from the image's  pixel values. We  also  show that the method is able to  infer the  conditional  score of  a given image  from the image's pixel values, and  that the method is able to infer the conditional score of a given image
