Abstract The study aims to identify the parameters that determine the spin orientation transition in (Ga,Mn)As by using  an  experimental method based  on the measurement of  the spin-reversal frequency (FMR). We use a  single-photon excitation technique and a  two-photon  detector to measure the spin-reversal frequency at different  angles between 0°  and  90°. Our results  show  that the FMR is determined by  the angle between the spin axis and the magnetic field vector. This result indicates that the  FMR can be  used as a  tool to probe   the structure of the material.

Abstract

In this work, we propose an  unsupervised image segmentation model based on the deffuant-weisbuch (DW) model.  The DW model has   been  used  to classify images into  categories such as faces and animals. We show that the DW model can  be applied to human  subjects in order  to identify facial features  and detect  emotions. Our  results demonstrate that the DW model can successfully distinguish between two  different expressions of anger, namely angry face  and angry expression. Furthermore, our  results indicate that the DW model can also be applied to  other types of emotion classification  tasks, including those involving  emotional contagion.

1.           Convex field theory suggests a way to account for the defects  found in  Liouville field theories and Toda theory.
2.           The theory in  question appears to be incomplete  and to be  dependent upon the inclusion of a  small number  of'superbounds'.
3.           These  superbounds can be considered to be the quantum vacua, the limits  of which  are often  only defined  at particular distances from the quantum  state.
4.             In  the D-brane cases discussed here there appears to be defects in the  model due to the inclusion of  such small superbounds for various parameters.
5.           The  resulting model  may be viewed   as being a model  with missing fields. The  quantum vacuum  is only defined at distances that lie outside the domain of the D-brane. In  which case the theories have no real  structure.
6.            I present  a derivation of the Todas field theory  under supervalleys  and of Liouville field theory with superstrains in a D-brane model.
7.           This derivation and model is extended  to  include   additional, non-deterministic, parameters   for a superdense model.
8.            The   derivation of Liouville and Toda models uses classical superstrains of Dirac equations. Given quantum fields at  infinity, it turns out not  to  be necessary to extend the definition of a superstrine to suit quantum fields at infinity. In this case, the superstrines may very well  be the superdense fields.
9.           When combined with quantum-fields in non-superstrung  superdense superstrates, the quantum vacuum becomes a superstratified  D-brane.  This superstratified D-brane then has  structure from  the classical point of  view.  This  means that the whole of quantum theory is completely non-local  since the quantum vacuum lies outside any non-local boundary.
10.            The general quantum theory may  be  viewed as being a series of  superdense D-branes with  a quantum potential at the root. This is a  very general solution  to the Schrödinger equation  where  an 'on'/'off' switch is flipped between two superdense superstr

We present a novel method to generate  deep active contour models (DCMs) using local distance vector flow (LDFV). We use LDFV to model the surface  of an object, and then  we apply DCM techniques to extract  features that are relevant to the object's shape. Our  approach  allows us to efficiently compute the contour volume  of a  complex 3D object without requiring any additional  information about  its geometry or orientation.  The  resulting  DCMs have  high accuracy and can be used in  many different  applications including image processing, robotics, and machine  learning.

I'm a student  at The Ohio  State University working in the Machine  Learning  group in the School of Mathematical  Sciences. Our  project focuses on the use of machine learning to enhance the  performance  and generalizability  of image classification  tasks by finding the best patterns or features to maximize accuracy. The core components of our system are  described  here, along with their underlying mathematical models which have been  validated through experiments.  We describe  several practical applications, including image filtering (for  the visually impaired without  stereo vision), object detection through facial recognition (which can be  automated using feature engineering) and language  adaptation (to help users read  written Arabic).  These algorithms   give significant benefits over simpler  approaches, such as  simple  classifier algorithms  that must train frequently  since they  are limited by the number  of labeled training examples available for testing. In particular  we demonstrate these results both in theory, demonstrating  how  one  model can perform near-perfectly as well as  nearly as  well as other classes while costing only logarithmic amounts of data, and in practice,   showing them performing comparably against traditional deep networks based methods.  The approach has received more scrutiny than  any  paper I've seen before (see  also this  recent blog post). The papers listed below are not intended to be exhaustive; rather, we hope will lead  others into research that might further strengthen the relevance  of my thesis!

Coding note: For reasons unknown it's difficult to get access to the code for these  papers; please  submit  pull requests if you  would  like to try and reproduce  each of them :)

In this  paper we present a method for automated thalamus segmentation in MRI using  a multi-contrast approach. We combine T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and T2  FLAIR  images in a single registration and segmentation  framework using a combination of atlas-based  and model-based methods. We evaluate our method on a  dataset of 30  subjects, and compare  our results to those of a  state-of-the-art thalamus segmentation method. Our results  show  that our method outperforms the  state-of-the-art in terms of accuracy,  while being significantly faster.

We propose  a new method for finding  graph cuts which  is based on the power-law degree distribution of the graph. Our  method is able to find graph  cuts  which are  significantly better than those found  by other methods, while being much faster.

In this  paper, we propose a novel deep learning approach for automatic 3D bi-ventricular segmentation of  cardiac images. Our  approach   is based on a shape-refined multi-task deep learning framework, which consists of two sub-networks: a  shape network and a segmentation network. The shape   network is used to generate a shape prior for the   segmentation  network. The segmentation network is then trained to segment   the left ventricle (LV) and right ventricle (RV) simultaneously, using the   shape prior  from the shape  network.  We evaluated our  approach on the ACDC challenge dataset, and  the results showed that our  approach outperformed the state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and efficiency.

In this paper, we  study the curvature tensors of Hermitian manifolds. We  prove that the  curvature tensors of Hermitian manifolds satisfy   certain identities  which are generalizations of  the well-known  identities satisfied by the curvature  tensors of Riemannian manifolds. As  a consequence, we obtain a characterization of the  curvature tensors of Hermitian manifolds in terms of the  Ricci tensor and the scalar curvature.

With the advent of  powerful Deep  Neural  Networks (DNNs),  semantic segmentation of images  and  videos has seen significant improvement in recent   years. However,   most existing methods are  limited to segmenting  a single object category in an image or video. In this    paper, we propose a novel approach to joint segmentation and  localization of multiple object categories  in images and videos. Our method is based on a new method  for foreground clustering, which we  call foregroundness-aware clustering. This method is able to cluster foreground objects in an image or   video, while  also accounting for their  spatial layout. We then use the clustered foreground  objects to train a DNN for joint  segmentation and localization. We evaluate our method on the challenging Youtube-Objects dataset, and show that  it outperforms the state-of-the-art methods for joint segmentation and localization.

In this paper, we study the  topology of  Fatou components for endomorphisms of CP^k. We prove that the topology of a  Fatou component is completely determined by the topology of the corresponding Green's  current. This provides  a link between the topology of Fatou components  and  the Green's current, which  is a powerful tool in   the study of dynamical  systems.

In  this paper, we propose a method for direct white matter bundle segmentation using stacked  U-Nets. Our method is based on the observation that white matter  bundles tend to be oriented along certain directions in the brain.   We use  this  observation to design a U-Net architecture  that  is able  to directly  segment white matter bundles  from diffusion MRI data. Our method is evaluated   on a publicly available dataset, and we show that it  outperforms state-of-the-art methods for white matter bundle segmentation.

In data mining,  clustering is the  task  of  grouping a   set of objects in such a way that objects in  the same group (cluster) are more similar to each other than to objects in  other groups  (clusters). Clustering  is a  mainstay  of unsupervised machine  learning and data analysis.

A common challenge in clustering is that of  relational ambiguity: two or more  objects may be  related in multiple ways, and it is  often unclear which relation is most relevant for the task at hand. This paper proposes a new approach to clustering that takes  into  account   relational ambiguity. The key idea is to represent data as  a set of relation instances,  where each relation instance represents a  pair of  objects and  a relation between them.  A clustering algorithm is  then applied to the set of relation instances, and the  resulting clusters  are used to group the objects.

The proposed approach is evaluated on a text data set and  a natural   data set. The results  show that  the proposed approach outperforms existing methods for clustering in the presence of relational ambiguity.

Cellular automata  have been increasingly used in  image processing and computer vision tasks such as image  segmentation, object  detection, and recognition.  In this paper, we propose a new approach for image segmentation using two-dimensional  cellular  automata. We utilize the well-known Conway's  Game of Life cellular automaton to  segment images into foreground  and  background regions. We adapt   an existing method for setting  the parameters   of  the cellular automaton to images. We also propose a new method for detecting seed points for  the cellular automaton, which are  necessary for its proper functioning.  The proposed methods are  compared with several state-of-the-art methods on a variety of images, and the results show that our  approach  outperforms the other methods in  terms of accuracy and efficiency.

Cardiac imaging is essential for the diagnosis  and management of cardiovascular disease.  Two-dimensional ultrasound is  the most commonly used modality for cardiac imaging, but  manual analysis is time-consuming and  subject to inter- and intraobserver variability. To address these limitations, we have developed  and validated  a computer vision pipeline for  automated  determination  of cardiac structure and  function and detection  of disease from two-dimensional echocardiographic images. The pipeline includes acquisition  of  standard echocardiographic images, correction for image artifacts, detection of the cardiac  silhouette, segmentation  of the left ventricle, tracking  of myocardial motion,  estimation of left ventricular volumes and ejection fraction, and classification of image quality.  The pipeline  has been  validated on a publicly  available database of echocardiographic images and on a clinical cohort of patients with known  cardiovascular disease. The  pipeline outperforms  state-of-the-art  methods for automated echocardiographic image analysis   and is capable of  detecting  a range of cardiovascular diseases with high accuracy.

The electronic transport properties  of pyridine-linked  single molecule junctions (SMJs) are investigated using a first-principles  approach. It is found   that the electrode density of states (DOS) has a significant impact  on the transport through the SMJs. When the DOS  of the electrodes  is  low, the transport through the SMJs is dominated by the  coherent tunneling process. However, when  the DOS of the electrodes  is  high, the transport through the SMJs is dominated  by the incoherent  hopping process. The results of  this study  suggest that the DOS  of the  electrodes can be used to control the transport through pyridine-linked SMJs.

This paper presents a novel approach for thalamus  segmentation using  multi-contrast Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI). The  focus of the study   is to enhance the accuracy,  efficiency, and effectiveness of thalamus identification and  volumetric analysis in the human brain via MRI. The method utilized  a combination of T1-weighted,  T2-weighted, and diffusion-weighted contrasts to differentiate between thalamus and non-thalamus  structures. Experimental results indicate that our  multi-contrast   MRI approach significantly improves thalamus segmentation compared to  traditional single-contrast  methods, promising  potential applications in studying various  neurological conditions that impact the thalamus.

This paper presents an  in-depth study on Power-Law Graph Cuts,  a novel approach  to partitioning large-scale graphs.  The  study explores  the theoretical underpinnings  of the power-law distribution in graph cuts and  its implications for network analysis. The  paper also introduces an  efficient algorithm for  computing power-law graph cuts, demonstrating its effectiveness  through extensive experiments on various real-world datasets. The results show that  power-law graph  cuts    can provide more accurate  and meaningful  partitions than traditional methods, especially for  graphs with skewed degree distributions. This research opens up new possibilities for analyzing and understanding complex networks  in various fields, including social networks, web graphs, and biological networks.

This paper presents an innovative deep  learning approach  for automatic  3D bi-ventricular segmentation  of cardiac images. The proposed method leverages a  multi-task learning framework that  simultaneously  performs segmentation and shape regression  tasks, thereby improving  the  accuracy and robustness of the segmentation  results. The model is trained on a large  dataset of cardiac images, and its performance is evaluated against manual segmentations by expert radiologists. The results demonstrate  that  the proposed approach outperforms existing methods in terms  of  both segmentation accuracy and computational efficiency. This research has significant  implications  for the development of automated tools  for cardiac image analysis, potentially improving the diagnosis and treatment  of heart  diseases.

This  paper  delves into the intricate study of curvature  tensors of Hermitian manifolds. It provides  a comprehensive analysis of  the   properties and characteristics of these tensors,  focusing on their role in the geometry and topology of Hermitian manifolds.  The paper also  explores the relationship between curvature tensors and other geometric entities,  such as  the Ricci tensor and the scalar curvature. The results obtained contribute to the understanding of the geometric structure of Hermitian manifolds and  have potential  applications in differential geometry, theoretical physics, and  other related fields. The paper  concludes with   a  discussion on the implications of the findings  and suggestions for future research.

This  paper addresses the task of joint segmentation and localization in both  videos   and images by introducing a  novel method, 'Foreground Clustering'. The  method  oversees identifying and clustering foreground  pixels  that share similar  object-level properties while discerning them  from the background. The authors articulate a  new algorithm that assimilates both spatial and temporal  cues, simultaneously localizing and  segmenting foreground objects efficiently. It surpasses traditional  methods, which perform these  tasks separately,  improving both accuracy and speed. The presented experimental results show that this Foreground Clustering  method outperforms existing  state-of-the-art techniques on several benchmark datasets, leading to more  precise and efficient segmentation and localization in videos and  images.

This  paper explores the  topology   of Fatou  components for endomorphisms of CP^k,  focusing on  the relationship  with the Green's current. The study delves  into the dynamics of holomorphic  endomorphisms, particularly the structure  and behavior of Fatou components. The paper  presents  a detailed analysis  of the  Green's current, a critical tool  in understanding the  dynamics of these endomorphisms. The results reveal a significant link between the topology of  Fatou components and the  Green's current, providing new insights into the complex dynamics of  endomorphisms of CP^k. This  research contributes to the broader understanding of complex dynamical systems and offers a foundation for further studies in this field.

This paper presents a novel approach for  direct white   matter  bundle segmentation  using stacked U-Nets. The study  aims to  improve the accuracy and efficiency of  white  matter bundle segmentation in diffusion MRI tractography, a critical aspect in  neuroscience  research and clinical applications. The proposed method leverages the power of deep learning   and the  architecture  of U-Nets, stacked in a hierarchical manner,  to segment complex white matter bundles  directly from diffusion MRI data. The results demonstrate that the stacked U-Nets  outperform traditional methods in terms of accuracy, precision, and   computational efficiency. This approach has potential implications for advancing our  understanding of brain connectivity and neurological disorders.

This academic paper explores the relationship between  clustering and relational ambiguity, specifically  within the  realm of text data and natural data. The study  delves into the phenomenon of relational ambiguity- the uncertainty that  arises due to ambiguous relations in  data- and  its impact on clustering, a common method of grouping similar data entities together. By  applying conventional techniques  and  developing innovative measures, the  outcomes highlight  the challenges and limitations encountered during the process. Furthermore,  the paper  discusses various ways through which these challenges can be tackled, focusing on  enhancements in machine learning and algorithmic advancements.  The findings  gleaned from this research  hold vital implications  for future work in data  analysis and   natural language processing.

This paper presents an innovative approach for image segmentation utilizing Cellular Automata  (CA). Image segmentation, a  crucial  task in image analysis and computer  vision, primarily involves partitioning   an image   into segments.  The  primary focus is to perceive CA as an effective tool for image  segmentation. It outlines CA's principle, its implementation for image segmentation, and the results  derived from these methods. The paper  demonstrates the results  through a  series of experiments  conducted on  numerous images. The results represent significant improvements in speed and segmentation precision compared to traditional methods,  making  it  clear  that CA possesses vast potential for image segmentation tasks.  This paper serves as a comprehensive investigation and technical augmentation toward using CA in  the field of image  segmentation and analysis.

This paper introduces a  computer vision pipeline designed for automated determination of  cardiac structure  and function, as well as disease  detection, through  two-dimensional  echocardiography. The  goal of the system is to enhance the efficiency,  accuracy and objectivity of echocardiogram interpretation, via automating assessment protocol. The  pipeline was established by  developing a machine learning algorithm  that  facilitates the  extraction and analysis of key cardiac features. The study  involves testing and validating the algorithm using a diverse set of echocardiograms, while  comparing  results  with manual  measurements taken by professionals. Experimental results demonstrate impressive robustness and accuracy in identifying various cardiac structures, evaluating their   functions, and detecting cardiac diseases. This suggests an encouraging potential for the application of  this pipeline in  clinical settings, contributing to swift   and objective  cardiac analysis.

This paper investigates the influence of the electrode density of states (DOS)  on the transport  properties of  pyridine-linked single molecule  junctions. Using a combination of experimental  and computational methods, we  demonstrate that the electrode DOS significantly affects  the   charge transport through these  molecular junctions. Our results  show that the  current-voltage characteristics  and the conductance spectra   are strongly modulated by the electrode DOS.  Furthermore, we find that  the transport properties are highly sensitive to the energy alignment between the molecular orbitals  and the electrode Fermi level. These  findings provide new insights into the  role of the electrode DOS in single molecule electronics and pave the way for  the  design of molecular devices  with tailored transport properties.

Abstract:

Left  atrial  segmentation from 3D gadolinium  enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)  is a  crucial  step in diagnosing and managing cardiac arrhythmias. However,  manual segmentation  of the left atrium can be time-consuming and observer-dependent,  leading to  variability in clinical decision-making.  In  this study, we propose a deep learning approach using dilated convolutional neural  networks  (DCNNs) for automated left atrial segmentation  in 3D gadolinium enhanced-MRI. Our proposed  method utilizes  a combination of spatial pyramid  pooling  and multi-scale features fusion to improve feature extraction and enhance performance. We evaluated our method on  a dataset of 100 patients  and compared it with traditional CNNs and  U-Net architectures. The  results show that  DCNNs outperformed both traditional CNNs  and U-Nets  in terms of segmentation accuracy, achieving an  average Dice similarity coefficient of 86.5%. Additionally, we  observed that DCNNs were more robust to variations  in heart   rate and image quality compared to other methods. These findings suggest  that DCNNs are a promising tool for accurate  and efficient  left atrial segmentation in 3D gadolinium enhanced-MRI, which  could potentially improve the consistency and efficiency of clinical decision-making in cardiology.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to improve the performance of  fully  convolutional networks (FCNs) by learning what to attend to in images. Our approach, called AttentionBoost, leverages the strengths of recent attention mechanisms to  boost the performance  of FCNs  in  various  computer vision tasks.

Existing attention  mechanisms have shown promising results in natural language processing and image captioning,  but they have limitations when applied to image classification and object detection tasks. Specifically, these mechanisms are designed to focus  on specific parts of an image, but they often struggle to identify  the most relevant regions when dealing with   complex images or multiple objects.

AttentionBoost addresses this issue by introducing  a novel attention module that  learns to attend to the  most discriminative  regions of an image. Our module is designed to be lightweight and can  be easily integrated  into existing FCN architectures. We  evaluate  AttentionBoost on several benchmark datasets, including CIFAR-10,  CIFAR-100,  and PASCAL VOC.

The key contribution of  this paper is the  introduction of a novel attention mechanism that learns to attend to the most   discriminative regions  of an image,  leading to improved  performance in  image classification  and object detection tasks. Our approach  outperforms existing  attention mechanisms and  achieves state-of-the-art results on several benchmarks.

The paper  is organized as follows: In section 2, we  review  related work  on  attention mechanisms and their applications  in  computer vision. In section 3, we introduce the AttentionBoost module and its architecture.  In section  4,  we  describe the experimental setup and the datasets used for  evaluation. In section  5, we present the results of our experiments and  compare AttentionBoost with existing attention mechanisms. Finally,  in section 6,  we conclude the  paper and discuss future directions  for improving AttentionBoost.

Overall, AttentionBoost  offers a promising approach to improving the  performance of  FCNs  in various  computer vision tasks,  and  we believe it has the potential  to be widely adopted  in the field.

This paper proposes a  new approach to modeling spatial data using dynamic spatial autoregressive (SAR)  models that account for both autoregressive and heteroskedastic disturbances. The  proposed model, called the  dynamic SAR(p,d,q) model, extends  the traditional SAR  model by incorporating time-varying  parameters  and heteroskedastic disturbances, which   allows for a more flexible and realistic representation of  spatial data. The model is estimated using  a Bayesian approach,  which allows for the incorporation of prior information and provides a natural way to handle model  uncertainty. The paper also  discusses the use of informative prior  distributions and provides guidance on how to choose appropriate priors.  The  model is applied  to a real-world dataset  and the  results show  that it outperforms traditional SAR models in terms of forecast accuracy and ability to capture spatial patterns.  The paper concludes  by discussing the contributions and limitations of    the proposed model and suggesting directions  for  future research.

Keywords:  spatial data, dynamic spatial   autoregressive models, heteroskedastic disturbances, Bayesian estimation, informative priors.

In this paper,  we investigate homotopy invariants of   combings  of 3-manifolds. A combing of  a  3-manifold is a way of decomposing it into smaller  pieces,  called teeth, that are glued together along their boundaries in a specific  way. We  focus on homotopy invariants  of combings,  which  are  properties  that remain unchanged under continuous deformations of the combing.

We first establish  a framework for   studying  homotopy  invariants of combings by defining a notion of homotopy between combings and introducing a category whose objects  are combings and whose morphisms are homotopy classes  of combings. We then prove that this  category is triangulated,  meaning that it has well-defined  notions of kernels and cokernels,   and that these can be used to define homology and cohomology groups of combings.

Next, we explore various homotopy invariants of  combings, including the number of teeth, the total space  of the combing,  and the fundamental group of the  complement of the teeth. We show that all of  these  invariants  can   be computed  using the above-mentioned homology and cohomology groups.

In particular, we prove that the number of teeth is equal to the dimension of the kernel of  a certain map from the homology group  of  the 3-manifold to its  cohomology group, while  the total space of the combing can be identified with the cokernel of another map between these groups. Finally, we  show that the fundamental  group of the complement  of the teeth can be realized as a quotient of the  fundamental group of  the 3-manifold modulo a certain normal subgroup that encodes information about the combinatorics of the   combing.

Our results provide   a new perspective on the study of 3-manifolds and their decompositions, and they have  important implications for  the understanding of topological   and  geometric structure of  these  spaces. They also demonstrate the  power of our proposed approach to the study of homotopy invariants  of combings, and pave the way for further  investigations in this area.

This paper presents a novel approach for identifying parallel passages across  a  large Hebrew/Aramaic corpus.  Using a  combination  of natural  language processing techniques and machine learning  algorithms, we developed a system that can automatically  identify instances where the same or similar text  appears in different parts of  the corpus.

Our methodology involves several stages, including text preprocessing, similarity measurement, and passage clustering. We first cleaned and  normalized the text data to ensure consistency and accuracy. Then,  we used  a statistical measure of similarity to  calculate  the  distance between each pair of passages in  the corpus. Finally, we applied a clustering algorithm to  group together passages with high  similarity   scores, resulting in  identified parallel passages.

Evaluation results show  that  our approach    outperforms existing  methods in  terms of precision  and recall. We achieved an F-score of 0.87 on  a subset of the corpus, indicating  a high  degree  of  accuracy in identifying parallel passages. Additionally, we observed that our method was able to identify many instances of parallelism  that were not previously known or documented.

The implications of this research are significant for scholars of Hebrew and Aramaic studies, as  well as for those interested in natural language processing and  machine  learning applications.  The  ability to quickly and accurately identify parallel  passages  enables new forms of  analysis and understanding of complex texts, such as identifying  themes,  tracking linguistic changes over time, and studying the evolution of religious ideas.  Furthermore, the techniques presented here could be adapted  for use with other languages and corpora, opening  up possibilities for cross-linguistic comparisons  and studies of literary  influence.

This paper  explores  the relationship between tail risk constraints and  maximum entropy in the context  of portfolio optimization. Tail risk constraints are  used to mitigate the impact  of extreme market  events on portfolio returns, while maximum entropy portfolios are constructed to maximize diversification and minimize risk.  We propose a novel approach   that integrates tail risk constraints into the maximum entropy framework, resulting in portfolios  that balance risk and  diversification in the presence  of  extreme events.

Our approach is based on  a modified version of  the traditional maximum entropy optimization problem, which incorporates tail risk constraints  in the form of conditional  value-at-risk  (CVaR) constraints.  We use  a robust optimization method to solve the resulting  optimization problem,  which allows us to address the uncertainty in the tail risk  estimates.

We test our approach using  a set of empirical asset returns and compare the results to those obtained using traditional maximum entropy portfolios and tail risk-constrained  portfolios.  Our results show that our proposed approach achieves a better  trade-off  between risk and diversification    than  the  other two methods, particularly in situations where tail risk is high.

Our findings have important implications for  portfolio  optimization  under extreme market  conditions. By integrating tail  risk constraints into the maximum entropy framework,  we can create portfolios that are better equipped to withstand extreme events while still  maintaining a high  level of diversification. This can help  investors to better manage risk and   achieve  their investment  objectives in uncertain markets.

In this paper,  we  propose a novel approach to long-term visual localization that   leverages the  power  of fine-grained segmentation networks.  Our approach is  based  on the  observation that accurate segmentation of the  environment  is  essential for robust localization, especially in the presence of changes in  lighting, viewpoint, and other factors.  To address this challenge, we propose a  self-supervised segmentation method that utilizes a fine-grained  segmentation network to  learn a robust representation of the environment.

Our approach is  based on  a novel architecture that combines  a convolutional neural network (CNN) with a  spatial pyramid pooling  (SPP) module. The CNN is  used   to extract features  from  the visual data, while the SPP module  is used to aggregate the features across  different spatial resolutions. This allows the network  to  capture both local and global features of  the environment, leading to improved  segmentation accuracy.

We evaluate our approach on several publicly  available  datasets, including the Oxford RobotCar dataset, the  KITTI dataset, and the Mapillary Vistas dataset.  Our experiments show that our fine-grained segmentation network outperforms state-of-the-art  segmentation methods, including fully supervised methods that require  manual annotation. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach for long-term visual  localization, showing that it can accurately  localize a vehicle  over  long periods of  time and in  diverse environmental conditions.

Our main contribution is the  introduction of a self-supervised segmentation method that utilizes a  fine-grained segmentation  network  to learn a robust representation of the environment.  This method does not require manual annotation, making  it scalable  and cost-effective. Our approach has important implications for a range  of applications, including autonomous driving, robotics,  and virtual reality.

Semantic image  segmentation is a fundamental   task in  computer vision  that involves assigning  a semantic label   to each pixel in an image. Despite the progress  made  in this field, existing approaches often  rely on manually designed  hand-crafted  features   and  suffer from limited performance, especially in the presence of various variations in  the  data. In this paper, we propose a novel approach called Locally Adaptive Learning Loss (LALL) that addresses these  limitations by leveraging the concept of self-supervised learning.

The proposed LALL method is designed to learn  a loss function  that is  adaptive to  the  local structure of the data,  which enables the model to  learn more robust and discriminative features. Specifically, LALL utilizes a  set of locally  adaptive anchors  that are learned  from  the data to guide the learning  process. These anchors are used to compute a loss function that  is tailored to the local properties of the image, allowing the  model to focus on  the  most relevant information.

We conduct extensive experiments on several benchmark datasets, including Cityscapes, PASCAL VOC, and BSDS500, and demonstrate that  LALL  outperforms state-of-the-art segmentation   methods.  Our results show that LALL  achieves an average gain of  3.5% in segmentation accuracy compared to  the baseline model. Moreover, we perform a series of ablation studies to  analyze  the effectiveness of  the proposed method and show that LALL is robust to different choices of hyperparameters  and  architectures.

The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of  a novel loss function that  is adaptive to the local structure of the data, which leads to better  performance and  robustness in semantic  image segmentation tasks. The proposed method has important implications for a wide  range  of applications, including  autonomous driving, robotics, and  medical  imaging.

In summary, this  paper presents a locally adaptive learning loss function for semantic image segmentation, which leverages the  concept of self-supervised learning to learn   a loss function that is tailored to the local properties of the data.  The proposed method is evaluated on several benchmark datasets and  demonstrates improved performance  and robustness compared to state-of-the-art  segmentation methods.

In  this paper,  we present nnDetection, a self-configuring  method for  medical object detection that leverages the strengths of deep learning and computer vision to accurately identify and   classify  various medical objects in  images. Unlike  traditional  object detection methods that require manual  annotation and domain-specific expertise, nnDetection uses a novel, self-configuring approach that automatically adapts to different medical datasets and  object categories.

Our approach combines  a convolutional neural  network (CNN) with a  novel algorithm that simultaneously  learns to  detect objects  and configure the  detection system. This allows nnDetection  to  learn from a small set of labeled   examples  and adapt to new  datasets with minimal  additional training data. We evaluate nnDetection on several  medical datasets, including mammography, ultrasound, and microscopy images, and demonstrate   its superior performance compared to  state-of-the-art object detection methods.

nnDetection has significant implications  for medical image   analysis, as it  can  accurately detect and classify various objects, such as tumors,  organs, and other  anatomical structures, in medical images. This can  aid clinicians in diagnosis and  treatment planning, and enable more accurate and efficient analysis of medical images. Additionally, nnDetection's self-configuring ability makes  it a versatile tool that can be easily  adapted to different medical domains and applications, without requiring extensive domain-specific knowledge or manual annotation.

Overall, nnDetection  represents a significant advancement in  medical object  detection, and has the  potential to revolutionize the field of medical image  analysis. Its ability to accurately detect and classify medical objects in  images, without requiring manual  annotation or domain-specific expertise, makes  it a valuable  tool for clinicians, researchers, and other medical professionals.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach  to fast  semantic image segmentation that incorporates high  order context and guided   filtering. Existing methods  often rely on low-level  features and laborious post-processing steps, resulting in slow  performance and suboptimal accuracy. Our method leverages recent  advances in  deep learning to efficiently capture high-order contextual information and employs guided filtering to refine the segmentation results.

We begin  by  introducing  a new architecture that integrates a high-order context encoder with a feature pyramid network  (HPN) backbone. The HPN extracts multi-scale features  from the input image, while the context encoder captures long-range dependencies using a hierarchical convolutional kernel. We then employ  a  novel guided filtering module that selectively emphasizes  relevant  regions based on the output  of  the context encoder. This allows the  model to focus on the  most discriminative areas when segments objects   or boundaries.

On several benchmark datasets  (Cityscapes, PASCAL VOC, and COCO), our approach demonstrates superior performance  compared to  state-of-the-art  methods.  Specifically, it achieves an improvement of X%  in mIoU on Cityscapes and  Y% in mAP on COCO without requiring additional annotation or training  data. Our ablation studies verify the effectiveness of  both the high-order context encoder  and the guided  filtering mechanism. Furthermore, we demonstrate the efficiency of our method--it  can be trained using  a  single GPU within a reasonable time frame while maintaining competitive performance.   

The  main  contributions of this work are:
1. A novel  deep learning architecture that  jointly learns high-order context  and features via a hierarchical  convolutional kernel; 
2.  An efficient guided filtering module that adaptively  weights feature responses  according to their  relevance; 3. State-of-the=art performance on  multiple public  datasets with minimal computational resources.
Our Fast Semantic Image Segmentation algorithm has far-reaching  implications  across computer vision applications including   object detection,  autonomous driving, and medical imaging.

This study  presents a comparative evaluation of three state-of-the-art statistical skin detection algorithms, namely Fitzpatrick's,   MATLAB's pigmentation model, and Monte Carlo method on sub-continental   human images. The aim   was to determine which algorithm provides the   best performance in detecting skin regions on  these images. A dataset of 1063 images of  individuals from six different sub-continental populations (African,  Asian,  European, Latin American, Middle Eastern, and  Native American) was used for testing. The   three algorithms were  implemented using MATLAB software, and their performances were compared based on accuracy,  precision,   recall, F1-score, and processing time. Our results revealed  that the Fitzpatrick's algorithm outperformed  the other two methods, achieving the highest  values of accuracy, precision, recall,  and F1-score across all  populations. In particular, it correctly classified 95.7% of African, 94.2% of  Asian, 96.8% of European, 93.5% of Latin American,  92.6% of Middle Eastern,  and 94.1%  of Native  American images   as  skin  or non-skin.  Notably, this  algorithm  also displayed the lowest average processing time per image. These findings suggest that the Fitzpatrick's algorithm is well suited for skin detection on diverse sub-continental  human images irrespective  of variables such as lighting   conditions, pose, facial expression, and occlusion. Future studies may build upon our work by exploring improvements  to further enhance its efficiency without compromising accuracy.

> In  this work, we propose an automatic prostate segmentation method based  on fine-grained recurrent neural networks (RNN). We first extract features  using a  convolutional neural  network (CNN) and then use RNN to learn the spatial context information between adjacent pixels. To  improve the performance  of our  model,  we introduce two  novel strategies into our framework. Firstly, we design a multi-scale feature fusion strategy that can effectively  fuse  different scale features  extracted by CNN. Secondly, we adopt a progressive training scheme which  gradually increases   the difficulty  level during  the  training  process. Experimental results show that our proposed approach achieves state-of-the-art performance  compared with other methods.

> In this work, we propose an automatic method to segment  brain tumors  in perfusion MRI scans using Cumulative Sum (CUSUM)  filtering and    machine learning techniques.  We use a combination  of intensity-based  features extracted from the original images as well  as texture descriptors  computed by applying Gabor filters at different scales and orientations. These features are used to train Support Vector Machines (SVMs),  which classify each voxel into one of   three classes:  normal  tissue,  edema or necrosis. Our results show that our proposed  approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods such as fuzzy c-means clustering and level set evolution.

> We propose Boundary Loss  (BL), which encourages the  model to  predict boundaries between different classes  in remote sensing imagery semantic segmentation  tasks. BL can  be  easily integrated into existing deep learning models, and  it does not require  any  additional annotations or training data. Experiments on  three public datasets show that our method outperforms  state-of-the-art methods by 1%–3%. Our code will be released at https://github.com/zjunlp/boundary_loss .

> Pre-training on  large datasets has become  standard  practice in deep learning.  However, it  can be   difficult to  adapt  these  models to new tasks or domains when they are not well aligned with the target data distribution. In this work we propose  a method that allows us to  extend existing pre-trained models  by adding new classes without retraining them from scratch. We show how our  approach can  be used to add new  anatomical structures to segmentation networks trained on medical imaging  data. Our experiments demonstrate  that our model outperforms other methods at extending pre-trained  models  while maintaining their performance on original classes.

> We  consider the discretized fluid-structure interaction (FSI)  system
    with a  nonlinear fluid model and  a linear  elastic structure model.
  The fluid  model is the incompressible  Navier-Stokes equations with
  a nonlinear pressure-velocity coupling. The structure model  is the
  linear elasticity  equations. The fluid-structure interaction is
  modeled by the immersed boundary method. We prove the well-posedness
    of the discretized FSI system  and the convergence of the  discrete
  solution  to   the continuous solution. We also   propose a robust
  preconditioner for  the discretized FSI system. The preconditioner
  is based on the Schur complement of  the fluid-structure interaction
  system.  The preconditioner is robust in the sense    that it is
  independent  of the fluid viscosity and the structure stiffness.
  Numerical experiments are presented to  demonstrate the effectiveness
  of the preconditioner.

Title:    Sigma Point Belief Propagation

Author: John Doe

Abstract: This paper presents a  new approach to  belief propagation  in Bayesian networks, based on the sigma point method. The sigma point method is a  technique used in stochastic process  control to estimate the state  of the process, and it can be extended  to  belief propagation  in Bayesian networks by using sigma points to represent the state of the  network.

The proposed approach uses sigma points to initialize the belief distribution  and  then iteratively updates the belief distribution  using Bayesian  rule and the sigma point method. The paper also presents a  new algorithm for computing the probability of the  next  sigma  point using Bayesian update rule  and   the sigma point method.

The proposed approach is shown to be  effective in  estimating the  posterior  probability of  the network parameters in a Bayesian  model,  as  well as in  computing the  likelihood of the network parameters given new data. The paper concludes with a comparison with existing belief propagation methods, and the  results show that the proposed method is computationally efficient and accurate.

The  paper presents  an automatic image  pixel clustering   algorithm based  on the Mussels  Wandering Optimization (MWO) algorithm. The proposed algorithm is designed to efficiently  cluster pixels in an image based on their  similarity in color and intensity. The MWO algorithm is used  to optimize the clustering process by iteratively adjusting the  cluster centers until  convergence is achieved. The algorithm is tested   on a variety of images  and compared  to other clustering algorithms. The results show that  the proposed algorithm is effective in clustering pixels in an image  and is more efficient than other clustering algorithms.

The  paper  presents a novel method for fast and accurate 3D medical image segmentation using data-swapping. The proposed method involves swapping  the data  from the  source image with the target image to improve the segmentation accuracy. The data-swapping  process is performed using a deep learning-based approach that involves   training a neural network to  predict the segmentation labels  of the target image  based on the source  image.  The proposed method is evaluated  on a  large  dataset of 3D medical images and compared with state-of-the-art methods.  The results show that the proposed method achieves faster and more accurate segmentation than  the  existing methods. The paper concludes that the data-swapping  method is a promising  approach for improving the accuracy and speed of  3D  medical  image segmentation.

Blind facial image quality enhancement   is a challenging task in computer vision,  as it requires enhancing the visual appearance of faces  without any prior  knowledge about   their identity  or pose. In this  study, we  propose a novel approach to blind  facial  image quality   enhancement that utilizes non-rigid semantic patches. Our method first extracts semantic patches  from the input face images and then applies a  deep learning model  to enhance each patch based on its semantic content. The enhanced  patches are  then reassembled into an output  image with improved facial  features. We evaluate our  method on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate  significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods. Our results show that our approach can  effectively enhance the visual appearance of faces  while preserving their identities and poses.

LadderNet is a novel approach to multi-path networks that utilizes the architecture of  U-Net, a state-of-the-art convolutional neural  network (CNN) designed specifically for medical  image segmentation. The proposed  model  extends  the capabilities of U-Net by  incorporating multiple  pathways into its design,  allowing it to  process and analyze complex medical images with  greater accuracy and efficiency.

The  LadderNet architecture consists of  several layers  that are connected through a series of interconnected   nodes or "ladder rungs." Each  rung contains a set of  filters that extract specific features from the input image, which  are then combined using concatenation operations. This allows the model  to learn multiple levels of abstraction simultaneously,  enabling it to identify patterns at different scales  and  resolutions within the image.

To further improve  performance, LadderNet  also includes skip connections between adjacent rungs, which allow information to flow directly between  them without having to pass through additional processing stages. These  skip connections help to reduce  overfitting and increase the overall capacity of the model, making it more effective at handling challenging medical imaging   tasks   such as tumor detection and segmentation.

Experimental  results demonstrate  that  LadderNet  outperforms other state-of-the-art CNNs in terms of both accuracy and  speed, achieving excellent segmentation results on a variety of  medical image  datasets. Overall, the proposed  LadderNet architecture represents an  important  advancement  in the field of medical image segmentation, providing a powerful tool for clinicians and researchers  alike.

Image  segmentation is a fundamental task  in computer vision that  involves  partitioning an image into multiple meaningful regions.  Traditional methods often rely on strong shape  priors to achieve accurate results, but these can be computationally expensive and limit  generalization.  In  this  paper, we propose a novel approach to image segmentation  using weak shape priors, which leverage minimal structural information while still benefiting from  prior knowledge. Our approach employs a  novel shape descriptor that captures weak constraints and is easy to compute.  Experimental  results show that our method outperforms state-of-the-art methods in  terms of speed and  accuracy on various  benchmark datasets.  Additionally, our weak shape  prior  can be  easily integrated with other methods  to improve their performance, highlighting its versatility.

The phenomenon of single-photon interference (SPI) is a  fundamental aspect of quantum  mechanics, which describes how the  probability distribution of particles can  be affected by their interactions  with each other. In  this study, we investigate  the effects of SPI on  the behavior of individual photons in various experimental  setups.  We find  that the presence   of multiple photons can lead to unexpected  results, such as  the breakdown of spontaneous superposition. Our findings have important  implications for our understanding of the nature of light  and its interaction with  matter, and may have practical  applications in fields such as quantum computing and  cryptography.

In this  study, we propose a  novel  approach to left atrial segmentation using dilated  convolutional neural networks (DCNN)  on 3D gadolinium enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (GE-MRI). The proposed method  utilizes a combination of traditional convolutional layers and dilated convolutional layers  to improve the  accuracy  and efficiency of the model. We evaluate  our method on a dataset   of 105 patients with varying degrees of cardiac abnormalities and demonstrate significant  improvements in both precision and recall compared to  state-of-the-art methods. Our results  suggest that DCNNs  are an effective  tool for left  atrial segmentation in GE-MRI and have potential  applications in clinical  practice.

The concept of  morphological neurons has revolutionized the field of artificial intelligence,  offering  a  unique approach to machine learning based on their ability to model  complex spatial and temporal signals. However, despite significant advancements in recent years, much remains  unknown about their underlying mechanisms and limitations. In this  abstract, we present an explorative study  investigating the boundaries of what can be achieved  through the use of morphological networks.  Our analysis  reveals  that while morphological neurons are capable  of processing highly complex data sets,  they appear to suffer  from certain inherent constraints, including difficulties with contextual interpretation and generalization. Additionally,  we demonstrate  that  these  constraints  may  not necessarily correspond to computational  shortcomings but  could instead reflect broader challenges related to the nature of sensory perception itself.  Ultimately, our findings  suggest that further research is   needed to fully understand  the  potential of morphological networks, as well as to overcome some of the  challenges they face.

In this paper, we  present a novel approach for learning  to segment microscopy images with lazy labels. Our method utilizes a combination of  deep  learning   and  active learning techniques  to automatically segment images with minimal human  intervention.   We use a   convolutional neural network (CNN) to learn the features of the images and a lazy  labeling strategy  to select the most informative  samples for labeling. Our approach is able to achieve high accuracy  with a small number of labeled  samples,  making  it suitable for applications where labeling is time-consuming or expensive. We evaluate our method on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its  effectiveness in segmenting a variety of microscopy images.

We study a problem of inverse solving a linear system of equations with  additive noise. This  problem  occurs in various imaging fields with different constraints and additional goals, for instance,  image reconstruction in positron  emission tomography (PET) and computer tomography (CT). In this paper,  we propose  a novel   algorithm  that  combines the advantage of iterative and non-iterative algorithms as well as the benefits  of using a deep neural network and a generative model. In every iteration, we simultaneously  perform image reconstruction, regularization, denoising, and a gradient descent update of the network parameters.  We  show that it is beneficial to train  our network in an end-to-end fashion with noisy  ground-truth data and it leads to better results as  compared to using clean data, particularly in the case of low-dose PET. Moreover, the  method achieves  competitive performance compared  to the iterative algorithms.

Graphs are ubiquitous in science  and  engineering, with applications ranging across social networks to molecular  structures; however their   analysis has been limited by computational complexity issues  that have prevented large-scale graph  processing on  modern  supercomputers or clusters [1].  The advent of high performance computing (HPC) systems based upon manycore processors such as GPU's offers an opportunity not only improve scalability   but also enable  new algorithms which exploit parallelism at  multiple levels within graphs themselves - including  vertex-, edge-(sub-)graph level operations  along side traditional matrix algebra primitives  like addition/multiplication etc.. This work presents mathematical foundations behind these concepts using linear  algebraic  techniques developed  over past decades combined together into  one unified framework  called 'Linear Algebraic Programming' where each operation corresponds directly back onto some underlying  algorithm implementation(e).g., sparse  matrices via CSR format  while dense ones  use  DAG representation instead."

The  purpose of this research paper is to propose a method for improving state-of-the-art  image segmentation methods  for biomedical images. They  do this by improving upon Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) in order  to improve  results with regards to accuracy and speed.    We have previously shown that state-of-the-art  semantic segmentation  results outperform  other methods for brain tumor segmentation and are competitive with expert annotator measurements.  However, these networks are not fully convolutional in nature,  meaning they may not be  well-suited for fast applications. One of  the most significant   advantages  of  the fully convolutional network is that it is very fast and computationally  efficient  in that it does not need to have a pool   layer and  fully  connected layers. Another reason is that fully convolutional networks are trainable end-to-end and  they  provide full  segmentation mask output with  one pass per image at run-time, which  is advantageous if time in one of the critical resources for biomedical image analysis. The  paper shows through various experiments that  full networks with quantized  weights and activations  are significantly better than  a network with  floating-point (32-bit) weights and activations. For example, quantizing weights and activations reduce  memory  requirements  by 4x, memory requirements by 8x, and runtime by 3-30x, depending on input size and   computational complexity  of each image. The paper  also includes a  discussion of the performance impact of different weight  and activation bit-depth trade-offs. The results of the experiments show that  the network architecture proposed here for biomedical segmentation  is significantly  faster than existing  fully convolutional biomedical segmentation  networks, while maintaining accuracy.

The  realization of ultracold quantum gases with intrinsic  Rashba spin-orbit coupling is a crucial  milestone  towards the simulation of topological phenomena   in  non-interacting quantum matter with  ultracold atoms. The  key features that lead to  topological properties,  such as the  existence of   topological edge states, are the   non-trivial quantum geometry of  the underlying  Bloch Hamiltonian and the spin-orbit coupling term in the  Hamiltonian of the gas. An essential element in  this setup is how the spin-orbit coupling  between electrons in solids is effectively realized as a contact interaction via a  Feshbach resonance. To  date, there exists  no realization of such magnetic spin-orbit couplings  in cold atoms. Here  we show an effective way of simulating magnetic coupling in  bosonic alkali  atoms in the presence of a circularly polarized laser light via Raman assisted dressing of hyperfine levels   and show, using  a variational  approach, that such  a scheme supports strong interactions  between topologically localized eigenstates. This opens the way for the experimental realizations of topological properties in quantum gases with contact Rashba-like spin-orbit coupling.

We show that quantum nonlocality and entanglement
properties of a  four-Majorana-bound-state  system can be demonstrated
via the implementation   of teleportation based on a circuit.  We
introduce a  new teleportation protocol by generalizing a teleportation
protocol  based on Bell states to the four-qubit circuit. Our new
entanglement-dependent protocol is different from  the existing entanglenment-independent protocol that uses  teleportation for Bell
 state measurement.   We show that  even if  there are   local  quantum operations
allowed  by physical constraints only in a three-Majorana-bound-state
subsystem in the implementation of the four-qubit circuit, the
quantum correlation for nonlocality for the whole four-Majorana  system
can be shown.   If we do not  make any local  quantum operation  but consider
the three-Majorana system  as a set, we can find  that the Majorana
bound states are not entangled. However,  the result   of our teleportation
protocol is successful, which means that the Majoranas that are
not entangled  among themselves  can  be used   for quantum
teleportation. Therefore, the teleportation protocol based on the
4-qubit Majorana system without   any local quantum operation in  the
circuit suggests a new way to teleport the  quantum state  even  if we
cannot obtain a fully entangled Majorana system.

A: In general, Majorana fermions would be  used in the creation of a Fault Tolerant  Quantum Computer since they are the easiest fermions to entangle with  other fermions but don't  need to be protected by an environment that  doesn't corrupt their phase. Thus, one might  have a  Majorana qubit, or a Majorana-based  qubit. It is theorized  that Majorana-based qubits  do not  need to have their spins measured and   reset when two  qubits are entangled since the  Majoranas that make up both qubits  will  simply interact with the Majorana pair that forms the  computer's environmental  null  or "ground"  energy.

We present Gen-LaneNet, a  generalized and scalable approach for 3D lane detection and tracking in outdoor  scenes. Our approach provides  unified models for static scenes without dynamic obstacles,  dynamic scenes, and complex scenes with significant viewpoint change. Gen-LaneNet is also capable  of online  adaptation,  which is essential for fast-moving ego-vehicle lane tracking  problems. Furthermore, the proposed  approach  demonstrates   scalability when extending   to  multiple lanes. Extensive experimental results show that  Gen-LaneNet  achieves  state-of-the-art performance in  a broad range of different 3D lane detection and tracking scenarios.

The following is the  full text of the abstract for research paper titled  "Hierarchical Cross-View Stereo and Structure-from-Motion for Self-Localization with  a Moving Camera" from arxiv.org:
Current approaches to self-localization of a  moving camera  with structure  from motion can suffer from  drift for scenes where  camera movement is significant compared to the  scene's features. Additionally, in  some scenes, such as those  with significant motion blur caused  by high ego-motion, methods such  as direct feature matching  are not  suitable and alternative methods,  such as indirect  methods based on epipolar geometry must be applied. However, the use of epipolar geometry  requires the estimated camera-to-map pose to be fixed, which is not the case in the general case.
In this paper, we propose a method which performs  localization by combining  the benefits of  both direct and indirect motion estimates. We make this  possible  by applying the hierarchical stereo estimator  from Couprie et al. (2018), thus enabling the efficient  estimation of local camera egomotion independent  of  a fixed map pose. Specifically, our approach relies on epipolar  geometry to generate an indirect  motion estimate which improves the local scene reconstructions and  the image similarity values  of the stereo-correspondences  of Couprie et al.  (2018).
Our contribution  enables the efficient self-localization   of a moving camera  in real-time, allowing  for the  self-localization of complex scenes with high  ego-motion where traditional direct  match-based methods  would not

We  present a new  deep  learning method for cardiac  cine MR image segmentation. Our method consists of  a three-module  cascaded network for coarse-to-fine segmentation. The first module  of the network is a dense prediction-based  recurrent convolutional network for  coarse segmentation. Then, the  region-aware residual network (R2U-Net) [36] is integrated  into the second module of  the network to refine the segmentation results. Specifically, we designed a distance map regularization loss  to force  the R2U-Net to preserve more  sharp structures and reduce the  blurring. Finally, the third module, a  graph convolutional neural network (GCN),  is used to regularize the predicted segmentation results with respect to the segmentation labels. The GCN is a fast-implementation of the conditional random field. By incorporating three-stage cascaded learning,  we aim to take advantage of the dense supervision for coarse segmentation, the region-aware residual learning for detailed refinement, and  the graph refinement for post-refinement,  thus leading  to more  accurate segmentation results.
Our    main contribution  is to design a multi-stage learning strategy to use the advantages of each single module to achieve improved segmentation. In addition,  we design a new loss function named distance map regularization  and a graph refinement model based  on GCN. Our  proposed method achieves higher  segmentation accuracy and faster inference time.  Also,  in  terms of uncertainty estimation, we achieve  better  performance compared to other methods.

In clinical practice, radiologists often  face  high uncertainties on the accurate radiation dose estimation due to the lack of information such as the effective dose.  This study  investigated  a deep-learning-based  solution for  accurate  estimation of  the radiation dose of the brain MRI. In this study,  we developed a convolutional neural network  (CNN)-based  method using radiomics features as  the    input, and obtained  a  dose prediction model to predict the effective dose. The architecture of our  CNN model consisted of an input layer,  nine convolution-max pooling layers, two dense layers, and  an output  layer.  We  trained this  model using a dataset that  included the radiomics features extracted from  a training dataset  and  the dose  values. We then tested the  learned CNN  model

This study investigates the use   of  dilated convolutions  in  neural networks for left atrial segmentation in three-dimensional gadolinium enhanced-magnetic resonance imaging (3D GE-MRI). The aim  is to improve the accuracy and efficiency of the segmentation process. We  trained a deep learning model   using 2D and 3D  convolutional layers with different  dilation rates, and evaluated its performance  on a dataset of 30 patients. Our results show  that incorporating dilated convolutions significantly improves the dice similarity  coefficient compared to models without dilated convolutions. Additionally, we  found that increasing the  dilation rate  leads to better segmentation  outcomes. Overall, our approach  provides an effective solution for left atrial segmentation in  3D GE-MRI utilizing state-of-the-art  network  architectures.

AttentionBoost is  a   method  that  enhances fully convolutional networks by learning what to attend to  in an image. It uses a boosting approach to iteratively refine the  network's attention map, leading to improved performance on  various computer vision tasks. By  incorporating attention mechanisms  into the  network, AttentionBoost allows for more efficient and accurate processing of  visual information, making  it a valuable tool for a range of applications in computer vision.

This research examines the relationship between supersymmetry and the topological   properties of eigenfunctions in the context of  the  planar quantum pendulum. By analyzing the  Schrödinger equation  via semiclassical methods, we reveal that a hidden symmetry manifests itself through specific topologial  structures within the wave  functions associated with discrete energy levels.  Our findings shed new light on the role of symmetries in shaping the spectral and   dynamical features of nonlinear systems, providing  insights   into  potential applications ranging  from condensed matter physics to high-energy particle interactions.

Utilizing techniques from algebraic  topology, we analyze these  structures to better understand their  significance  within the broader context of geometry processing tasks  involving complex spatial arrangements. The  study seeks to contribute positively   towards  advancing current understanding regarding mathematical models applicable across diverse problem domains ranging  between computer graphics animation workflows up through applied physics  simulations concerned with  manipulating realistic fluid dynamics representations  while preserving  desired perceptual  coherence cues known collectively as 'combinging effects'.
