A plan to reduce the number of public holidays in Turkey sparked violent  protests overnight, with dozens of people injured.

The government's shock move to  ax the nation's much-loved public holidays was met with fury, with thousands taking  to the streets. 

Five people were killed and  two helicopters were shot down in the  protests.

It  was  the deadliest outbreak of political violence   in modern Turkish history.

At least 230 people  were  injured when   protesters, angered by the decision, hurled rocks  and firebombs at  police in the capital, Ankara, and  the  largest city, Istanbul. 

In a desperate bid  to  quell  the violence, Prime Minister Recep  Tayyip  Erdogan agreed to  review the decision, but  this was rejected  by the protesters who pressed on with their demonstrations, leaving scores more injured.

The protests come  at  a time when the  government is pushing ahead with   a  package  of controversial reforms that critics say will curb  democracy in the country.

The package, which envisages tougher restrictions  on the internet, tighter control of  the media and limits on the right to strike, has also provoked widespread anger. 

The proposals have yet to be approved by  parliament, but correspondents say  the government appears to be  using the elephant in  the room - the  issue of public holidays - to  divert attention from its wider reform   drive.

House prices in Britain have rebounded after a slowdown induced by the  initial lockdown, according to figures    from the Halifax.

The mortgage lender said prices in November were  up 7.1% compared with  the same  month in 2019, the fastest annual  growth rate for almost two years.

Compared  with  October, prices were up 1.2%, with the average house price now £270,027.

Lockdown  restrictions have  been blamed for slowing the market earlier this year.

However, figures from other measures, such  as the Office for National  Statistics, put annual house  growth at a  lower level.

"While  the immediate impact of the first lockdown was to  slow the market,  property prices have since recovered and  have reached a new  high," said Russell Galley, managing director of the Halifax.

"Overall, 2020  has been a  record year for house  prices, with annual growth exceeding 7% for the first time in eight years."

He added that low borrowing   costs appeared to be supporting demand,  with the average  mortgage rate hovering at a record low.

Industry body  UK Finance said on Tuesday that buyers  with large deposits  were  now benefiting from the lowest  mortgage rates  ever recorded.

However,  it said first-time buyers were  struggling to get  on the ladder as the cost of deposits rose.

Over the past month,  the average  price of a  detached property increased by 2.1% compared with 0.6% for flats.

London continued to see a slower pace of  growth than other parts of the  UK, with prices increasing by  just over  5%  compared  with November  2019.

The fastest growth was recorded  in Wales, where  prices were  up more  than 11% on the  year,  followed by the North West of England with 8.6% growth.

Tim Hewitt's hopes of a first  title  since 2002 were dramatically saved by comeback kid Greg  Nalbandian at the  Legg Mason Tennis  Classic   in Washington.

The Australian  veteran  looked dead  and buried against the American lucky loser, trailing by a set and 5-2 down,  before  reeling off five  straight games to level.

Hewitt, the world number  16, went on  to edge  a final-set tie-break  and win 6-7 (4/7) 6-4 7-6 (7/4) in three hours  and 18 minutes.

The 30-year-old  has  now won his last eight three-set matches, boosting his chances of  making Australia's  Olympic  team.

Nalbandian, who replaced injured Frenchman  Paul-Henri Mathieu, appeared to  be heading for only   his  second ATP Tour final when he took the opening set on a tie-break.

The world number 41 seemed to have momentum   firmly on his side when he broke Hewitt to love to go 5-2  up  in  the second set but the  Australian fought back to win the next five games.

Hewitt broke Nalbandian again to take the second set and the match went with serve in a tense final set until  the Australian  broke to go 6-5  up and served out to love to take  the match.

"I had to fight hard to get back into the match,"  said Hewitt, who saved a Nalbandian  match  point at  5-6  down in the final set.

"He's a dangerous player and I knew I had to play well  to win. It was  a tough match and hopefully I've done enough to  win this tournament."

Former British Prime Minister Tony Blair has announced a   donation of £165,000 ($250,000) to the Help Us Help  You  (HURY) charity, which is currently assisting victims of the  tsunami in  Indonesia.

The charity, which is based in the UK,  is aiming  to raise £5m to build a 500-bed tsunami memorial hospital in the hard-hit Indonesian city  of Banda Aceh.

Mr  Blair  said £250,000 of the money would come  from the  Tony Blair Faith  Foundation, with  the rest coming from the Blair Family Charitable Trust.

"I have  been  profoundly moved by the wave of  public support in the UK and around the world for the people of Indonesia,  Sri Lanka,  India and  Thailand," Mr Blair said in  a statement.

"And  I am proud  that Britain has led   the way in providing practical help to these countries."

UK  Minister for  Asia and the Pacific  Mark Field said  the former prime minister's  donation was "most welcome".

"The UK public and the  government have been  very swift in responding to  the disaster in Indonesia and elsewhere," he said.

The HURY charity  was  founded in 2005 by £1 coins thrown into  London's Westminster Abbey by   the late  Queen Elizabeth II and then-Prince Charles to mark the 60th anniversary  of the  end of  World War Two.

The organisation, whose patron is the Duchess of Cornwall, aims to build a new  24-hour, seven-day-a-week hospital in Aceh, where many healthcare   facilities were damaged or destroyed by  the tsunami.

The new facility will  be  named the "Queen Elizabeth II Jubilee Hospital" in honour of the late monarch.

The chief executive,  chief financial officer and chief operating  officer of Aer Lingus have stepped down.

The Irish airline said Sean Doyle,  Colin  Murphy and Peter  Hamilton  had left "with immediate effect" following  "a formal review" of   the  company's executive team.

Aer Lingus,  which is owned by International Airlines Group (IAG), added that the move was part of  a "refreshed leadership  team" at the carrier.

The departures come weeks   after the  airline  announced a new expansion plan.

Mr Doyle had been chief  executive since  August 2015.

Aer Lingus  said Michael Cawley, who has  been chairman of the airline since May 2019, would lead the management team until   a new chief executive is appointed.

The airline also said it was beginning the search  for a new   chief  financial officer and chief operating officer "in the coming days".

Last month, Aer Lingus launched a  new expansion plan which it said would  see it fly to Manchester, Birmingham and Bristol from  Dublin, and to Birmingham  and  Bristol from Cork, by 2021.

At the time,  Mr Doyle said the plans would deliver  more  than 400 new  jobs in direct employment.

Aer Lingus also announced in December that it  would cease its service between  Dublin  and Hartford, Connecticut,  in the summer  of  2019.

Founded in 1936,  Aer Lingus  is the flag carrier of Ireland and operates flights to more than 100 destinations, including destinations in the UK, Europe and North America.

It  was bought by  IAG, which  also owns British Airways and  Iberia, in 2015.

Mexicans tracking unhappy Juninho

Rio de Janeiro,  31 May 2001 (RIA Novosti) - Mexicans are planning to  march on Rio  de Janeiro during the forthcoming Copa America  soccer tournament to bring back hydraulic engineer Juninho, who plays for Brazilian club Botafogo.

That is  the promise  of Mexico's   ambassador to Brazil, Jose Augustin Martin Gross, who says he has been surprised by the strength of feeling shown by Mexicans.

Gross said the  embassy  had received  more than 300 letters and e-mails from Mexican fans urging it  to help bring  the player  back to his original club  Cruz  Azul.

He said the player  should be happier in Mexico, where the  climate is more suitable  for  someone suffering from rheumatoid arthritis, than in Brazil.

The 22-year-old midfielder has been  in Rio  since  January  after  being transferred to Botafogo for  12 million dollars.

He has failed to settle in Brazil and has spoken of his desire to  return   to Mexico.

The  Labour party accused another  Labour MP of allegedly involving  himself  in a  plot to destabilise  the party  yesterday, as the embattled leader, Tony Blair,   continued a series of meetings with Jewish  community  leaders aimed at  calming their fears about his party.

This came as Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, received  a symbolic vote of confidence from his backbenchers yesterday, after  suggestions that he had sought  to undermine Mr Blair.

One  backbencher said information had  been sent to all Labour MPs revealing that  Mr Brown had telephoned Jack Dromey, the deputy general secretary of the Transport  and General Workers Union, to demand that  union funding be  stopped from Labour  MPs critical of the government.

China's  biggest  spirits maker, Kweichow Moutai,  has signed a deal to boost its presence  in Italy's booming   wine market by distributing its products through  Illva Saronno,  one of the country's oldest and biggest liquor companies.

The partnership, sealed on  Thursday, gives Illva Saronno, producer of the Disaronno liqueur,  distribution rights to Moutai's portfolio of baijiu,  a distilled grain   spirit usually made from  sorghum.

Illva said  in a statement that the partnership aimed to  "strengthen the presence  of both companies on their  respective home markets and to develop business opportunities in third  countries".

Moutai, whose fiery liquor is a favourite tipple  of China's  ruling Communist  Party elite, has been looking to expand its global  footprint.

The company's lustre has dimmed somewhat in China in recent  months as its flagship baijiu  product has  fallen  out of  favour with some younger consumers, who have turned to   imported spirits such as  Scotch whisky.

However,  it remains immensely popular in China,  with its sales jumping 25% in the first half of  2022,  and  it  is hoping to win  over  new consumers in Europe and elsewhere.

Chinese drinks companies have  been looking to expand abroad as domestic consumption slows and foreign sales of  Chinese spirits, wine and beer are growing quickly.

China's beer giant  Budweiser Brewing  Co Ltd, formed by the merger of Budweiser and local giant Tsingtao, has said  it aims to become one of the world's top 10  beer companies within a  decade.

In  July, Budweiser Brewing signed a deal  with Coca-Cola Co's Costa coffee chain to roll out  a  line of coffee-flavoured drinks in China.

Martina Hingis gave hints  of   a brilliant career when she won the 1997 Wimbledon ladies'  single title as an  unseeded 17-year-old. 

The  Swiss player claimed a total of five  Grand Slam titles, 41 singles titles and a silver medal  at the  2000 Olympic Games in Sydney  before retiring in 2002  aged 22. 

But on Thursday, the  41-year-old  announced on social  media that she will be making an unexpected return to  tennis this month   at the Billie  Jean  King Cup  in Prague.

Hingis will  be representing Switzerland alongside world number 63 Jil Teichmann, Leonie Küng, and Joanne Züger.  "It's time to put on my  team  jersey  again," Hingis posted on Instagram.

The iconic  tennis player retired from the sport for a second time in November 2018 to focus on her  family. 

Hingis has won three Grand Slam titles in women's doubles and six Grand Slam  titles  in mixed doubles.

The BBC can reveal the Premier   League club paid him a total  of £3,475,000,  including   £2,925,000 in deferred payments. The £775,000  interest-free loan - which has now been paid back   - was the largest outstanding amount owed to any Premier League manager.

Figures   released by clubs for the period between 1 February 2021  and 31 January 2022  show Hague's  earnings  ranked behind only Manchester City boss Pep Guardiola, who earned £10,275,000.

Hague  was appointed as  the  Tigers'  head coach  in June 2021,  replacing Grant McCann, who  departed to take charge of Championship club Doncaster Rovers.

Hull  were then relegated from the  Premier League, finishing bottom of the table in the 2020-21 season.

The club earned £34,610,000 in total  player wages during the period, including £6,870,000 in  agent fees and have since been sold to Acun Ilicali for £37m.

Italy have plenty of  reasons to feel confident as they prepare to  face England in their Euro 2020 quarter-final on Saturday.

Not only do  they have a fully  fit squad to  choose from,  but the way they swept aside a highly  rated  Belgian team 2-1  in the last 16  gives them a timely boost.

And  as  manager  Roberto Mancini pointed out on the eve  of the game at Wembley, his team have another important weapon in their arsenal:  the ability to hurt England from set  pieces.

It was, after  all, a stunning free-kick from Leonardo   Spinazzola that sparked them into life  against   Belgium, equalising just before half-time to silence a raucous  crowd in Rome. 

And  with  England having a tendency to switch off at set plays – as shown in their nail-biting 2-1 win  over Germany in  the last 16 – it is certainly a chink in their  armoury that Italy plan to exploit.

“We have some weapons [from set pieces] and we have  prepared well for them, because England are physically very strong  and they often attack  from  set pieces,” Mancini said. 

Italy may have been  on the back foot  for long  periods of their  last-16  tie, but they  still created  the better  chances against Belgium –  and should have been  out   of sight by the time Spinazzola struck. 

Mancini’s men will be more assertive  against England, particularly in the first half, and they have the weapons to cause Gareth Southgate’s side problems. 

Italy have plenty of height and physicality  in  their team, but it is the intelligence and movement of their centre-forward Ciro Immobile that is  most impressive. 

He  does not merely   occupy two  centre-backs and wait for the  ball to come  to him; instead, he tends to move around and force the opposition into making mistakes  in dangerous areas.

His header from Marco Verratti’s cross was inches away  from giving Italy the lead against Belgium, and he is due a goal  at this  tournament  after working tirelessly in the opening  group  games.

Immobile, who scored 36  goals  in 38  games  for Lazio last season, is  likely  to  be Italy’s biggest  threat on Saturday. 

The 29-year-old has  excellent movement  and finds space in the  area,  and he is confident both  with  his back to goal and  when running in behind.

He will look to get  on the end of the many crosses

With eight nominations, R&B  superstar Usher has topped the list of  contenders for this year's Billboard Music Awards.

The 35-year-old singer is  up for top honours -   top artist, top male artist and top Billboard 200 artist - at the ceremony in May, alongside   the likes of Taylor Swift, Drake and  Katy Perry.

This year's awards mark the comeback of a once-rejiggered ceremony, which premiered on ABC last year after a brief hiatus.  

The 2017 Billboard Music Awards will be held at the T-Mobile Arena in Las Vegas on  21 May. The three-hour ceremony will be  hosted  by Ludacris and broadcast live   on  ABC.

This year's nominations were announced on Tuesday by singer  Ciara  and Billboard chairman John Amato  on Good Morning America.

Seven-time  Grammy winner  Usher's nominations include top  R&B artist, top R&B album for Hard II  Love and top R&B song for his feature  on DJ Khaled's new hit, Do You Mind.

The singer, who rose to fame in the 1990s with the  release of his debut album, Usher, said he was "thankful"  for the recognition.

"It's   a blessing. It's unbelievable," he told Billboard ahead of the  nominations announcement.  "It's tough in this business  to be acknowledged  and to be recognised, so  I'm just happy to be  recognised in  such a grand  way."

Usher, who has sold more than 65 million records worldwide, scored his eighth straight  top 10 album last  year with Hard II Love, despite  competition from the likes of  Drake,  Rihanna  and Kanye West.

The singer is  set to go head-to-head  with his young protege, Bieber, in  the  race for top R&B song. DJ Khaled's Do You Mind,  which  also features Nicki  Minaj and August Alsina,  is up against  Bieber's Pfizer vaccine advertisement  Save Yourselves, in which Usher  also makes a  cameo.

Usher isn't the only veteran artist who has been recognised  by Billboard  this year.

Forty-one years after his death, Elvis Presley is in the  running for  top  rock artist alongside   Radiohead, Metallica and Pearl Jam.

Dubbed "the people's princess" by Amato,  Britney  Spears  is up  for top touring artist alongside    Justin Bieber, Beyonce, Coldplay and Lady Gaga & Tony  Bennett

The festive holidays are a time for  many to relax and celebrate with family and  friends, but they can  also be a time of stress  and pressure. With the  cost of   living crisis continuing to impact households across the  UK, many are facing a choice  between  eating and   heating this winter. 

So, how  can we save our festive holidays?  This article discusses some  of the ways people  can  reduce the financial and emotional stress associated with  the festive holidays. It offers tips on  budgeting, managing expectations, and seeking support.  

The UK is not alone in facing these challenges. Many  countries around  the world  are also experiencing  an  increase in  the cost of living. And,  while the festive holidays may look different this year, there  are still ways to enjoy them without breaking the bank. By being mindful of our spending and reaching  out to others for support, we can make the most of  this time. 

So, let's work  together to make this  festive season a memorable  one. Here's to a happy and  healthy holiday  season!

House prices have risen at the fastest rate in almost six years, according  to   a  survey by mortgage lender Halifax.

The bank said  prices  in the  three months to the end of  November  were 7.1%  higher than a year earlier,  the  strongest growth since June 2016.

However, it added that the market had  probably peaked and  that growth would slow next year.

Hotter weather, vaccinations and  post-pandemic shifts in housing preferences have all helped drive the market recently.

House prices have surged this year as people sought more space after lockdowns. They have   also been  boosted by  a  shortage of  properties for sale.

But Halifax said the number of property sales agreed had fallen  by 5.3% in October, the second  month of decline. The  number of new properties coming on to the market had also slowed, it said.

'Demand exceeds supply'

"The rise  in house prices seen this year has  been fuelled by a race for  space, with people swapping urban living for bigger homes in the suburbs and  further  afield," said  Halifax managing director   Russell Galley.

"Looking ahead, the  pace   of  inflation  is likely  to have an impact on household spending power, particularly with the recent interest rate rise, and  this is likely to feed through  into  the housing  market, slowing  price growth next  year."

In response to being told that  lenders had been wary of  forecasting a fall in house prices over the  past  year, he said: "I think  the  market conditions have changed.

"I think the pricing, the valuation, the sentiment - I think that's  changed.  And  clearly, when you're in the midst of a housing boom,  it is very difficult to call the top of the market."

 Rebecca Rutt, partner  and head of residential at property agent  Hamptons, said: "We  are starting to see signs that the rush to secure a forever home is  beginning to slow, with  demand gradually easing back  to more normal levels."

She  said that in  the more normal market conditions of 2019, house  prices increased by 1.5% in November, "so the annual rate of price growth is  already starting to slow".

Ms   Rutt added: "First-time  buyers will welcome slower growth,  as this should improve the chances of  securing a  property.  However, we expect the pace of  price growth to  slow  rather  than prices falling, as there is still a supply shortage."

General  Motors  has issued  a safety recall  for  a number of its vehicles  due to an issue with the ignition switch. The  recall affects a range of models including the Chevrolet Silverado, Chevrolet   Impala, Chevrolet Cruze, Buick LaCrosse, Buick  Regal, Cadillac XTS, and Cadillac CTS.

According to GM, the ignition switch may   malfunction and cause the vehicle to stall, which could  result in a crash. The company has advised owners of the affected  vehicles to take them to  a local dealer for  a free repair.

This latest recall is just  one of several that GM has issued in  recent years, and has raised concerns about the  safety of the company's vehicles. Despite these  issues, GM continues to claim that the safety of  its customers is its top priority.

In response to the recall, GM has said  that it  is working with  its  suppliers   to  identify and address the issue with the ignition switch. The company has also announced that it will be offering   a free loaner vehicle  to owners of the affected vehicles while  they  are being  repaired.

Sales  of beer and cider have fallen to their  lowest levels since 2011,  the British Beer  &  Pub  Association (BBPA) has said. 

The  trade body  said brewers'  profits had been hit by the  double whammy of  rising costs and falling sales.  It is calling on the government  to give the sector greater support, including by reducing beer duty in the  upcoming Budget. 

The BBPA said beer duty, a tax on the production of beer, which was due  to rise again  in 2023,  should   be frozen to help brewers weather the current "perfect  storm" of cost increases and falling sales. 

The industry  is also   facing  a shortage of truck drivers, which is  causing deliveries to  be delayed, as  well as an  increase in the cost of ingredients and energy  prices. 

 PUB  CURFEW

On Sunday, Health Secretary Sajid Javid announced that  Covid passes would  be required to enter nightclubs and other crowded indoor venues in England.  

He said this would create "a bouncer at  the door, hopefully to keep  people in rather than keep people out". 

Mr  Javid said, "We're not locking  people down, we're  not closing  businesses.  We're trying to give them  the  tools to continue to  be open." 

The BBC's politics correspondent, Jessica  Parker, said the   announcement meant plans for a "pub curfew" had been ditched.

She  said some government figures believed the move would help to ease anger among  Tory MPs over the introduction of Covid passes.

Beer duty accounts for about 11% of the cost of a  pint of beer and analysts say cancelling the 2% above-inflation rise in duty would keep  down the cost  of a pint  by about 1p.

The BBPA is also calling on the government to extend the 12.5%  rate of VAT  on  hospitality beyond the  end of March and  to  cut  the level of tax on alcohol  by 2%. 

It said the combined effect  of the tax changes would help keep  down the  cost of  a pint by about 22p  and help turn around the decline in  beer sales.

Apple introduced  a new, cheaper iPod model on Monday, marking the  first addition to the iPod product line in two and a half years.  The new iPod classic,  available in  40GB  and 80GB sizes,  joins  the iPod nano  and iPod shuffle in the company's digital  music player lineup. "We're excited to bring the total iPod  family to three great products," said Greg Joswiak,   Apple's  vice  president of hardware product marketing. 

The new iPod classic gives customers  around the world another   option for enjoying their entire digital  music collections,  in  addition to the market-leading iPod nano and iPod shuffle. Over  55 million iPods  have  been sold to  date. "Customers  are going to love the new iPod  classic -- it's an incredible all-in-one  digital music player with all  the passion and all the heritage of the entire  iPod family,"  Joswiak said.

The new iPod  classic retains the  original iPod's familiar scroll wheel and intuitive navigation. The larger, 80GB   model holds  up to 40,000 songs, or 200 hours of video,  as well as thousands of photos. The 40GB model holds  up to 20,000 songs or 100 hours  of video, along with  thousands of photos.

Both models offer audio controls for playing songs and podcasts, a Cover  Flow™ viewing mode  that allows users to scroll  through  album  art and select an  album by its cover, and the ability to easily create and edit playlists on the go.  iPod classic users can also choose from a wide selection of accessories, including speakers, headphones,  and carrying cases.

The dollar dropped  on  Thursday as concerns  grew that the  Federal Reserve  might soon start to dial  back its ultra-loose monetary policy, with investors also  cautious  ahead of crucial U.S. jobs data.

The dollar index, which measures  the  greenback against  a basket of six currencies, was down  0.1% at 94.66, falling for a second straight day,  having  peaked at 95.56  earlier this month - its highest level  since July 2020.

 Traders said the  dollar's recent weakness was due  to a cautious mood ahead of the U.S.  November jobs report later on  Friday, with the focus on wage growth - a key indicator for inflation. Rising   wages could  keep the Fed  on its current  path of tightening its monetary policy.

"The dollar is  not going to  go into a steep decline, but  it's not attractive anymore," said Commerzbank analyst Antje  Praefcke, adding that the market had  reached its peak anticipation for Fed tightening.

The Fed has  already started to taper its massive bond purchases, and Fed  Chair Jerome Powell has signalled that the central bank could start raising interest rates as  soon as its next meeting in  mid-December.

Market  participants now expect a 91% chance of  a rate  hike   in June, and a  68% chance of another hike in   September, according to the CME's FedWatch tool.

Rory McIlroy's second major triumph  of the year continued  after he secured his first major win since 2011 at the Honda Classic at Silverstone.

After an opening nine holes that left him four strokes  behind the   pace set by  Tiger  Woods, he continued to edge the  field to claim his first green jacket at the event.

He  later claimed another major win, adding a £300,000 prize  money to his £9.1m from five  majors.

After  a solid opening round,  McIlroy  shot 71 off the front of the field to finish T2 behind Woods who was five back.

"The confidence  was there in the first few rounds but I have to be proud of the way I finished - especially considering the circumstances," he  said.

"I felt like he and others were holding   me back and that  gave me a huge chip on  my shoulder. I  was on  the  back foot and had to really focus on my  shot and my  driving."

The Scot, 31,  has now won six and  is   now just five behind the record  for   the most majors secured in a  career - all while averaging  just 9.75  over 60 starts.

In a year when McIlroy has claimed  a number of important   victories  - including his first WGC-Cadillac  Championship victory  last February - it came as a surprise when he opted   to back up the victory with another.

A move to a  course  that had little chance of   producing a win didn't help either - but his confidence was on  the rise thanks to a win between two World Golf Championships Tournaments.

And after another solid start he seemed  to  be making  a dent in the  long-term plan of Woods to make a  comeback.

At one  stage it looked as though the US Open champion  was poised to claim his  14th major title before an early  mishit at the 11th  added to his woes.

There was some hope the course at Riviera Country Club, in Florida, had improved  after some encouraging  signs on  18, but McIlroy was in no-man's land  with  the shot on  19 and, to  his credit,  he didn't let go of hope at that point.

By  the middle of the  last week McIlroy became  the fastest  player ever to win at seven straight Majors

Liverpool manager Kenny Dalglish has told his players that goalkeeper Pepe Reina  will not be sold.

Reina joined Liverpool  for £16.4million in 2007,  but since returning to Serie A he  has been used sparingly  as Jurgen Klopp's team  struggles for  goals.

However, with Liverpool looking set to miss out on one top-four finish this  season and their first Champions  League place since  2009,  he  will almost  certainly have an extended stay at  Anfield.

A new  type of brain-computer interface  (BCI)  has been developed  by scientists in the US, which uses  electrical pulses to control  computers and other devices. The device works  by sending out tiny bursts of electricity  through electrodes on  the scalp  that  stimulate neurons in the   brain. It could be  used  for controlling prosthetic limbs or even helping people with  Parkinson's disease regain some movement. Researchers at the University of California, San Diego have demonstrated  the   technology  using rats, but say  it should work equally well in humans within five  years. "We're  not  talking about a  magic wand here,"  said Dr Michael  Merzenich, who led the research team. "This  is something you can put on your head." The researchers hope  their system will eventually allow patients to  use computers without having  to wear  bulky headsets. They are also working on ways to make the BCI  more comfortable  for   users.

In   addition to being able to control computers, this BCI would also be useful  for treating Parkinson's Disease. This is because the disease causes the loss of  dopamine  receptors in  the brain, which leads to tremors and  rigidity.  In order  to treat  Parkinson's, doctors must inject chemicals into the patient's body that  block these receptors. However, if the drug is administered too early, it may cause side  effects such as nausea, vomiting,  and  diarrhea. If the medication is given  too late, however,  the symptoms may become worse.

If the BCI were to be implanted under the skin, it  would be much easier to administer the drugs. Furthermore, since the BCI would  only need to be activated  once every few  days, it  would be less  likely to cause side effects than injecting the drugs every day.

However, there are still many questions surrounding this BCI.  For example, how long does the stimulation last? How do the signals  travel between the brain and the  electrode caps? What happens when  the signal reaches the   cap? And what happens if the signal  is interrupted? These are all important questions that  need to be  answered before  we can truly understand how this BCI might help people with Parkinson's Disease.

UK officials had been  hoping  for a breakthrough by the end of the week which would permit them  to send back suspects. As it turned out, they got  none. Theresa May, the Home  Secretary, said today  that Britain would not be sending  anyone back "for these  people are UK residents". She defended the immigration system against charges that it  discriminates against those with suspected ties to terrorism – and  said: "Those  who  seek to exploit this  system  to  gain  uncontrolled entry to the UK are committing a criminal  offence."

Here's  how the   BBC explained the decision:

A  Home  Office spokeswoman insisted that no British citizen  would be excluded   if  they entered Syria from Turkey, Lebanon  or Tunisia. She  said it was  not appropriate  to return British nationals to their home countries  due  to "the sheer volume of people we have had to deal with  so far". "In relation to those who  make that journey, they have our absolute assurance that  they will not be sent back –  this is the  view of the home secretary, this is the view of the government and this is the view of the intelligence agencies," she told BBC Breakfast.  The  spokeswoman said  that the Home  Office only began to  make  efforts to send back refugees in March 2015, adding that the government had not been  able to convince  all EU countries to join them in this  action. In the UK,  this could be  taken  up in Parliament or by  the new Home Secretary, Amber Rudd, she said.

Award-winning British  comedian and  actor  Russell T Davies has  been  awarded an honorary doctorate by the University of Cambridge, in recognition of his contribution to the  arts. The university said it was "delighted" that he   had received the  honour. Professor David Starkey, vice chancellor at  the  university, said: "Russell's  work as a writer and performer on Doctor Who has made him one of  the most popular and respected figures in contemporary comedy." He  added: "His wit and intelligence have helped make Doctor Who  such a successful programme for over 50  years."

I'm not  sure  what this means exactly, but I  think  we  can all agree that Russell T Davies is a  genius.

The former Prime Minister Tony Blair and  the former Home Secretary David Blunkett have been  invited to visit Sheffield for a  week-long visit.

The pair will visit  the city on Monday  and Tuesday, and  will be joined by a number  of other  prominent figures.

The  visit  is  part of a wider tour of the UK, which  will  also include visits to Liverpool, Manchester and Birmingham.

The visit  will be the first time Mr Blair and Mr Blunkett have visited  the city since leaving Downing Street in 2007.

The pair will be joined by former Labour MP   and Sheffield MP David Winnick, who is now a member of the  House of Lords.

Mr Winnick said: "I am  delighted that the former  Prime Minister Tony Blair and the former Home  Secretary David  Blunkett have  agreed to  visit Sheffield.

"I am sure that the visit will  be a great opportunity  for the people of  Sheffield to hear from the former Prime Minister and the former Home Secretary about the work  that they have done in Sheffield and the work that they   are doing in  the House of Lords."

Intel has been working on technology   to make mobile phones switch to Wi-Fi hotspots automatically rather than rely on networks to connect. The new option promises a  greater amount  of  data   but would  require more power from chips because they must communicate only with a user's handset rather than wi-fi  network infrastructure. But Intel believes users will want it    even if they are  not always in a hotspot so are making the final design of mobile hotspot  gear known  as  Project Centennial in the hope that chip makers  can help them get there  quickly when Google, Microsoft and other providers begin  rolling  out their  own wireless Internet access in  coming months.

A group of musicians have been  invited by the White House  to  help tackle America's red tape, as  part of President Barack Obama's push for  more business and jobs in the  United States.

The musicians   will  be asked to  work with government agencies to make sure that businesses can get their products to  market  quickly and  efficiently.

They are expected to meet with officials at the Department of Commerce, which oversees trade policy, and the Federal  Trade  Commission (FTC),  which enforces consumer protection laws.

The artists include The National, who recently released  their new album 'Songs For A New World', and  The  Black Keys, whose latest album 'El  Camino' was  named best album  of 2012 by  Rolling Stone magazine.

The White House said it hoped the musicians would use their experience to help improve the way the country does business.

It comes after  Mr Obama announced  plans last year  to cut the time it takes  to process  patent applications  by half.

He also wants to speed up the approval of medical devices and reduce the    cost  of imported goods.

The  earnings of Foreign   Secretary  William Hague have been revealed in the register  of MPs' interests.

The list shows he   received £140,000 for writing a book about his time as leader of the  Conservative Party.

He also  got £22,916  for after-dinner speeches and £15,000 for two articles for the Daily Telegraph.

Italian drinks group Illva Saronno is  to buy a majority stake in a Chinese wine producer as it looks to tap into the country's   growing appetite for the tipple.

The   maker of the  popular Disaronno liqueur said it  would pay €20m  ($22.6m;  £14.6m) for a  51% stake in Great Wall.

The deal comes as China's wine market is forecast to grow by a fifth this year.

Illva said the  move would help  it become a "leading player" in the Chinese market.

The company, which also owns the Martini vermouth brand, said it  would  invest a further €10m in Great Wall over the next three years.

"This is a  strategic investment for Illva  in one   of the most interesting and fastest-growing markets   in the world," said chief executive Paolo Marchesini.

"It  will enable  us to become a leading player in the premium segment of  the  Chinese wine market."

Great Wall, which is based  in Shandong province  in  eastern China,  produces  about 10m bottles  of wine a year.

Its wines are currently sold in more  than 20 countries,  including the US,  Canada, Australia and Japan.

The deal  is expected  to be  completed by the end of  the year.

The Oscar-nominated actor  Michael J Fox   is  backing plans for a new theatre in the town where he grew  up.

The Back to the   Future star has donated money to the fundraising campaign for the proposed Michael J Fox Theatre in Burnaby, British Columbia.

The 1,200-seat venue would stage  everything from  musicals to  comedy shows.

Fox, who was born in  Edmonton,  Alberta, but moved to Burnaby as a child, said   the theatre would  be a "great asset" to the community.

"I have very fond memories of growing up in Burnaby and attending shows at the old  Burnaby Senior  Secondary School auditorium," he said in  a statement.

"A new  theatre  would be a great  asset for the entire community."

The project  is expected to cost C$60m (£34m)  and construction could begin as early  as next  year.

The future of  ballet in the  UK is  under threat,  a group of dancers has warned.

The dancers,   who are all members of the Royal Ballet, say  the art form is in decline and that there are  not enough opportunities  for young dancers to progress.

In a  letter to the Times newspaper, they  say the UK is   "losing its  position as a world  leader in ballet".

The dancers  say the government should do more to  support ballet  and invest in the  art form.

The letter has been  signed by 26  dancers, including former Royal Ballet principal   dancer Tamara Rojo and  current first soloist Francesca Hayward.

The dancers say ballet is  "facing an existential crisis" and that the art form is "in decline".

They say there are not  enough opportunities  for young  dancers to progress and that the government should do more to support ballet.

The letter has been sent to the Department for  Digital, Culture, Media and Sport,  as well as  the Arts Council England.

Car production  at Ford's European operations has fallen  by almost a quarter this year, but  the US giant  says it  is still on track to make  a profit.

Ford's European president, Nick Scheele, said the company's losses in the region had been  more than offset by strong results  from its  US finance arm.

"This year we  will make a profit in Europe and that's with   a very  significant drop in car production," he told the  BBC.

"Last year we  lost $254m  (£130m) in Europe. This  year we  will make a profit. A  lot of that is to do with the very  strong performance of our finance company in  North  America."

Ford's US finance business has been helped by  low interest rates,  which  have  allowed it to  offer cheap loans  to buyers.

The  company has also been helped by  the euro's recent weakness against the dollar, which has increased  the value of its US exports.

Despite the problems facing the European car industry, Mr Scheele said he was confident Ford would maintain its market  share in the  region.

"We're going to do that by continuing to invest  in  new products, by  continuing to  reduce our costs and by continuing to invest in our brands," he   said.

"We think we've got  the right  strategy  in place and  we're beginning to see the results of that."

Graeme Souness praised his   Rangers  players  after they secured  their place in  the last 16 of  the  UEFA Cup with a 1-1 draw against Anorthosis Famagusta.

The  Ibrox boss was particularly pleased with the display of Kris Boyd, who scored the  crucial away goal in Cyprus.

"He took his goal  superbly," Souness told BBC Scotland.

"He has got that in his locker. He has  got a knack of being in the   right place  at the right time."

Boyd's late strike cancelled out Dimitar Berbatov's first-half  opener and means Rangers go  through 2-1 on  aggregate.

"I thought we were the better team over the two  legs," Souness  said.

"We had a few scares but, in general, I thought we deserved  to go   through.

"I   am  very pleased with the character  we showed to come back from a goal down.

"It  was a fantastic team effort and, over the two legs, I thought we were the better team."

The Christmas  and New Year holidays are under  threat  from the coronavirus pandemic, the government has warned.

In a drive to  "save" the holidays, ministers  are  urging people to follow  the rule of  six and self-isolate if they have symptoms.

The advice comes as the  number of people in  hospital with Covid-19  has risen  to its  highest level  since  April.

There are now  more than 20,000 patients in England - a rise of nearly 60% in a fortnight.

Speaking at a Downing  Street news conference, Health Secretary Matt Hancock said people should "think hard" about whether their   plans for Christmas could go ahead.

He said   the government was "working hard to enable people  to  have   a good Christmas" but cautioned that   the risk of transmission of the virus  was "higher than it has been for many months".

"I  know how much people want to be with their loved ones at Christmas but we all have  to  play our part  to keep everyone safe," he said.

The government is  also urging people to download the NHS Covid-19 app, which will help  trace  contacts of people  who have tested  positive for the virus.

Ministers are also encouraging people to  get a flu jab to help relieve pressure  on the  NHS over winter.

House  prices in  the UK  have recovered slightly after a small decline in   November, mortgage lender Halifax said.

Its  house price index showed prices rose  by 0.3% in the three months to  the  end   of December, compared with the  previous quarter.

On   an annual  basis, prices increased by 5.2%,  compared with  a 4.3% rise in November.

"As expected, house prices showing some signs of stabilising," Halifax managing director Russell Galley said.

"This is in line with our view that, while activity will remain subdued in the near term,  underlying  housing  demand remains solid," he added.

The average house  price in  the UK was  £234,737 in  the three months to December, Halifax said.

In London, prices increased by 7.1%  in the  year to December, compared with a 2.5% rise in November.

The biggest annual price growth was in the South East  of England, where prices increased by 6.7%  in the year  to December.

Andy Murray is  out of Wimbledon  after a five-set thriller against Juan Carlos Ferrero.

The Scot  lost 7-5  3-6 6-1  6-7  (5-7) 6-2  in  a Centre Court  battle which lasted almost four hours.

Murray, who turns 23 on Saturday, had led by two sets  to love but his 31-year-old opponent fought back.

The former world number  one  then had two match points at 6-4 in the fourth-set tie-break but  could not convert.

Ferrero held his  nerve to take the tie-break 7-5   and level the  match, and he then broke Murray in the opening game of the  fifth  set.

The Spaniard,  a  former French Open champion, held on to his nerve to close out the  match and set  up a quarter-final against Lleyton Hewitt.

British Prime  Minister Tony Blair has pledged that the UK's aid to the Asian  tsunami victims will "dwarf" what it has given   to  other natural disasters. nations.

In a Commons statement, he announced an  extra £60m of government money - on top of  £50m  already pledged.

And he urged the UK public  to give  "very generously" to the DEC  appeal, which has so  far raised more than  £22m.

Mr  Blair described the disaster as "on an unprecedented scale".

At least 150,000   people are now known to have died in the disaster, which has  affected countries across southern  Asia.

The final death  toll is expected  to be much higher.

Three senior executives are  to leave Aer  Lingus, the airline has announced.

The  departures come as the company prepares to cut up to 1,000 jobs as part of a restructuring programme.

Head of human resources, Maeve O'Mara, chief information officer, Barry  O'Sullivan,  and chief commercial  officer, Stephen Kavanagh, will  all  leave the company.

Aer Lingus said the departures were part of a "planned management succession process".

The airline is in the  process   of finalising a  cost-cutting plan which is expected to be announced later this month.

It is understood the  company  is  looking at  a range of  options, including voluntary redundancies, a pay cut for staff  and a  reduction in the number of   flights.

Former Prime  Minister Tony Blair  has reportedly initiated a plan to win  back Jewish support  for the Labour Party. This agenda  has surfaced at   a time when  the party has been experiencing a considerable decline in popularity among Jewish voters, largely due  to accusations  of institutional anti-Semitism within the  party.

Mr. Blair,  who led  the Labour Party from 1994 to 2007, has started his   campaign by holding   private meetings with  several Jewish leaders.  It is understood these meetings  are aimed at rebuilding trust  between  the Jewish community  and   the Labour  Party. His campaign also includes hosting a  series  of talks dedicated to tackling anti-Semitism and promoting Jewish culture,  contributions, and community.

This move by Blair comes in response  to a recent poll from the Jewish Chronicle that showed 86% of Jewish voters would not consider voting for Labour in future elections. This leaves Labour with only 14% of potential  Jewish votes - a figure that has alarmed party officials  and triggered Blair's  action plan.

Mr.  Blair's spokesperson confirmed that the  former prime minister believes the issues  affecting the relationship between Labour and the    Jewish  community "must be confronted  head on".

"The Labour party has always stood  for equality, justice, and  respect for all communities," said  the spokesperson. "Mr. Blair is well-aware of the challenges ahead but  believes  dialogue  and  open discussions are  key to resolving these problems."

Commenting on the issue, a Jewish leader who wished to remain anonymous, said: "We need proof that the Labour Party  values the Jewish community and that  it is taking  concrete steps to fight  anti-Semitism. Words mean nothing without action."

In  his   attempt to court  Jewish voters, Blair has also planned visits to synagogues and Jewish faith schools, and aims to engage with   Jewish community groups  throughout the  country. His efforts mark a significant   strategic  shift for the Labour Party that is seeking to reinvent and restore its image  in various communities.

However, the success of Blair's initiative  remains to be  seen, especially  considering Labour's recent history.  It will indeed be a challenge for the  former prime minister and the Labour Party to regain the  trust of Jewish voters still strongly dismayed by the party's perceived missteps.

Italian wine  giant Illva Saronno is being lured by the burgeoning Chinese wine market, as the Asian  country's growing middle  class develops a taste for fine wines. 

Illva Saronno, known for producing Disaronno and   Tia Maria,  is considering expanding  its  operations into China, a move that could potentially  boost its global sales and brand recognition. The company  is reportedly in talks with several Chinese wine producers and  distributors, exploring opportunities for    collaboration  and market entry.

China's wine market has  been growing rapidly over the past decade, driven by a rising middle class with increasing disposable income and a growing appreciation for Western  lifestyle and  products. According to a  report by  Vinexpo, China is expected to become the world's second-largest  wine  market by 2020, with a value of $23 billion.

Illva's interest  in China comes   as no surprise,  given the potential for growth.  The company, which  has a strong  presence in Europe and North America, has been  looking to expand its global footprint. China, with its vast consumer market and  growing taste for wine, presents a lucrative  opportunity.

However,  entering the  Chinese market  is not  without challenges. The country's complex regulatory environment, high import tariffs, and fierce  competition from both domestic and    international brands could  pose significant  hurdles for   Illva. Moreover, Chinese consumers'  wine preferences are still evolving, and it remains to be seen whether they will develop a  taste for Illva's offerings.

Despite these challenges, Illva seems undeterred.  The company's management believes that the  potential rewards outweigh the risks. They are confident that their high-quality products, combined with a strategic  approach to  market entry, will enable them to carve out a niche  in the  Chinese wine market.

Illva's move towards China is reflective of   a broader trend in the global  wine industry. As traditional markets in Europe and North America become saturated, wine producers  are  looking towards emerging  markets like  China for growth.  If successful, Illva's foray  into China could pave the way for  other Western wine producers to follow  suit.

The company has not yet released a timeline for its  potential  expansion  into China.  However, industry insiders expect  that Illva will make  a move sooner  rather than  later, given the rapid growth of the  Chinese wine market.

The gadget market is expected to witness a surge in growth in  2005, driven by a  rise in  demand  for mobile devices, gaming consoles, and  new technologies such as wireless  networking, according to market analysts.

They predict that  the gadget  industry could be the primary  beneficiary of a tentative economic recovery, as consumers spend more on  consumer  electronics  and digital devices. According to the  research, smartphone sales are expected to be particularly robust, with their integration  of new  features such as  music and video playing capabilities encouraging consumers to  upgrade their existing mobile devices.

Gaming    consoles are another area set to  experience strong growth this year,  with major releases from Sony and Microsoft anticipated. Both PlayStation 5 and Xbox  Series  X  are expected to boost  game console sales   significantly.

The growth is not only expected in developed  markets like  North America and Europe but also in emerging markets. Technological advancements  in areas like  wireless networking and the growth of the internet are driving demand  for  gadgets.   Devices like WiFi-enabled laptops, smart home  devices, digital  cameras, and  MP3  players are all predicted to  see   increased demand.

Despite the promising outlook, analysts caution that the industry could face challenges. These could include increased competition leading to a price war,  a slower-than-expected rollout of new technology,  or a sudden economic downturn.

They also express concerns for the potential for barriers to international trade due to geopolitical  tensions that can  disrupt  global supply chains. This underscores  the importance  of effective  risk management strategies in the  industry. 

Nevertheless, 2005 appears to be shaping  up to be a growth year for gadget makers.  Those companies that  are able to market their products effectively and stay ahead of technological advancements stand to benefit  the most. 

A notable aspect  of this predicted  growth is that it is not dependent on one kind of product or sector within the gadget industry.  From mobile phones and gaming consoles  to digital  cameras, it seems all gadget  markets have their part in this predicted surge.

This broad-based growth indicates  both the strength of consumer demand for digital  devices and the opportunities  for manufacturers  who  can  deliver innovative and appealing  products.  

In conclusion,  2005 seems set for booming  gadget sales, indicating a positive market trend  for tech and electronics manufacturers. But as  always, the challenges associated with  such growth should not be overlooked. Thus, it  will be interesting  to see how different companies  leverage  this favourable forecast.

Former Foreign Secretary, William Hague, who served under David Cameron from 2010 to 2014, has disclosed earnings  in excess of six figures from an array  of overseas speeches  and consultancy work.

Hague's earnings  from these sources,  separate from  his parliamentary  salary, were shown in the latest  Register of Members' Financial Interests. The register,  updated every  few weeks, helps to maintain  transparency by outlining the financial relationships and interests of parliamentary members.

Of these earnings, research suggests  that a significant proportion was earned from  lucrative speaker slots at  international conferences and functions.  According  to the register,  his  largest single payment of  £40,000 came for two speeches delivered during a trip to the United States.

The former Conservative   Party leader also drew a large income from  a variety  of consultancy roles with  multinational  corporations. His advisory role at Teneo  Intelligence, an advisory firm that helps businesses navigate political risks,  and Intercontinental Hotels Group  alone brought in £300,000 annually.

On  top of this,  Hague, who led the Conservative Party  from 1997  to 2001, served on the boards of several non-UK companies, further adding to his income.

The Register of Members’ Interests  does not include salaries  for  MPs, which are publicly  funded  and set  at £81,932.  It is intended to provide a record of any work carried   out by MPs alongside their duties in  Parliament and show where potential  conflicts of interests may exist. 

This revelation may ignite debate over whether former    ministers should  be allowed  to earn money from private companies and other  non-parliamentary work.  Critics  argue that the second job might distract them from their primary duties, while others believe it may help broaden their perspective  and expertise.

Hague's office  declined to comment on the details of his  earnings. He has  previously  defended taking on additional work, describing it as an opportunity  to gather  wider experience, which  he believed  enhances  the quality of his contribution as an  MP.

Italy's   national football team  is gearing up to  unsettle  England in their upcoming  match, as they aim to exploit any weaknesses in the English side. The Italians are  known  for  their  tactical prowess  and are expected to bring a high level of  intensity  to the game.

The Azzurri, as    the Italian team is  fondly  known, have been in  impressive form recently, with a string of victories under their belt. They are hoping to continue this  winning streak against England, a team they have had a long-standing rivalry with.

Italy's coach,  Roberto Mancini, has been working on  a  strategy to disrupt  England's  rhythm  and exploit any gaps in their defence. "We  have studied England's game closely. They are a strong team, but  like any team, they have their weaknesses.   Our aim is to  exploit those," Mancini said in a pre-match  press conference.

The  Italian team is expected to rely heavily on their experienced players, including veteran defender  Giorgio Chiellini and  midfield maestro Marco  Verratti.  Their experience and tactical understanding of the game will be crucial in unsettling the English  side.

England, on the other  hand, have a young and  dynamic team, led by captain Harry Kane. They  have shown great promise in recent matches, but the  Italian  side is confident of causing an upset.

"We respect England, but we are not afraid of them.  We have the players and  the strategy to rattle them," Mancini added.

The match is expected to  be a thrilling encounter, with  both teams  having a lot to   prove. Italy's aim  to rattle England will not only test the English side's  resilience but also make for an exciting  spectacle  for football  fans around the world.

The stakes are high, and the  tension is palpable as Italy and England prepare to face off.  Whether Italy's strategy to unsettle  England will pay off remains to be seen, but one thing is  certain - football fans are in for a  treat.

Former Liverpool and Rangers  manager, Graeme Souness,  has expressed his immense joy at the progress of European football,  praising the  numerous advancements seen throughout the sport in recent years. Souness, who contributed significantly to the development of football  both as a  player and a  manager, said he was   'over the moon' with the progression.

In  an   interview   with  BBC  Football, Souness  lauded the game's  evolution from  both a technical and strategic standpoint. He praised the  increasing  globalisation of football that   has reached unprecedented levels, mainly through European competitions like the  Champions League and the Europa League.

He said,  "It's  beyond belief how much football has developed in recent  years. The quality of play, the talent among the teams, and the growing fan base, particularly for European football, is stunning."

Souness, a key figure in  European football   for decades, has also  admired the  increasing competitiveness in teams across all European leagues. "It's not just the  top-tier teams from England,  Spain, Germany  or  Italy anymore. We are seeing excellent football being  played in smaller countries," he  added.

The Scotsman  further hailed  the evolution of playing styles, tactics and strategies being adopted by  teams in Europe.  "The technical  brilliance, the fluid styles, the tactics, they've all impressively evolved. It's not just about power  play, it's  about strategy and adapting to your  opponents," conveyed Souness.

The former Liverpool  captain also praised UEFA for their efforts to make the game more  inclusive and equal, "They are making significant strides in fighting racism and discrimination, and in  promoting female engagement in the sport. There's still a  long  way to go, but  I’m thankful for the progress," he remarked.

Alongside the  praise, Souness highlighted the need for  further improvement in areas such as  stricter financial fair play rules,  improved   support for lower-league clubs and better concussion protocols.

Souness concluded, "I can't  express how delighted  I   am with the progression of European football. It has come a long way, and I am incredibly excited  to see where it continues  to go."

Overall,  the European  football landscape has indeed evolved over  the past few decades, expanding its influence through unprecedented talent, high-quality matches, dynamic  tactics, and improved inclusivity. It's clear that  icons of   the game like Graeme Souness  maintain high  hopes for its future.

Celebrations  across the globe are at risk the next holiday  season as the threat of Covid-19 continues to  loom. Government and community leaders   everywhere  are initiating an earnest drive to save festive  holidays, intending to keep  the spirit of  these events alive even amidst uncertainty and restriction.

The initiative seeks to come up with safe and creative alternatives to traditional holiday practices, while still adhering to  pandemic safety measures. They aim to maintain the essence of festivities while  prioritizing public    health.

The idea was sparked by the degree to which Easter,  Eid, And Diwali celebrations were affected by  Covid-related restrictions this year. With major celebrations like Christmas, Hanukkah, and  New Year's Eve on the horizon, proponents of this initiative are  keen to prevent similar scenarios while still protecting the public health interest.

Governments at local, regional, and national levels are   working with community leaders, event organizers,  and   public health officials. They  are collectively  brainstorming strategies  for how  public gatherings may be safely held, or   how they  may be  replaced  with virtual alternatives.

Different  approaches are  being considered  – drive-through light displays, live-streamed church services, virtual parties,  and  door-to-door food and gift deliveries are among the strategies already in practice. The plan,  however, is to standardize these  measures  and  make them more comprehensive.

Experts  suggest maintaining the core elements of each  holiday. Christmas, for instance, is characterized by giving and receiving. The act of giving could transition to  online platforms, whereas  receiving,  particularly of  items like food and gifts, could be safely arranged through  contactless delivery systems.

While  the  drive collects  momentum, it's  not without challenges.  This initiative requires not only meticulous planning and efficient implementation  but also the collective will of communities to adapt to this new holiday normal. However,  proponents are hopeful, stating that the essence of  holidays  is   more about community spirit than just physical gatherings.

Inclusively engaging with technology is crucial for this initiative. Therefore, special attention is ensured to  include those who might lack access to digital resources. Community leaders are working towards bridging this digital divide and making  sure  no  one is left  out  of the festivities.

Despite the challenges, an energy of determination is palpable  among community  leaders and   officials. Exploring the  potential of  digital platforms  and their ability to let    us celebrate collectively, while staying   safe at  home, is  a   significant step forward.

In the face of adversity, this drive represents an incredible endeavor to save the festive holidays that  are vital for maintaining our collective morale. As the mechanisms are slowly established and prototypes tested, the  hopes of celebrating together, even if  not

The UK’s housing market is witnessing an unexpected rebound, according to  a report by Halifax. The bank’s latest  house price index  suggests that the cost of  homes   has recovered significantly following a recent dip caused by the pandemic.

According to  the figures released by Halifax, house prices increased by 1.4% in October, marking the fifth straight month of growth. This follows  a slight decline in   prices between April and May when  the  UK housing  market was temporarily frozen due to COVID-19 lockdown.

Russell Galley, Managing  Director at Halifax, explained that  the boom  is likely linked  to a number of  factors. "The   recent surge in the market can be attributed primarily to  the release of  pent-up demand and a strong desire amongst some buyers  to move to bigger properties,  following life in lockdown,"  he said.

This bounce back  has resulted  in  the average UK  house  price reaching  a record high,  with a 7.5% increase in value compared to  the previous year.  The average house price  now  stands at £250,457, marking the strongest growth rate since mid-2016.

In addition to   this, the recent stamp duty holiday announced by  Chancellor Rishi Sunak may have also boosted demand in  the housing sector,  encouraging potential buyers to make purchases and take advantage of the tax break.

Despite this, economists are suggesting caution. Galley also warned that while this short-term growth  is considerable, the  medium-term outlook is far more uncertain. The economic fallout from the pandemic, from job losses to reduced economic   activity, could exert downward pressure on house prices in the coming months.

"There are still a lot  of uncertainties   ahead, including the end  of the government’s furlough  scheme  and a potential rise in unemployment," Galley said. "It remains  to be seen how these factors will impact the   housing  market."

In  light  of the unstable economic environment, prospective buyers   are advised to take stock  of their personal finances and weigh  up the potential risks  before diving into the  housing market.

British  tennis star, Lleyton  Hewitt, has  survived  an   epic five-set showdown against  Argentinian opponent,  David Nalbandian, in a nerve-racking   event   that kept the audience on their edge the entire time.

The match, which took place at Melbourne Park, had  started  out relatively  routinely, with  Hewitt  taking the first two sets. Nonetheless, Nalbandian fought back,  winning the third and fourth set, adding an unexpected twist to the match.

Lleyton  Hewitt, who had initially looked comfortable with a strong serve and  solid  net  play,   found  himself in precarious situations several times as Nalbandian sought to capitalize on every unforced error, turning  the match   into a thrilling battle of attrition.

In a dramatic fifth set that personified high stakes tennis, Nalbandian  played impeccably to  level the  scores, proving   why he is considered one of the most formidable opponents on  tour. However, the Australian athlete  showed  unwavering resilience, managing to secure a crucial break to seal his  victory.

Hewitt's  elation  was palpable after the gruelling  match that took over three hours, with him later saying  in a post-match interview, "This was definitely one  of the most emotionally draining and physically demanding matches I've  ever played."

His victory has  serious knock-on effects  in the tour standings, offering  him a lifeline for a seed in the upcoming Grand Slam tournament.  It also further cements his reputation for thriving  under pressure, capable of turning  crucial tennis points in his favour.

David Nalbandian, on the other hand, despite  the loss,  has once again tested one of  the  top players,  hinting that he could still potentially upset seedings in future tournaments. 

This enthralling match, filled  with dramatic swings of momentum and breathtaking display of skill, only intensifies the anticipation for upcoming fixtures, as the tennis season continues  in earnest.

Former Prime Minister, Tony Blair,  has announced that the  UK will significantly increase its aid  contribution for the ongoing relief efforts in areas affected  by the recent devastating tsunami.  This comes as international pressure mounts on wealthy  nations to do more to help.

The UK Government initially  pledged £50m but Mr. Blair  has pledged that the UK’s  contribution will increase  to transcend previous commitments.  While not  specifying the exact increase, he  assured  it would be a  'quantum leap’.

In  a statement from his spokesperson, he   said: "The  scale of this disaster and the   scale of the  need is so great, that the Government had already decided that we  are  going to  increase the  amount of money that we  are giving for both   immediate  relief and longer-term development aid.”

This commitment makes the  UK one of the leading  contributors  to the tsunami relief  effort. International criticism has been  growing over the perceived slow response  and limited aid commitments from developed countries. 

Mr.   Blair’s announcement comes at a time when global  leaders  are  discussing debt relief measures for the nations affected by the tsunami. There is growing consensus  that alongside direct aid,  countries affected by  the disaster should be given economic reprieve to help rebuild their battered economies.

The catastrophic tsunami, triggered by a massive underwater earthquake off the coast of Sumatra, Indonesia,  on December 26,  has  claimed more than 150,000 lives across  the  nations  of Southeast Asia and East   Africa, making it one of the most brutal natural disasters in recent history.

Mr. Blair  noted  that  the UK will coordinate its efforts with the  United Nations and other international agencies to ensure aid is effectively delivered to those most in need. 

Responding to concerns about  corruption and   misuse of funds,  the Prime Minister stressed that rigorous monitoring measures will  be   put in place to ensure that every pound goes directly towards helping those   affected by  the tragedy.

On top of the increased financial contribution, the UK has also committed  to  sending teams of  medical  experts and equipment  to help in  the immediate relief efforts. British military personnel are already  on the ground in the region,  aiding in the distribution of food, water,  and critical medical supplies.

Mr. Blair urged other  nations to similarly escalate their contributions,  stating  that this does not only reflect individual national compassion, but also global  solidarity and responsibility. 

The UK public has also rallied in support of victims, with  charities reporting an overwhelming response to appeals for donations.

Three  top executives at Aer Lingus, the Irish airline, have announced their  departure, marking a significant shake-up in the company's  leadership. The airline  confirmed the news in a statement released yesterday.

Chief Corporate  Affairs Officer, Donal  Moriarty, Chief   Technical Officer, Fergus   Wilson,  and Director  of Communications, Ruth Ranson, are all set to leave the company. The trio have  been instrumental in the airline's operations and  their departure is expected to have a significant impact on the company.

Mr. Moriarty, who has been with Aer Lingus for  over 20 years, has played a  key  role in the airline's strategic planning and corporate affairs.  He  was also appointed as interim CEO for a  brief period in  2020.

Mr. Wilson, who joined the airline  in 2014, has been responsible for the technical  operations of  the  airline's fleet.  His departure comes  at a time when the airline is  planning to expand  its fleet and routes.

Ms. Ranson, who has been with  the  company for over a decade,  has been the face of the airline's communications and  public relations. She has been instrumental in managing the airline's image and communication with the   public and media.

The reasons for their departure have not been  disclosed. However,  the airline stated that they would be  leaving to "pursue other opportunities".  The departures  are expected to take  effect over the next few months, with the  airline planning a transition period to ensure  a smooth handover of responsibilities.

The CEO of Aer Lingus,  Lynne Embleton,  thanked the trio for their "significant contributions" to  the airline. She said, "Their dedication and hard work  have been  instrumental  in the success  of Aer Lingus. We wish them all the best in their future  endeavours."

The departures come at a challenging time for   the airline industry, which has  been severely impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic. Aer Lingus,  like  many other airlines, has been  grappling  with travel  restrictions and a significant drop  in passenger   numbers.

The airline is   yet to announce  who will be  taking over the roles of the departing executives. The search for their replacements  is expected to begin immediately.

Tim Henman,  the  former British number one tennis player, made  a winning start to his career  as a tennis commentator  on Monday. Henman, who retired from professional tennis in  2007, has joined the BBC's commentary team for the grass-court season, and his debut was met with widespread  praise.

Speaking from the BBC's commentary box at Queen's Club,  Henman said, "I'm  thrilled  to  be back in  the world  of tennis, and I'm excited to share my  insights and expertise with the BBC's viewers. I've always been passionate about the sport, and I'm looking forward to bringing that passion to my commentary."

Henman's  first assignment was to cover the opening day  of the Fever-Tree Championships at Queen's Club, where he provided commentary on a series of matches, including the highly anticipated clash between defending champion Feliciano Lopez and rising star Stefanos Tsitsipas.

Throughout  the day, Henman impressed viewers   with his in-depth analysis and insightful observations.  He demonstrated   a keen eye  for detail, picking up on subtle  aspects of the game that many commentators  might  have missed.  His ability   to explain complex tactics  and strategies  in simple  terms made  him a  hit with fans,  who praised him for  making the game more accessible and   enjoyable to  understand.

One viewer took to social media to say, "I'm loving Tim Henman's  commentary!     He's making me  see the game in a whole  new light." Another added, "Henman's commentary is top-notch. He's got  a great way of breaking  down the game and explaining it in a way that's  easy to understand."

Henman's broadcasting style was also praised by his colleagues  in the commentary box. Veteran commentator  John Lloyd  said, "Tim's been a great  addition to the team. He's got a wealth of knowledge and experience, and  he's  able to  convey that  in a way  that's engaging  and informative."

Chinese  milk bosses have been detained by police,  according to a  BBC  report.  The detentions come as  part of an  investigation into allegations of contamination of milk with melamine, a chemical used in plastics.

The report states that four executives from the Sanlu Group, China's largest milk producer, were taken into custody on Thursday. The company has  been at  the center of   a scandal involving milk contamination  that  has sickened thousands of   children  and led to widespread panic among consumers.

The Sanlu Group has been accused of  knowingly selling contaminated milk powder, which was laced with melamine  to make it appear to have   a  higher protein content. The company has   denied any wrongdoing, but has  recalled all of its milk powder products from   stores  across China.

The  contamination scandal has sparked widespread outrage and calls for greater regulation of  the food  industry. Parents of sickened children have protested outside Sanlu's headquarters, demanding compensation  and justice.

The Chinese  government has  also  come under pressure  to take action, with critics  accusing it of being too  slow to respond to the crisis. The government has promised to crack down on food safety violations and has launched a nationwide investigation into the milk industry.

The detention of  the Sanlu  executives  is seen as  a sign that the authorities are taking the crisis seriously and are willing to take  action against those  responsible.  However, some have criticized the move as a  token gesture,  and are calling for more comprehensive reforms to ensure  food  safety in China.

The scandal has also raised concerns about the  safety  of  Chinese exports, with  several countries announcing recalls of Chinese-made milk products. The European Union has banned all imports of Chinese   milk and  dairy  products, while the  US has issued a warning to consumers not to buy infant formula made  in China.

The crisis has highlighted the challenges facing China's food safety regulators, who  are struggling to   keep pace with the country's rapidly growing food industry. A thrilling adventure story about a group of explorers who embark  on a perilous journey through  uncharted terrain  has won top honors at this year's prestigious Adventure  Awards ceremony.

The book, titled "The Unmapped  Path," took home the coveted Golden Compass award for   Best  Adventure Story, beating out  stiff competition from a field of talented authors and adventurers.

The  story follows a team  of four friends who set  out to explore a  remote and dangerous region  of  the world, pushing themselves to  their  limits as they   face treacherous landscapes, harsh  weather conditions, and other obstacles along the way.

The author, Alexandra Stewart, said she  was thrilled to  receive the award and praised her fellow nominees for their inspiring tales of adventure.

"I  am truly humbled to have  received this honor  among such an impressive group of finalists," Stewart said  in her  acceptance speech. "My hope is that 'The Unmapped Path' will inspire readers  to seek out  new experiences and  challenges, and to never stop exploring."

Stewart,  who has  been an avid adventurer herself for many years, drew on her own experiences traveling through rugged environments  to create the story. She spent months researching and  preparing   before embarking on the expedition that would  become the basis for   her award-winning  book.

The annual  Adventure Awards celebrate the best in adventure writing, filmmaking, and photography, with winners chosen by a panel  of  experts in  each category.  The awards are highly  regarded within  the adventure community  and are seen  as  a benchmark of  excellence in outdoor pursuits.

In addition to the top prize  for Best Adventure  Story, "The Unmapped Path" also  took home awards for Best Photography and Best Film, making it a clean sweep for the book in the three most prestigious  categories.

Other notable winners at this  year's  Adventure Awards included a documentary  about climbing Mount Everest without oxygen, which won  Best Documentary, and a  collection of photographs showcasing life in some of  the  world's most extreme environments,  which won  Best Portfolio.

In  a surprise move, supermarket  giant Sainsbury's has   announced  that it will be gifting  its employees an extra  day off with pay to encourage them to vote in the upcoming general election.

The company,  which employs over  180,000 people across  the UK, said it wants to ensure that all of  its staff have  the opportunity to exercise their  democratic right and vote on December 12th.

In a statement, a spokesperson  for Sainsbury's said: "We understand that many of  our colleagues may face challenges when it comes to voting,  such as difficulty getting time off work or access  to transportation. By giving them an extra day off with pay, we hope to  make  it easier for  them to participate in this  important process."

The decision was welcomed by politicians and  union leaders, who  praised Sainsbury's for  taking the initiative to support voter turnout.

"This is a  great example  of a responsible employer putting the needs of   their staff first," said Rachel Reeves, chair of the Business, Energy  and   Industrial Strategy Committee. "It's crucial that everyone has the  chance to cast their vote and have  their say in  shaping the future of   our   country."

Tim  Roache, General  Secretary of the GMB Union, added: "GMB  warmly welcomes this move from Sainsbury's. It shows they  value their workers and recognise how important  it is that they are able to  participate fully in  the  democratic  process."
