According to reports, several other major  employers are considering following suit and offering similar benefits to their employees. The government has  also pledged   to take steps to increase voter turnout, including allowing people to  register to vote online and trialing a new  system of electronic counting.

A prominent ally of former  Russian oil tycoon  Mikhail Khodorkovsky has denied charges of embezzlement and money laundering, his lawyer said on  Thursday. Platon  Lebedev, who was arrested in 2004 along with Khodorkovsky, the former CEO of oil company Yukos, denies any wrongdoing and  claims the charges  are politically motivated.

Lebedev, who was  once Russia's richest man, was sentenced to  11 years  in prison in   2005,   but was released in 2013 after a court reduced his sentence.  However, he was re-arrested in 2020 and  charged with embezzling  billions of dollars from Yukos.

Lebedev's  lawyer,   Anton  Dautov, told reporters that his client "categorically denies all the charges" and   accused  the authorities of trying to "rehabilitate the old case" against Khodorkovsky  and his associates.

Dautov  claimed that the new charges  against Lebedev  are based on the same evidence that  was used  in the previous  trial, which he  said  was   fabricated. He also pointed out  that the charges were brought shortly after Khodorkovsky announced his plans to return to Russia and engage in politics.

Khodorkovsky,   who was pardoned and released from prison in 2013, has been a vocal critic of President Vladimir Putin  and has announced plans to form a new political  party. His supporters say that the charges against Lebedev are part of  a broader campaign to discredit Khodorkovsky and prevent him from challenging Putin's grip on power.

The case against Lebedev  is seen as a test of the  Russian authorities' willingness to re-examine high-profile cases  that were widely seen  as politically  motivated. Lebedev's  lawyer said  he will appeal the charges  and called on the international community  to put pressure  on Russia to  ensure a  fair    trial.

In a  groundbreaking initiative, Google has announced plans to digitize the  collections  of some of the world's most  famous  libraries.  The tech giant has partnered with several prestigious institutions, including the British Library,  the New  York Public Library,  and the  Library of Congress, to scan and make available millions of books, manuscripts, and  other cultural artifacts.

The project, which  is expected to take  several years to complete, will enable people around  the world to access and explore the rich cultural heritage of these libraries from the comfort of their own homes. Google   will use advanced scanning technology to  digitize the materials,  ensuring that the highest  quality images  are available for viewing online.

"We are thrilled to partner  with these esteemed libraries to bring their  collections to a global audience," said a spokesperson for Google.  "Our mission is to make  information accessible  to everyone, and this project is a  significant step towards achieving that   goal."

The libraries  involved in the  project are   equally excited about the opportunity  to share their collections with a wider public. "We are proud to  be  a part of  this initiative and look forward to seeing  our collections reach  new audiences,"  said the director  of the British Library.

The  project has been welcomed by academics, researchers, and book lovers alike. "This is a fantastic opportunity for people to  explore the rich  history  and culture of  these libraries without having to physically visit them," said a professor  of history. "It's a game-changer  for research and education."

The  digitization process is  set to begin  in the coming months, with the first  batch of materials expected to  be made  available  online next year. Google has promised to work closely with the  libraries to ensure that the digitization process is carried out with the   utmost care and respect for the  materials.

The  project is not  without its challenges, however. Google  will need to navigate complex copyright laws and work with libraries to ensure that  sensitive materials are not  made  available  online without permission. Additionally, some have expressed  concern about the potential  impact on the physical libraries themselves,  as people  may be less inclined to visit in person   if they can access the materials  online.

A leading construction company has agreed to pay out millions of pounds in  compensation to victims of asbestos-related diseases. The company, which cannot be  named for legal reasons, has been accused  of  exposing its workers to the deadly substance during the construction of several  major buildings in the 1970s  and 1980s.

According to lawyers representing the victims, the company failed to  provide  adequate protection to its   workers despite knowing the risks  associated with asbestos. Many of the workers  have since developed serious health problems, including mesothelioma, a rare and incurable form of cancer caused by asbestos exposure.

The compensation package, which is believed to be  one   of the largest of its kind, will be divided among more than 100  claimants, many of whom are now in their 60s  and  70s. The exact amount of the    payout  has not been disclosed, but it is  expected  to run  into millions of pounds.

The case  highlights the  ongoing  legacy of asbestos exposure  in the  UK,  where thousands of people are still diagnosed with asbestos-related diseases every year.  Asbestos   was widely used in construction and other industries until its  use was banned in the 1990s,  but the effects  of exposure can take decades to manifest.

The victims' lawyers  have welcomed the  compensation package, but say that it  is only a  small step towards justice for  those who have suffered as a result  of asbestos exposure. They are now calling for the government to take action to prevent further   cases of asbestos-related illnesses  by  implementing stricter regulations and  providing better protection for workers.

The construction  company has apologized for its failure to protect its  workers and has promised to take steps to ensure that such  cases do not happen again in  the  future. However,  critics  say  that more needs to be done to   hold companies accountable for their actions and   to  prevent further tragedies.

The case serves as a stark  reminder  of the dangers of asbestos and the need for greater vigilance in protecting  workers from  harmful substances. The

Greek sprinter  Kostas Kenteris has denied  allegations that he faked a  road accident to  avoid a doping test, calling the claims "baseless and  ridiculous."

Kenteris,  who was involved in a car crash on Monday, was accused  by some media outlets of staging  the incident to avoid a surprise drug  test  that had been scheduled for the  following day.  However, the  athlete has now spoken out against  these accusations,   insisting that  they are completely unfounded.

"I am deeply disappointed and frustrated  by these baseless and ridiculous allegations,"  Kenteris said in a statement. "I would never resort to such tactics  to avoid a  doping test. I have always been a  clean  athlete and  I will  continue to  prove it."

The 31-year-old Olympic champion sustained  minor injuries  in the crash, which  occurred when his car collided with a truck  on  a highway near  Athens. He was taken to  hospital for treatment but was later released.

Kenteris's lawyer, Ioannis Pantelidis, also dismissed the  allegations, saying: "There is no evidence whatsoever to support these claims. My  client is an honest   and hardworking athlete who has dedicated his life to his sport. We demand an apology  from those who have made these  false accusations."

The Hellenic Anti-Doping Agency (HADA) has confirmed that Kenteris underwent  a doping test on Tuesday, the day after  the  crash, and that the results were negative.

This is  not the first time that Kenteris has faced  doping allegations.  In 2004, he  tested positive  for  the banned substance stanozolol and  was subsequently stripped of his gold  medal from the Athens Olympics. He served a two-year   ban  before returning to competition.

Despite this past controversy,  Kenteris remains adamant that he is innocent of  any wrongdoing.  "I have learned  from my mistakes in the past and I am committed to competing cleanly," he  said. "I  hope that people will believe me  and give me the benefit  of the doubt."

In a statement released on Tuesday,  Cardinal Vincent Nichols, the Archbishop  of Westminster, has spoken out against the cost of the Iraq war, calling it    a "moral  scandal."

Cardinal Nichols,  who  is the leader of the Catholic  Church in England and  Wales, expressed  his deep concern over the financial cost of  the war, which he believes has had a disproportionate impact on the poor and vulnerable.

"The cost of the    Iraq war has been  staggering, with estimates suggesting  that it has cost  the UK alone  over  £20 billion," Cardinal Nichols said.  "This is a moral scandal,  when we consider the impact  that this money could have  had on the poor and  vulnerable both in  our  own country and around the world."

The Cardinal also criticised the human cost of the war, which  has  resulted in the loss of countless lives and the displacement of  millions of  people.

"The Iraq war  has  caused immense  suffering  and destruction, with innocent men, women, and children caught in the crossfire," he said. "It is a tragedy that we will be  dealing with the consequences of this conflict for  generations to come."

Cardinal Nichols'  comments come as the UK government faces increasing pressure to reveal the true cost of  the war, which has been shrouded in secrecy.

"We have a right  to know the true  cost  of this war,  both financially and in terms of human life," Cardinal Nichols said. "It is our moral duty  to speak out   against such injustice  and   to  demand transparency  and accountability from our leaders."

The  Cardinal's comments have been met with widespread support  from religious leaders and  anti-war  activists, who have long been calling for an end  to  the conflict.

"We stand in solidarity  with Cardinal Nichols in his call for transparency  and accountability," said  a spokesperson for the Stop the War Coalition. "The Iraq war has been a disaster from  start to finish,  and it is time  for our leaders to take  responsibility for their actions."

Mukesh Ambani's Reliance Industries  has seen a significant increase in its share price, despite  being embroiled in a high-profile feud with his younger brother  Anil Ambani's Reliance Group.

The company's stock  rose by over 3%  on Monday, with investors seemingly unfazed by the ongoing legal  battle  between the two brothers. The  dispute   centers around a  loan agreement  signed in 2018, which Anil  Ambani   claims was never properly  documented and is therefore invalid.

Mukesh Ambani's side has  maintained that the agreement was binding and has alleged  that  his brother's  actions  are an  attempt to sabotage the family business.  Despite  this, shares  in Reliance Industries surged, with analysts suggesting  that investor confidence may have been bolstered by last week's announcement that the companies  would continue negotiations.

While it remains  unclear how long  it will take   to resolve  their differences, both sides expressed optimism about finding a resolution. This  has helped soothe concerns  among  shareholders who had  worried that the bitter public spat could destabilize one of India's largest conglomerates.  Shares in Reliance Group also saw  gains, although they   did not rise as sharply as those of Reliance Industries.

There  were fears that if no settlement can  be reached then there  could be negative consequences for each  company,  given how closely their finances remain intertwined following years under shared  ownership before they diverged six years ago. However at present markets appear untroubled – quite possibly due to reassurance offered last Thursday when directors announced plans to  maintain cooperation until matters get sorted    out once and for all – giving hope instead that we  might see more positive days  ahead!

A new variant of the Windows worm has been discovered, and it's  using an unusual method to spread itself  - by hiding inside the popular video game Tetris.

The   worm,   known as  WannaTetris, was first identified  last  week  by security researchers at a leading IT  firm. It is believed to have originated in Russia, where it has already infected thousands of computers.

"This is a very sophisticated piece of malware," said John Smith, chief security officer  at XYZ Security.  "It uses a technique called 'game-based obfuscation' to disguise   its true nature. Essentially, the worm encrypts its  code and hides it within the Tetris  game data. This makes it  extremely difficult to detect."

Once a computer is infected with WannaTetris, the worm begins to replicate itself and spread to other  machines on  the same network. It can also  give hackers remote access  to the compromised  systems,   allowing them to  steal sensitive information  or install additional  malware.

The  exploit takes advantage  of a vulnerability in the way Windows handles multimedia  files. When  a  user opens a  legitimate-looking Tetris game file, the worm is  activated and begins to run in the background.

Researchers say that WannaTetris  is particularly dangerous  because it  can evade detection by most  anti-virus software. Traditional  scanners are   unable to identify  the hidden malicious code within the  Tetris game  data.

To avoid falling victim to this type of attack, experts recommend users be cautious when opening   email attachments or downloading games from untrusted sources. They should also keep  their operating system and  antivirus software up to date.

Microsoft has released a patch to fix  the  vulnerability exploited by WannaTetris. The  company urges all Windows users to apply the update as soon  as possible to  protect themselves against  this threat.

Scotland   head coach Gregor Townsend has named   his 31-man squad  for  next month's Six Nations  campaign, with  Glasgow Warriors prop Zander Fagerson and Edinburgh back row Jamie  Ritchie returning after injury layoffs.

Fagerson missed last year's tournament through injury while Ritchie was ruled out by concussion in November.

Glasgow centre Nick Grigg also  makes the cut despite being dropped  for their Champions Cup defeat against Leinster  on Saturday.

The  Scots  open their campaign at home to Italy on Sunday, 2 February (kick off 14:15 GMT).

Townsend said: "We  have selected  a  strong group that we believe can challenge  for  silverware this season."

The judge overseeing the retrial of  John   Warboys for a 2003  murder  has  apologised after comments  made earlier.

Mr Justice Bean said a juror  had been dismissed after being found not to have told the truth  during questioning.

He said he   needed to put on  record "what appears to  have been a misunderstanding" for a transcript of  comments he made.

A  Court of Appeal is hearing  the case  of Woolf, the  youngest  of Warboys'  seven victims.

Mr Justice  Bean had earlier made a reference  to  her "witnesses" -  which is what a juror is technically  called.

'Confusion'

He  said he had not been referring to a  witness who had given evidence in court, but a female friend of 26-year-old Woolf, who was with her at  the  time she died.

"I need  to set  the record straight: there is confusion here, in part because the reference  I  made during an in-court-whisper, about the 'witness', may have been  misunderstood,  and in part because I made a reference to her without going into detail and, in retrospect, I  should have."

Mr Justice Bean told jurors he was  sorry if his words had caused any  confusion.

"I wanted to be very clear about this so I   am making  the point now and hope that it will clear the  air," he   said.

'Disgusted'

Woolf died in 2003 when she was  run  over by Warboys   at the foot of his drive in Gateshead.

A jury  had earlier failed to convict Warboys over her death  and a retrial was ordered.

The 61-year-old is also accused  of murdering two other women -  Lindsay Owen-Jones, 22, from West London, and Ann McDonnal, another  22-year-old whose body has never  been  found.

He has already  been jailed for  seven years for a string  of sexual assaults  and will be sentenced after  the murder case is concluded.

But for now the hearing has become a police investigation.

>  The  Budget Aston Martin has taken on the might of  Porsche, as the 1959  Aston Martin  DB4GT continues its fight for survival at a Bonhams sale in Marbella, Spain. The  DB4GT is one of  only 75 made, and was once  part of  Aston Martin chairman David Brown's private collection.
>
> The ultra-rare Aston   will be accompanied by another classic DB4GT, at Bonhams' Marbella auction on Sunday.  Both  cars  have less than 600 miles and  were purchased by British businessman David Duckham when the original owner decided to sell them  during the late 1980s.  It's understood that the cars were bought specifically for the  current owner who  has spent the best   part of 25 years restoring them to their original glory.
>
> But  the cars are expected to go  for under  their original   price.  The  DB4GT, which is part of  the original owner's family collection and   is  likely to have been one of the last cars built,  is estimated to  fetch in the region of £2.3m to  £2.7m (US$3m to  US$3.47m),  while the other car, a factory competition car believed to have been prepared in the 1960s by Aston  Martin's own competition department, is estimated to make between £1m (US$1.45m) and £1.3m.
>
>
>
> Aside from the DB4  GTs, a 1962   Fiat  Dino  Spyder is expected  to make between £2m and £3m (US$2.8m and US$3.54m), while  a 1955 Mercedes-Benz 300 S Cabriolet A has a pre-sale estimate of  between £1m (US$1.4m) and £1.5m.

Two US men have been found guilty  in   separate cases for running  websites that allowed users to illegally download music and  films, prosecutors say.

Jury members took less than two  hours to convict 28-year-old Eric McGowan on charges  including  conspiracy  to commit  copyright infringement.

He ran the site TVShack.net which offered links to  illegal copies of  movies  and television shows.

In another case, a jury also found 30-year-old Jason Goldman  guilty of similar offences. He operated the website MovieTiger.com.

Both defendants face up to five years  in prison when they are  sentenced later this year.

The verdicts were announced by the  US Department of Justice (DoJ) after  both trials concluded at  federal courts in New York City.

Mr McGowan was accused   of operating TVShack.net between January 2005  and March 2010. It had more than one million   registered users who could access content via BitTorrent file  sharing software.

Prosecutors  said he earned $47,000 (£30,000) through advertising revenue during his time as administrator of the  site.

They added that  Mr McGowan's actions caused  losses of about $6m to film  studios   and other rights holders.

Meanwhile,  Mr  Goldman    was charged with running MovieTiger.com -  a site offering  links to unauthorised versions of  Hollywood blockbusters such as Avatar and Transformers.

It was estimated that the site generated  more than  $90,000 in ad revenues over its lifetime.

Labour, Conservatives and Liberal Democrats have all pledged to end  24-hour drinking.

Labour wants to bring in minimum price for alcohol   as well as stricter laws on drink marketing.

Lynton Crosby, Tory adviser, told  the   BBC the party supported the principle of   a change.

There are fears the move  would make life  harder for the public and pubs in an already tight  climate.

There are warnings that banning people from buying alcohol after a certain time could reduce police numbers on the street and also   mean more work  for A&E departments.

24-hour pubs were  allowed in England only after two high court cases resulted in  major changes to  pub licensing laws in 2005.

The Conservatives said  they would  want  to  consult on ending the regime of 24-hour premises before taking a decision on  the matter.

Mr Crosby told  the  BBC that the policy had been put   forward  by Liberal Democrat parliamentary candidate Chris Huhne when he was in the Conservative Party's  predecessor the SDP.

"The  Conservatives strongly support the principle  but,   at the same time, we will consult properly and listen to what people tell us and take some advice from  professionals too," he said.

The  Conservatives,  however, wanted to go even  further by clamping down on 24-hour supermarkets  and  preventing the  large shops, whose size  exceeded the minimum 300  square metres   set down by Labour when it came into  office, from   opening before 9am and after 9pm,  he added.

He  said that if people were being encouraged to drink too  often,  what the country ought to be doing  is  teaching people how to  manage their drinking better.

"You don't achieve that by   trying to have people  being banned from buying drinks  at 11 o'clock at night," he said.  "You do it by making  them aware of the dangers of drinking too much, educating them in responsible drinking  and the other benefits of not drinking  too much - the health,  financial benefits."

UK Home Secretary Jacqui Smith has  said it is possible ministers  knew that private investigators were    illegally intercepting the phone calls of hundreds of people.

But she played  down the significance of the phone-taps -  most were "banal" calls unrelated to political activity - and said they "posed no threat to national security".

Ms  Smith is under  pressure to explain why the Home  Office   had not suspended the  controversial private eye Steve Whittamore while he carried out illegal work.

He was paid 650,000 pounds  ($1.3m) by newspapers to obtain sensitive information  on individuals between 1987  and 2003. His activities were exposed by the  News of the World on  Sunday.

The newspaper said the Home Office paid Mr Whittamore to track down  "subversive information" including details  of  the  home addresses  of 115 asylum seekers    and  the phone numbers of 90 MPs and 32  cabinet ministers.

The Conservatives have pledged  to cut  192 government bodies,  including the  BBC Trust and the Human  Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA).

They say they will   also scrap the Equality and Human Rights Commission and the  National  Consumer Council.

Shadow  chancellor George Osborne said  it would  save £3bn over four years -  but Labour called the plan "reckless".

Labour's  Ed Balls accused Mr Osborne of being "in  denial about the scale of the economic  crisis facing Britain".

Mr Osborne  told the Conservative Party conference in Manchester that he wanted to see  an end to what   he described as   "the age of big government".

He said the Tory party was committed to cutting public spending by £6bn  next  year if elected at the general election on 6 May 2010.

But he added: "We are not going to do this by slashing frontline services  or raising taxes."

Instead, he promised to make savings through  reducing bureaucracy and wasteful spending.

In his speech,  Mr Osborne listed more than  50  organisations  which he claimed were unnecessary and should be scrapped.

These  included the Housing Corporation, the British Film  Institute, the Arts Council England, the  Royal Parks Agency,  the Forestry Commission, the Food Standards  Agency, the Health Protection Agency, the Legal  Services Ombudsman,  the  Office for Civil Nuclear Security, the UK Atomic Energy Authority, the  Serious Organised  Crime  Agency, the  Strategic Rail Authority, the Sustainable Development Commission, the Teaching Awards Trust, the Tourist Board, VisitBritain, the  Water  Industry Regulator, the Waste &  Resources Action Programme,  the Youth Justice Board and the Young People's Learning  Agency.

Other organisations  earmarked for closure include the Advisory Committee  on  Business  Appointments,  the Audit Commission, the Central Office of Information,  the Child Support Agency, the Children's Workforce Development Council, the Countryside Agency, the Departmental Accommodation Service, the Disability Rights  Commission,  the Employment  Appeals Tribunal, the English Partnerships,  the  Environment   Agency, the Financial Reporting Review Panel, the

The financial state of Bundesliga  club Borussia Dortmund is so unstable  that there are  fears  it could go bankrupt, German newspaper Bild has reported.

The report quoted the club's supervisory board, or  Aufsichtsrat, as saying  it  was unlikely the club would get the 15m  euros it needs to sign players.

Former Liverpool  star  Jurgen  Klopp is manager at Dortmund.

Bild said the club's biggest  problem was  the 100m euros  ($135m;) it still  owed 17 former players, including  Germany captain Philipp Lahm, Brazil midfielder Lucas, and Dutch striker Ruud van Nistelrooy, who helped the club reach the Champions League  final in 2013.

"Borussia Dortmund is in a serious financial crisis," Bild  wrote

Dortmund were the Bundesliga champions in 2010-11 and 2011-12  but have finished eighth and sixth in the last two  seasons.

The club reached   the Champions League  semi-finals   in 2012-13.

But it has not qualified for the competition this season and  instead is contesting the Europa League, where it will face Tottenham  in Wednesday's last 16  second leg (17:00   GMT kick-off).

"The current situation has nothing positive to  do with sport," Bild added, referring to Dortmund's failure to qualify for the Champions League.

The  club declined to comment. In October,  however,  managing director Hans-Joachim   Watzke said:  "We're  not in financial danger."

## 'New sponsor needed'

Former Liverpool and Newcastle manager Klopp, who has a year remaining on his  contract, is  widely tipped to leave in the summer

Bild quoted  the supervisory board  as saying  that Klopp "must be  replaced"  if Dortmund did  not  qualify for the  Champions League this season.

"Dortmund need a new sponsor  for the future," added Bild, in  response to a comment  made by the managing director of German  drinks giant Radeberger, who  is close to the  club.

France coach   Philippe Saint  Andre  was  angry   with several  players for not turning up when they  were meant to be available  for selection in  preparation for their summer Tests against England and  Australia.

He has also confirmed Mathieu Bastareaud will miss Sunday's match against the Barbarians because he is still injured.

French media reports claimed as many  as eight France stars did not  turn out on  schedule,  meaning some had just 24  hours with  the  squad before missing out.

It's understood  scrum-half Jean Marc Dousset has been  dropped after  claiming an elbow injury during training last week. He has  only recently returned to  play after suffering several concussions through his career.

Despite claims to  the  contrary, centre Wesley Fofana suffered no injury at all  but failed to turn  up until Thursday while wing Aurelien Rougerie said he was unable to take part due  to suffering from   swine flu. Rougerie was replaced  by Florian Fritz who joined Leinster over the  summer.

Meanwhile, there are growing signs that  French fans may turn away  this weekend if Bastareaud  keeps his place  for the trip to Twickenham  next Saturday - despite making clear statements about wanting to concentrate solely on rugby rather than promoting himself outside  of matches.

Microsoft has  announced that it will be offering  a swap program to users who  have purchased pirated copies of Windows XP. The program, which is available until  June 30th, allows eligible  customers  to exchange their   unlicensed copy of Windows XP for a legitimate one at no  additional cost.

To qualify for  the program, users must provide proof of purchase  of  the pirated version of Windows XP and meet certain eligibility requirements. Those  who are  accepted into the  program will receive a new license  key  for a  legal copy of Windows XP, as well as access to any necessary updates  and support.

Microsoft's decision to launch  this program comes in response  to concerns about  the widespread use of pirated software, which  can lead to security  vulnerabilities and other issues. By providing  an easy way for users to switch to   a legitimate version of  the operating system, Microsoft hopes to help protect  both its own business  interests and the broader technology  community.

And  so far, reviews have suggested  that those promises are not  just hype -  the updated  machine appears to deliver on all  accounts.

However, this seems to  have  been addressed in the latest update, as the new M1 chip is designed specifically for macOS and offers impressive thermal management capabilities. A UK-based  property company is facing legal  action   in Venezuela over its ownership of thousands of  acres of  land, following allegations that it has failed to  pay taxes and violated local laws.

The dispute centres on a 100,000 hectare estate owned by the  British firm,  which was  acquired from the government in  the  early 2000s as part of a joint venture with a local partner. However, according to  reports in the Venezuelan press, the  company has been accused of failing  to pay taxes on  the land for several years, leading to a court  case being brought against them.

In addition to tax issues, there  are also claims that the company has  breached environmental regulations and failed   to provide adequate  compensation to indigenous communities living near the estate.  These allegations have led to protests and demonstrations by local groups who say  they  have been  unfairly affected by the company's activities.

The UK government has  been contacted by  both sides  in  the dispute,  with representatives  from the property  company  denying any wrongdoing and insisting that they are working closely with the Venezuelan authorities to resolve the issue. The Foreign  Office has said  that it is  monitoring the situation  closely and providing support to  British nationals  involved in the case.

Apple's iTunes, the popular media player and online  store, is facing a new threat from   hackers who have discovered a vulnerability in the software.  The vulnerability, which  was discovered by a group of security researchers,  could potentially allow hackers to access users' personal information and make unauthorized   purchases on their behalf.

The vulnerability, which has  been assigned a severity  rating of "high,"  affects all versions of iTunes,  including the latest version, 12.5.1. The researchers  who discovered the vulnerability have not yet disclosed the  specific  details  of how it can be exploited, but they  have warned that it  could  potentially allow hackers to steal users' login credentials, access their iCloud accounts, and  make purchases on their behalf.

Apple has not yet  released a   patch to  fix the vulnerability, but the company has said that  it is working on a  fix and will release it as soon  as possible. In the meantime,  users are  being advised to  avoid  using iTunes on unsecured networks and to regularly update their  software to the latest version.

The discovery  of the vulnerability  comes at a time when Apple is facing increased scrutiny over its security  practices. In recent   years, the company has been   the target of several high-profile hacks, including the  one that led to the  theft of millions  of users' iCloud data  in 2014.

Apple has  since implemented a number of security  measures  to  improve the security of its products and services,  but the latest vulnerability in iTunes highlights the ongoing challenges of keeping software secure in the face of  increasingly sophisticated attacks.

British actor  Colin Firth, known  globally  as one of cinema's most  versatile actors, is to  be honoured by the International  Film Festival  in Berlin (Berlinale)  during its 2018 edition.

Firth has won numerous awards throughout his  career in movies including Best  Actor  Oscars  for his performances in The King's  Speech and Shakespeare-inspired The Theory of Everything.

At a ceremony organised  by Germany's Academy of  Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (AMPAS),   he will receive this year's Berlin  Career  Award on behalf of AMPAS members who are  currently based outside North America but have  made  outstanding contributions  to global film production.

The  decision  was  announced at  the festival today  at an event held at CinemaxX - the CityPlex of European  Film Culture - where AMPAS president  Richard Gere expressed his enthusiasm about what he considered "an important recognition" of international  talent.

"We  are delighted that the Academy  chose to recognize our colleague  Colin here," said Gere while adding, "It emphasizes the importance of understanding  that our industry truly  transcends borders."

Last  year saw another notable British  personality  awarded the same prize: actress Judi Dench. This tradition  serves overtly to showcase diverse nationalities represented in Hollywood.

Aside from  being celebrated as a talented entertainer and humanitarian ambassador to UNICEF, Firth also received the Queen Elizabeth II Diamond   Jubilee Gold Medal earlier  this year - further underscoring an impressive career marked with multiple accolades. His works continue captivating   audiences worldwide.

The legendary  music studio, known for producing some  of the greatest  hits in the music industry, is  set to close its doors after more  than 50 years in operation. The studio, which  has been a hub for creativity and innovation in  the   world of  music, has seen countless musicians and bands  pass through  its doors, many of whom went on to   achieve  global success.

The closure of the  studio, which has been in operation   since the 1960s, is a blow to the music  industry, and to the  countless  musicians  and bands who have  recorded there. The studio's unique sound and atmosphere have  been  a major factor  in the success of many artists, and its closure is likely to have a significant impact on the music scene.

The  studio's owners have cited a variety of reasons for the  closure, including the changing nature of the music industry and the  rise of digital technology. However, many musicians and industry insiders  have expressed their disappointment at the news, and have called on the  owners to  reconsider their decision.

Despite the closure, the legacy of the  legendary music studio is  likely to live on, as many of the recordings made  there continue to be celebrated and enjoyed by music  fans around the world.  The  studio's closure is  a reminder of the ever-changing nature  of  the  music industry, and  of  the importance of preserving the  unique sounds and experiences that  have shaped the history of  music.

Pete Doherty, the former frontman  of  the band Babyshameless, has missed  his bail deadline. The 47-year-old musician was released on bail in February after being arrested on drug possession charges.

According to court officials, Doherty  failed to appear at a scheduled  hearing on Monday, leading  to a   warrant being  issued for his  arrest.  It is not clear where he is currently located.

Doherty has   a history of drug use and  has been arrested multiple     times for drug possession and other offenses. In 2006, he was sentenced to 18 months in prison for  drug possession  and robbery.

The news of Doherty's  latest  arrest has sparked concern  among his  fans and  fellow musicians. Many have taken to social media to express  their support and worry for his  well-being.

It is not yet known what will happen  to Doherty next. He is due to appear in court on March 15th.

The Welsh rugby team is  facing  injury  concerns ahead of their upcoming  Six  Nations  Championship match against England. Several key  players, including captain Alun Wyn Jones and flyhalf  Dan Biggar, have been ruled out due to injuries sustained during training sessions.

Wales coach Warren Gatland has expressed his frustration at the situation, stating   that it's a major blow for the team to lose such  influential players. He said: "It's disappointing to see some of  our key players go down with injuries. We've worked hard to build up our  strength and  depth over the past  few months, but now we face  a challenge in  terms  of  fielding a competitive side."

The extent of  the  injuries remains unclear,  but  it's believed that  several other players may also be forced  to withdraw from the squad. This could include prop Rhys Carré, who was substituted early on in Wales' recent victory  over Italy after suffering an ankle injury.

Gatland will need to call upon  new blood to fill the gaps left by the injured stars. Some  youngsters are expected to make their debuts in the  coming weeks, while  others may be called up from the domestic  scene.

Despite the setbacks, Gatland remains  optimistic about  Wales' chances  of success in the Six Nations. He said: "We    still have a  strong squad  capable  of    competing at the highest level. It's  important that we stay focused and work  together as a team  to overcome these  challenges."

Despite increased  sales in  recent  months, concerns about Britain's high street have intensified, as  many major retail chains  still struggle with a significant decline  in  footfall.  A  new report  by economists suggests  that  online shopping continues to be a key  driver for retail growth, while brick-and-mortar   stores are experiencing slow recovery following  several years of  closure  and weak demand.

The  study found that while online shopping is  responsible  for approximately 13% of total retail sales in the UK,  physical store visits remained stagnant overall - down  from 40 to 33 trips  per capita over the past  five years. Furthermore, research indicates that more than half  (62%) of  consumers shopped  less often in-store during  the  pandemic due to  health concerns, lockdown  restrictions, or  simply because it was easier to do so digitally.

In contrast, e-commerce has seen strong  growth rates: a 59% increase in annual sales in 2017-18 and another fourfold jump between 2015 and 2020. According to analysts at   Retail Economics,  this trend will continue into the future, stating  that they expect online  retail to account for up to two thirds all retail sales and almost  90%  of  discretionary spend within  ten years.

This paradigm shift poses serious   questions for the UK  high  streets which  were once  teeming with department stores, independent boutiques, and cafés. In particular, local authorities have come under criticism for neglecting non-core business activities such as public realm improvements.  Many town centres now resemble outdated shopping malls  plagued by empty spaces,  declining foot traffic, and struggling businesses.

John Lewis  announced earlier this month that it would close its flagship  Oxford Street store next year to  focus on smaller regional locations and  its online  platform. This decision marks further evidence of traditional  high-street retailers adapting to changing consumer habits. Yet experts warn that these changes could  exacerbate existing problems  faced by town halls and their communities.
   
"It creates an even bigger divide if those areas aren't regenerated," said Retail Economics chief Iain Pinfield.  "We are  seeing  too much attention focussed   on these large city

Despite stepping down as prime minister more than eight   years ago, former leader Tony Blair remains dogged by  allegations over his decision to go  to war in Iraq  and Afghanistan.

Throughout his time in office, Blair faced  numerous calls for an independent investigation into  the  decisions that led to Britain’s involvement in the conflicts, which  claimed tens of thousands  of  lives. However, despite several high-profile investigations, including those led by  Sir John Chilcot and  Baroness Hutton, no definitive answers have been provided  on  Blair's  role in launching these  wars.

This issue has become even  more relevant in recent years with growing evidence linking military interventionism abroad to domestic issues such as Brexit, austerity, and  social   fragmentation. Critics argue  that  Blair should be held accountable for  policies they say have  had long-standing consequences on British  society.

However,  supporters of  Blair contend that war was necessary at the time and that he acted with good intentions. They  also suggest that this ongoing debate is politically motivated,  aimed at  undermine the legacy  of the country’s longest serving premier since  Winston Churchill.

In addition, some observers  point out  that the Chilcot report, published five years  ago, did conclude that there  were serious mistakes made in Iraq, but it stopped short of  apportioning  direct blame. This highlights the complexity of  the issue and the lack  of clear consensus on  how best to address   it.

Blair insists that he  continues to  work  to  promote global peace and stability through his foundation, but admits that he  has no plans  to   answer  critics directly anytime soon. Instead, he says, he will focus  his efforts  on helping others who are facing similar challenges around the world, continuing his advocacy for humanitarian aid, reconciliation, and conflict  resolution.

Tennis legend Tim Henman has expressed his anger  over the use of performance-enhancing  supplements in the sport.

The  former world number one, who won the Wimbledon title  in 1993  and 1994,  has spoken out about the issue after a recent report revealed that some of  the top  players in the game are using  banned substances.

"I am absolutely disgusted by what I  have heard," Henman  said. "It is cheating and it is wrong. There  is no excuse  for it.

"I have always played fair and I have   always been against  the use of performance-enhancing drugs. It is not  just about the rules, it is about the spirit of  the game.

"I hope that the authorities take a tough stance on this and that they do  something to stamp out this cheating. It is  not  just about the  players, it is about the fans and the integrity   of the sport."

SEOUL, SOUTH KOREA (REUTERS)  -- South  Korean  police seized   credit  cards belonging to hundreds of  thousands  of consumers and  arrested a key  executive on Thursday after a popular  payment company failed, wiping out  stock  market values and leaving  clients  scrambling   for cash.
South Korea's biggest credit card group failed to  pay banks  as promised on Thursday and on Friday told a court-appointed  investigator that investors had lost about 2 trillion won, or 1.64 billion dollars, in total.
Police said  they had  seized  at least 500,000 cards from South Korea's second-biggest payer by credit sales, Hansung Card.  But they are expecting to uncover an even greater  number of cards, possibly millions,  since they estimate 90 percent of Hansung customers held cards  with other  companies.
The  company had been   selling prepaid cards for  cash  since mid-October, with which customers could purchase  goods online or at stores.
Officials say Hansung customers  have become panicked after the government allowed banks to hold back funds from Hansung-affiliated   stores, and have started lining up  at card issuers' offices to withdraw cash.
Hansung told the court   it has  about 20 million dollars  in cash in its accounts and another 30  million dollars of pledged assets, but  was unable  to access the latter given the current financial uncertainties.
About 1 trillion  won of Hansung's debt is owed to banks, and it has a total  liability of approximately  4.5 trillion won.  It has so far been unable  to pay the interest on credit card bills, causing some of its partner banks  to  refuse customers cash.
Police say the company's shares, which  have  been suspended  since Oct 12, could be wiped  out.
A Hansung employee said  his company had not told  customers how many cards had been  lost and so they  were coming in to get theirs returned before any more damage was done. "
But he  did not know how many cards have been lost due  to Hansung's failure  and what  would happen to the cards.
Hansung said the company had tried  to inform customers about what it was doing to help them retrieve their cards but  many had not picked up the  cards to replace lost ones.

Beijing has  suspended  construction on more than two dozen coal-fired and nuclear energy  plants, in an  effort to  reduce pollution levels that have become one cause for public discontent with China's leaders... The suspension order was issued by NDRC [National Development Reform Commission] after it found some  local governments had   approved too many  new capacity  additions without considering  their  impact or whether they were  needed at all." (BBC News)

Arsenal manager Arsene  Wenger is  prepared to give out-of-favour striker  Adrian Mutu an early route back into the first team by offering him out  on loan this month.
But although Wenger appears  open to sanctioning such a move, the 28-year-old's  availability will depend  on the  Gunners finding a suitable club before Sunday's 11pm transfer deadline.
Mutu  arrived from  Roma last summer, but has scored only  two goals in 13 outings. He  has made just nine starts  in all competitions.
The Romanian is now facing a struggle to secure first-team football next season after  a number of his team-mates, including Frenchman Sylvain Wiltord  and Brazilians Jose da Silva and Gilberto Silva  have recently signed  contract extensions until 2007.
Mutu has one year of  his £40,000-a-week deal remaining and he has already  indicated that he  would be willing  to join another Premier League  side to  improve his chances of playing in Europe during the  2003/04  season.
However, the financial  constraints on many lower-division sides,  who have  already spent their budget  on improving  their squads by the summer transfer   deadline, could mean he remains  in north  London.
"I don't say no, why not,  absolutely, but he has to go to a club which  can use   him," Wenger said.
"We haven't  decided  yet what to  do  and we will  have to decide between  now and Sunday.
"It could be to go  on  loan to another English  club, but  I  don't know  whether we can find a solution until then."
Another factor in the mutu transfer has  been that he has become a victim of the Arsenals 'french and brazilian only' club policy.

England coach  Eddie Jones has named  Liam Williams at full-back for Saturday's Six Nations match against Wales at Twickenham.

Williams, who plays his  club rugby  for Scarlets, has been in sparkling form for Wales this season and has  been rewarded with  his first England start.

Jones has also handed a first cap to Bath prop Charlie Ewels, who comes into  the starting line-up in place of the injured   Alex Corbisiero.

Meanwhile, Harlequins winger Marland Yasaia has been named on  the bench, with Jack Nowell dropping  out of the matchday squad.

England  will be  hoping to   build on their  opening day victory over Italy,  while  Wales are  yet to get their Six  Nations  campaign off the  mark.

Shares in  British spirits company Diageo surged on  Monday after reports emerged that it is considering  making a £6bn bid  for France's Pernod Ricard, which could lead to  job cuts and  affect  sales  of  brands such as Jameson Irish whiskey and Malibu rum.
The  potential acquisition has sparked speculation  about how this would impact  iconic  drinks labels owned by both companies, including Martell cognac and Beefeater gin. If successful, the  deal would create the world's largest   liquor business with  annual revenues exceeding $14 billion.
However, sources close to the matter have stated  that no official  approach has been made  yet, with  discussions at an early stage. The move  comes amidst  growing pressure on  big alcohol  firms  to  cut costs amid shrinking consumer demand due to health concerns and rising  taxes.
Analysts predict significant redundancies  if the two  giants merge forces as there might be duplication within  overlapping brand  portfolios, leading to streamlining efforts  across production sites worldwide._

Meanwhile, French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire expressed concern over losing one  of its top luxury goods exporters to foreign ownership but acknowledged talks  were  still preliminary.__

The rapid pace of technological  advancement has led to growing concern  over   its impact on the environment, with experts warning that gadgets and  electronic waste are becoming major environmental challenges. The increasing demand for  smartphones,  laptops, tablets, and  other devices is contributing  significantly to carbon emissions  and e-waste production. According to recent studies, electronics account for  up  to  70% of toxic  waste in landfills worldwide. This alarming trend highlights the urgent need for sustainable manufacturing  practices   and responsible disposal methods to mitigate the negative effects of  technology  on our planet. Experts believe that consumers can  play an important role by choosing environmentally  friendly products and recycling their  old gadgets responsibly. Governments  also have a crucial part to play in addressing this issue  through policies aimed at  reducing energy  consumption and promoting circular  economy principles. As we continue to rely  heavily on digital technologies,  it  is  essential that we prioritize sustainability and take steps  to minimize the harm caused by these innovations to our fragile ecosystem.

The EU's top  court has ruled that the UK government violated the rights of Romani people by failing to recognise them as an ethnic group in  immigration law. The  Court of Justice of  the European Union (CJEU)  said British  legislation was discriminatory because it  did  not cover   Roma as  a  distinct group. The  ruling comes  after a case   brought by the son of  a Romani  woman  who was denied  citizenship because  her partner was not classified as a member of a "racial  group." The court said the British government's policy  of only recognising people who are members of "racial groups" was discriminatory and breached EU law. The UK government said it disagreed with the ruling  but would study it carefully.

Japanese businesses have become less confident  about the country's economy,  according  to a survey by the Tokyo Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

The  quarterly  report found that business   sentiment had declined for three consecutive  quarters due to factors  such as weaker global demand  and trade tensions  between major economies.

Manufacturers were particularly pessimistic, with their confidence  hitting its lowest level since 2013. The weakening yen was seen   as both  an opportunity and challenge - while it boosts exports, it   also raises costsfor  companies  importing raw materials  and parts.

However,  services  sector firms remained relatively upbeat, partly thanks  to steady domestic  demandand ongoing public works spending under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’sprivatization agenda.

Overall, the decline inbusiness optimism indicatesthatJapan's economic  recovery may be losing momentum despite years of  stimulus  measures fromthe government. Analysts say policy makers need toimprove corporate profitability throughderegulation and structural reforms  to revive growth prospects.

Italian dairy giant Parmalat  has launched lawsuits against  45 banks, accusing  them of causing losses of up to €5bn (£3.8bn) during the financial crisis  of  2001-2.

The lawsuits, filed in Milan, claim that  the  banks "deliberately concealed the true   state of Parmalat's accounts and failed to warn other investors of the  company's mounting financial troubles".

Parmalat, which at the time  was one of Italy's  biggest companies,  filed for bankruptcy in November 2002, leading to losses for scores of banks, insurance companies and  pension  funds.

The company's  former chief executive, Calisto Tanzi, was sentenced  to more than 10 years  in jail for  fraud and embezzlement.

Since  the scandal, Parmalat has been  restructured and is now owned by the  Dutch  dairy group FrieslandCampina.

A row has  erupted in court  over the responses given by  officials to a series of questions by the  judge.  The judge had  posed the questions to  the officials  during a hearing, but the responses given by  the  officials have been disputed by the judge. The matter has  now been  taken up by   the court  and a full  investigation is underway  to find out the truth.   The judge has accused the  officials of providing incomplete and incorrect information,  which has  led to confusion in the court. The officials  have refused to comment on  the matter, stating that it is an internal issue and they cannot discuss it with the media. The outcome of the investigation could have serious implications for the officials involved and the court as a whole.

The  year 2004 has seen a  significant rise in the number of broadband internet connections in the UK, according to the latest figures released by the Office for National Statistics.

The  data  shows that the  number of broadband subscribers in the UK has increased  by over 50% in the past  year, with over 6   million households  now having access to high-speed  internet.

This surge in broadband uptake has  been driven by  a  range of factors, including  the increasing availability  of   broadband services from a variety of  providers, the falling cost of broadband packages, and the growing demand  for online services such as streaming and gaming.

The rise  in broadband adoption  has also had a  positive impact on  the  UK economy, with many businesses now relying on high-speed internet to communicate with clients and  suppliers, and to access online  markets.

However, despite the progress made in 2004, there are still many  areas of the UK where broadband access is limited or  non-existent, particularly in rural areas and on some islands. The government  has pledged to address this  digital divide,  with plans to invest  in new  broadband infrastructure and to encourage more competition in the market.

Overall, the  rise of broadband  in 2004 is  a positive   sign for  the UK's digital economy, and suggests that  the country is moving in  the right direction when it comes  to connecting households  and  businesses to the online world.

Blackburn  Rovers have rejected  a third approach from  Manchester  United for their striker Dimitar Berbatov, according to reports. The  Championship  club are believed to have turned down an  improved offer worth around £20million plus midfielder  Anderson in exchange for the Bulgarian  forward.

Manchester United had previously had two  bids for Berbatov rebuffed by Blackburn earlier this  summer and it  remains unclear whether   they will make another  move  for the player before the transfer deadline on Monday. Berbatov  has been reportedly keen on reuniting with former  manager  Sir  Alex Ferguson at Old  Trafford but Blackburn boss Steve Kean is determined to keep hold of  his prized  asset.

The 28-year-old joined Blackburn from Tottenham Hotspur last season and  scored 14 goals in 29 appearances  as theclub secured promotion back to the Premier League.

In a  surprising   turn of events, the iconic computer company Commodore, known for its pioneering  role in the personal computer revolution, has made a comeback with  a new line of products.  The   new Commodore devices have been designed to appeal to retro enthusiasts  and modern tech-savvy users alike, with  a blend of  classic styling and cutting-edge features.

The  new Commodore line-up includes a range of desktop and laptop computers, all running on  the latest hardware and  software. The flagship model, the  C64, is a high-performance desktop  computer that pays homage to the  classic  Commodore 64, with  its distinctive keyboard and sleek design.

In addition to the C64, Commodore has also released the PET, a laptop computer  that draws   inspiration from the  company's early portable devices. The PET  features a 13.3-inch touchscreen display and is powered by  the latest Intel  processor.

Commodore's return to  the market has been met with enthusiasm from both old and new fans of the brand. The  company's founder, Jack Tramiel,  who led   Commodore through its heyday in the 1980s,  has even  expressed  his support for the new products.

"I am thrilled to see Commodore making a comeback," said Tramiel. "The new products are a  testament   to the company's enduring legacy and  its commitment  to innovation."

Commodore's return to the  market  has also sparked interest from investors, with the company recently securing funding   to expand its  product line and increase its presence in the  global  market.

"We are excited to  be part of this new chapter in  Commodore's  history," said a  spokesperson for the company. "We believe that there is a strong   demand for our products and  that we can  continue to build on the legacy of  this iconic brand."

Paul Tergat, the 1998  New York City Marathon champion, has confirmed  that  Julius Chepkemei  will join the Edinburgh roster for the upcoming  season. Chepkemei, who has a personal best time  of 2:06:20, will be looking to make an immediate  impact in the Scottish capital.

"We are  delighted to have Chepkemei  on board," Tergat said. "He is  a highly talented athlete  with a lot of experience, and I believe he will be a  valuable addition to our team."

Chepkemei, who has represented Kenya in multiple international events, including the  Olympics and  World Championships, hinted that he was  excited about the new challenge.

"I am  really  looking forward to joining  Edinburgh," Chepkemei said. "I have heard a lot of  good  things  about the  club and the city,   and I am excited to  be part of such a prestigious organization."

Chepkemei's signing comes as a boost  for Edinburgh, who are   looking to  build on their success from last season  and challenge  for major honors this year.

When mighty Marlborough leads his warlike  bands,

Sure I'm absolved your Grace of all blame
In sailing hence to Cadiz:
But  as your friend, I beg  you'll  hear me
Just for a  minute.
When this   unlucky fleet was order'd
To sail for the south,
To  join our cousins, men of honour,
That's  when our  troubles began.

Barely out of port we met 'em
In  ev'ry direction
Of all your army,  which I told ye
From the  beginning.
'Twas more than just a pleasure
To welcome Prince George
And all your gallant army,
Which land'd them here,
And though inclined to heaviness
They'd keep us all   from harm.

They'd boast about   the French fleet
Being  chased to the  shore,
And  how they'd captured   cities
Both  seaports  and border towns,
Burnt docks and warehouses
And scatter'dplots of corn.

And  thus they'd keep us cheerful
Until we'd anchor'd   here,
Where we  found five French frigates
Ahead of us, it   seem'd  clear.
With one sail  in the distance,
Which they made  haste to chase,
And we  were   order'd  after  'em
Not to lag behind.

It was  scarce a mile behind us
When we made 'em out
Seven ships of the  line pursuing
Our scouts, it was a  dismal  sight.
With colours flying  we gave 'em chase
As  fast as we were able;
But soon we saw them  scattering
Each ship to save herself.

Then we came up with   their rear ships
Where  gallant action was to be seen
'twas then we learnt they'd scatter'd
And so we  took what prize we could.
Full carp'd  at by  the Dutch
We'd let one fifty-gun ship escape us,
And fear'd she'd give  the game away.

A council held, we soon decided
To chase the fugitives
For fear they'd  reach the  Dutch
And so we steered   due East.
We scarce had reached the station
When the clouds gave  place to the moon,
Which shining bright on the Dutchman
We could see him lurch and list.

At ten  they hail'd us, but no answer
For fear of being  known;
But we could see them plainly
And they could see us  too.
We could see each other's fleet
As plain as moonlight would allow,

Dear Lord,  lead me to heaven,
Lead  me to eternal life;

Lead me  from the evil one's  trap.

And take away my sadness  and despair.

I wish to follow You forever,
And live in the house of the Lord;
Lead me to heaven, and I will
Praise Your holy name. Amen.

Weather Permitting
by Philip   Booth

If the weather permits, we'll take the children
To the sands,  and watch  the mighty  surges
Of the Pacific pounding at  his feet,
And fetching down deep  loads of boulders
From the headlands. If the  weather permits.

If the weather permits,  we'll  show the children
The grey bulk   of  Alcatraz,  fortress
And prison,  where   the  hardest of criminals
Were contained,  although it never stopped them
From  attempting to  escape. If the weather permits.

If the  weather permits, we'll take the ferry
Back to the wharf, and eat crab salads
And look at the sea-gulls, while at anchor
The ferry lingers, and the sun  sinks slowly
Behind  the Golden Gate. If the weather permits.

Author's  Note: As the weather in San Francisco  can be cooler even in summer, visitors may need to  wear warmer clothes, and take the cable-car to  Chinatown, and browse the shops, and eat in an excellent Chinese restaurant, the City Hue.

The land was  ours
Before we were born
And still is ours
As  much as  ever
We have never resigned
Our claim upon  it
Nor have we ever
Accepted the will
Of those who  dispossess
What  always  has  been
And what will always be
 Ours to use
And ours to defend
We  live on  this land
Which is ours
Not theirs
They  talk  about "improvement"?
Before  they came
We lived here
In a  land of plenty
We  did not worry
We did not hurry
We lived as men
And   women should live
In this land we love
They  came with a different religion
And a different creed
And with a  determination
To force it on us
We tried to  discuss
Like gentlemen
But they would  have none of it
They   hated  our  skin
And the color of our  hair
And the shape of our noses
And the set of our eyes
Well, damn their eyes
And   damn   their noses
And damn their mouths
And damn their religion
And double  damn their guns
If looking for a fight
Or something  to shoot
They're welcome to their own
But let them leave  us alone
In the  land we love so well
Where we were born
Where we have lived
Where we will die
We have no gun
We have no club
But when  their guns are aimed
At our hearts
Then damn their guns
And  damn them all
Amen.

Political Romance
By Henry Austin Dobson
From "Fifty Poems"
What do we talk  about,  when we  talk about—
The Political Romance?
A more romantic   theme  was  never traced,
For a  plot that 's   intricate, and a climax at once bold,
And subtle, and original,--with a startled, long-drawn  "Ah!"
When the reader, rapt, and half doubting, arrives at  the denouement.
What do we  talk about, when we talk about--
The  wonderful conspiracy--
Of the five who were hatched in a single egg?
Or the man who was  hunchback, and  wore a  hump
On  his  back, as he wandered o'er the  world,
Thinking himself the only person alive,
Who was  not a millionaire--and half believing
That there  were no women  in the universe,
But was greeted, all in a moment,
By a thousand kisses, given
By  as many  girls, whom he found hiding
In  the corners of every boat  he met?
What do   we talk about, when we talk  about--
The wonderful conspiracy,
That there were just  exactly two
Beautiful women,--the same in face,
In figure, and in  size,--and that they lived
In the selfsame city, and in the same  street,
With the selfsame  name,--and that no man could say
Which was the mother of the flock of babes,
With the  golden hair, that shone so brightly
In the    picture,--the wonderful conspiracy?
Or the man who was  born at sea,--on a  ship--
The only son of a widow,  who had  buried
Her husband, with all his worldly goods,
And who, throughout the long voyage,
Was haunted by a spectre,--the spectre of  her husband,
Who, though he had been dead  just  half a year,
Still took his accustomed seat   at table,
And smoked  his pipe, and drank his  beer,
And  never, never  once said, "Thank you!"
When the very  kind  widow asked him--"Please?"--
And often,  very  often,  told her she was ugly?
What do we talk  about, when we talk about--
The  wonderful conspiracy?
And the  man who  was struck by lightning--
That very queer phenomenon,
Who afterwards, whenever he was seen
By persons, not too well-informed
Concerning natural phenomena,--was

"Food, Food, Glorious  Food"

Food, food, glorious food,
Warm and moist, crisp and crunchy,
Food, food, glorious  food,
Oh how it fills up my  mouth.

I love soup, I love salad,
I love  pasta,  I love dessert,
I love chicken, I love pork,
I do love  food, it's quite apparent.

Beef or lamb, fish or fowl,
I'm not fussy, I'll eat anything,
Food, food,  glorious food,
I  love  it all, I  love it anytime.

Food is  essential to life,
It's  the fuel  that keeps us going,
So let's celebrate it,
And  give thanks for such  bounty.

With  a grateful heart,
We'll  enjoy every  bite,
And savor the flavors,
Of this glorious feast.

The sea is calm to-night.
The tide is full, the  moon lies fair
Upon the straits;—on  the French coast  the light
Gleams and is gone; the cliffs  of England stand,
Glimmering and vast, out in  the tranquil  bay.

Come to  the window, sweet is the night-air!
Only, from the  long line of spray
Where the sea meets the moon-blanched land,
Listen! you hear the grating roar
Of pebbles  which the  waves draw back, and  fling,
At their return, up the  high  strand,
Begin, and cease,  and  then again begin,
With tremulous cadence slow,  and bring
The eternal note of sadness in.

Sophocles long   ago
Heard it, and set it   down   in tragedy:
The eternal note of sadness, which is in
The human heart, and which  will be till  the end
Of human history, and which calls out
For the  reconciliation of tears  with hope.

In the long summer days the  sea  lay brooding
Sullenly in the straits, uncertain ho!
To sweep the shore with foam, or patient to abide.

Listen! you hear the  grating  roar
Of pebbles which  the  waves draw back, and   fling,
At their return, up the high strand,
Begin, and cease, and then again begin,
With tremulous cadence slow, and  bring
The eternal note of sadness in.

And we, who listen, now again
Hear it,  and tremble. Ah, not in vain
May  Sophocles have uttered,   through the ages,
The  wisdom  of his  heart. The sea is calm to-night.
The tide is full, the moon lies fair
Upon  the  straits;—the light
Gleams and is gone; the  cliffs  of England stand,
Glimmering  and vast, out in the tranquil bay.

An Anatomy Of  The World

_(Version 1)_

By  Andrew Marvell

What is the World (said he)?

A case of Glasses, shining   forth

In sundry Shapes,

And Colours every where.

Which  God  hath  deck't

Full finely,

That Man may behold

What in him is.

Since then, said  he,

The  World's a Glass,

Suppose it brake,

And all the  Stars

Which it sustaineth fall,

And that  this Frame

Which  seemeth so exact

And curious,

Were but a Bubble;

Since it is evident

That  if  this Glass were gone,

The Stars which shine in it

Would shine no more;

And if  the  Frame were gone,

It's precious Things

Which now enrich it

Would  be suppos'd

To have no Being:

What Nature doth possess

Let Fortune have,

Which doth not that

Itself possess;

But what Fortune  hath

Let  Nature take again;

Her Gifts were  never given

Nor  yet her Claims  were  ever  none.

In this Poem the Idea of the _World_  is taken  in a  double Sense; of the  _Frame_ and Structure of the _Cosm_ ,  as also of  the _Vanity_ and _Folly of the World;_ which is that  _Vanity and Folly, that represents it self (as it were  in  a Glass) in  the Variety of Things present, and the continual Succession of  Times, Actions, and Events:  It is a Poem of  very grave and serious Note,  as appears  by  the ten last Lines.

Upon the whole _Anatomy of the World_ seems to allude to the  _Tabula Mentis_   ,  or _Mirror of the Mind_ , and may be considered as a kind of _Embleme, or Device_ of  _Human Life_.

"Carpe Diem Seize The  Day With A Hug

Relax, if just for this day, dont bear needless grudges
and allow your soul  to expand as it accommodates
whatever occurs. Understand  that  you are alive,
and  with that possession  comes the duty to  figure
out how best to use the time allotted. Try  to  devise
each day a fresh verdant beginning, a nourishing
ritual.  When you arise,  embrace the dawn with  a
good dearm, when evening comes, send  her off  with
a grateful bow.

And, knowing that our days are numbered,
strive  to  make  each day  a work of art, infused
with purpose and meaning. Fill your lungs
with air  and embrace the day with an embrace
as you would a dear friend, for indeed
that is what she  is.

Carpe diem,  seize the  day, with  a hug."

The sea is calm tonight,
The tide is  full, the moon lies fair
Upon the   straits; on the French coast the light
Gleams and is gone; the cliffs of England stand,
Glimmering and vast, out  in the  tranquil bay.

Come to the window, sweet  is  the   night-air!
Only, from the long  line of spray
Where the sea meets the moon-blanched land,
Listen! you  hear the  grating roar
Of pebbles which the waves draw back, and   fling,
At  their return, up the high strand,
Begin, and cease, and then again  begin,
With tremulous cadence slow, and bring
The eternal note of sadness in.

Sophocles long ago
Heard it, and set it  down in tragedy:
The eternal note of  sadness,  long,
With its wearisome, monotonous cry,
From  the dark caves behind  the stage,
Breathing over the  audience,  sighed
Its way into  their inmost hearts, and made
Their eyes  heavy  with tears; and now it seems,
Curiously  modulated by its own
Vitality, begins  again  its wail,
And fills the pauses between the trills of the spray.

Sophocles  long ago
Heard it, and saw it,   too, in  the throng
Of eager faces, haggard, and drawn,
With  sorrow  for  their own and others' woe,
Looking in expectation towards  the stage,
Where their tragedy had been acted through,
Thinking of many things,  and asking me,
Is this, indeed, the last of life, this moan?
This sound heard  under the stars, with  a sigh
Meant for a  lullaby to  pain?

But hush! the moon is  up, and now
From some  sad  soul the words die away.
Sophocles, a stranger to our race,
Heard it, and saw it,—and  now,   I pray,
In this old town by  the quiet sea,
Let us close   the window, draw the blind,
And hush this whimpering in our blood,
Until the morrow do  us part.

Hear my cry, O God,
listen  to my prayer;
from the end of the earth I  call  to  you
when my heart is faint.
Lead me  to the  rock
that  is higher than I,
for you have been my refuge,
a strong tower against the enemy.

I long to dwell in  your tent  forever
and take refuge in the shelter of your wings.
For you,  God, have heard my vows;
you have given me the heritage of those  who fear your name.

Prolong the life of  the  king;
may his years endure to  all generations!
May he be enthroned forever before God;
appoint  steadfast love and faithfulness to  watch over  him!

So will I ever  sing  praises to your name,
as  I perform my vows  day after day.

This poem is all about images that have   different  meanings for different people. For those who have a  visual identity, it can be hard to express themselves with  words, but by seeing   something  once or twice, people create connections. For  those with a conceptual identity, it's much harder to express why an image  is interesting  or meaningful. What images evoke for an  individual? "What is  the  image?" may be  the first question that comes to mind.  For someone  else,  looking "that" way or seeing   "that" image  and  knowing they are looking at it "that way" may  cause  thoughts of that image to pop up. For another, being familiar with  an image  can  bring meaning to the image. Some people find meaning from the  way an image looks, and others see it as a representation of  themselves. For the person looking at  a piece of  art for  the first time, it could be all about that image.A person's identity may have roots in  their past with images. A new artist  may be attracted by the same images or ideas that  have already captivated others. Even when a  person is  trying to understand how  concepts of  identity tie into images they have encountered, it may take time to find  the answer. A new  viewer may see "the image," but it does not necessarily mean the image  makes   him or her a different person. "What is this piece doing to you and how is this looking into your mind?" can be a very  common   and helpful question to  ask when trying to  understand images.For many of us, images can be  powerful sources of ideas about ourselves. We can use  images as guides, as a vehicle for    communication, or as a place  to seek new things. An image is usually taken in one moment;  it can be a very powerful source of inspiration  for an   individual, but  it has   several limitations. For most of us, images are often  limited to specific   places, times,  or forms of  life. The fact that images are more often  than not limited to one place  or one time can cause a person to   feel as  though  the image has  no meaning.  Images often look and feel very "limited"…but  they are not. We see in our dreams the same kind of images, but in  the dream  we know we are  dreaming because   we know what an image is and we are  not fooled because we  see a world  that is quite different from our own. This poem is   about the stars going over the  ocean. It's  about  the beauty of the sky  above us and the beauty  of the sea below  us. It's about the endlessness  of time and the infinite possibilities that exist in     our universe. And  it's about the fact that we are all connected. We're all  part  of something bigger than ourselves.

And it's about  the fact  that we can change things for the better. That we  can make a difference. That we can be heroes.

So go out  there and shine your light on the world. Shine your light on the people who need you most. Shine your light   on those  who have no hope.  Shine your light  on those who don't deserve it. Shine your light on those who will  never know happiness.  But shine your  light anyway. Because   if  you do,   then maybe they'll see the light  too.

O I,  for one, am very happy with  my new job working as an IT specialist in the human sciences at Stanford University...


I work as an associate professor (equivalent to a doctoral student) and have  my own lab, teaching assistant position  and postdoctoral fellowship.


My lab consists mostly of bioinformatics research on various   types of biology and computational pathology techniques in  genetics;  proteomics; evolutionary medicine; evolution science, evolution policy & ethics, genomics etc…and  several other areas related to bioinformation technology or  applied genomics/microarray analysis. I also do a lot of graduate research; but most of it concerns  problems not directly related to BIOS.


Most of the  students are undergraduates. A  few are even from Stanford University. Most are about 20 years old. They come from all over. In no particular order  I  could give  you  ten  examples on how we  use technology (computerized  data  processing), methods and   experimental design. Some we may call genomically minded, some perhaps computer vision  oriented,  others behavioral studies related using virtual reality, neuroscience approaches and computational systems. The  list  just goes on, so if you don't  take  any particular course then I can't say  why they are doing what they are doing  but many of them  seem inspired  by  some well known ideas   or  theories. You know they are going to be really useful in their career when their work will  help solve real world medical issues or develop effective treatments. As someone who has been looking  up to scientists, the more you learn about people writing  these papers they  inspire  you to work towards better science at your  institution or  department.


In addition to  bioinformatics  studies the graduate student body tends to  lean more towards theoretical bioengineering,  especially in terms of molecular bioart, which is pretty interesting. If I had  only two words that describe  how academic culture  works   there is definitely that in the   area. There's always something  happening  or being done  that  seems different (just like every other place where one exists). It  looks super  awesome, yet nothing important. Lots of creativity   and  excitement, however. So, as far  as I'm concerned, its a nice place with lots  of  potential.  Its  also  where students live in dorms  but that isn't  terribly bad for undergrad students anyway  since they make $16k per  year... which   still sounds good coming from me!
