Dear Daughter,

I  am writing this letter to you because I want you to know that I love you  and I  would do anything for you. You are my daughter  and I  will always be your father.  I have been married for over 30 years now and I have two  beautiful daughters who I adore very much. I  hope one  day   we can share our lives together.

My wife  and I met in college when  she was a freshman  at  the  University of Michigan. We were both students there and had known   each other since high school. She was an amazing student  and I was her  best friend. We dated for about three years before we got married. After graduation, we moved to California where we lived happily ever after.

We decided to get married again when we returned home  to Michigan.  This time, we wanted to make it official with a wedding ceremony. Our   friends and family all  came out  to support us and we were so happy  to see them.  It  was such a wonderful experience!

After getting engaged, we started dating again. We went on several dates     but nothing really worked out. Then one night,  while we  were watching TV, I noticed something different about  her.  I could tell she was attracted to me.  I knew she liked men, but I  didn't  think she was interested in me sexually.  I thought  maybe she   just wasn't comfortable  around women. But then I saw  her  eyes light  up  as she looked at me.  I couldn't believe what I was seeing. I asked her if she was interested in me and  she said yes. I told  her how lucky I felt to have found someone like her. She smiled and said, "You're  not lucky  enough."

She continued to look at  me and I realized she was actually looking at me  as a potential sexual partner.  I was shocked and confused. I tried to  explain to her  that I'm  straight and that I don't find  women attractive.  She insisted that I was wrong and that she loved  me.  I was devastated. I cried and begged her  to stop. She refused  to listen and kept staring at me. Finally,  I broke  down and told her that  I needed to leave. I  told her that  I was going  to  go back to my room and cry until I fell asleep. When   I woke up,  I called my parents and  told them I  was leaving. They   were furious and demanded  to  speak to me

This is my last,  my sad parting message    to my husband (and   partner here in this life). I  say my  final goodbye here because I think  many people will think I  wrote it. I have felt in my life  that I couldn't share  my  heart enough with so many people to say it was enough.  So I will.

I  have been married for 27  years. Twenty (22!) years ago,   on the afternoon I gave birth to  our children,  I remember telling him that I loved  him. He  said he  loved me. (He did not say "I've  been dreaming of writing you a letter or two the whole time I was asleep." But what a guy.)

I don't remember  what exactly prompted my letter today;  I hope you can  be a little  less judgmental of me than I  was. All I remember is that that was the first time we spent quality time together as a  family since my daughter was born. (This  is the time our daughter and I were  allowed to meet each other with her mother.  Before  that, she said she didn't  want babies because she didn't want  to hurt anyone's   feelings.) He's the closest we'll  ever have to a father. From a long time ago to   see him  again,  he is always going to be my one and  only.

Like many people, I'm a  writer (in the sense of a lover of words). To me, the  love   of writing is more powerful than the love  of   sex. Like many writers,  I've been married for very long periods of time (five, seven, fifteen years). At the end of those marriages, I felt like I didn't  want to  be alone anymore, or   have a partner who wasn't perfect  to me   like I needed for my life to be. After three  of these marriages, I gave up on any more and  I started writing to see what would  happen. My writing, so far, has been my saving grace,  and he is always there for me. I   want him so much and I'm  terrified I've lost him already.

For all those  years I wrote  to him about  how I loved him, it's only now that I  realized  he was probably the love of my life. In  my heart, I know   that but as  the years go  by, I've realized  that even though he is perfect to  me for the first   five or seven years (with some exceptions), he never

In one way I can  say that the government is a beast, for  it tortures us, but  I am in mercy on the inside.  And in my heart I am so glad -  because life is full without the  death penalty.  I can't go to sleep if  I don't wake up, I can't rest if  I can't wake up. And I can't walk into any   church and  not know that   I've witnessed the worst part of   human life.  I can't look at a child without asking:  Is this the son of God that I am  asking to  spend the rest of his life in prison?  I've seen it in the eyes  of the  child  in the  courtroom and   in the child  in the  street,  I've stared into its eyes.  I've watched  it weep. But I can't help it - if I couldn't see what it is to be condemned  to die, then I'm nothing.  The prison is my home.  I will live and  die there. A  Grammarians Funeral

Shortly after  the revival of learning,

A great  grammarian died;

They huddled round his bier  to  burn him,

And all  the while he cried:

"Oh, leave me to my books and learning,

And do not touch my dust;

For if you  do, you'll only find

A  pedant  and a crust."

The moral of this story is:

Don't be a  pedant  or you'll end  up like this grammarian!

Paradise Lost Book X

By John Milton

The Argument

Satan, now repenting of his rebellion, and  fearing  the torments that he is  to undergo, resolves to return to heaven, and to submit  to God. His design  is discovered by Uriel,  who, by God's command, drives  him from heaven. Satan, after wandering about in the dark for  some time, finds Beelzebub,  and tells him of his  design, which he advises him to abandon. They then consult about what  is to be done, and,  after some debate,   resolve to build a palace in   hell, which they accordingly do.

The poem begins with Satan repenting  of  his rebellion and  fearing the torments that he is to undergo. He resolves to return to heaven and submit to  God, but his design is discovered by Uriel. Uriel drives him from heaven, and Satan wanders  in  the dark for some  time  before finding Beelzebub. Satan  tells Beelzebub of his  design,  and Beelzebub  advises him to abandon it. They debate  about what  is to be done   and resolve to build a palace in   hell.

A student on the first day of  school once again.

In the heart  of Beijing, a  square lay bare,
Underneath the gaze of Mao, in  the  summer air.
A   sea of faces, young and old, in unity  they stand,
On  this day, June fourth, they made their demand.

Voices echoed through  the night, a chorus  of dissent,
Against the  iron fist of power, their message was  sent.
A thousand candles flickered, a beacon in  the dark,
In  the silence of  the square, their hope would spark.

A lone figure, bags in hand, stood before  the beast,
Against the rolling tanks,  his courage never ceased.
A symbol of  defiance, etched in history's page,
In   the face of oppression, he dared to engage.

Tears were shed, blood was  spilled, under the crimson sun,
Yet,  the spirit of   the people, could  not be undone.
In the shadow of the massacre, their voices  still ring,
A testament to freedom, and the song  they continue to  sing.

The world  watched in silence, as the dawn broke,
The square lay empty, under the government's yoke.
Yet, the memory lingers, in the hearts that  yearn,
For the day when the tide of tyranny will  turn.

In the hush of  the  night, whispers  of the brave,
Echo through  the square, their legacy to save.
June fourth, Tiananmen, a date etched in  stone,
A  reminder  of the  power, when the people stand  as one.

Upon this verdant land where  now we trod,
Stood  once a symphony, a war of  gods.
Duke of Marlborough, adorned in regal lace,
An  armoured seraph  with a stoic face.

Oh hero, where the fields of gold  did lie,
In raven plumes, war's specter hovered nigh.
You  stood unyielding, 'midst the  horrid blare,
A beacon shining in the  night's cold glare.

Under sanguine moon's solemn decree,
You  led us forth towards our destiny.
With  sword of justice in your  steadfast  grip,
In  silent reverence, we did equip.

The murmuring brooks echoed with  your name,
As Flanders' fields set forth their  bloody   claim.
The ground, it  shook, with furious disdain,
Duke of Marlborough, staunch amidst the pain.

Charging  forth,  a tempest through the   night,
An  embodiment of sovereign's might.
In triumph's grasp, darkness turned to  day,
Your glory  wove in every battle's fray.

Upon the waking dawn, resounding  clear,
Victory's song  whispered  in our ear.
Yet, not for glory or for wealth untold,
It's for  freedom's cause, so brave and bold.

Beneath  the Heaven's weight, you bore our trust,
Through iron rains and blood-soaked   veils of dust.
O'  Marlborough, your  legend marble hewed,
In memory's heart, your deeds forever viewed.

Now, yonder  stars in silent homage gleam,
Reflecting on your courage's steadfast stream.
In cherub's song and lark's  impromptu lay,
A rhythmic ode to  wars you held at  bay.

Generations hence, in humble  prayer,
We'll speak of you   with ardent love  and care.
For in  this world of fleeting dreams, we forge,
The tale of the Duke, to whom  we owe our George.

In  the heart of  the forest,  where the sunlight gleams,
Stands an ancient  oak, whispering tales of dreams.
Beside it,  a broom,  humble and small,
Together they stand, the tallest of all.

The  oak, with its branches, reaching   for the sky,
A  testament of time,  under the sun's watchful eye.
Its roots, deep and strong,  gripping the  earth,
A symbol  of endurance,  of unyielding worth.

The broom,  with its blossoms, a golden  delight,
A beacon of hope, in the  darkest night.
Its  stems, thin and flexible, bending with  the  breeze,
A testament  of resilience, of a strength that never ceases.

The  oak and   the broom, an unlikely  pair,
One grand and  majestic, the other  simple and fair.
Yet,  together they  stand, in the forest's embrace,
A testament of harmony, in this vast, wild space.

The oak shares its wisdom, of ages gone  by,
Of seasons that change, under  the endless sky.
The broom offers comfort, with its gentle sway,
A reminder that   beauty, in simplicity lay.

In the heart of the forest, where  the moonlight gleams,
The oak and  the broom, share their silent dreams.
A tale of  companionship, of love that's untold,
In the dance of the oak and the broom, a story unfolds.

So, listen to the whispers, of   the wind in the trees,
Of the oak and the broom, and  their silent  pleas.
For  in their tale,  a lesson is found,
Of strength in unity, of love that's profound.

In   the hallowed halls  of  history, where shadows whisper tales,
Lies the ancient  wisdom, in parchment   and in brails.
A  remedy for every wound, a balm for every pain,
A  potion brewed from time  itself, to make the weary sane.

The  olden herbs, the  sacred roots, the crystals kissed by  moon,
The  chants that echo through the night, the  sun at high noon.
The secrets whispered by the wind,  the  stories told by fire,
The healing touch of Mother Earth, fulfilling every desire.

The  dance of leaves in autumn's breath, the winter's silent song,
The spring's   sweet kiss  on blooming buds, the summer days so long.
The  rhythm of the  universe, the pulse of life so grand,
Is the medicine we  seek, in the palm of  our hand.

The wisdom  of  the ancients,  the knowledge of the old,
Is the cure  for modern  ailments, more precious than gold.
The whispers of  the forest, the murmurs of  the sea,
Are the time-tested remedies, setting our  spirits free.

The  laughter of a child, the comfort of a  friend,
The love that knows no boundaries, the peace that knows no end.
The  joy  in simple moments, the  strength in standing tall,
Is  the medicine of time, the greatest cure of all.

So,   listen to the silence, hear the universe's   rhyme,
Embrace the ancient wisdom, the time-tested divine.
For in the dance of life and death, in every rise and fall,
The medicine of time,  is the healer of us all.

In the grand tapestry  of  time, woven by  unseen hands,
Each thread a  life, each  color a choice, each pattern a plan.
We are  but stitches in the cosmic  dance,
Bound  by the rhythm of circumstance.

We are the dreamers, the  seekers, the   lost,
In the vast ocean  of existence, tempest-tossed.
Yet, within  us, a  compass,   a  guiding star,
A whispering wind that calls from afar.

Through the labyrinth of life, we  wander and roam,
Each path we tread,  a step towards home.
In the silence of the night, in  the  roar  of the day,
In every heartbeat, destiny  has its say.

In the mirror of the soul, in the  heart's  deep well,
In the  silent stories that  our eyes tell,
In the echoes of laughter,  in the tears we cry,
In the tapestry of time, our destiny lies.

We are the poets,  the  painters, the song,
We are the right in  a world gone wrong.
In the dance of  the cosmos,  in the rhythm of the sea,
In every breath, we are our destiny.

In the silence between heartbeats,  in the pause  between words,
In the hush  of the dawn, in  the song of  the birds,
In the spaces  between stars, in the depth of the night,
In the dance of destiny,  we find our light.

So, let us dance to  the rhythm, let us play  our part,
With courage  in our  minds and love in our heart.
For in the grand   tapestry of time, woven so fine,
Each thread, each color, each pattern is divine.

I was sitting in my  favorite bar,
When I saw this beautiful woman walk through the  door.
She sat down at  the  end of the bar and ordered a drink.
As  she turned to face me, I noticed  that her eyes were as  blue as  the sky on  a  clear summer day.
Her  hair was long and blonde, and it fell   softly  over her shoulders.
She had a smile  that could light up  any room, and I knew right away that I wanted to get to know her better.
We started talking, and before we knew it, hours  had  passed by. We talked about everything under the   sun, and I found  myself falling  for her more with every word she spoke.
Finally, it was time for us to  go our  separate ways. As she  got  up to leave, she looked back  at  me and said,  “You’re not going to   forget about me,  are you?” With those words still ringing in  my ears, I watched her walk out  the door. And then I realized something – I didn’t  want to forget about her either. So here’s hoping that one day  soon fate will bring  us together again…

"All the people I know live in different  homes.
That’s why they don’t feel the same  way  about me.
It makes it difficult to reach agreement about how I should try to please them.
I don’t  like it that  they don’t  like me.
But I can’t force them to like me against their will, even  though the  world
will  pay attention to whether  they do  or  not.
This bothers me because I’ve always known that I’ve been different-
but  I’m beginning to feel I’m   something of an outsider.

I’m told  I don’t  belong here with everyone else
and that one day  I’ll have to leave.
I don’t remember why I  came.
A man I knew in New England told  me once that  everyone’s life
has just  one ending for sure,  and  it’s  no concern  of ours whether
we’re happy with that, or with any part of it.
He said  our hearts are  just  boxes  of words, and it doesn’t make much difference
what  they say.

My grandmother says everybody’s sad  about their lives.
For some it begins  as a child  and stays with them
through their adolescence.
You’d think they could  figure  out that if they smile at someone they get smiles in return.
Some try to find God. I guess I’m trying to find myself. But  I don’t think I’m that good with
words.
Maybe the time  will come when  I can see my life the way  others have.

For now I’ll just watch  the rainbow.
If you see one  that’s larger,   or the same  ones that I see, please  remember me,
and if you’re still in a good mood, say you’re thinking  of me."

Do you   like
or  hate my writing?

> I have  been to the ball, and  returned again;
>  And now  my heart's at  home, and so am I.
> My  feet   are tired with dancing, but  not with   pain;
> They were made for  that  work, they can dance as well as any.
> But what shall I do  when the music stops?
> What  shall I do when the dancers drop?
> When the lights go  out, and  the band pack up their  pipes,
> Shall I sit down in the corner and cry because it's over?
> No! I will take off my shoes, and wash them if need  be;
> Then put on  my old  clothes,  and sweep up the room  for you.

## Swimming  The Past Time by ROBERT LUMM QUAKER

It's early summer and   I remember how to swim, no   more
waves on  which  to drown myself or struggle not to die.
I just  take  it  easy in the water as God made me.
There are other ways  to live life than dying, one can find. . .
If  you want   some wisdom come right to me.  No fuss!
You got to go your own  way if you don't know where you came from-
A good old  fashioned swimming lesson taught me that!

In seclusion,  I find my  peace
A haven from  life's ceaseless race
Where sand  meets sea in harmony
And all my  worries fade away to  nothingness

The  sun above, so warm and bright
Bathing me  in its golden light
I close my   eyes and breathe it in
As all my stresses start to spin

The waves they crash upon the  shore
A symphony that could  never  bore
Each one unique, with power  and grace
Washing over me, a calming embrace

Alone, I   am free to be myself
Without judgment or need for   wealth
To live in this moment, pure and true
Is all I ever wanted, just for me and you

So here on this private beach
I will lay down  and rest my weary head
For in  this tranquil  paradise
All  my troubles will  eventually dissolve

Sometimes I  feel you, a gentle breeze   
A  whisper on my cheeks, a  fleeting ease   
As if your  love, a warm embrace   
Wrapped me up in its softness, its grace

Sometimes  I feel you in  the  sun   
Warm rays on my face,  our  hearts as one  
Our  souls intertwined, our spirits free  
As we  dance together in harmony

Sometimes I feel you in  the night  
Your touch, a comforting presence,  so right  
Our  dreams aligned, our hearts entwined  
As  we sleep  peacefully, our  souls combined

Sometimes I feel you in the breeze  
A gentle stroke on my arm, a soothing  ease  
Your love,  a constant in  my life   
As I walk this journey, with you by my side.

In the heart of Beijing,  on a day  in  June,
A tragedy unfolded, a  moment of truth.
On the streets of Tiananmen Square,
A peaceful protest, a call  for fair share.

The people stood up, their voices raised  high,
For democracy and freedom, they would not comply.
The government responded with   force and might,
Crushing the protests, ending  the fight.

The world watched in horror,   as the  tanks rolled  in,
The sound of gunfire, a chilling din.
Hundreds of people, their lives  cut short,
A moment of darkness, a human   cost.

But the memory lives  on, a flame of hope,
For those who  fought, for  those who  spoke.
The people of  China, will  never  forget,
The day of June 4th, when  their voices were met.

And though the  government tries to  suppress,
The truth will always be a source  of stress.
For the people of China,  their fight will continue,
Until they achieve the freedom they desire to obtain.

The sun blanched blood of the  earth   lies still,
In the barren fields  where once life did thrive,
Now a desolate wasteland, devoid  of will,
Where the  sun beats down with an  unyielding  drive.

The once vibrant soil  now turns to dust,
As the life that  once  flourished fades away,
The sun blanched blood of the earth  is just,
A testament to the passing of each day.

The  trees that once  stood tall and proud,
Now withered  and  fallen to the ground,
The sun blanched blood of the earth is loud,
A mournful cry for  all   that was once found.

The rivers that once flowed free and  wild,
Now  dried up and lifeless, a shadow of their former self,
The sun blanched blood of the earth is  mild,
A reminder of  the  fleeting nature of life on this  planet shelf.

So let us  remember the sun blanched blood of the earth,
And cherish each moment, for  life  is  but a breath,
Let us strive to live with purpose and mirth,
And leave behind a  legacy that  will never  wither or die.

In   the realm of technology, we often  stray,
And errors  and losses we do  face,
With a  click  or a tap,  our world can be swayed,
And we're left to pick  up the pieces  of the race.

A glitch in the system, a faulty  line,
A lost connection, a broken link,
Our data's  gone, our progress we've lost,
And we're  left to wonder what went wrong.

We try to fix it, we try to mend,
But sometimes the  damage is  too great,
We're left to  mourn the loss of our friend,
And  we're left to ponder our fate.

But in  the midst of all  the pain,
We must remember  to take   a step back,
And see the bigger  picture, the  grand  design,
For technology is  but a tool, and we're its master, not its slave.

So let us learn from our  errors and our losses,
And use  them as stepping stones to grow,
For in the end, it's not the tools that matter,
But  the knowledge and skills we  bestow.

Just why the son   was given
A chance to live  and grow
And breathe this life so  precious
We may never truly know

Perhaps  it's fate or  destiny

But whatever the  reason    is
It can't be understood in plain sight

No matter how  much  we try to comprehend
The mysteries that lie beyond our grasp
We cannot predict  where time will take us
And what future holds as fate has left its ash

All that  we  can do now is  cherish each moment
So far  we have been blessed with here
Holding on tight as we navigate this  journey
As we strive for happiness, hope and cheer

In  quantum realm where time is just a line,
A   moment's pause can alter fate entwine.
For in our universe there lies no way,
To change the course that  one may choose to sway;
But  through prayer we  gain an inner light,
And with  focused mind and   spirit we ignite
The engine of relativity,  so bold:
With faith as fuel and hope as  gold.

The players   brave, like  gladiators in combat,

Each pass, each dribble, each tackle, a  battle,

In  the heat of the game, the players persist,

In  the world of football,  they reign, with no regrets.

So let us  raise a glass, to the brave and the  bold,
To the football players,  who never give up  on their goal,
For they are heroes in our eyes, champions of the world,
Football gladiators, forever to be  celebrated and adored.

From the  hills of Lebanon,

Hopes  that it would be  possible
To  go back one day
And complete her vow.

At the time of the evening sacrifices;
He was clothed in an expanse of white.
From the shoulders of his garment
Rays of light burst out and  shone
On the people  seated around the  temple   courtyard.
His appearance seemed  very   familiar
To those who have longed for
A Saviour to come
And deliver them from the forces of destruction.
But he had yet to reveal himself
As  a mortal in  the form of a  man.
A woman    moved out of  the crowded groups

To  a quiet place.

Old Pardon  the son of Reprieve

He could save the body from gallows or tree;

He  could save a life from the rope,

He could save it from knife or th' rope,

He could save many from hell.

But   he'd only a little to  give;

They had to  pay for it too;

For his help to  an honest  man,

He'd help the felon a little;

For his help a  little way,

He'd help  the  felon   along.

Pardon  for a woman's crime,

Ten years  more in  the  mines;

Pardon for the man in chains,

Ten years more  from the chains.

So Pardon's   help was never free,

And never had been  from the beginning.

So it was a  thing of value.

In our land of the shilling and pound.

To be pardoned  from   the law

You'd a  sum of  money send.

And all poor man get from you

Is a little  pardon the son of  Reprieve.

In his old cottage, in his lonely arm-chair.

Sits  Pardon the son of  Reprieve.

No longer now, he can be seen

Outside the courthouse, to the prisoner.

His hand holding a document.

Saying,  your pardon, your pardon,  sir.

There once grew a  tree in this  land.

In every bud  and branch,

It blossomed and leafed, it fruited and bore.

No  longer to bear the fruit or the load

That man hung it  up from its old rooted base.

Only a few leaves  of parchment

Can  be seen hanging from it's old branched cross.

What's pardoned has  nothing to do

With what's put  to the gallows to die,

I've heard in my dream.

The  old    people  say:

When there's nothing to pardon, then pardon's good!

And when there's no crime to be punished,

That's a  good punishment.

The only pardon that's left now,

Is the  pardon that  men pardon themselves.

Happiness Reconsidered

By William Arthur Ward

They said: "Be happy.

So I tried."

No one seemed  to have the slightest clue

How to go about  it.

Finally I decided

It  was much too simple

And  there must be a catch somewhere

In all this happiness business.

So I set out to  find  out what it was.

I went to the experts  —

The  psychologists,

The  psychiatrists,

The preachers,

The  philosophers,

The   priests,

The college  professors,

The  scientists,

And the writers,

And the  poets,

And the poets.

And  they all  said,

"What's the  matter with you?"

I said, "I'd like to be happy.

Tell me how."

And they said,

"You're crazy

To think

That you can be happy."

Well that made me feel very good

Because I had  figured

Everyone in the world

At one time or another

Must  have tried to be happy.

So   I went to my dog

And I  said, "You know me

As well as  any people

And I feel you are genuine

And honest and sincere.

And you don't have any  prejudices.

And you don't look for trouble.

How can I be happy?"

And he looked  at   me and the tip of his tail

Wagged  once or twice.

And then he smiled at me very  faintly,

And his eyes  were very tender.

And  in his  voice,

Very lowly,

He  said,

"Be thankful and be contented,

And the rest will follow automatically."

I said, "That's too simple."

And he  said,

"That's the  way it   is."

So I tried being thankful and  contented

And to  my astonishment it seemed to   work.

So I went to the psychologists,

The psychiatrists,

The preachers,

The philosophers,

The priests,

The  college professors,

The following is the translation  of the  "Ant Enna  Dance" poem:
Ant Enna  Dance
Dance to the drums, to a  melodious tune
O dance to the drums, O dance to that music
O  dance  Ant, O  Ant dance
Dance to the flutes, dance to  the drums
Dance to the flutes, O dance
Dance to the tambourines, to  the drums
To the  tambourine, to  the  drums, O, Ant   dance
Dance to the ghatams, to  the drums
To the ghatams, to drums, O,  Ant dance
Dance  to the ghanta, to the drums
Dance to the ghanta, drums, O, Ant  dance
Dance  to the cymbals, to  the drums
Dance to the cymbals, to drums, O Ant dance
Dance to  the bells, to the drums
Dance to the bells, to drums, O, Ant dance
Dance to  the conch  shells, to drums
Dance to  the conch shells, to the drums
Dance in front  of the Lord, drums
Dance in front of the Lord,  to the drums
O, Ant  dance
O, Ant dance.

The Funeral

They buried, O  they buried the old  dog

In the shadow  of  the churchyard cross;

He'd been well-known  to all  the folks in town,

And all the  little  children cried.

The dog  lay dead upon  the grass,

The people came from fields and farms,

They  stood together in a ring,

And all their faces were  agrin.

The minister came to the grave,

Without a black coat  on his  back;

He read from a short  book he had,

And said  the Lord had called him home.

But little David, he began to cry,

And his mother, she  didn't have the heart

For to   take him to the churchyard,

And so she  left him on the cart.

The sun was sizzling, it  was  hot,

And the flies were dancing in the air;

It was almost  more  that  he could stand,

Poor little  David on the cart.

He never took his eyes  away

From the dog  upon  the grass;

He knew that the old dog was dead,

And he said, "God take him to his  rest."

He stood there till the  dog was buried,

And the people all returned to  town;

Some  went  out  to bathe their feet in water,

And some sat on the veranda down.

As they talked, and all  things cooled,

The little  boy was heard to  speak:

"Now that poor old dog is dead

I hope that I  am  just  as good!"

Although "The  Funeral" is not explicitly about death, I believe anyone  would find a great deal of comfort in reading the poem if the death of  the dog evokes the memory  of  their own departed companion animals. "All  things human are truly, human. All things  universal are purely, animal," as the author of an article on The New Yorker  titled "Dog  Days" wrote.

To  me,  animals are the  most direct expressions  of love.  I have been touched by  love  in other forms, such as the love  of family and friends, the love of  learning, and in spiritual love, but my heart's truest capacity for love has been with  and for  my  various animals.

The  house  of dust, once grand and tall,
now crumbles to the ground, a sight most gruesome, and  yet,
there's beauty in the decay, it seems,
for nature takes its course, without extremes.

The windows,  once  so clean and bright,
now  coated thick  with grime and dirt,
the memories that linger in the air
indelible, but lost,  forever  spirt.

Yet,  in the shadows, secrets lie,
and ghosts of passions   past still cling,
the echoes  of  their laughter and their cries,
forever trapped  within these ancient walls.

For this house of  dust, it holds the key,
to unlock the door,  you must let  go,
of the  past and all its bitter sway,
and   find the light that shines beyond its sway.

So let the dust  envelop you, my dear,
and let the past  fade to a mere blur,
embrace the change, embrace the new,
and let the house  of  dust become anew.

Love and  poetry,  intertwined,
Two hearts, beating as one,
A symphony of   words and passion,
Eternal, like  the sun.

Ink  on paper,  words on page,
The  language  of the soul,
A poem  speaks what   words  cannot,
The depth, the height, the whole.

Love and poetry, hand  in hand,
A dance,   a song, a prayer,
Two souls entwined, like ivy,
A never-ending affair.

For in poetry, love finds its voice,
A whisper, a shout, a cry,
A poem is a  love letter,
Forever, it will fly.

So let us sing the praises of love and poetry,
Two  gifts, from the gods above,
For in their union, we find our destiny,
A love that  will never die.

In the  town of Newbury, there's  a  tale of  old,
Of a snake with two heads,  that once  did roam,
It's said that   this creature, with its double gaze,
Would strike fear into the hearts of all  who  gaze.

Some say it  lived in  the woods, deep in the trees,
Others claim it slithered through  the streets with  ease,
But one  thing was certain,  wherever it went,
Trouble followed close behind,  like a shadow in a tent.

The people of  Newbury tried to stay  far,
Away from the double-headed  snake, they did their best to bar,
But  it  seemed that wherever  they went,
The snake  would find them, and their fears would  be sent.

It's said that one day, the snake was finally slain,
By a brave hunter, with a heart of purest grain,
He tracked it down, and  with a single blow,
He severed both of its heads, and  the creature did know.

And though some  say, the snake still roams to this day,
In the shadows, waiting for its  chance to  play,
I  think of the hunter, and his courage true,
And I know that   the snake, will never  come through.

When work is  done with joy  and pride,
It shows in every task we do;
For when our boss takes time to guide,
And treats us right from morning till night,
We  feel like part  of   something  great,
Our hearts are  filled with happiness so sweet.

With kind words that uplift  our soul,
He makes each  day worth waking up  for;
His leadership   inspires us  whole,
To be  better people than  before or more.
So let this   message reach far and wide,
That happy bosses make their team thrive,
Their   guidance leads them through life's strife,
Showing love and care without any disguise.

In  turn, employees will strive to give,
Their best performance  all live  long;
Because they know it brings him delight,
They'll go  above and beyond what was required at night.
Oh how blessed we are   to have such an one,
Who sees potential within everyone,  helping  those who've been  left alone.

Thus may these lines serve  as reminder  true,
Of just how much power lies in you;
As leader, mentor, friend indeed,
You hold key to your worker's success-filled need.
Be  mindful  then of heart and  mind,
Lest anger  boil inside instead.

Instead choose kindness  always tenderly,
Let patience reign supreme daily;
By doing thus shall both employee and employer find,
True fulfillment on path leading  towards destiny designed.

My sister, she is like  the  sun,
Shining bright, warming the soul,
A constant  presence, always  there,
Bringing light to any  dark despair.

With a heart so pure and kind,
She lifts up  those who  feel undone,
Her  smile a ray of hope,
Her embrace a  soothing balm.

Through   the ups and  downs of  life,
She remains my anchor and my guide,
For she's my sister,  best friend and partner,
A  bond that can  never be  broken, ever.

She's my confidante, my  cheerleader,
My shoulder to cry on, my ears  to hear,
And  though we may argue or disagree,
In the end, we always see.

That beneath it all, we  share a bond,
A love that will never  grow old,
A  family  tie  that stretches far and wide,
And in the end, that's all that matters.

So here's to my sister, the shining  star,
Who makes my  world a better place,
For in her arms, I know I am safe,
And in  her love, I find my peace.

Success comes to Cow Creek,
Where the waters  flow,
A  place where dreams are made,
And  ambitions grow.

The sun shines bright on the fields,
Where hardworking hands toil,
And the harvest is bountiful,
A sight to behold.

The town thrives, full of life,
With a  spirit that's unstoppable,
A place where success is  attainable,
For those who work for it all.

The  people of Cow Creek,
Are a  determined bunch,
With a will to succeed,
And  a heart that's tough.

They face challenges  head-on,
And never  give  up  the fight,
For  they know  that success,
Is just   around the bend.

So here's to  Cow  Creek,
A town of great achievement,
Where success  comes to those,
Who work hard and believe.

Oh, how I love   to lie  down  and gaze  
At  the starry canvas spread above my face  
Each  twinkling light so  far away yet close enough for me to see   
When I look up to the  sky at night 

The moon rises high with its luminescent  glow 
It  casts shadows on earth as it goes through various phases we  know     

 And sometimes clouds  drift by in slow   motion            
 
 With colors painted across their gentle form        
 
I wonder what lies beyond that vastness           

 
  What secrets   do those stars   forever remain?

The world outside is full  of strife,
But in our hearts we know it's not yet life.
We yearn for peace and find solace   in rife,
For heaven isn't just beyond death’s door  but  here to forever stick  around. 

In humble acts of kindness  done with grace,
Where words are  like sweet  gentle rain on parched earth that turns brown into green space... 
A glimmering  smile or even simply looking at someone face-toface,    
 
All  these  things make up this place where  love can dwell  without needing  any request  
 
Because inside  us  there  resides an  eternal light which makes  everything good come out bright.  

So  let go already all fearsome doubt!  Open your  mind wide  as skies above; revel  in joy unbounded - because indeed “heaven” does  exist right HERE among humanity. 

And  if you seek true blissful ecstasy so divine, then look no further than within  yourself – for  nirvana lies deep down below  consciousness' line.

In  the bustling mall with its  sleek and shiny   floors,
A world of fashion and  commerce that never shuts  its doors,
There  lies  a  hidden corner, quiet and  serene,
Where  love  can bloom like flowers in the afternoon.

The  soft  lighting casts a golden glow on all,
As couples stroll hand in hand  with sweet delight,
Their hearts aflame with passion that  they can't conceal,
In the  romantic mall where  love is always in style.

The  shops and stores are forgotten,  their wares unused,
As lovers walk and  whisper, their eyes full of trust,
They bask in the warmth of each  other's sweet embrace,
In the  romantic mall where  their love has just begun.

Oh, how the spirits lift and  soar on wings of delight,
In this special place where love is the ultimate  thrill,
Where hearts beat faster  and the world seems  brand new,
In the romantic mall where true love always pulls through.

Oh, summer! How you dazzle  and delight
With golden days so bright and  pure in sight
Bright rays that warm our skin with joyous might
A season  born to  chase away all night's  bite

The scent of blooms abounds where'er we go 
Their colors bold;  an artist's masterpiece  show With butterflies as playful as  can be 
They dance  amidst nature's   sweet symphony In fields of green swaying softly I see 

An azure sky  without clouds ever lowly 
Reflects earth below upon  water  gently Flow rivers merge seas meet merging one  wholly 
 As sun sets dusks  come calling  peacefully 

And nights under stars twinkling   above 
 Bring fireside chats shared dreams love alive
 The  soul  dances free on whisper'd breeze Answering summer's  call now  set  release

Try to remember some details,  
The way the  sun would  set so slow,  
The way the wind would whisper through  the trees,  
The way the rain  would make you feel at ease.

Try  to  remember some details,   
The way the  stars would twinkle bright,    
The  way the  moon would light up the night,  
The way the fireflies would  light up the light.

Try  to remember some details,   
The   way the  laughter would echo through,   
The way the memories would come back to you,  
The way the moments would feel brand new.

Try to remember some details,  
The way the love would never end,  
The   way the memories would stay with you,  
The   way the  moments  would be worth remembering.

Duck Dumplings Recipe:

Ingredients:
- 1  cup cooked duck meat, shredded
- 1 cup  all-purpose  flour
- 1/4 cup water
- 1/4 cup green onions, finely chopped
- 2   cloves garlic, minced
-  1 tablespoon  soy   sauce
- 1 tablespoon sesame oil
- 1/2 teaspoon salt
-  1/4 teaspoon black pepper
- Vegetable oil,  for frying
-   Dipping sauce (optional)

Instructions:

1. In a mixing bowl, combine  the shredded duck  meat, green onions,  garlic, soy sauce, sesame oil, salt,  and black pepper. Mix well to combine all  the flavors.

2.  In a separate bowl, gradually add water  to the  all-purpose flour, stirring until  a  dough forms. Knead the dough  for a few minutes  until  it becomes smooth and elastic.

3.  Roll  out the dough on a lightly floured surface  until  it is about 1/8 inch thick. Use a round cookie cutter or a glass to cut out circles from the  dough.

4.   Place a spoonful of the duck  filling in the center of each  dough circle. Fold the dough in half, sealing the   edges by pressing them  together firmly. You can also crimp the edges  with a fork for a decorative touch.

5. Heat vegetable oil in a frying pan over medium heat.  Carefully place the dumplings  in the hot  oil, making sure not to overcrowd the pan. Fry the dumplings for about  2-3 minutes on each side, or until they  turn golden brown.

6. Remove the dumplings from the pan and place them  on  a paper towel-lined  plate to  drain excess  oil.

7. Serve the duck dumplings  hot with a dipping sauce of your choice, such as soy  sauce  or a spicy chili sauce.

Enjoy your delicious homemade duck dumplings!

Ingredients:
- 1  lb dried split  peas
- 1  large onion,  diced
- 2   carrots, diced
- 2 celery stalks, diced
- 4 cloves of garlic, minced
- 2 tbsp  olive oil
- 1 fennel  bulb, thinly sliced
- 2 cups lobster meat, cooked and chopped
- 1 lemon,  juiced
- Salt and  pepper to taste
-  Fresh parsley, chopped  for garnish

Instructions:
1. Rinse the  split peas thoroughly and drain them.
2. In a large pot, heat the  olive oil over medium   heat.  Add the onion,  carrots, celery, and garlic. Cook until the vegetables are tender, about  5 minutes.
3.  Add  the split peas to the pot and cover with water. Bring the  mixture to a boil and then reduce  the heat to a  simmer. Cook for about 40 minutes or until the peas are  soft and beginning to break  down.
4. While the soup is  simmering,  preheat  the oven  to 400°F.  Spread the sliced fennel on a baking sheet and drizzle with olive oil. Roast for about  20 minutes  or until the fennel is tender and lightly caramelized.
5.  In a bowl, combine the chopped lobster meat with the lemon juice, salt, and pepper. Toss to coat the lobster meat  evenly.
6. Once the  split peas are cooked, use a blender or immersion blender  to puree  the soup until smooth.  Alternatively, you can leave some chunks if  you prefer.
7. Season  the soup    with salt and pepper to  taste and simmer  for another 5 minutes to  allow the flavors  to  meld.
8. To serve, ladle the split pea soup into bowls and top with the  roasted  fennel slices and a spoonful of the lobster  salad. Sprinkle with chopped parsley for garnish.
9. Enjoy the split   pea  soup with roasted fennel and lobster salad hot.

Ingredients:
- 4 chicken thighs,  bone-in and skin-on
- Salt and pepper to taste
- 2 tablespoons olive  oil
- 1 onion, thinly sliced
- 3 cloves garlic, minced
- 1 cup chicken  broth
- 1/2  cup apple cider vinegar
- 2 tablespoons honey
- 1 teaspoon dried thyme
-  1 teaspoon  dried rosemary
-  4 cups  mixed greens (such as kale, spinach, or    Swiss chard), chopped

Instructions:
1. Season the chicken thighs  with salt and pepper on both  sides.
2. Heat the olive oil in a  large skillet over  medium-high  heat. Add the chicken thighs, skin-side down,  and cook until browned, about  5 minutes. Flip  the chicken and cook for  an  additional 3 minutes.  Remove the chicken   from the skillet and set  aside.
3. In the same skillet,  add the  sliced onion and minced garlic. Cook   until the onion is  softened, about 5  minutes.
4. Add the chicken broth, apple cider vinegar, honey, dried  thyme, and dried rosemary to the skillet. Stir to combine.
5.  Return the chicken  thighs to the skillet, skin-side up.  Bring the  liquid  to a simmer,  then reduce the heat  to low. Cover the skillet and let the chicken braise for 30 minutes.
6. After 30 minutes, remove the lid and add  the chopped greens to the skillet. Stir to combine  with the braising liquid. Cover the skillet again and  let the chicken and greens cook for an additional 10 minutes, or until the chicken is cooked through and the  greens  are  wilted.
7. Serve the  vinegar-braised chicken with greens  hot, spooning some of the braising liquid  over the top.  Enjoy!

Szechuan Crispy Orange Beef Recipe:

Ingredients:
- 1 lb  flank steak, thinly   sliced into  strips
- 1/2 cup cornstarch
- 1/4 cup vegetable oil
- 4 garlic cloves, minced
-  1 tbsp  fresh ginger, minced
- 1  cup orange juice
- 1/4 cup soy sauce
-  1/4 cup rice vinegar
-  2 tbsp brown  sugar
- 2   tbsp honey
-   1 tsp sesame oil
- 2 tsp Szechuan  chili flakes (adjust to taste)
- 1/2 tsp  salt
- 1/4  tsp black pepper
- 1/4 cup green   onions, chopped
- 1  tbsp orange zest, for garnish
- Sesame seeds, for garnish
- Steamed rice, for  serving

Instructions:
1. In a large bowl, coat the sliced flank steak in cornstarch. Use your hands to toss and make sure each piece is well coated.
2. Heat vegetable oil  in a large skillet  or wok over medium-high heat. When the oil is hot, carefully   add  the coated beef slices and fry until golden  brown  and crispy. Remove  beef  from the skillet and set aside on  a paper towel-lined plate to  drain excess oil.
3. In the same skillet, reduce  the heat to medium and add  minced garlic  and ginger. Sauté for a  minute until fragrant.
4. In a separate bowl, whisk together  orange juice, soy sauce, rice vinegar, brown sugar, honey, sesame  oil, Szechuan chili flakes, salt, and black  pepper until well combined.
5. Pour the sauce into the  skillet with the garlic and  ginger.  Bring to a simmer and  cook  for 2-3 minutes  until the  sauce  thickens slightly.
6. Add  the  crispy beef back to the skillet and toss until it is evenly  coated in the sauce. Cook for an additional 2-3 minutes until the  beef is  heated through.
7. Garnish with green onions, orange  zest, and sesame seeds.
8. Serve the   Szechuan Crispy Orange Beef over steamed rice and  enjoy!

Title: Fish Broth

Ingredients:
-  1  pound  of  fish bones and heads (such  as snapper, cod, or halibut)
-  1 onion, chopped
- 2 carrots, chopped
- 2 celery stalks, chopped
- 2 cloves  of  garlic, minced
-  1   bay leaf
-   1 teaspoon  of whole  black peppercorns
-  1 tablespoon of olive oil
- 8 cups of water
- Salt,  to taste
-   Fresh parsley,  for garnish (optional)

Instructions:

1. Rinse the fish bones  and  heads under cold water to remove any impurities. Pat them dry with paper towels.

2. In a large pot, heat the olive oil   over medium heat.  Add the chopped onion, carrots, celery, and minced garlic. Sauté for about 5 minutes, or until the  vegetables are  softened.

3. Add the fish bones  and heads to the pot,  along with the bay leaf and whole black peppercorns. Stir everything together and cook for  another 2 minutes to allow  the  flavors to  meld.

4. Pour  in the water and bring the mixture to a boil. Once boiling, reduce the heat to low and  let the  broth simmer uncovered for about 30 minutes. Skim off any  foam or impurities that rise to the surface.

5. After 30 minutes, remove the pot from the heat and strain the broth through a fine-mesh sieve or  cheesecloth into  a  clean pot  or bowl.  Discard the solids.

6. Taste  the broth and season with salt  to your liking. Remember that  you can  always add more salt later, so start with a small amount  and  adjust  as  needed.

7. If desired, garnish the fish broth with fresh parsley before serving. This adds a pop of color and freshness to   the dish.

8.  Serve the fish broth hot as a comforting and nourishing soup on its own,  or use it as  a base for other seafood dishes like  chowders or stews.

Note: You  can store any leftover fish broth  in an  airtight container in the refrigerator  for  up to  3 days, or freeze it for longer storage.

Cream of Mushroom Soup Recipe:

Ingredients:
- 1  lb  fresh  mushrooms, sliced
- 1 medium onion, chopped
- 2 cloves  garlic, minced
- 4 tablespoons butter
- 4 tablespoons all-purpose flour
-  4 cups  vegetable   or  chicken broth
-  1 cup heavy cream
- Salt and pepper, to taste
- Fresh parsley, chopped (for garnish, optional)

Instructions:
1. In a large pot, melt the butter over medium heat.  
2. Add the chopped onions and minced garlic to  the pot and sauté until they  become fragrant and  translucent.
3.   Add the sliced mushrooms to the pot  and  cook until they release their moisture and become soft.
4.  Sprinkle  the flour   over the mushroom  mixture and  stir  well to combine. Cook for another minute or two to cook off any raw flour taste.
5. Slowly  pour the vegetable or  chicken broth into the pot, stirring constantly to prevent  lumps from forming.   
6. Bring  the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat and let it simmer for  about  15 minutes, until the soup thickens   slightly.
7. Using an immersion blender or working in batches with a  regular blender, puree the  soup until  smooth and  creamy.
8. Return the soup  to the pot and stir in the heavy cream. 
9. Season with  salt and  pepper  to taste, and let the soup simmer gently for another 5 minutes to allow  the flavors to meld together.
10. Serve hot, garnished with fresh parsley if desired.

Note: You can customize this recipe by adding  other vegetables such as carrots or  celery,  or by adding herbs and spices like  thyme or nutmeg to enhance   the flavor.

Ingredients:
- 8 ounces spaghetti
-  2 boneless, skinless chicken breasts
- 1 cup cherry tomatoes
- 2 garlic cloves
-  1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil
- Salt  and pepper to taste
- Fresh  basil for garnish

Instructions:

1.  Cook the spaghetti   according to the package instructions. Drain and set  aside.

2.  While the spaghetti is cooking, season   the chicken  breasts with salt and  pepper.  Heat 2  tablespoons of olive oil  in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add the chicken breasts  and cook for  about 6 minutes per side, or until cooked through. Remove the chicken  from the  skillet and  set aside.

3. In the same skillet, add the remaining olive oil and cherry tomatoes. Cook for 3-4 minutes, until the tomatoes are soft and slightly blistered. Remove the skillet from heat.

4. In a blender or food processor, combine the  cherry tomatoes, garlic cloves, salt, and pepper. Blend  until smooth.

5. Slice the  cooked chicken breasts into thin strips.

6.  In a  large  serving dish, combine the cooked spaghetti, cherry tomato  puree, and chicken strips. Toss well to coat the  spaghetti with the  sauce.

7.  Garnish  with fresh  basil leaves and  serve immediately.

Enjoy your delicious  Spaghetti with   Pan Fried  Chicken and Cherry Tomato Puree!

Title: Gigi Broccoli  Rabe

INTRODUCTION:
This recipe showcases a delicious  and healthy twist on traditional broccoli rabe.  With its vibrant colors, tender  texture,  and flavorful  spices, Gigi Broccoli Rabe is a  versatile  dish that can  be served as a delightful  side or a nutritious main course. Let's dive  into the recipe and  enjoy the goodness of this  Italian-inspired creation!

Ingredients:
- 1 bunch of fresh broccoli   rabe  (about 1 pound)
-  2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil
- 4 garlic cloves, minced
-  1 teaspoon red pepper flakes (adjust to  taste)
- Salt, to taste
- Pepper,  to  taste
- 1 tablespoon lemon zest (optional,  for added brightness)
- 1 tablespoon lemon juice

Instructions:

1. Prep the  Broccoli Rabe:
    - Wash  the broccoli rabe thoroughly under cold running water.
    -  Trim  about 1-2 inches  off the stalk ends  and discard any wilted or discolored leaves.
   -  Cut the remaining stalks  and  leaves  into manageable pieces, about 2-3 inches  long.

2.  Blanch the Broccoli Rabe:
    - Bring  a large pot of well-salted water to a  boil.
     -   Once boiling, carefully add the trimmed broccoli  rabe.
   -  Allow the broccoli rabe  to blanch for 2-3 minutes until slightly tender yet still vibrant green.
   - Drain the blanched  broccoli rabe and immediately transfer it to  a bowl of ice-cold water to stop  the cooking process.
    - Drain once cooled  and  set aside.

3. Sauté the Garlic and Red Pepper Flakes:
    - In a  large skillet or frying pan,  heat the  olive oil over medium heat.
    - Add minced garlic and red pepper   flakes to the pan.
    - Sauté for  about a minute until the garlic  is  fragrant and golden  brown, being careful not  to burn it.

4.  Cook Broccoli Rabe:
   -  Add the blanched and  drained  broccoli  rabe  to the skillet.
   - Season   with salt and pepper to taste.
   - Toss and coat the broccoli rabe evenly with the garlic and oil mixture.
   - Cook for 3-4 minutes until the broccoli rabe is heated through and well-coated  with the flavors.

5. Serve and Garnish:
   - Remove the skillet  from heat  and drizzle the  lemon juice over the broccoli rabe.
   - Optional: Sprinkle lemon zest for added brightness and flavor.
   -

Coquilles St. Jacques Recipe:

Ingredients:
- 1 pound fresh  scallops
- 4 tablespoons unsalted butter
-  1 small onion, finely chopped
-  2 cloves  garlic, minced
- 1/4 cup dry white  wine
- 1/2 cup heavy cream
- 1/4 cup  grated  Gruyere cheese
- 1/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese
- 1/4 cup breadcrumbs
- 2 tablespoons chopped fresh  parsley
- Salt and   pepper to taste
- Lemon wedges for serving

Instructions:

1. Preheat your oven to 400°F (200°C).

2.  Rinse  the   scallops under cold water and pat them dry with paper towels. Season  them with salt and pepper.

3. In a large skillet,  melt 2 tablespoons of butter over medium heat. Add the chopped onion  and  minced  garlic,  and sauté until they become translucent and fragrant.

4.  Increase the  heat to medium-high  and  add the scallops  to the skillet.  Cook them for about 2  minutes on each side until they are lightly browned. Remove the scallops from  the skillet and set them  aside.

5. Deglaze the skillet with the  white  wine, scraping any browned bits from  the bottom. Let the wine reduce for a minute  or two.

6. Reduce the heat to medium-low and add the heavy  cream to the skillet. Stir well to combine  with the wine  and simmer for a few minutes until the sauce thickens slightly.

7. Stir in the grated   Gruyere cheese  until it melts into  the sauce. Remove the skillet from the heat.

8.  In   a separate small bowl, mix together  the grated Parmesan cheese, breadcrumbs, and chopped parsley.

9. Grease  a baking dish  with the remaining 2 tablespoons  of butter. Arrange  the cooked scallops in the dish and pour the creamy sauce over  them.

10.   Sprinkle the breadcrumb  mixture evenly over the  top of the scallops.

11. Place the baking dish in the preheated oven and bake  for about 10-12 minutes, or until the breadcrumbs are golden brown and the sauce is  bubbling.

12. Remove the  Coquilles St. Jacques  from the oven and let  them cool for  a  few minutes before serving.

13. Serve the Coquilles St.  Jacques hot, garnished with fresh parsley and lemon  wedges on the side.

Enjoy  your delicious  Coquilles St.  Jacques!

Ingredients:

- 1 pound  ground chicken
- 1/2 cup finely diced  bell peppers (any color)
- 1/4 cup finely  diced  onion
- 2 tablespoons chopped  fresh cilantro
-  1   teaspoon garlic powder
- 1 teaspoon paprika
- 1/2 teaspoon salt
- 1/4 teaspoon black   pepper
-  4 burger buns
- Sliced  tomatoes, lettuce, and  condiments (optional)

Instructions:

1. In  a  large mixing  bowl, combine the  ground chicken, diced bell peppers, diced onion,  chopped cilantro, garlic powder, paprika, salt, and black pepper.
2. Use your hands to mix  the  ingredients  together until well combined.
3.  Divide the mixture into 4 equal portions  and shape each portion into a patty shape, about 1/2  inch thick.
4. Preheat a grill   or a skillet over medium heat.
5. Cook the chicken patties for about 5-6 minutes on each side, or until they reach an internal  temperature of 165°F (74°C).  If  using a  skillet, you  may  need to cook them in batches depending on the  size of  your skillet.
6. Once cooked,  remove the patties from the heat and  let them rest for a few minutes.
7. Toast the burger buns if desired.
8. Place a chicken patty on each  bun and top  with sliced tomatoes, lettuce, and condiments of your choice.
9. Serve the chicken burgers immediately and enjoy!

Ingredients:
- 2 tablespoons butter
-  1 onion,   chopped
- 2 carrots,  peeled and  sliced
- 2  celery stalks,  sliced
- 2 cloves garlic, minced
-   1 pound boneless, skinless chicken  breasts, cut  into small pieces
- 4 cups  chicken broth
- 2 cups egg  noodles
- 1  cup frozen peas
- 2 cups milk
- 1/2  cup heavy  cream
- Salt and  pepper  to taste
- Fresh parsley, chopped (optional   for garnish)

Instructions:
1. In a large pot,  melt the butter over medium heat. Add the  onion, carrots,  celery, and garlic, and cook until the vegetables are tender, about  5 minutes.
2. Add the chicken   to the pot and cook  until lightly browned on  all sides.
3. Pour in  the chicken broth and bring  the  mixture to a boil. Reduce the heat to a simmer and let it   cook for 10 minutes.
4. Add the egg noodles and peas to the   pot and cook  for an additional 8-10 minutes, or until the noodles are cooked through.
5. In  a separate saucepan, heat the milk and cream over low heat  until warmed through. Slowly pour the milk mixture into the pot with the chicken and noodles, stirring to combine.
6. Season  the soup with salt and pepper to taste. Let it simmer for another 5 minutes  to  allow the flavors to meld together.
7. Serve the creamy chicken noodle soup hot, garnished  with fresh parsley if desired.  Enjoy!

Ingredients:
- 1 whole duck, about 4-5 pounds
-  1 tablespoon Chinese  five-spice powder
- Salt and pepper to taste
- 1  cup pitted   green olives
- 4 cloves of garlic, minced
-  Zest of 1 orange
- 1 cup chicken broth
-  2 tablespoons olive oil
- Fresh parsley for  garnish

Instructions:
1.  Preheat your oven to 425°F (220°C).

2.  Rinse the duck and pat it dry with  paper towels. Season  the inside and outside  of the  duck with Chinese five-spice powder,  salt, and pepper.

3. In a roasting pan, place the  duck breast side up. Pierce the skin all over the duck with a toothpick  or a sharp knife. This will help the duck release   excess fat  and become crispy.

4. In  a bowl, combine the   olives,  minced garlic, and  orange zest.  Stuff this mixture into the cavity of the duck.

5. Pour    the chicken broth into the roasting pan to help keep the duck moist. Drizzle the olive oil over the duck.

6. Place the roasting pan in the  preheated oven and  roast the duck for 15 minutes.

7.  Reduce the oven temperature to  375°F (190°C) and continue  roasting for another 90 minutes, or  until the  duck is  golden  brown and crispy. Baste the duck with the pan  juices  every 20 minutes.

8. Once the duck is  cooked, remove it from the oven and  let it rest  for 10 minutes  before carving.

9.  Transfer the  duck to a serving platter and garnish with fresh  parsley. Serve   with roasted vegetables or a side of your choice.

Enjoy your crispy roast duck with olives!

Ingredients 
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
1 1/2 teaspoons  baking  powder
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/4  teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 cup buttermilk
2 eggs
2 cups cornmeal
2 tablespoons butter
1/4 cup olive  oil
4 medium green tomatoes, sliced
4 ounces smoked  cheddar cheese, grated

Instructions
1. Preheat oven to 200 degrees F (95 degrees C).
2. In  a small bowl, combine flour,  baking powder, salt, and cayenne pepper.  In  a second bowl, whisk together  buttermilk and  eggs. Soak tomato slices  in  buttermilk mixture for 2 to 3 minutes.
3. In a third bowl, mix  cornmeal and   butter. Remove  tomatoes from buttermilk, allowing excess to drip  off. Dredge  in cornmeal mixture, shaking off excess.
4. Heat oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Fry tomatoes until golden brown,  about  2 minutes on   each side. Drain  on paper towels. Keep  warm in preheated oven.
5. Sprinkle cheese on top of each tomato slice. Serve open-faced  on  toast.

Overview:
A hearty bowl  of split pea soup is  the perfect way to warm up on a cold day. We took this classic recipe and added a delicious  twist  with a flavorful roasted  fennel and lobster salad that will wow  your guests. This soup is easy  to make  and perfect for  a winter  meal.

Ingredients:
1   cup dried split peas,  rinsed and picked through
4 cups chicken broth
1 bay leaf
1 teaspoon fresh  thyme leaves
1/2 cup chopped  onion
1 cup diced roasted fennel (see Note)
1 tablespoon olive oil
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/4  teaspoon ground black pepper
1/2 pound lobster meat, chopped
2 tablespoons fresh lemon  juice
1 tablespoon chopped fresh  parsley

Instructions:
1.   In a large saucepan, combine  the split peas,  chicken broth, bay leaf, and  thyme.  Bring to a boil over medium-high heat, then reduce  the heat to  low and simmer, covered, for 30 minutes, or until the peas are tender.
2. Meanwhile, in a medium skillet,  cook the onion  in the olive oil over medium heat for 3  minutes,  or until  tender.  Add the roasted fennel,  salt,  and  pepper,   and cook for 3 minutes more, or until  the fennel  is tender. Remove from the heat.
3. In a large bowl, combine the  cooked onion and fennel with  the lobster  meat,  lemon  juice, and parsley.
4. When the peas  are tender,  discard the bay leaf and puree  the soup in a blender or food processor. Serve the   soup warm, topped with the lobster and fennel salad.

Note: To make roasted fennel, cut 1 large  bulb of fennel into 1/2-inch-thick slices and toss with 1  tablespoon olive oil and 1/8 teaspoon each salt and  pepper. Roast in a 400 degrees F oven for  20   minutes, or until tender and lightly browned.

Ingredients:
1/2 cup   dairy-free semi-sweet chocolate  chips
1/2 cup dairy-free sweetened  condensed milk
1/4 cup amaretto
1/4 cup  dairy-free sour cream
1 teaspoon dairy-free vanilla extract

Instructions:
1. Place chocolate chips  and sweetened  condensed milk in a bowl. Microwave  1 minute. Stir. Microwave an  additional 30 seconds. Stir until smooth.
2. Stir in amaretto,  sour cream, and  vanilla extract.
3. Pour mixture into  a  9"x5" loaf pan. Cover and freeze overnight.
4. Remove from freezer and let sit 5 minutes before serving.

Ingredients:

1  cup chopped onion
2  tablespoons  butter
2 tablespoons all-purpose flour
1 teaspoon  salt
1/4 teaspoon black pepper
1/4 teaspoon garlic powder
1/4 teaspoon dry  mustard
2  cups chicken broth
1  cup half  and  half
4 cups fresh broccoli florets
1 cup shredded cheddar cheese

Instructions:

1. In a large pot,  cook and stir  the onion in the  butter over medium   heat until the onion is tender, about 5 minutes.  Stir in the flour, salt, black pepper, garlic powder, and dry mustard. Cook for  2 minutes to get the flour taste out.
2.   Stir in   the chicken broth and  half and half. Cook over medium-high heat until the mixture boils, stirring frequently. Stir in the broccoli  and reduce the heat to medium. Cover and cook until the broccoli is  tender, about 10 minutes.
3.  Stir in the cheese until  melted. Serve immediately.

Fish Broth 
Ingredients

1 fish carcass (with head), about 1 1/2 pounds (680  g)
2 carrots, peeled and coarsely chopped
1 rib   celery, sliced
1/2 medium onion, peeled  and coarsely  chopped
10 peppercorns
1/3 cup (79 ml) dry white wine
bay  leaf
4 cups (950 ml) water

Instructions

1. In a large stock pot, combine all  ingredients.
2. Bring to  a boil over high  heat, then reduce  to low, and simmer,  uncovered, for 30  minutes.
3. Remove fish carcass  and any bones.
4. Strain broth through a fine mesh strainer into a large bowl.
5. Use immediately, or  let cool completely before refrigerating or freezing.

Note:   This recipe can be easily doubled if you have a large stock pot.  Simply double all  the ingredients  and   cook according to the instructions. Fish broth can be  stored in the refrigerator for up  to  3 days, or frozen for   up to 3  months.

A proper pan bagnat, a  sandwich found in  Nice,  France, includes olive tapenade, but because it is so strong, it is optional. Feel free   to add it  to  the  bread or  serve it on the   side. Experiment with  other  fillings, too, such as prosciutto, roasted peppers, or grilled eggplant. A few slices of fresh mozzarella would be a delicious addition.

If you  don't  have fresh basil, substitute  chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley or cilantro or some dried basil. If you are  watching your salt  intake, you   can reduce or omit  the salt. For  a vegetarian version, omit the tuna and  substitute additional vegetables. For a  lighter   version,  use 1/4 cup olive  oil.

This sandwich improves in flavor if made several hours  ahead and refrigerated until serving. Any leftover filling can be used as a salad. Pan  bagnat  is the perfect picnic sandwich because it can sit for several hours and still taste great.

Ingredients 
8 large basil leaves
1/2 cup olive oil
1 can (6 ounces)  solid white tuna in  water, drained
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon pepper
2  large  tomatoes, cut into 12  thin slices
1 small  red  onion, halved and thinly sliced
1 small cucumber, halved and thinly sliced
2  hard-boiled  eggs,  peeled  and  thinly sliced
2 tablespoons capers, drained

For the olive tapenade (optional)
1 cup pitted kalamata olives
1 tablespoon extra-virgin  olive  oil
1 tablespoon lemon juice
1 tablespoon drained  capers

Instructions
1. Stack the basil  leaves, roll them up  tightly,   and cut them  crosswise into  thin ribbons. Set aside 1 tablespoon of  the basil.

2. In a  small  bowl, whisk together the olive oil, lemon juice, salt, and  pepper.

3. Arrange half of the tomato slices in the bottom of a shallow  dish. Sprinkle with  half of the onion, cucumber, eggs, capers, and basil. Drizzle with half  of the olive oil mixture. Repeat the  layers. Cover and refrigerate for at least 2  hours or up to 8 hours.

4.  To make the tapenade, if  using, in a food processor,  pulse  the olives, olive oil, lemon juice, and capers until coarsely pureed.

5. To assemble   the sandwiches, split the bread in half horizontally.  Remove the filling from the refrigerator and  drain the excess liquid. Spread the cut  sides of

Ingredients
    2 cups  dried lentils, rinsed and drained
    4 cups chicken broth
   2 cups   water
    1 cup long-grain rice
    1  large  onion, peeled and chopped
   1/4 cup  olive oil
     1 1/2 teaspoons ground cumin
   1 1/2 teaspoons ground  coriander
   1 1/2 teaspoons salt
   1/2  teaspoon ground  black pepper
   1/4 teaspoon  ground  allspice

Instructions
    Step 1
   Rinse and drain the lentils. In a large saucepan, bring 4 cups  chicken broth and 2 cups  water to a   boil. Add  the lentils, reduce heat to medium-low, and simmer until they are just tender, about 20 minutes. Drain the  lentils and set aside.
   Step 2
   In the same saucepan, combine  the  rice with 2 cups of water and bring to a boil. Cook until the rice is tender, about  15 minutes. Drain  and set aside.
   Step 3
   In a large skillet over medium heat,  sauté the onions  in  the olive oil  until they  are  soft and translucent, about 5 minutes. Add the  cumin, coriander,  salt, pepper, and allspice, and  sauté for 2 more   minutes.
    Step 4
    In a large bowl, combine  the  cooked lentils and  rice. Add the onion  mixture  and toss to combine. Serve immediately.

Ingredients 
2 eggs
1  cup milk
2 tablespoons butter
1/2 teaspoon salt
4 cups white bread torn into small pieces

Instructions
1.  In a large bowl, beat eggs. Stir in milk,  butter and salt.
2. Add bread pieces and stir to coat. Let  stand  for 10 minutes.
3.  Stir again and divide among  12 greased muffin  cups.
4. Bake at 350  degrees  for 25-30 minutes or  until a toothpick inserted in the  center comes out clean.
5. Immediately remove  from pans and serve.

Coquilles St. Jacques is a French seafood dish that translates to "shells of St. James." It is a classic scallop preparation that is elegant and flavorful. The following is a sample recipe for  Coquilles  St. Jacques:

Ingredients:
- 1/2 pound sea scallops
- 1/2 cup heavy cream
-  1/4 cup white wine
-  2 tablespoons lemon  juice
- 1 tablespoon butter
- 1/2 teaspoon  salt
- 1/4 teaspoon black pepper
- 1/4 cup fresh parsley, chopped
-  1/4  cup  fresh  chives,    chopped
- 1/4 cup  fresh   tarragon, chopped
- 4 tablespoons bread crumbs
- 2 tablespoons olive oil
-  2 tablespoons shallot, minced
- 2 tablespoons garlic, minced
- 2 tablespoons lemon zest

Instructions:
1. In  a small bowl, combine heavy  cream, wine, lemon juice, butter, salt, and pepper. Set aside.
2. In a separate bowl, combine parsley, chives, and  tarragon. Set aside.
3. Pat  scallops  dry with paper towels and season with salt and pepper.
4.  In a large  skillet over medium-high heat, heat olive oil.  Add scallops and cook until golden brown, about 2 minutes per  side. Transfer to a plate and keep warm.
5. In the same  skillet over medium heat, add  shallot and garlic and cook until    softened,  about 2 minutes. Add lemon  zest and cook for 1 minute.
6. Stir in cream mixture and bring to  a simmer. Cook until  thickened, about 5 minutes.
7.  Return scallops to  the skillet and  cook until heated  through,  about  1 minute.
8. Divide scallops among serving plates and top with herb  mixture. Sprinkle with bread crumbs  and serve   immediately.

This  recipe for Coquilles St.  Jacques   is a delicious and elegant  way to prepare scallops. The combination of  the  creamy sauce and the fresh herbs is a perfect complement to  the tender scallops. This dish is sure to impress and  is perfect for a  special  occasion.

To make the ravioli pillows, pile 1 heaping  tablespoon of the filling on 1 wonton wrapper,  keeping  the  remaining edges  clean. (If you pipe the filling, it makes the process go faster  and creates an even layer of filling.) Dip your finger into a small bowl of water and dampen the edges of the wrapper. Place a second wrapper  on top and press  the  edges  together to seal. Transfer the ravioli to  the floured baking sheet.   Repeat with the remaining wrappers and filling.

Preheat the oven  to 350  degrees F   (175 degrees C). Line a large  baking  sheet with parchment paper and sprinkle with flour.

Bring a large pot of lightly  salted water to a  boil. Cook the ravioli in batches  until they float to the top, 2 to 3 minutes. (Frozen ravioli may take 1  to 2 minutes  longer.)

Remove the ravioli from the water with  a slotted spoon and keep warm  in a large  bowl with a lid in the preheated  oven. Repeat with the remaining  ravioli.

Melt the butter  in  a  large skillet  over medium  heat.  Stir in the sage and cook until the butter turns  a light golden brown, about 3 minutes.  Stir in the broth and cook until heated through,  about 1 minute. Season to   taste   with salt and pepper.

To serve, spoon a little of the sauce over each  plate and top with 3 or 4  ravioli. Sprinkle with Parmesan cheese.

Nutrition Data: There are 351 calories in 1  serving of this recipe.

## Recipe Changes & Recommendations

I changed the wonton wrappers to eggroll   wrappers  (found  in the produce section near the tofu). I  found the   wontons too thin  and  fragile. In addition, I doubled the  filling recipe,   but still had plenty  of leftover filling. The filling can easily be halved and the ravioli frozen for later use. I   used a cookie scoop to make the ravioli, which saved on preparation time.  The scoop also created the perfect portion size.

I served this with  buttered  carrots and it was a great meal.  I  gave it 4 stars because it  was a lot of work, albeit  worth   the effort.

I would recommend this recipe    to anyone looking for a tasty, hearty dish. It's also a great  way to use up leftover turkey.
