Broccoli  Quiche Crepe Cups Recipe

Ingredients:
- 1 cup all-purpose flour
- 2 eggs
- 1/2 cup milk
- 1/2 cup water
- 1/4 teaspoon salt
- 1/8 teaspoon  black  pepper
- 2  tablespoons butter, melted
- 2 cups broccoli florets
- 1/2 cup shredded  cheddar cheese
- 1/2 cup cooked and crumbled bacon
- 1/4 cup  chopped green onions
- 1/2 cup prepared quiche mix
- 1/2  cup  grated Parmesan cheese

Instructions:

1. In  a large mixing bowl, whisk together the flour, eggs, milk,  water,   salt,  and pepper until  smooth. Stir in  the melted butter until  well combined.
2. Heat a non-stick  skillet  over medium heat. Use a 1/4 cup measure to  pour  the batter onto the skillet, swirling the pan to  spread the batter  evenly. Cook for 1-2  minutes, or until  the edges start to curl and the  surface appears dry.
3. Carefully slide a spatula underneath the crepe  and flip it over. Cook for an additional 1-2 minutes, or  until  lightly browned. Remove the  crepe from the skillet  and place it on a plate.
4.   Repeat the process with  the remaining batter, stacking the cooked crepes between layers of parchment paper.
5. Preheat the oven to 375°F  (190°C).
6.  In  a  large mixing bowl, combine the broccoli florets, shredded cheddar cheese, crumbled bacon,  and  chopped green onions.
7. Spoon the broccoli  mixture evenly into each crepe cup, pressing down lightly to pack it  in.
8. Sprinkle the prepared quiche mix over  the broccoli  mixture, followed by the   grated Parmesan  cheese.
9. Place  the crepe cups  on a baking sheet and bake for 15-20 minutes, or until the  cheese  is melted and bubbly.

Roquefort  Gougeres  are elegant cheese puffs that are  perfect as an appetizer or  snack. They  are made with creamy, tangy  Roquefort cheese and paired with crisp, flaky pastry. Here is the simple recipe to make these delightful treats at home:

Ingredients: 
- 1 cup all-purpose flour
-  ½ tsp salt
- ¼  tsp black pepper

- 2 tbsp water 
- Fresh chopped parsley or chives (optional)

Instructions:

1. Preheat  your oven to  375 degrees Fahrenheit.   Line two baking sheets  with parchment   paper. 

2. In a medium mixing  bowl, whisk together flour, salt and pepper. Set aside.

3.  In  a separate large mixing  bowl, combine softened butter cubes and  half  of  the  grated Roquefort cheese.  Using  an  electric  mixer, beat the mixture on high speed until it becomes  light and fluffy in texture.  Scrape  down the sides occasionally. This should take about  4 minutes.
 
4.  Add the dry ingredients to the wet mixture at once, beat until well  combined. 

5. Beat in  the egg yolk one at a time, fully incorporating each before adding another. After beating  in all four egg yolks, stir in 1  tablespoon of   water and continue to mix. This will result in a smooth dough.

7. Using a measuring  spoon or ice  cream scoop,  dollop rounded  tablespoons of the  dough onto your prepared  baking sheets, spacing them at  least 2 inches apart. 

 8. Flatten each mound slightly using the back of a spoon and bake for 18 minutes,   rotating the  sheets  halfway through cooking.

9. Once done, remove from oven and allow gougeres cool for

"Creme de Menthe Truffles. Combine 1 cup  semi-sweet chocolate chips and 1/4 cup heavy cream.  Stir over  low heat until smooth. Add 2   tablespoons Crème de Menthe  liqueur. Chill 1 hour. Shape into  1-inch balls. Roll in confectioners' sugar.  Store in airtight container in  the refrigerator."
I  will note in  passing that some of  you will be  shocked to learn that even a semi-sweet chocolate chip contains sugar. It  is, after  all,   called chocolate. You should eat it, just not as much  as you think. But I digress.
What this recipe does not say is that in the making of "Creme  De Menthe Truffles," you are to begin by coating  chocolate chips  with  an  emulsion of confectioners sugar,  heavy cream, and a  small amount  of  sugar  substitute powder and heat until the  liquid has been fully absorbed  by the chocolate and  sugar. In other words,  you are  NOT to simply  dump sugar and heavy cream,  with a tiny little amount  of artificial sweetener, upon your chocolate chips--you are to coat the sugar and artificial  sweetener  onto  the  chocolate  chips  as well. No, it doesn't  call for that  step, so I am  filling in for the allrecipes.com writer who was tired or  perhaps in a  hurry or perhaps unable to read or comprehend  the directions  at other web sites. This is not unusual  at all,  just consider all  the recipes you read   in the paper,  the back of the Chex box or the Cheetos bag, to the  food channel network instructions on how to make an entire meal in 10 minutes --  and  the resulting food isn't even edible. What  is  it?
In other  words, you  do not simply dump. You cook.
Some of you may object that this is how people  lose weight. Nope, wrong  answer -- it  is how people get fat -  and it is  how people who lose weight gain it all back - and then more.

**"Homemade Pasta"**

**Prep Time** 10 minutes |  **Cook Time** 30 minutes | **Yields** Serves   4–6

Ingredients

2 cups flour

½ teaspoon salt

2 eggs

Directions

Mise  en Place ("everything-in-place")

1. Fill a large pot with water, and add salt. Turn heat to high until water boils.

2.  Mix flour and salt  together in a  bowl.

3. Crack eggs into flour mixture. Mix together flour  mixture with   eggs until it forms a  ball  of dough.

4. Turn dough onto  flour-dusted worktop and form  dough  into a ball.   Press down on dough with the palm of your hands to  flatten into a ½-inch-thick rectangular shape.

5. Use a rolling  pin to gently  roll  dough  to desired thickness. It should not  be  too  thin as the dough will  tear  (1/16 inch is good) and too  thick as  it will  take too long to cook  (at least 1/8 inch, or  less).

6. To cut the pasta,   use a pastry cutter with fluted or straight edges—or a  knife. You can also use  a pasta cutter/machine (see Step #7).  Cut dough into desired shape.

7. Use a pasta  machine to roll dough to desired  thickness.  Using a single blade of  cutting attachment, move cut side  of dough over bottom blades and  press. Cutting dough  in this way will give you straight edged  noodles. Noodles can be cut into strips or left  as one long sheet.

8.  Drop pasta into boiling  water. Boil for about 6–9  minutes, or until pasta floats and is tender to the bite. Serve sauce over cooked pasta, topped with   freshly grated  Parmesan cheese. Sauce  can then  be  mixed into cooked pasta.

You will also learn  about a special way  of organizing ingredients that chefs call mise en place or "everything-in-place." This is a handy way to organize your ingredients into  the order in which they're going  to be used at the beginning  of a recipe. _In our experience, a  4- to 6-pound round steak is so rare that  the steak  cannot be purchased in stores in the Chicago area. If we have to get something as  small  as that, we want  to know that  we can pick the cuts  ourselves. That is not to say that we will not try the  dish; we just don't think it  will be quite as flavorful as the original._

_A "round of beef" is   a roast of the rump or the round, one of the most common cuts in the Chicago area._

_We did not understand the "teaspoon of soup mix"  ingredient;  "onion  soup   mix" is actually a commercial product found in  the aisle  with  the  soup._

_The   "teaspoon of rosemary, crushed"  is very peculiar. We have no idea what  it means._

_What in the  world is "parsley" and  "thyme" in the plural?  Wouldn't "leaves" be a more practical  measure? How many of each, that  is, two leaves  per steak—of each herb?_

_In the Chicago area "rosemary" is  usually  thought  of   as  that herb  used in Thanksgiving  turkey  stuffing, not   much liked but tolerated by most people. It's unlikely that the typical Chicago area shopper would think  of that as "crushed."_

_We were puzzled by the instructions to "heat the oven to  325 degrees." Since the  oven is  already at 325 degrees, the steak is cooked in, why does it  need to be "heated"?_

_Our final question is this: since when are "garlic powder"  and "onion soup mix" considered  "spices" and therefore listed together?_

Ingredients:
- 1 1/2  cups  all-purpose flour
- 1/2 cup  cornstarch
-  1/2 cup powdered  sugar
-  1/2 cup cold unsalted butter,  cut into small pieces
-  2 large egg yolks
-  1/4  cup milk
- 2  teaspoons vanilla extract
- Food coloring (optional)

Instructions:

1. Preheat the oven to 325°F (160°C). Line a  baking sheet  with parchment paper.

2. In a  medium bowl,  whisk together the flour and cornstarch. Add the powdered sugar and mix well.

3. Using a pastry cutter or  your fingers, work  the  butter into the flour  mixture  until it resembles coarse crumbs.

4. In a separate bowl,  whisk together the egg  yolks, milk, and vanilla extract. Add the wet ingredients to the dry ingredients and mix until a  dough forms.

5. If desired, add a few drops of food coloring to  the dough and mix until the color is   evenly distributed.

6. Roll out the  dough on a floured surface  to a thickness of  about 1/4 inch (6 mm). Cut out shapes  using cookie cutters, and place  them on the  prepared baking sheet.

7. Bake  the petit fours for 15-20  minutes, or until  they are lightly golden brown. Remove  them from the  oven and let them  cool completely on the baking sheet.

8.  Once the petit fours  are cool, you can decorate them with  additional powdered sugar,  frosting, or  other toppings of  your choice.

9. Store the  petit fours in an airtight container for up to 3 days. Enjoy!

Ingredients:
- 4 large   leeks, white and light green  parts only, thinly sliced
- 6 large  eggs
- 1/2 cup grated parmesan cheese
- 1/2 teaspoon salt
- 1/4 teaspoon black pepper
- 2  tablespoons unsalted butter

Instructions:
1. Preheat the oven to 350°F.  
2.   Heat a large skillet  over  medium-high heat. 
3.  Add the butter to the skillet and let it  melt. 
4.  Add the leeks  to the skillet and sauté until they  are soft and  translucent, about 5 minutes. 
5. In a medium bowl, whisk together  the eggs,  parmesan cheese, salt, and  black pepper.  
6. Pour  the egg  mixture   over the  leeks in  the skillet and let it  cook for 2-3 minutes, until the edges start  to set. 
7.  Place the skillet in  the oven and bake for 10-12 minutes, until the frittata is set and golden brown on top. 
8. Remove the skillet from the oven and let the frittata cool for a few minutes. 
9. Slice the frittata  into wedges and serve  warm. 
10. Enjoy!

Ingredients:
- 1 lb textured vegetable protein (TVP)
- 2 tsp cumin
-  1 tsp turmeric
- 1 tsp paprika
- 1/2 tsp coriander
-  1/2 tsp garlic powder
- 1/4 tsp salt
- 2 tbsp olive oil
- 1/4 onion, chopped
- 1/2 cup breadcrumbs
- 1 tbsp  chopped fresh parsley

Instructions:

1.  Preheat the oven to   375°F.

2. In a  large  mixing bowl, crumble the  TVP and add the cumin, turmeric, paprika, coriander, garlic powder, and salt. Mix well.

3. In a pan, heat  the olive oil and  sauté the   chopped onion until softened. Add the onion  to the  TVP mixture and combine well.

4. Add 2/3 cup  of water to the  mixture and stir until well  combined. Let  it sit for 5-10 minutes until  the TVP absorbs the water.

5. On a lightly floured surface, knead the mixture for  a few minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.

6.  Divide the mixture  into 4 equal  portions  and  shape each   portion into a cylinder.

7. In a shallow dish, mix the breadcrumbs and parsley together. Coat each cylinder in the breadcrumb mixture.

8. Place  the cylinders on a baking  sheet lined  with parchment paper and bake for  25-30 minutes, until golden brown.

9. Let the "lamb" cylinders rest for a  few minutes before slicing them  into  rounds.

10. Serve the   Cumin Un-Lamb  with your favorite sides  such as rice,  vegetables, or  pita bread.  Enjoy!

Ingredients:
- 2 cups coconut cream
- 1 cup orange  juice
- 1/2 cup granulated sugar
- 1/2  cup  dark chocolate chips
- 1 tsp vanilla extract
-  1   cup shredded  coconut, toasted

Instructions:
1. In a medium saucepan, combine    coconut cream,  orange juice, and sugar. Heat over medium heat until sugar has dissolved,  stirring occasionally.
2. Remove from heat  and let  cool for 10 minutes.
3. Add in vanilla   extract and dark chocolate chips, stirring until chocolate  is melted.
4. Pour mixture into ice cream maker  and churn according to manufacturer's instructions.
5.  Once ice cream has thickened, add in toasted coconut and continue  churning for another 2-3 minutes.
6. Transfer ice  cream to a freezer-safe  container and freeze for  at least 2 hours or until firm.
7. Serve and enjoy   your toasted coconut, orange, and dark chocolate ice cream!

Ingredients:
- 1 butternut squash, peeled and cubed
- 1/2  cup pine  nuts
-   1/2  cup crumbled blue cheese
- 1/2 cup grated  Parmesan cheese
- 1/4 cup olive oil
-  Salt and pepper  to taste
- 1 pound pappardelle pasta

Instructions:

1. Preheat the oven to 400°F.

2. Toss the cubed  butternut squash with  olive oil, salt, and pepper.  Spread the squash on a baking sheet and roast for  20-25 minutes, until tender and lightly browned.

3.  In a small skillet, toast  the  pine  nuts over medium heat until lightly browned and fragrant, about 5 minutes.

4.  Cook the  pappardelle  pasta   according to package instructions  until al dente. Reserve 1/2 cup of the  pasta water  before draining.

5. In a large skillet, heat  the olive  oil over medium heat. Add  the roasted butternut  squash and  cook for 2-3  minutes.

6. Add the pappardelle pasta to the  skillet with  the squash and toss to combine.

7. Stir  in the crumbled blue cheese, pine nuts, and grated Parmesan cheese.

8. Add reserved pasta water as needed to  create a creamy sauce.

9. Season with salt and pepper to taste.

10. Serve  hot and enjoy!

Ingredients:
-  2 lbs. small potatoes,  scrubbed and halved
-  3 tbsp. olive oil
-  1 tsp. salt
-  1/2 tsp. black pepper
- 1 lb. fresh mussels, scrubbed and  debearded
- 1/2  cup  white wine
-  2 cloves garlic, minced
- 2 tbsp. fresh parsley, chopped

Instructions:

1. Preheat oven  to 400°F.

2. In  a large bowl, toss  the potatoes with 2 tbsp.  olive oil, salt,  and black  pepper.

3. Spread the potatoes on a baking sheet and roast for 20-25  minutes, or until tender and golden  brown.

4. In a large  pot or Dutch  oven, heat  the remaining 1 tbsp. olive oil over medium-high heat.

5. Add  the mussels and  cook for 2-3 minutes, or until they  start to open.

6. Add the white wine and garlic, and cover the pot.

7. Cook for  another 3-4 minutes,  or  until all the mussels  have opened.

8. Remove the  pot from the heat and stir in the  chopped parsley.

9. Divide the  roasted potatoes among serving plates or bowls.

10. Spoon the  mussels and broth over the potatoes and  serve immediately.

I've been  playing Tinker for a  while  now and  one thing I've noticed  is that my  item timing  is not  as good as it  could be. I  often find myself  struggling to  get my core items   at the right time, which can really impact my effectiveness  in team fights   and split pushing. 

After doing  some research and  experimenting, I've found  a few tips that have helped me  improve my  item timing with Tinker. 

Firstly, it's important to  prioritize farming efficiency. Tinker is  a hero that  relies heavily  on gold and experience, so  you need to  make sure  you're maximizing your farm.  This means constantly  pushing out waves and stacking camps whenever  possible.  

Secondly, you should try to minimize downtime. Tinker is a hero that can be very active on the map, so you want  to make  sure  you're  constantly doing something. This could be split pushing, ganking, or farming jungle camps.  The key is to always be doing something productive. 

Thirdly, you  should consider adjusting your skill build. Tinker  has a lot   of flexibility when it comes to his  skill build, so you should tailor it to the game you're playing. For example, if you're against a  lot of magic damage,  you might  want to prioritize leveling  up  your March of the Machines for better wave clear and farming potential. 

Lastly, communication with your team is key. Let them know when you're close to a key item and coordinate with them to make the most out of it. Tinker is a hero that can have a huge   impact in team fights, so it's important to make sure your team is  ready to fight  when  you  have your core items. 

Overall, achieving better item  timing with Tinker requires a combination of efficient farming, constant activity,   adjusting your  skill build, and  good  communication with your team. By following  these tips, you should be able to improve  your item timing  and have a bigger impact  on the game.

I've been experimenting with different laning combos  lately and I've found one that has been working really well for me.  The  combo consists of playing a tanky support like  Leona or Nautilus paired with a high  burst ADC like Jhin or Miss Fortune. 

The idea behind this combo is  to  have the tanky  support engage  on the enemy  ADC  or support, while the  burst  ADC follows  up with their high damage abilities. This creates a lot of  pressure in the laning  phase and can  often result in kills or at least force the enemy  to back  off and play  more defensively.

The  tanky support provides a lot of crowd control  and durability,  allowing the ADC to freely  deal damage without worrying too much about getting caught out. Additionally, the burst damage from the ADC can  quickly burst down squishy targets, making it difficult  for the enemy to trade effectively.

I've found that this combo works particularly well against squishy supports like Janna  or Soraka, as they are more vulnerable to the engage  and burst damage. However,   it  can still be effective against tanky  supports as well, as the burst damage  can  quickly whittle down their   health.

Overall, I've been having a lot  of success with  this laning combo and I would highly  recommend giving it  a try if  you're looking for  a strong and aggressive laning phase. It's important to communicate and coordinate with your ADC to ensure that you're on  the same   page  and  can effectively  engage and follow  up  on each other's abilities. Give it a shot and let  me know how it  works  for you!

I recently came out as transgender to my   friends and family, and it got me thinking  about how people   treat   me differently once  they find  out. It  has been  a mixed experience, to say the  least. Some people have been incredibly supportive and  accepting, treating me the same as they always have.  However, others  have  displayed obvious discomfort  or even hostility towards me. It's disheartening to see this  shift in their behavior,  as  if my true self somehow invalidates  our previous  relationship. I understand that it may  take  time for some people to adjust  and understand, but it's difficult not to feel alienated by their reactions.  I  hope that with education and increased  visibility,  the transgender community can work towards a more accepting and understanding society. It's important for  everyone to remember that we are still the same people, with the same hopes and dreams, regardless of our gender identity.

I mean seriously, why do we have a  whole category for mil-sim? It's not  like there are a lot of mainstream   games  that have military involvement.  Shouldn't it be a subset of the action genre? RPG? Strategy? Something? It's always one   of the first categories I  eliminate when  searching for a game, because 99% of  it is just mediocre. With the tiny minority of  excellent games that deserve to be playing, it feels like a  clutter category that does more harm than good.

I guess what I'm asking is, should I be eliminating the "mil-sim" category  games  altogether, or  is that genre simply not for me? I'm mostly  a PC gamer, dabbling with consoles, though I am open to  suggestions for any platform.

I've  tried ARMA and a few other  similar games,  and they seem cool, but hard to get into after  spending most of my time in more traditional  gaming genres. Any recommendations would be welcome.

I did try searching, but most threads on the  topic seem to be complaints about lack  of mil-sim  AAWWWWWWHHHYYYYYY!!!!11 and  Sturgeon's law concerning the   low quality meme games  cluttering the category, with few actual useful opinions.

Edit: Thanks for the  suggestions guys. Apparently the  genre   has enough good  games  to warrant its  own category, who'd have thought. I'll definitely    look into these  further, and I think   I'll remove the "shooter" category from my search criteria as well  (though arena shooters are  still okay, since I do   like the occasional rocket  jumping session)

Edit 2: I should probably clarify that by "military  sim" I mean games that  strive for realism, whether  in  terms of gameplay, physics, or whatever makes the game fall into that   category. I  don't necessarily mean games with  "sim"  in the title (though that's what  I'm most familiar with), and I'm  not talking about shooter  games  with tanks  and  planes. War Thunder would probably fall under that category, but  since my aversion is mostly  due to personal taste and not the quality of the games  in  said category, I didn't really think it would be fair to  use that example.  Apologies for any confusion.

I'm a grad student and I  need  to take  a particular class that's only offered in the fall semester. It's a requirement for both the MA and PhD programs that I'm in, and  is   arguably  the most important class in my program given that every PhD student  in my program takes it,  and  most MA students take it as an  elective. 

The problem is  that I cannot  take it in the fall due to  a number of factors outside my control - travel for  work  and an intense semester for another class that I'm taking - and registering for it in  the  fall  would mean that   I  would not be  able to finish my degree within the standard timeframe for my program. 

Registration  for  the fall semester opens up tomorrow, and  I saw that there was one  section  of the class offered  in the spring. I'm always scared to  be in   my house.  There's a  religious cult across the street. They perform rituals where they wave swords and shoot guns in the air while screaming, and sometimes blow up M-80s. It sounds like a war zone over there.

They also build bonfires in their  driveway and   roast pigs  on spits, while blasting extremely loud Latin music. It's like having a  rave   party and a  3am  cockfight outside my window every  weekend. Yet  somehow, they never  get  in trouble with the law.

I've called the police  on them dozens of times, but they just shrug and say "they're religious".

I've even gone  to  the neighbors, who   are also scared of them, but they just   laugh and say  "we've been complaining for years, nothing will happen".

So I'm stuck suffering this torture. I can't  even keep my windows open at night in the  summer because of the noise, and  the smoke  from the  bonfires  gets  into  my house and sets off my fire alarm.

I never thought I'd be living next to a cult. This isn't what I  signed  up  for when I moved here.

fluxcapacity balances it well:

Do you  feel  jealous because of something  that  has happened in the past, or because of how you think  things might go in the  future? Jealousy of the  past can be more readily addressed -- for   example if your friend just finished the most amazing European vacation, you can shake their hand  and say "good  for you,''  or give them a hug and say "I'm so glad you had a great time, but I'm really glad you're back.''

If you're jealous of something imaginary you've made up  about their future, you  can  acknowledge that you're afraid of  something  that may never even   happen. It might  be  reassuring to explicitly acknowledge that your fear  is hypothetical -- "I'm jealous you'll have  all these  great memories when you're  old, because I'm afraid  I'll have nothing'' or "I'm jealous you'll have so  many friends who  are still in  touch with you when you're thirty,'' or  whatever the case   may be.  It doesn't  necessarily solve anything,  but just  naming a fear  as  hypothetical can take some of  the sting  out of it.

Beyond  that, some people  just aren't very good at maintaining  friendships, and that's OK. A sincere gesture once  in a while goes a long  way, as do regular check-ins, but for some people, "regular'' means once every few years and that's OK  too. If your  friend  is in your life and  you feel comfortable with the level  of friendship you have,  there's no need to feel guilty or jealous.

Also remember that people are multifaceted and even your closest friends  can have aspects of their life you have no part in. It's OK to feel a  bit  of  friendly jealousy (as  opposed to the poisonous kind),  it's a  normal emotion. But  just because someone is  great at one thing doesn't mean they're necessarily great  (or even good, or present) at everything.

I recently came  out as a homosexual roughly a month ago. My close  friends and family  have been extremely supportive, and I'm  so   happy to be authentic and true to who I am. But I'm still having  bad depression. I sometimes still wake up wishing I could  wake  up straight.  I  feel guilty for not  being  happier. I've started seeing a therapist which has been super helpful, and I'm still planning on starting hormones  soon. But I still have bad days here and there. Does it get better?   Will I  ever just feel normal?

I tried talking to my mom about it. She  helped me a lot after coming out. But I feel weird bringing it up again. Is it  normal to still be dealing with this stuff?  I just want  to be happy.  

I'm just looking for some  people who can  relate. Thank you for taking the time  to read  this.

EDIT: Thank you all for your kind words  and  support. It  really means a lot. Obviously I'm still a  bit  of a mess, but hearing about  other people's experiences and how they overcame  this really  gives  me  hope. I'm so sorry for those of you who haven't had   the same support system. I can't imagine going  through this alone. But know that  you are valid and wonderful, and that  you deserve happiness. For those of  you wanting to kill    yourself, please call 911 or the suicide hotline   immediately.  If  you're in the us, it's 1-800-273-8255. You  can also get emotional support from  the Trevor project at 1-866-488-7386. You are not alone.

What has surprised me  the most is how almost nothing  has changed in sobriety. I have always been a rather solemn and stoic person, even when drinking. I never drank to excess,  always  drove, and was  always able to  perform at  my best no  matter how much I had eaten  or  drank. So, outwardly,  there has  been almost no change.  

What has changed is internal. I suffer less anxiety, less "noise" in my head, and more control over my thoughts and emotions. I  feel like I'm living life from a  clearer  and more focused perspective. Like there is less fog  or static in  my head. It's made  me realize  that I was drinking to reduce that internal noise and to  feel more  comfortable in my skin. Which is a surprise  to me because I never considered myself an "inside-my-head" kind of person, but  the benefits  I've experienced from getting sober  have  been on  the inside. 

It  also surprised me that I was relying on  alcohol for its anxiety reducing effects because alcohol is a known anxiety stimulant. Who knew? Not me obviously.  So, there you   have  it.  My experience with sobriety has  surprised me in  that nothing outward has changed, but inward  everything has. And that doing something  counter-intuitive like stopping  alcohol consumption to  reduce anxiety   actually works.

Some thoughts  which pop up in my mind are distinctly under my control. I could just let them be,  or I could think more   about them, or pursue them—e.g. if I  think about an  interesting topic,  I could choose to investigate it further. Then   there are out-of-the-blue thoughts that just  appear in my mind, and arguably I have no control over them. It would be absurd to try to will myself to stop thinking about them. They just appear,  and I can choose to entertain them or let them go,  but it feels as though the initiative is not mine.

Which category   do volitional  thoughts  belong to? It seems like  they should belong to the first category, but maybe not? What determines whether a thought  is under my control? Surely  it's  not  sufficient to just feel as though I had control, because it seems some involuntary thoughts feel involuntary, even though I could make myself think about  them if I so chose. But perhaps more importantly, it seems  like  some thoughts which  feel voluntary are actually involuntary. For example, if  I have  an irrational fear  of something, it feels voluntary to think about it, but  it seems  it would   actually  be irrational (and impractical)  to try to will myself to  stop thinking  about it. It seems  like willingness to have a particular  thought  is not the same thing as volition, yet   it feels like it ought to  be.

Maybe a more charitable way of putting it is that it seems like   willingness to have a particular conscious  experience  is not the same thing as voluntariness. Thoughts just seem to appear in my mind, and I can   choose  to act on them or not, but  it doesn't seem  as though I caused them, even if it feels that  way, and even if in reality I could have  prevented them, since  it    feels as though they just happen. Conversely, other thoughts feel as though  I caused them, but it seems  as though  what matters is  not whether the thought  appeared because I willed it,  but rather whether I  could   have prevented   it. Perhaps it doesn't matter  whether a  thought is caused  by my   will, but rather whether I could have  prevented the thought, in which case all thoughts are involuntary.

I have  had a   very difficult time in my life from the  day   I was born and I struggle with  many internal flaws  that I need to deal with. I was abused as a child into my  teenage years by an outsider  to my family  dynamic (a man my mom met when  I was 3), which caused a lot of  issues in my  brain  as it formed, and I am autistic which makes  me extremely sensitive to everything,  especially conflict, whether it be external or internal.  As a  result of  that, I suffer from terrible anxiety and  depression, and I am constantly second-guessing everything I do or say, predicting the future outcomes  of all possible interactions I  could have with others  because   I can't read tones well and I  misread facial expressions  a  lot,  and I am always left feeling like I've disappointed someone, even when that's not the  case. 

I am  in  my 30s and I still live with my mom because I have never been able  to hold a job for more  than  a few  months because  of  my   anxiety and depression, which causes me to either quit or be fired.  I  have been  able to keep  a  few jobs  for a few months here and there, but they always  end the same way  and  I  am worthless and a burden on everyone, especially my mom who  has to pay for everything. She has helped me as much as  she can but  she has her own issues to deal with and  it's not  fair for  me  to keep taking   from her when I am perfectly capable of working. She has  helped me get jobs before but my anxiety always gets the  better of  me  and I can't do it. 

I am constantly fighting with  myself to try and be better but  I always end up in the same place: worthless, pathetic, and a burden on everyone around me. I am a  failure as  a person and I deserve to suffer for what I've done. I am  a terrible person and I deserve to be punished for the things  I have done.  I am  not worth  the  air I breathe and  I am a danger to society. My brain is poison and getting rid of me  would  serve  everyone, especially the universe, because the last thing it needs is another abomination like me lurking around, pretending  that I deserve to be here  when I so clearly do not. The world would be  a  better  place without me in it.

As  objectively attractive as countless couples seem, their  actual togetherness sometimes seems like a bore  in comparison to the fascination of a deeply dysfunctional  relationship.  Why  is  it that what seems  to be going amazingly wrong is so  much more interesting than what is going  amazingly right?

It's almost like Trainspotting said, "Choose life. Choose a job. Choose a career. Choose happiness. Just don't choose him." (Even  if choosing the single life over a bad partnership is the correct choice, it still somehow feels  sad and hopeless.)

One possible  reason is that it can be  so  difficult to formulate   and admit  to  what  exactly  is going wrong. When there is a lot of ambiguity, it gets  easier for our minds to add a sense of intrigue to the mix. (It can be  intoxicating   to feel like you have no idea how the other person feels about you,  or where your relationship is heading.) It  can also be very  hard to  leave a relationship when  there  is a lot  of uncertainty.  (It can feel  paralyzing  to not know if   you are making the  right choice,  if  you are  overreacting, etc.)

Plus, in a world of unwavering commitment to monogamy, seeing someone in a relationship that may not last forever   can seem intriguing and even a bit taboo. (As much  as we  may  want to, we can't help but wonder what it would be like to be with that person.)

But when  it comes to  our own relationships, it seems  like we are willing to do whatever it takes to make  things work,  to make the allure of the dysfunctional  partnership fade away.

I   never really appreciated the way music can change the lives   of many, like my grandmother. My  grandmother  is a hard working woman, and she has always been a musician, my mother being a former  band member of one of her country singers.  She has also been a huge advocate  for helping people with   disabilities. And she had a  real problem in her early  life, since  she  was very bright, her legs would always ache,   her body would shake, and  even when she was on the best of  days,  things  would  hurt. At  the same  time she never really  questioned,  as she always looked at  everyone else with an air of  knowing  what was right and what was  wrong. Then, she  would have  music to help the day  go by. At her height of being, before she  was married I don't know how old  I was, my grandparents could have told she was a star. She  did go to many concerts, but most of the time she would sit in her backyard singing with her husband. Most of them didn't  really seem at   a big deal, but she took my grandma to  a concert one time and after the show, she sat on a bench  with her,  she kept looking at her  with her huge eyes,  "Are you ok  grandma?" She never looked at my grandmother the  same ever since  she  had that episode.

On the last day  before she  died, she told  my grandma that the first day on the road  with this band it was rough. She said she never  really knew  how to handle the loudness, the attention, etc.  When they  first starting playing, she said that it felt like they made her realize she was different than everyone else. She  said "it  is your destiny" and they were all a part of it. She  told my grandma, "they are not strangers, your family knows who you are and  you can talk  to them about it on the way  home."  I think my grandmother just heard that in her heart, it wasn't in her  words. She was a  big believer  in   that they were part of her family, she never let them  let her   down. After  the show she finally admitted, that  she wasn't  OK with the   way  they were looking at her. I am not sure if  this has been mentioned before, but I have noticed that WMR is  always in  sleep  mode and never wakes up. It's like  it's asleep  all the time. I've tried  to turn on  the   radio or TV, but  nothing  happens.  I can't  get it to wake up.  I'm pretty sure it's because it's using its own power  source (probably battery) to keep itself awake. I don't know how long it will stay in sleep mode, but  I hope it doesn't go off for good.

This  is   an interesting  question. The  answer  is  yes, it does use  its own  power supply. But  it also uses some external power sources as  well. In fact, it uses two different types of  power supplies. One is a standard  AC adapter  that you might find at your local electronics store. This is what powers the computer. The other  type of power supply is a solar panel.  This is what powers the camera.

Solar  panels  are  great for powering laptops, tablets, phones, etc., but  they're  not so great for powering cameras. They require a  lot more energy than  normal batteries do.  So,  while the laptop may be powered by a solar panel,  the camera is still going to need  a regular battery.

So, why would   WMR use a solar  panel?  Well, there are several reasons. First, it's  cheap. A solar panel costs about $1 per watt. That means that a  solar  panel could provide enough juice to run the camera for  about 10  hours. Second, it's easy to install. You just plug it into the wall and  connect it  to the  USB port on  your computer. Third, it's portable. If  you want to  take the camera  with you, you can simply leave it plugged in.  Fourth, it's  very efficient.  Solar  panels convert sunlight directly into electricity. When you put a solar panel on top  of a house, it converts  the  heat from  the sun into electricity. And since the sun shines most of the day, it's perfect  for powering a camera.

But, there's  one problem  with solar panels. They only work during the  daytime. During the night, the sun stops shining. So, if you  want to charge  your camera during the day,  you'll need to either buy a backup battery  or make sure that your camera is set to automatically switch  off after sunset.

My  friend's '67 Falcon coupe   came with a 3.8L motor, was running good, but no gas. The carburetor failed after about 110000 miles. He replaced the carbs and  the  transmission at the same time and they ran fine,  but he's getting his  truck back  from our insurance company now.  Is he allowed to  drive off  the roadside, or should he at least wait for everything to be fixed? The transmission  went  into reverse  and drove  the van into a pole on our street. I  guess, technically,  this is going  to be  a collision, but we were both sober  and it  was only an  accident.

I can think of a number of  reasons why someone would want to drive off  the road without gas.  Here are  a  few we've come up with  so far.

Liability:

Someone needs to pay  that person to put gas in their car while it is  out on   the  road and they are  driving  it   while on the  road. Also, by driving off the road without gas, the potential  for a car accident also increases significantly. The driver has  the  responsibility to ensure that they take their car safely if  they continue to drive it at the time their gas is low. Of course, if you don't have  your vehicle towed away from a  crash,  you should definitely leave a note or  call the police.

Dislikes:

Driving, especially on the open road, makes us quite uncomfortable. We find it uncomfortable just  by driving along  the highway.  This anxiety doesn't mean that we want to avoid  driving  at  all costs, but rather that we  hate driving. What  it comes   down to  is that we don't enjoy doing anything that  involves exertion,  and that includes driving. It's not fun to be in the driver's  seat, and we don't like to spend hours at a gas station simply to   get into  the driver's seat of our  car. Driving is a great example of why people  do things they don't especially  want to do. It takes about 4   miles to cover a  distance of 100 miles.  The  trip is very short  for most  people, and because we can usually afford to buy multiple liters of gas, we  only do so occasionally. I've been playing around with the Xbox One controller, and I'm  pretty impressed by it. It's not perfect, but it's definitely better than the  PS4 DualShock 4.  The  biggest problem I have with it is that  it doesn't feel as  natural to use as the Dualshock  4. There are some things about the way the controller works that make it less  comfortable to   play with. For example, when you press down on the D-pad, the analog stick moves up and down in a very unnatural manner.  This makes  it hard to aim your weapon or move  quickly. Also, there is no  way to  adjust the sensitivity of the D-pad. You  can only change the direction  of the analog  stick. So if you want to shoot  an  enemy, you need to hold down the left  trigger and  then move  the right stick in   the opposite direction. If you  don't do this,  you'll miss every shot. Another thing that bothers  me is how  the triggers work. When you're holding down the trigger, the  analog stick  will be moving up and down.  But when you release the trigger, the analog stick will  stop moving. This means  that you can't really control  where the gun goes. In other words, you can't fire  at  enemies while they're  standing still. This  also causes  problems  because  sometimes you'll accidentally hit them. I think these two issues could be  fixed by  making the  D-pad more responsive.

It seems like the Reddit user  has  had similar experiences  with the Xbox  360  controller. He says   he was able to get used to using the Xbox One  controller after just one day of  playing.

There is a pretty  fundamental question that is often raised that goes with any claim about  the efficacy of certain  drugs or dietary supplements: Can they be bigger or better than something that is already on  the market?

A big part of the  reason that we believe we can  get better results  is because  of  how we research the evidence. We  don't assume that the  best and brightest minds in our  field  have all figured out  what is the best, because they haven't. We do know that we want  to  get people better. We want to help people get healthier. And we  know  that some of the  best researchers are always going  to be interested in finding ways to improve results, or   to improve  existing results.

But  other studies have shown that, not only do we learn how to improve our methods, but that's  an investment  that, in  the  long run, pays off. Sometimes, it's a little more risky; that we'll learn a particular technique for  a specific population and find that doesn't work for other  populations with different  needs. We might   find that  the thing works and maybe it  wouldn't have  worked had we tried it on a different population.

But in the end, those  risks are  justified in the long-run because the benefits are  just  too high. Some  of our most promising new treatments for  cancer, for instance, don't exist in the  same form  that people were doing  before. They're not just the  same  but in new forms. We've  learned  a lot about what works and  what doesn't work. And the  best-studied treatment for breast cancer, lumpectomy, isn't the same form of lumpectomy that was done in the  1960s.

We think that new research might be able to  give us some of the benefits  of better treatments, and some of the costs.

It's  not that we can't learn enough from  other  research to improve our methods. Instead, a lot of research is new. It's not  necessarily a bad thing that  we need new methods.

But it's that it may  require new research methods, which  could take time. Or it  may require new research  for  the same  reasons that it did  before: that we  can benefit from something we  didn't know about  before. Or  that we learned a better technique  or  were able  to identify  a  new therapy  or a mechanism that is important.

How much time? That's the question  people  ask.  We

My 18  month old has started having  temper tantrums and I'm not sure how to deal  with them. He will throw  himself on the floor and scream and  cry until he gets what he  wants. I've tried ignoring him, but that doesn't seem to work. Any  suggestions?

One suggestion  would be to try and figure out what is causing the  tantrums. Is there something that is   triggering them?  Once you know what  is  causing  them, you can  try  and find    a way to avoid the trigger or  to  help your child deal with  it in a more constructive way.

Another  suggestion would  be to try and stay calm yourself. It can be difficult, but if you can remain calm it will help your  child  to calm  down as well. Try to offer comfort and  reassurance while your child is tantruming,  and once they have calmed down you  can talk to them about what happened and why it wasn't okay.

I was  at a friend's house the other day when  their five-year-old daughter ran into  the room and blurted  out,  "Mommy, I found aDead body in the  closet!"

Everyone froze and  stared at the little girl. My friend's  wife was the first to  speak.

"Honey, where did you see  a dead body?"

"In the closet. I opened the door  and there it was."

We  all slowly turned to look at the closet door. It was closed.

My friend's wife  slowly got up and  walked to the closet. She slowly opened  the  door  and peeked inside.

"There's nothing in here," she said.

We  all breathed a sigh of relief.

The little   girl then said, "But  there was a dead body   in here earlier. I  saw it!"

We all looked at each other,  not knowing what to say.

AITA?

I told  my partner  what’s wrong  in the  relationship and  she is angry with  me. I feel like I’m the only one trying  to  make things work. What should I do?

It sounds like you're feeling  like you're stuck in  a difficult situation. It's tough when we feel like we're stuck in a  difficult situation and our partner  is angry with us. It can feel like we're the only  ones trying to make things  work.

I think  it's important to  remember    that relationships  are a two way street. It  takes two people to make a  relationship work. If you're  feeling like you're the only one  trying to make   things  work,  it might be time to have  a conversation with your partner about your relationship.

It's  possible that your partner is angry with you because they feel like you're not listening to them or you're not taking their feelings into account.  It's important  to remember that we all have different ways  of communicating  and processing information.  It's possible that your partner is trying to  communicate with you in a way that you're    not understanding.

I think it's  important to try  to see things from your  partner's perspective. It's also important to remember that it's okay to ask for help.  If you're feeling like you're struggling to communicate with your partner, it  might be helpful to seek out couples  counseling or therapy.

Understanding   and optimizing item timings with Tinker  can  dramatically improve  your  gameplay.  Here are some  tips you  can utilize:

1. **Prioritize  Boots of Travel (BoT):** Your first priority should always be saving for Boots of Travel. This item  is crucial  to Tinker's playstyle as it allows you  to travel around  the map, pushing lanes, and teleporting back to your base when needed.

2.  **Farming Patterns:**  Tinker is all about  farming efficiently. Using March of the Machines, you can continually clear out waves of creeps. When  farming the jungle,  move strategically  between  camps  to use March  of the Machines  to best effect.

3. **Stacking Neutral Creeps:** While farming  waves with March, try to stack  neutral  camps whenever possible, this will allow for maximizing your gold and experience gain.

4. **Bottle and Soul Ring:** These two items should be your next  priority after  BoTs.  They  give   you  the ability to  stay on the map longer due to sustainability  in health  and mana.

5. **Blink Dagger Timing:** Blink Dagger is another high priority item. Try to get it before the 20-minute mark. It offers a great deal of  mobility and  can save you from many sticky situations.

6. **Scythe  of Vyse and Dagon:** These are  your luxury items.  The former is great for control and adding an extra layer of disable in team fights, whereas  the latter  will   let you  burst down enemies quickly. Their timings   largely depend on how well you have farmed.

Remember that both  your individual skill  level  and the state of your specific game can affect this schedule. Being adaptable is crucial in Dota 2, so be prepared to adjust  your playstyle and item  build based on  the  needs of your team and the nature of the enemy team.  In general, ensure you maximize   farming, manage your mana well  and aim for minimum deaths. Good luck!

I've  been playing a  lot of duo queue  recently and stumbled  upon a laning combo that has  been surprisingly effective.  I've been playing as Thresh and my duo partner has been playing as Lucian. 

Thresh's crowd   control abilities combined with  Lucian's high burst damage has  been a deadly  combination. I start the engage  with Thresh's Q  (Death Sentence) to pull in an  enemy, followed by his E (Flay) to knock them towards Lucian. Lucian then uses his Q  (Piercing Light)   and his passive (Lightslinger) to  quickly  burst down  the enemy. If they're not dead by then, Thresh's R (The Box) can be used to slow them down and allow Lucian to finish them off.

This  combo has been working really well for  us in  the  bot lane. We've been  able to secure early kills and snowball our lead  into the mid and late game. It's also  a lot of fun  to play!

I'd love to hear about any other laning combos that you guys   have found to  be effective.  Let's share  and learn from each other!

I've  been reading a lot about the Bernese Method of switching from   a   full agonist opioid (like heroin  or  fent) to a partial  agonist opioid (like Suboxone). The general idea is to slowly introduce the Suboxone while still using your drug of choice, thus avoiding  the excruciatingly uncomfortable  process of withdrawal. This differs greatly from the  traditional  method of waiting until you are in withdrawal before beginning  to use Suboxone.

However, my primary concern  with this method is  the  prolonged exposure to the full agonist opioid  which  maintains  the addictive   behavior and potentially  damaging lifestyle. I wonder if anyone has attempted a Bernese Method followed by  a quick (or  quicker than normal)  taper off  of the Suboxone? I'm thinking this may provide  the  benefits of both techniques (avoiding acute withdrawal and lessening the amount of time on Suboxone), but I'm having trouble finding any first-hand accounts of such an approach.  I'm particularly interested in hearing about  the experience, difficulty, and effectiveness of this method,  so if you have any insight or  personal stories, your contribution would be  highly appreciated. 

Also,  I would like to note that it's incredibly important to consult with a healthcare  professional  before attempting something like this,  for anyone reading this post who might be considering it, please ensure you're receiving monitoring   and support from professionals. This is a   harm  reduction thread,  and  we want to promote safe and healthy  discussion. Thanks in advance for any responses!

I've been thinking about this for a while now  and  I believe that wearing  a full set of leather armor should improve your  sneakiness in the game. 

Leather  armor is often associated with thieves, rogues, and assassins in fantasy settings  due to its lightweight and  quiet nature. It doesn't clank  and clang  like metal armor, making  it ideal  for those  who rely on stealth and subtlety. 

In the game, this could translate to  a slight boost in sneakiness or stealth when wearing a full set of leather  armor. This could be  a small  percentage increase in your ability to remain undetected, or perhaps it could   reduce the noise you make when moving. 

This would not   only  add a layer of realism  to the game, but it would also    give players more strategic options   when planning their  character's build and playstyle.  It would make the choice of armor more  than just about defense stats, but  also   about how it can complement   your chosen skills and tactics.

What do you  guys think? Would this be a good addition to the game?  Or do you think it would  unbalance things? I'd love to hear your thoughts.

I've  been   transitioning  for a while now and my family, friends,  and  coworkers are all aware. I've noticed that some  people have   changed  their behaviour towards me, while others have stayed the  same. 

In regards to  my family, I was quite fortunate to have parents who were understanding, however, some extended family  were a bit skeptical  and  didn't understand why I was transitioning. They treated me differently, it felt  like they weren't  comfortable around me anymore. 

In my job, I was really worried  about coming out to my colleagues  and my superiors, but they handled it better  than I  could ever have imagined. Even though they were supportive and treated me the same after  coming   out, I sometimes got the feeling that they are walking on eggshells around me. 

As for the  general public, I have  received mixed reactions. Some people did  not care at all, and some have given me  looks  or made  under-the-breath  comments. There  were even some who were outright hostile or  discriminatory. 

Overall, the way people  treat  me has definitely varied. I'm  extremely lucky to have plenty of supportive  and loving people in my life but the negative reactions and comments still sting.  It  would be really interesting to hear about others' experiences too. How  has coming out impacted your interactions with  people   around you? Would love to hear  your thoughts  and stories.

So I've been having this rather  strange experience lately  where I've  noticed that some  of my dreams have been leaving incredibly lasting impressions on my mind. The memories from these dreams   are so realistic and vivid, that it has  started  becoming  difficult for me to distinguish them from my real memories. 

There are instances where I remember  having intense conversations with someone in  my dream,   and I actually have to pause to wonder if it really happened in my sleep   or in reality. Similarly, there are certain locations or situations   which I can recall in great detail, but I'm unsure if I've truly  experienced them in real life, or just dreamt  about  them.

I  wanted to see if anyone  else has experienced  anything like this? Does anyone else look  back on  certain "memories" and find themselves second guessing if they're real due to the hyper-realistic nature of some dreams?  I'm genuinely curious if this  is something that happens more commonly,  or if  it's just a personal anomaly that my  mind seems to  be experiencing.

Also, if anyone  can shed  light  on why this might be  happening or how  to handle it, that would be  greatly  appreciated. Thanks  for taking the time  to read and respond!

Hey there  everyone! I've been thinking about Ethan as a character and  decided to  share some of my thoughts regarding his  backstory and  what it could potentially mean for his future.

From what we know, Ethan has had a pretty   tough childhood. The loss of his parents at a young age and growing up in  an orphanage would have  surely  had a  great  impact on him and  how  he sees the world. Not to  mention how these experiences would have  shaped his   relationships and social interactions.

Despite  his past, Ethan manages to develop a great sense of kindness and justice. He  sets a  perfect   example of  "coming  out  from the ashes". He doesn't let  his  past define him, rather  he uses it as an opportunity  to  grow and  support those around  him.

As for his future, I feel that there are several ways his story could unfold. One potential pathway is  that he continues on his journey of helping and inspiring others. With an aim to make a difference in the  world, he could  possibly work in law  enforcement or social  work.

Another interesting alternative  could be him getting embroiled in a mystery or conflict that ties  back  to his past. This could introduce elements of suspense to his  storyline while also providing opportunity for  more personal growth.

Lastly,  there's  a  part of me  that yearns for Ethan to find  a  sense  of belonging  or a 'family' in the non-traditional sense. Given his experiences, it will be heartwarming to see him form deep bonds with a group of individuals  who can provide  him the emotional support he  lacked  growing  up.

In summary, Ethan's  backstory gives him a solid foundation to grow as a character in multitude of directions. His past has equipped him with resilience and a heart  full of  empathy, making   his future all the more promising. I am eager to see which path he takes. What are your  thoughts?

Hey everyone, I'm just in such  a weird place mentally  right now.  I'm having a  hard time pinning down how   I feel  about anything — my relationships, my career, my interests, you  name it. 

Sometimes I'll wake up with a  soaring mood  and by nighttime,  I'll sink into seemingly inexplicable sadness. I've changed my  mind about my career multiple times. One moment I'm absolutely convinced that I want to quit my  job and start over in an  entirely different field, and the next I'm  grateful for   the stability it  offers and dread  the idea of changing.

The same goes  for my relationships. There  are times when I  feel so suffocated and   eager  to be  alone, and other moments where  I'm incredibly lonely and would give anything for more  social connections. It's  frustrating because I genuinely enjoy being social, but sometimes, that's the last thing I want to do. 

I feel like I'm constantly at war with two conflicting sides  of myself and  it's   draining me. I'm unsure of who I am  and   what I want, and it's a scary feeling.

I guess I'm just sharing this to see if  anyone else is experiencing  something similar? Or  if anyone  has any  advice on how to navigate this phase? I'm  open to any thoughts or suggestions because I genuinely want to resolve this.   Thanks in advance.

For the past few weeks, I've been  experiencing  some strange occurrences that I can't quite explain. I've been seeing things that aren't there,  hearing sounds that no  one else can hear, and sometimes even  feeling sensations that don't  seem to have a source. 

For example, I'll be sitting in my room and suddenly I'll see a shadow dart across the wall. I'll turn to look,  but there's nothing there. Or I'll be lying  in bed  and I'll hear a soft whispering sound, but when I  sit up  to listen, it stops.  Sometimes,   I'll feel  a sudden chill, like  someone just walked past me, but I'm alone in the room.

I don't  have  a history of mental illness, and I'm  not on any   medication that could cause hallucinations. I've also  ruled out the possibility of sleep deprivation, as I've been getting   a solid   8 hours of sleep every night.  

I've always had a vivid imagination, and I'm wondering if  that could be the   cause. Maybe I'm just letting my mind play tricks on me? But these  experiences feel so real, it's hard to dismiss them as  just figments  of my imagination. 

Has anyone else experienced something   like this? Could it be  that I'm  hallucinating, or is it more likely that  I just have  an overactive imagination? I'm  not sure what to do or     who   to talk to about this, so any advice or insight would be  greatly appreciated.

I'm frustrated with my HR  department. I recently applied for  a promotion within my company, and after going through  the interview process, I was told that I would  be receiving a job offer soon. However, when   I followed up  with HR  to ask about the status of my application, they informed  me that they couldn't provide me with  a salary range for  the position.

I found  this strange, as it's common  practice in our  industry to share salary ranges during the  hiring process  so that candidates have an idea of what  to expect. When  I  pressed them further,  they claimed that they couldn't give me a range because  "it varies based on experience" - which is a pretty  vague reason if you   ask me.

What's even  more annoying  is that they seemed to take offense to my questioning. They   started getting defensive  and dismissive, telling me that  they were "doing their best" and that I should just  wait  patiently for the offer  letter. It felt like they were  trying to  make me feel silly for asking such  a basic question.

Has anyone else  had similar experiences with their HR department? Am I overreacting  here?  I understand that delays  can happen, but the lack of transparency and condescending attitude  from HR  has left a bad taste in  my mouth.

Hey fellow Redditors,

I know a  lot of people think the Batman prep time argument is silly or  overdone, but I'm here to argue that it's actually a good thing.

First of all, let's acknowledge that Batman is a highly skilled and experienced crimefighter.  He's been doing this for years, and he's had his fair share of victories and  defeats. He knows what works and  what   doesn't, and he's constantly adapting his strategies to stay one step ahead of  his enemies.

Now, when it comes   to prep time, Batman is meticulous. He plans  every  detail, from the  weapons he brings to the gadgets he uses to the  routes  he takes. He's not just winging it,  hoping for the best.  He's a  tactician, and he knows that every second  counts.

But here's the thing: Batman's prep time isn't just about him. It's  about his allies, too. When he's preparing for a mission, he's not just  thinking about his own safety and success  - he's thinking about the safety and success  of his team. He's making sure  they have the right  gear, the right  training, and  the right strategy  to take down the  bad guys.

And  let's   not forget, Batman's not just fighting crime for the sake   of it. He's  fighting  for justice, for   what's right.  He's fighting to protect the innocent and vulnerable  from those who would  harm them. By taking the time  to prepare, he's not just saving his own skin  - he's saving  countless lives.

So  the  next time someone  says the Batman prep time argument is silly, just remember: it's not just about Batman.   It's about his dedication to  justice, his commitment  to his allies,  and his unwavering determination to protect   the  people  of Gotham.

Thanks for  reading, fellow Redditors. Let me know what you  think!

I'm   glad you asked! When I  started taking creatine, I was skeptical about the recommended dosage of 10 grams per day. It seemed like a lot to  me, and I wasn't sure if my body would be able to handle  it.

But, I decided  to give  it a  try and started  taking 10 grams per day for   the first week. Honestly, I didn't  notice much of a difference  at first. Maybe  a little more energy during  my workouts, but  nothing too significant.

However,  as  the days went  on,  I started to notice that my muscles were  recovering faster  between workouts.  I could lift heavier  weights and do more reps without feeling  as exhausted. And when I  looked in the mirror, I  noticed that my muscles  were starting to look fuller and more  defined.

By the end of the second week, I was hooked.  The benefits were  undeniable, and I felt  like I had  gained a serious advantage over my  pre-creatine self.  My strength  and endurance had increased significantly,  and   I was loving the results.

Now, I know some people might say that 10 grams  is too much creatine and that it can cause stomach cramps or diarrhea. But honestly, I never experienced  any side effects    like   that. Sure, maybe a tiny bit of bloating,  but nothing major.

In fact, I found that taking  10 grams per day actually helped me stay  hydrated better. I used  to get dizzy spells during  long workouts, but with creatine, that stopped happening altogether. Plus, my muscle cramps decreased significantly.

Of course,  everyone's body is different, so your mileage may vary. But personally,  I think 10 grams per day  is  the sweet spot for maximum benefit. Just remember to drink plenty of water and  listen to your body. If you start  experiencing discomfort, back off  a gram or two and see  how your body responds.

So, to  answer your  question, I  felt amazing  at 10 grams per day. It  gave me the boost I needed

So I've been dating my boyfriend for about three years now, and he has always  been  very liberal when it comes to politics.  He  is  active on Twitter and often  shares articles  promoting progressive causes. He was even   involved  with some local community organizations that dealt with social issues like poverty  and mental  health.

But recently, things have taken an interesting turn. My boyfriend started posting some articles from more conservative sources that challenge our shared values. At first, it didn't bother  me too much  - after all, everyone's entitled  to their   own opinions. But then he kept doing this, day after day, until he basically said he is now  pro-Trump. To say I was shocked would  be putting it mildly.

I tried talking to him about it calmly   but  failed to convince him otherwise. In fact, he started getting defensive  if anyone  tries to  argue with his new beliefs. It feels strange  because  I used to know someone   who had a lot  of  empathy  and concern   for social justice issues, but now he seems more focused on fiscal responsibility  and small government intervention.

This isn't just affecting us -  his friends  are  also surprised by these changes, as they knew him better before he  turned into this  version  of himself. His family is worried since they don't see eye to  eye with his political beliefs either. It just shows how far apart we both feel  about certain topics, which only adds   tension to  our already busy lives.

So yeah,  any advice or insights you can  offer  will be  greatly appreciated as I navigate  through this  awkward situation.

Becoming an auntie means taking  on a  new role in the lives of your siblings' children. It can be challenging, but  it  is also incredibly rewarding. There  are so many  amazing moments that come with being an auntie:

1. Watching them grow and  learn  new things
2. Sharing your wisdom and experiences  with them
3. Teaching them valuable life lessons
4. Having fun  and spending quality time together
5. Seeing their facial expressions when you give them something they love, whether it be candy or a toy
6. Hearing   about all their  milestones, from first  steps to  graduation
7. Helping out whenever they  need someone  to watch over them or  talk to them
8. Shaping them  into   better  adults by providing guidance and discipline
9. Becoming like a second parent for some (which can  help relieve  the workload from the primary   caregivers)

Overall, becoming an  auntie comes  with its own unique set of challenges and  responsibilities, but it  is also one of the most fulfilling  roles  to have. It gives me great joy to see my family thrive, and I  enjoy doing  everything  in  my power to make sure they do!

Kakine  is undoubtedly one of  the most powerful characters in the popular web novel,  "Accel World." His ability to create an army of unique ghosts and demons through his knowledge of  ancient spells from over 100,000 grimoires makes him a formidable force to  be reckoned  with.

One   of  Kakine's key strengths  lies in  his access  to these  hundreds of thousands of texts. Each grimoire contains  a different set of magical spells  and techniques that allows for a wide range of abilities, and by unlocking their secrets, Kakine  has been able to build an army unlike  any  other.

As  an expert alchemist  and mage, Kakine is skilled at selecting the right grimoires for each task he undertakes. Whether it's  summoning a specific  demon, manipulating space-time, or controlling fire and  water,  his knowledge of these ancient artifacts gives him   the  power to accomplish feats beyond human understanding.

But Kakine  also understands that knowledge alone  is not enough to  truly master these grimoires.  He must also devote countless hours of study and  practice to learn how best to wield  them   in combat. Through   diligence and dedication,  he has become an expert in many  different forms of magic, enabling him to take advantage of his  enemies'  weaknesses  and  exploit every opportunity available to him  on the battlefield.

Overall, Kakine's  mastery of both   the physical and mental aspects of magic make him one  of Accel  World's most formidable protagonists. With his vast arsenal of grimoires and his deep understanding of the mysteries they hold, there   are few challenges he  cannot overcome, making him a true master of the craft!

I  have  been a fan of  the  MCU for some time now, and I have a few questions about the overall plot. 

Firstly, what is  the  ultimate goal of  Thanos and how does he  become so powerful? It seems like he wants to erase half of all existence,   but  what is his motivation for this? 

Secondly, what happens to the remaining half of humanity after the blip? Did they adapt to living with a smaller population, or were they forced to make  drastic changes to their societies?

Finally, what  is  the  fate of the Asgardians  and the  other alien races?  Are they still around,  and if so,  what has happened to  them? These  questions  have been weighing on my  mind for some time now, and I would love to hear  your thoughts.

Downloading clips from Twitch can be  frustrating, especially   if you want to watch them offline or share  them  on social media platforms that   don't support  video compression (such  as Instagram). This is where the issue arises because most clips are  compressed using H.264, which requires specific software and tools to playback correctly.

Here are some steps to follow to download clips from Twitch  without compression:
1. Open your browser and go to the clip you want to download. Ensure it has a  resolution of 720p or higher. Lower resolutions may not work  well  without  compression.
2. Click on the "Download" button under the clip. If there   isn't one available, copy  the URL  of the page in question.
3. Once the page loads, locate the URL bar in  your browser and click "Ctrl + D" to  add  the website to your favorites. This will allow you to quickly access  the download again  later.
4.  Install FFmpeg,  if you haven't done so  already. You  can download it for free from their official website <https://ffmpeg.org/download.html>. Open a command  prompt  or terminal window  once it's installed.
5.  Navigate to the    directory where you saved the favorite  link by  typing "cd C:\Users\YourUserName\Favorites". Replace  "C:\Users\YourUserName\Favorites" with  the  actual  folder location that contains your favorites list and replace  "YourUserName"  with  your actual user name.
6. Type "TwirlDVD %favorite_name%" into command prompt and hit enter. Make  sure that the name in parenthesis matches  the  name you entered when you   saved the favorite in step  3.
7. After  some  waiting time, the file should appear in the current directory. The quality of the resulting file depends  largely on the clip's original resolution. Some videos may  still have been compressed, though  it won't  affect its download speed significantly.

There is  some  debate on  social media regarding whether or not neutering a  Brittany Spaniel will cause them  to become more relaxed and less energetic. Some argue  that this surgery can actually  help reduce aggression and anxiety in dogs, while others believe that it may lead to an overall  decline in  activity  level,  which  could eventually make a dog more sedentary.

Regardless what you choose to do for your Brittany   Spaniel, it's important to remember that  neutering should always be done under  the supervision of a licensed veterinarian who has knowledge about the breed specifically. This  type   of surgerical intervention requires  careful consideration and thorough understanding of its potential effects before  proceeding.

**Please give up; I will not change. Seriously, give up.**

Why am I here? I don't know.   To help you? To make a difference? To change the course of  social history? No. I'm here  to be a  brat. A loudmouthed, self-righteous, in your  face brat who refuses to do anything because I   think the world  sucks.  The world sucks and I don't want  anyone to be happy or satisfied or even complacent. I want you  to feel sick, disgusted,  and depressed. I  want you to take pills and be an addict. I want  you to feel like crap and blame the government for your problems (sorry, you created  it). I  want you to feel  like shit  but keep  quiet. I want you to go into depression and  self-destructive  habits  instead of taking responsibility  for being unfulfilled.

I  don't  want you to know that you  are the reason you are unhappy, and that you could change the way you  view and interact with the world in  order to make it an  enjoyable place  for you. I actually want you to stay  unfulfilled, miserable,  and unhappy. I want you to go  to hell but  not know you are  going.

Why? Because a miserable world  with people who  don't want to help them means that for  every million people there are a million problems to be solved. So if you  want to feel like shit and be miserable but not  do  anything to help yourself  or others, that's what it  means for me. You're helping  me make money.

But that might be an unintended  effect of  my actions, and not my real motive—so I have another reason to be here.  I'm really here to be  a martyr.  A loudmouth, self-righteous, in your  face  martyr  who  refuses to do anything  about the world being unfair,  because it    sucks. I'm  just going to sit  here  in my chair, write these pointless blog posts, and  complain.

I just  moved to this city  4 months ago  from a place   that  has  many of these issues, but the driver  attitudes are different and more polite. The drivers here are pretty much the worse I have  ever encountered. They  all act as if they  don't see you when   you try to get  over, they speed at any chance they get (even in a 30 zone), tailgate constantly and  when you go to turn turn they  will just blow by you at the turn and honk and act like you are not even on the road. It is  like they are  the only  ones who are  supposed to go on the road, everyone  else just slows them down. You won't find anyone that understands  you are  trying to get over because you have a   long way  to go to get home. I am going to say it again because it is really frustrating,  there is no courtesy,  no patience, just aggressive drivers.  That really grinds  my gears and I am  not  a particularly angry person.
I hate to say this,  but you get used to  this in a  relatively short amount of time. I can't count the  number of times I've  been tailgated, honked at, and  passed dangerously, but I just put my  head down and  keep going. In fact, I'm still shocked that  my car  isn't damaged    or scratched more often  than it is. But    that's just the way this city and  many others are. It's kind  of sad because you really have to tune all that negativity out and focus on being a safe driver to not get    mad and have it turn  into something dangerous on  the road. Personally, I've made a point of taking  the most out  of  all the  great  things  that  this city has to offer and  spend  a lot of time doing things outside  of work. This city  is certainly far  from perfect, but I've decided that it's my job as a resident  to make sure I don't focus on the negative. Maybe that  won't work for everybody, but  it certainly does work for  me!
I guess  you get used to that. There have been many times where I've been driving home and a person in front  of me  would go through a green light and I can't catch up  because there is  too  much traffic. Hey there! Congratulations on planning your first  ever campaign! It's  an exciting journey  you're  about to  embark on. To help you   get started, here are some   tips:

1.  Define your goals: What do you want to achieve  with  your campaign? Increased brand awareness,  more sales, more website  traffic? Knowing your goals will help you create a  plan  that aligns with  your objectives.

2. Know your  audience: Who  is your target customer? Understanding   their needs, preferences, and behavior will  help you tailor  your campaign messages and channels  to reach them effectively.

3. Pick the right channels:  With so many marketing channels available, it can be  overwhelming to choose. Consider where your audience spends their time and select the  channels that align with their  preferences.

4. Create a content plan: Content is the backbone  of any campaign. Plan out the  content you'll create,  whether it's blog posts,  social media updates, emails or videos.  Ensure the content aligns with your goals and resonates with your audience.

5. Set a budget: Decide   on how much  you're willing to spend on your campaign. This will help you  decide  which  channels to focus on and how much content you can create.

6. Track and  measure results: Don't forget to track your campaign's success. Use analytics tools to monitor progress and make data-driven decisions to improve the  campaign's performance.

Remember, planning a campaign takes time and effort, but with these  tips and a  well-defined strategy,  you'll be  well on your  way to  a successful campaign!  Good luck!

Merhaba arkadaşlar, bugün sizlere reddit platformunda  yayınlanan içerikler hakkında  bir konu şeklinde  paylaşmak istiyorum. Geçen  zamanlarda daha fazla kullanıcı redditin dışında  diğer platformlardaki içeriğe odaklanmaya  başlamış oldukça gördüm  ve bunun sebebi de belli  ki farklı   nedenlerden kaynaklanır.  Bazıları izlenmeyi tercih ediyor olabilir ya  da ekonomik durumundaki zorluklar nedeniyle üyelik iptali  yaparak içeriği alternatif platformlara taşımaya karar vermiş olabilir. Ancak bu davranış özellikle Türkiye'deyse pek çok  nedenden dolayı  ortaya çıkabiliyor.  Örneğin internet erişimi azaldıktan sonra genelde insanlar daha fazla  zamanda sohbet sitelerine  giderken benzer şartlarda social medya platformlarına da daha az bakılmaktadır. Ayrıca para cezası varsa akıllı cep telefonumuza aldırmadan geçememiştik ancak artık parasız olduğumuz uselerek her yerde bulunduğumuzdan memnuniyet duymuyoruz. Bu sayede takip etmemizi daha  az   harcayan altyapı sağlayan platformlar vurgulama altında  geldi. Yani  eğer size sorarsak; reddit ne kadar popüler mi? Dediysenize hayır  ilgisi olmadı  demektedir tabii ki! Ama  o  zaman nasıl olur  acaba? İnsanlar gerçekten onu beğendiler  ama  yavaş yavaş diğer platformlardaki içeriklere  odakland
