"The Girl with the Dragon  Tattoo" is a dark and intense thriller that will keep you on the edge  of your seat from start to finish. Based on the best-selling novel by Stieg Larsson, this  film  adaptation does justice  to the intricate and gripping  story.

The  standout performance in this  film is undoubtedly Rooney  Mara  as Lisbeth Salander. She fully embodies the  complex and enigmatic character,  delivering a performance that is both vulnerable  and fierce. Mara's portrayal  is  truly captivating, and she brings a level of  intensity and depth to the role that is exceptional.

Daniel  Craig also delivers a strong performance as journalist Mikael Blomkvist. He  portrays the character with a  perfect balance of determination and vulnerability, making him relatable and likable. The   chemistry between Mara and  Craig is undeniable, and their scenes together are electrifying.

Director  David Fincher does a remarkable job of capturing the dark and gritty atmosphere of the story. The cinematography is  stunning, and the use of lighting and colors adds to the overall mood  of the film.  The pacing is perfect,  keeping the audience engaged and invested in the  story without any dull moments.

One of  the most impressive aspects of  "The Girl with the Dragon  Tattoo" is its  intricate  plot. The story is filled with  twists and turns that constantly keep you guessing. The  mystery unfolds  gradually, unraveling the dark secrets and hidden agendas of the characters. The    tension   builds steadily,  culminating in a shocking and satisfying   conclusion.

The  film also tackles  sensitive and important themes, such as violence against women and corruption within  the justice system. It does so with a thought-provoking and unflinching  approach, shining a light  on  the dark underbelly of society. These  themes  are handled with  care  and respect, making  the film even  more impactful.

While "The  Girl with the Dragon  Tattoo"  is undoubtedly  a  fantastic film, it is  not for the faint of heart.  It  contains scenes  of violence and  disturbing content that may be difficult  to watch for some  viewers. However, if you can  handle the grittiness, this movie is an absolute must-see.

In  conclusion, "The Girl  with the  Dragon Tattoo" is a thrilling  and thought-provoking film that will  leave you pondering its themes long  after the credits roll. With  exceptional performances, stunning visuals, and a gripping plot, it is a masterpiece  in its genre. Highly recommended for fans  of dark and intense thrillers.

Ocean's Thirteen is a thrilling  and entertaining heist film that successfully brings back the  charm and wit of the original  Ocean's Eleven. Directed by Steven Soderbergh, the  film reunites the star-studded cast including George Clooney, Brad Pitt, and Matt   Damon, who once again deliver charismatic performances.

The plot revolves  around Danny Ocean (Clooney) and his team seeking revenge on  a ruthless casino owner, Willy Bank (Al Pacino),  who double-crossed their friend Reuben (Elliott   Gould). The group plans  an elaborate scheme to  ruin Bank's new  casino on its opening night, using their unique skills  and expertise.

One of  the strengths of Ocean's Thirteen is its clever and intricate plot. The heist is meticulously planned, with each member of the team  having a specific role  to  play. The film keeps the audience engaged and  guessing as the plan unfolds, with unexpected twists and    turns along the  way.  The  pacing is excellent, never dragging or feeling rushed, and   the script is filled with witty dialogue  that adds to the enjoyment.

The chemistry between the cast members  is another highlight of  the film. Clooney, Pitt, and Damon effortlessly slip back into their  roles, displaying  the same camaraderie and  banter  that made the first film so enjoyable.  The addition of Al Pacino as the antagonist brings a new dynamic  to the group,   and his performance is suitably menacing and charismatic.

Visually, Ocean's  Thirteen is stylish  and sleek, capturing the glitz and glamour of Las Vegas. The production design and cinematography  are top-notch, creating a visually appealing  backdrop for the heist. The film also  features a fantastic   score by David Holmes, which adds  to  the overall cool and sophisticated atmosphere.

While Ocean's Thirteen may not offer anything groundbreaking or revolutionary, it is a highly entertaining and  well-executed heist film. It successfully captures the spirit of the   original    Ocean's Eleven  and  delivers a  fun and enjoyable  experience. Fans of the  franchise will not be disappointed,  and newcomers will find   themselves easily  drawn into the world of  Danny Ocean and his crew.

"Borat: Cultural Learnings of America  for Make Benefit Glorious  Nation of Kazakhstan" is a satirical  masterpiece that pushes the boundaries of comedy and social commentary.  Sacha Baron  Cohen's portrayal of the fictional Kazakh journalist, Borat Sagdiyev,  is both  hilarious and thought-provoking.

The film follows Borat as  he travels   across  America, interacting with real   people who are unaware that they are  part of a  mockumentary.   Through his  outrageous behavior  and offensive remarks,  Borat exposes  the  underlying prejudices and  ignorance that exist in American society.

What sets  this film apart is its ability to simultaneously entertain and challenge its audience. The humor is often cringe-worthy, but it serves a purpose. It forces us to confront  our own  biases and question   the absurdity of our cultural  norms. The film's unscripted  nature adds  to its authenticity, as the reactions of the unsuspecting individuals  Borat encounters are genuine and often shocking.

Sacha  Baron  Cohen's performance as Borat is nothing short of brilliant. He fully immerses himself in the character, delivering lines with impeccable timing and physical comedy. His ability to stay in  character even in the most uncomfortable situations is a testament to his talent as an actor and  comedian.

While some may argue that the film  goes too far in its  portrayal of stereotypes and offensive humor, it is important to remember that it is intended to be a  satire.   It uses exaggeration and shock value to highlight the absurdity of  prejudice and ignorance.  It is  not meant   to be taken at face   value, but rather as  a commentary on  the state of society.

"Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for  Make  Benefit Glorious  Nation of Kazakhstan" is a bold and daring film that  challenges its   audience to confront uncomfortable  truths. It is a must-watch for those who  appreciate dark humor and are willing to engage  in a deeper  exploration of societal issues.

Peaceful Warrior is a thought-provoking and inspiring film that  combines  elements of drama  and  spirituality to  create a unique and engaging story. Based on the memoir of the same name by  Dan Millman, the movie  follows the  journey of a talented gymnast named Dan as he struggles to find meaning  and purpose in his life.

Scott Mechlowicz  delivers an exceptional  performance  as   Dan,  effortlessly capturing the complexities  and internal conflicts  of the character. Through his  encounters with a mysterious gas station   attendant, played by  Nick Nolte, Dan begins to question his beliefs,  challenge his limitations, and embrace a  new philosophy that changes his life forever.

The movie beautifully  explores themes  of self-discovery, personal growth, and the power of the human spirit. It encourages   viewers to reflect on their own lives and question the choices they   have made, inspiring them to  seek a deeper understanding of  themselves and their  place in the world.

Director  Victor Salva succeeds in  creating a visually stunning film, with  breathtaking gymnastic sequences that are not only impressive but also serve as powerful  metaphors for the obstacles and triumphs we face in life.  The cinematography   and editing are top-notch, making every  scene visually  captivating.

What sets Peaceful Warrior apart from other films in its  genre is its ability to balance the spiritual and philosophical teachings with a relatable  and engaging  narrative. The screenplay  is beautifully written, effortlessly  blending moments of humor, drama,  and  profound wisdom. The  dialogues between Dan and the gas station  attendant are particularly memorable,  filled with pearls  of  wisdom that resonate even after the film ends.

The film's message is  delivered with  subtlety and nuance, allowing the  audience to come   to their own conclusions and interpretations. It encourages viewers to question societal norms, embrace change and growth, and find their own path towards happiness and  inner peace.

Overall,  Peaceful Warrior is an  incredibly  inspiring and thought-provoking film that will leave a lasting impact  on anyone who watches it. With its powerful  performances, beautiful visuals, and profound message, this movie  is a must-see for   anyone seeking a deeper understanding of  themselves and the world  around them.

"We're  the Millers" is   a hilarious and  entertaining film that will keep you laughing throughout. This comedy follows a group of misfits who pose as  a typical American family  in order to  smuggle drugs across the Mexican border.  

The film is led  by a  superb cast, with Jason Sudeikis in the  role of David, a  small-time drug dealer who  forms  the  fake family.  Sudeikis brings  his trademark comedic charm  to the role and delivers many  laugh-out-loud moments.  Jennifer Aniston shines as Rose, a  stripper hired to play  David's wife, and proves once again that she can excel in  comedic roles. Emma Roberts and    Will Poulter complete the  "family" as the sarcastic and  rebellious daughter and son,  respectively, and their performances  are equally strong.

What sets  "We're the  Millers"  apart from other comedies is its witty and clever script. The jokes are fresh and original, and the  film   isn't afraid to take  risks. The situational humor is spot-on, and the comedy is  balanced with  some heartwarming moments that  add depth to the characters.

The movie  also benefits  from its excellent supporting cast. Nick Offerman and Kathryn  Hahn  steal scenes as a conservative couple who become entangled  in  the Millers' drug smuggling  scheme. The chemistry between  the actors is palpable, and  their comedic timing  is impeccable.

Aside from the stellar performances, the film boasts impressive visuals,  particularly  during the  road trip sequences. The cinematography captures the beauty of the American landscape and adds to the overall enjoyment of the film.

While "We're the Millers" may not be the most  original concept, it executes its premise with flair and provides plenty  of laughs  along the way. It's a great choice if you're looking for a lighthearted comedy that will keep you entertained from  start to finish.

"The Disaster Artist" is an absolute masterpiece that takes viewers on a hilarious and captivating  journey   into the strange world  of  filmmaking. Based  on  a true story, this film follows the  dreams and struggles of aspiring  actor Greg Sestero and the enigmatic Tommy Wiseau, who is determined to become the next  big Hollywood star.

James Franco shines in his dual role as  director and  actor,  perfectly capturing the eccentricity and passion of  Tommy Wiseau. Franco's performance is nothing short of amazing,  as he  fully   immerses  himself in the role of Wiseau  and manages  to bring  humor, empathy, and  depth   to a character  who is so outrageous  and enigmatic.

The chemistry between Franco and  his real-life brother, Dave Franco, who portrays Greg Sestero,  is  electric. Their on-screen dynamic adds  an authentic and endearing layer  to the  story, as we witness the friendship between these two aspiring actors blossom amidst the chaos of  creating a film that  becomes a  cult sensation for all the wrong reasons.

The writing and directing by James  Franco are top-notch. He successfully navigates the fine  line between re-creating the hilariously awful moments  from the original film,  "The  Room," while also presenting the human side of the  story. The pacing is spot-on,  engaging the audience from   start to finish,  and  providing a  balance between laugh-out-loud moments and  more introspective scenes that explore the complexities of Wiseau's character.

While  "The Disaster Artist" is undeniably a comedy, it also offers a deeper exploration of friendship,    dreams, and the pursuit of artistic expression. It  delves into the idea that even in the face of tremendous failure, there is something admirable about those who dare to create and put themselves  out there.

The supporting   cast is exceptional, with standout performances from  Seth Rogen, who brings his signature humor and wit, and Alison Brie, who portrays Sestero's girlfriend  with charm  and sincerity.   The film also features several cameos from well-known    actors and industry figures, adding to  its overall authenticity and entertainment value.

The visuals and  production design successfully transport viewers back to the  early  2000s and  the  world of independent  filmmaking.  From  the awkwardly staged green screen scenes to the infamous rooftop setting,   there is attention to detail that amplifies the absurdity and charm of  the original film.

Overall,  "The  Disaster Artist" is a triumph. It serves as a loving  tribute to the cult classic "The Room" while  also offering a universally relatable story about the pursuit of one's dreams. James Franco's tour de force performance

Remember  the Titans    is a  powerful  and inspiring film that tells the true story of a high school football  team's journey towards  racial integration and   unity in the 1970s.   Directed by Boaz Yakin, this  movie is  a  perfect blend of sports, drama, and social commentary.

The   film is set in Alexandria, Virginia, where the  local high school is forced to integrate its black and white students. This leads to tensions and  conflicts, especially  within the football team, as the players  struggle  to  accept and trust   each other. However, under the guidance of their new head coach, Herman Boone, brilliantly portrayed by Denzel Washington,  the team  gradually learns  to put  aside their differences and work together   towards   a common goal.

One of the  strengths  of Remember the Titans  is its exceptional cast. Denzel Washington delivers  a captivating performance as Coach Boone, displaying both strength and vulnerability. Will Patton  also shines as Coach Yoast, the former head  coach who becomes Boone's assistant and learns to overcome  his own prejudices. The chemistry between the actors is  palpable,  and their performances bring depth  and  authenticity to the characters.

The film's screenplay, written by Gregory Allen Howard, is another standout aspect. It skillfully  balances the football action with the personal stories of the  players, allowing us to connect  with them  on a deeper level. The  dialogue is sharp and impactful, delivering  powerful messages about racial equality and the  importance of teamwork.

Remember the Titans also benefits from its stunning cinematography and well-executed football sequences. The  games are intense  and exhilarating, capturing the spirit of competition and the  players' determination to succeed. The film's  soundtrack, featuring a mix   of Motown classics and original compositions  by Trevor Rabin, adds an extra layer of emotion and  energy to the story.

What sets  Remember the Titans apart from other  sports movies is  its ability  to tackle important social issues without sacrificing entertainment value. It explores themes of racism, prejudice, and friendship  in a  thought-provoking  and accessible  way. The film's message  of unity  and acceptance is as relevant today as it was when  the events took place.

In conclusion, Remember the Titans  is a must-watch film  that combines a compelling true story, outstanding performances, and   a  powerful message. It will make you laugh, cry, and  reflect on the importance of overcoming differences and working together. Whether you're a fan of sports movies or  simply appreciate a well-crafted film, Remember the Titans is  a true gem that  deserves  recognition.

Rocketman is a mesmerizing and heartfelt musical  biopic that takes audiences on a wild ride through the life and career  of the legendary musician,  Elton John. Taron Egerton  delivers a  stunning performance as the  iconic singer, capturing both his flamboyant  stage presence  and his vulnerable, troubled soul.

The film beautifully blends fantasy  and reality,  using Elton John's own  music to tell his story in a  way that feels  both authentic  and  magical. Director Dexter  Fletcher's imaginative approach to the musical numbers adds an extra layer of depth  to the narrative, making  them feel like  emotional extensions of the  characters' inner worlds.

One of the film's greatest strengths is its unflinching portrayal of  Elton John's struggles  with addiction, loneliness, and self-acceptance.  It doesn't shy away from the darker aspects of his life, but rather confronts them head-on, showing  the toll they  took on his relationships and mental health. This raw honesty adds a  layer  of  authenticity to the story, making it  more than  just a typical biopic.

Egerton's  performance is nothing short of  extraordinary.   He not only  captures Elton John's  physicality  and mannerisms   but also dives deep into the emotional core of the character. His singing voice is remarkably similar to the real   Elton John's, and he brings a  vulnerability and depth to the role that is truly  captivating.

The  supporting  cast is equally impressive,  with standout performances from Jamie Bell as Elton's  longtime collaborator and friend, Bernie Taupin, and Richard  Madden  as Elton's  manipulative manager and lover, John Reid. Their chemistry with Egerton is palpable, adding another layer of complexity to the relationships portrayed on  screen.

Rocketman  is a visual feast,   with stunning production design, vibrant costumes, and dazzling musical  sequences that  transport the audience  into Elton John's world. The film's use  of color and visual  effects  is  both bold and imaginative, creating  a sense of wonder and spectacle that perfectly complements the larger-than-life  persona of its subject.

Overall,  Rocketman is a triumph. It's a deeply  moving and entertaining film that celebrates   the life  and music of Elton John while also exploring the universal themes of love,  identity, and self-acceptance.  With its stellar performances, stunning visuals, and unforgettable soundtrack, it's   a must-see for fans of Elton John and anyone who  appreciates a  well-crafted and emotionally resonant biopic.

The Hangover is a wild and hilarious comedy  that  had me laughing from start to finish. The story follows a  group of friends who wake up after a bachelor party in Las Vegas with no memory   of  the previous night and must retrace their  steps to find the missing groom.

From the opening scene, I was hooked by the sheer absurdity of  the  situation and the  quick   wit of    the characters. The chemistry between the  cast is fantastic,  with each actor bringing their   own unique brand  of  humor to the table. Zach Galifianakis steals the  show as the eccentric and unpredictable   Alan, delivering one-liners that had me in stitches.

Not only is  the film incredibly funny, but it also has a surprising amount of heart.  As the group searches  for their missing friend, they undergo a series of  hilarious and often dangerous misadventures. But amidst all  the chaos, there are moments  of genuine emotion  that add depth and make the  characters more relatable.

The writing   is sharp and filled  with  clever  twists  and turns,  keeping the audience engaged and guessing throughout. The pace  never lets up, with every  scene delivering  something unexpected or outlandish. Director Todd Phillips  expertly blends comedy and action,  resulting  in  a  film  that  is as thrilling as it is   funny.

The Hangover is not a movie for the faint of heart, as it pushes  the boundaries of what is considered appropriate humor. It embraces  raunchy  and outrageous humor, and while some may find  it offensive,   for me, it added to the overall enjoyment of the film.  The comedic timing and  delivery of the jokes  are just spot  on, leaving no  room for a dull moment.

Overall, The Hangover is an absolute riot. It's a non-stop rollercoaster of laughs and surprises that will  leave you in stitches. If you're  looking for a comedy that doesn't take itself too seriously  and can deliver belly laughs, then this is the  perfect film for you. Just be prepared for a wild ride that you won't soon forget.

"Gettysburg"  is an epic war film that takes viewers on a gripping  journey through the    historic battle fought between the  Union and Confederate armies during the  American Civil War. Directed by Ron Maxwell, this film  is  a majestic   portrayal of the three-day battle  that changed the course of American  history.

From the very beginning, "Gettysburg" immerses  the audience in the chaos and intensity of  the war. The  battle sequences are masterfully executed with  visceral realism, creating a sense of authenticity that  pulls you right into the heart of  the action. The cinematography is  stunning,  capturing the vast landscapes and brutal warfare with breathtaking precision.

What truly  sets  "Gettysburg" apart  is its focus on  character development and  storytelling.  The film  delves deep into the lives and motivations of the  men  on both sides of the conflict, presenting a well-rounded and  human perspective on this bloody  chapter in American history. The cast is   exceptional, with standout performances by  Tom Berenger as General James Longstreet and Jeff Daniels as  Colonel  Joshua  Chamberlain. Their portrayals bring complexity  and nuance  to  their respective roles, adding depth and emotional resonance to the film.

In addition to the gripping battle scenes and strong performances, "Gettysburg" also explores the moral dilemmas faced by the   soldiers and the broader implications of   the war. It raises  thought-provoking questions about duty, sacrifice, and the price of freedom. This film is  not only a war epic but also a  powerful   examination  of the human spirit and the lasting impact of war on individuals and nations.

Although "Gettysburg" is quite long,  with a runtime of over four  hours, it  never feels tedious or  drawn-out.  The pacing is well-balanced, and the  narrative keeps you engaged and invested  throughout. The film's script is intelligent and poignant, offering poignant insights into  the complexities of war and the personal tragedies that come with it.

Overall, "Gettysburg" is a   monumental achievement in historical filmmaking. It successfully captures  the essence of  the   battle and   presents a rich, multi-dimensional  account of the individuals who fought on both sides.  With its stunning cinematography, superb performances, and thought-provoking storytelling,  this film is  a must-watch for any history buff or lover of powerful cinema.

Kickboxer is  an action-packed martial  arts film that  delivers on its  promise of thrilling fight  sequences and intense action. The movie follows the journey of  Kurt Sloane, played by Jean-Claude Van Damme, as he seeks revenge for  his brother's brutal  defeat at the  hands of  the ruthless Tong Po.

One of the standout aspects of Kickboxer is the impressive choreography  of the fight scenes.  Each fight is meticulously crafted,  showcasing the skills and athleticism of the actors. Van   Damme's martial arts prowess is on full display, and his acrobatic moves  and  lightning-fast kicks are a treat  to watch. The film also does a great  job of building tension and suspense leading up to the fights, making them  even more satisfying when they finally  occur.

The storyline of Kickboxer may not be  the most original, but it serves as a solid foundation  for  the  action.  The  film  explores themes of revenge, redemption, and the power of determination. While the plot may be predictable at times, it is the performances of  the cast that elevate the material. Van Damme delivers a charismatic   and engaging  performance as Kurt Sloane, and his chemistry with his co-stars  is  palpable.

In  addition to the action and performances, Kickboxer  also benefits  from its atmospheric setting. The film  takes place  in Thailand, and the exotic locations add an extra layer of authenticity to the story. The vibrant colors and bustling streets of  Bangkok create a visually stunning backdrop for the intense fight  sequences.

However, Kickboxer does have  its flaws. The  pacing can be uneven at times, with certain scenes feeling rushed while others drag on. Additionally,  some of  the dialogue  and character development   could have been stronger,  as certain relationships and  motivations     are not  fully explored.

Overall, Kickboxer is a highly  entertaining martial  arts film that delivers  on its promise of thrilling action.  While it may not be the most groundbreaking  or thought-provoking  movie,  it succeeds in providing an adrenaline-fueled  experience for fans of  the genre.  With its impressive fight choreography, charismatic performances,  and stunning setting, Kickboxer  is a  must-watch for action enthusiasts.

V for Vendetta is a thought-provoking and visually stunning  film that captivates from start to finish. Set in a dystopian future where a totalitarian government rules with an  iron fist, the story follows the enigmatic  character   known as V,  played brilliantly by Hugo Weaving. V, wearing a Guy Fawkes mask, becomes  a symbol of resistance against  the oppressive regime.

The film is filled  with political undertones and explores themes of freedom, justice, and the power of ideas. It raises important   questions about the role of government  and the individual's  responsibility to  stand up against  injustice. The  script, adapted  from  Alan Moore's graphic novel, is intelligent and thoughtfully  written, keeping  the audience engaged throughout.

Natalie  Portman delivers a powerful performance as Evey, a young woman who becomes entangled in  V's mission. Her character undergoes  a transformation throughout the film, and Portman portrays the emotional journey with depth and conviction.  The chemistry between Portman and   Weaving is palpable,   adding  an extra layer of complexity  to the  story.

Visually, V for Vendetta is a  feast  for the eyes.   The cinematography is stunning, with   dark and moody tones that  perfectly capture the oppressive atmosphere of the world. The action sequences are well-choreographed and exhilarating, keeping  the  audience  on the edge of their seats.

The film's message  is delivered with subtlety and nuance, allowing viewers to draw their  own conclusions.  It challenges the audience to question authority and think critically about the world  we live  in. V for  Vendetta is a powerful  and thought-provoking  film that will  leave a lasting impact.

This movie is a   masterpiece. It is a heartbreaking, beautiful story about true love between two friends that overrides everything else, even when the rest of the world seems against it. The  acting in this  film is  brilliant, and  it has a terrific cast. I especially loved  Jake Gyllenhaal's performance, but Anne Hathaway and Heath  Ledger were both amazing as  well. It's   a sad story,  but it  really is a must-see movie. The script is brilliantly written, and the scenery  is   gorgeous. Definitely worth buying a ticket  to!

While Rocky III contains  many of the same characteristics that made its predecessors so  great, this film,   although watchable, lacks the feel of the previous two films. Many things are different  this time around.  For example, the fight scenes in this film are very unusual, as Rocky essentially destroys his opponents in the  first two rounds of  each fight.  For the first time since the original Rocky,  Talia  Shire does  not appear in the film,   although her voice is heard during the opening scene. Also, Burt Young's  role as Adrian's brother is reduced  significantly. Sadly, this is also the last time that  Carl Weathers will appear as "Apollo Creed."

Once again,  Rocky  struggles with whether he should keep  fighting  or not.  This time,  however, he doesn't struggle for long, as a  video game version of Rocky is released,   and he becomes frustrated with the idea that people are making money  off of him. Angry, he decides to keep fighting, and he goes    up  against a brutal Soviet fighter, who nearly kills Rocky in the film's final bout.

While the story is  nothing special, the performances are  what make the film work.  Sylvester Stallone  is, as always, excellent in the   title role, and Mr. T is equally  effective as  Rocky's  nemesis, "Clubber Lang." The rest  of the  cast, including Burt  Young, is good as well.

While Rocky III  was  not as  good as its predecessors, it  is still an enjoyable film due to the performances of the cast. If you're  a  fan of the Rocky films, you'll want to  see this one, although I recommend the first two films  over this  one.

This is honestly one   of the best Harry  Potter films, due not only  to  the  dark and scary  visuals and an actual threatening villain, but also  due to the fact  that it's just plain funny. Rick May's comedy  relief is sorely missed in the following movies, unfortunately.

It's also the last one where the series retains  a  sense of innocence before it  started getting really dark and creepy (although to  be  fair,  it was always creepy, but the kids were  too young  to notice).

 relive the young years of the  HP  series anymore. The spiders,  the gnomes, the talking snakes, the feasts, the charms, the burps, the  potatoes. Man, this movie series had it all.

Sure, the  plot is downright ridiculous and completely  nonsensical, but ain't that how  all fantasy movies are?  At least this one made it funny, too. What  a concept!  A funny fantasy  movie, the likes of which  have not been seen since the LucasArts adventures  (yes, I'm aware those were animations, but still).

Who Framed Roger Rabbit is a  masterpiece. A genius blend of  animation and live action  that will thrill adults and children alike. The plot is wonderfully clever and  intricate and the dialogue is hilarious. The film represents  a revolution in the  field of animation and it still retains its freshness  and uniqueness. Who  Framed Roger Rabbit  is an inspiration for all movie  makers and a joy for all movie goers. Gene Siskel  saw this picture in 1988 and immediately declared it the best film of  the year, and he was  right.  This  movie has it  all:  drama, humor, romance, action,...  What else can I say -Watcher, wherever you  are,  this one's for you!

As   with  the first film,  director  Guy Ritchie's visualization of  Arthur Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes is bold, witty, and action-packed, with the necessary emotional undercurrents to ground the thrilling sequences.   This time  around, Holmes (Robert Downey Jr.) and his  stalwart partner, Dr. John Watson (Jude Law), take on elusive rogue hitter Professor James Moriarty (Jared Harris), who's always a step ahead of  Holmes, orchestrating a vicious series  of crimes that threatens to plunge Europe into  war.  Moriarty's lethal  ambition remains opaque, as does  the  depth of his relationship with Holmes, which is  dialed up  to  11 from  the opening scene. Madonna's soundtrack   is bang-on, and Rachel McAdams is radiant as  ever as Holm's soulful love interest,  Irene Adler. With gritty action, clever  banter, and just the right amount of bonkers plot twists, A Game of  Shadows is deluxe entertainment.

This is the second part of the epic "Harry Potter"  finale. In  this film, Harry, Ron, and  Hermione are on a mission to destroy the Dark Lord Voldemort's four remaining Horcruxes, the sources  of  his immortality. Although they must rely  on one another more than ever, dark forces  threaten to tear them apart. Voldemort's Death Eaters have seized control of the  Ministry of Magic  and they are searching for Harry  -- even as he and his friends prepare for the  ultimate showdown.

While reading this  review, a reader can understand the plot   of the movie, and their  interest may depend on how well  they've kept up with the franchise. However,  the review doesn't say if  the movie is  any  good. The reader  has no   idea about  the  movie's quality.

This review is  missing a conclusion.

'Us' is an effective horror  film that works on a number of levels. It's  a film that's best viewed with a knowing smile  on your face,  recognizing that the filmmakers are playing with  audience expectations and genre conventions. It's a film  that  also  has a lot  to say about the state of our  country and the  current state of the  world, but  it  does so in a way that's not  heavy-handed or preachy.

The film follows a family on vacation in California. Adelaide (Madison Curry)  is a mother who's struggling to cope with  the loss of her husband. Her daughter,  Zora (Shahidi  Joseph), is a typical teenager who's more  interested in  her phone  than in her  parents. Her son, Jason (Evan Alex), is a young  boy who's  fascinated by a nearby funhouse.

When the family  arrives at their  vacation home,  they discover that they have a  set of identical twins. The twins,  it turns out, are a set  of doppelgangers who have come to take their place. The family must fight for their  lives against   their own reflections.

The film is effective because it's not  just a standard  horror film. It's  a  film that's aware of itself  and is having fun with the genre.  It's a film that's not afraid  to be silly and fun, but it's also a film that has a   lot  to say. It's a  film that's worth watching.

I   have never  fallen  in love with a  city as I  did with Paris. I  recently went  to  Paris for the first time with my  girlfriend. I absolutely loved the city,  largely in part to this magnificent film. When   we returned home I  watched it again.  It  captured the magic I felt in Paris. Why can't Hollywood make films  like this  anymore? I  don't know why, but this film really moved me. The entire cast  was great. I don't know how else to describe it, but it made  me feel good, it made me smile, it made me want to be in Paris. This film is really special. I  hope you enjoy it  as much as I did.

I would encourage  everyone to watch this film because it is dense with meaning and symbolism, and it  is refreshing  to  see a film that does    not spoon-feed  the audience.  Also,  the ideas that it explores--the cycle of life,  the redemption of humanity,   and the importance of love  and family--are important and universal, and help to explain  the human condition, and answered some of the questions that I had about life, in a way that esoteric texts and religions  often do.

The  structure of the film--six stories, each unfolding and then  recursively  explaining aspects of  the  previous stories--is intriguing  and, as far  as I can tell, unique. While each story can  stand on its own, my interpretation of  the film is  that they are all part of the same "superstory," as in the  novel, and  that  they  are interconnected--not just in terms of theme, but also in terms  of characters. There are many parallels and mirror images between the stories, which help to  elucidate this idea. I would love to hear other people's interpretations of the  film and whether  they believe   that  the stories are interconnected in this  way.  

This  film reminded me of "Interstellar" in the way that  it explores universal ideas and generates thought and discussion. Like   "Interstellar," this film is ambitious, and tries to tackle big ideas.  It is a   film that makes you  think and wonder, and is an achievement in film making--one that certainly deserves commendation and recognition.

Great  zombie movie, it doesn't  try  to  reinvent  the wheel like "28 Days  Later"  but it doesn't need to, the wheel was  fine to begin with. Great cast, though  Sid Haig is a bit silly (no pun intended) but  he's still  fun.  The make-up and gore effects are  extremely well  done and the action  is great. This is  probably the best zombie  movie to date, even better than  the original  "Dawn Of The Dead" from 1978, that's saying a lot. If  you're  a  zombie fan you  gotta see this movie, you won't  be disappointed unless you  were looking for something a little more artistic like "28 Days Later" or "Resident Evil", you won't find it here, but you won't find  it in any  zombie movie because zombie movies by their nature don't really lend themselves to a deep  plot, they're just plain fun B-movies and   this one  is as good  as it gets. This movie  rules!

A great sequel and a great zombie movie, even better than  the original in many ways. Highly recommended.

This isOpponents of  violent comedy will have a field day  with South  Park: Bigger, Longer  & Uncut, a film adaptation of  the phenomenally   popular Comedy Central cartoon. While  the movie is violent, crass, and  shockingly  rude,  it's  also funny, razor-sharp, and with a surprisingly keen insight  into  human behavior. The story centers  around a coming-of-age  ritual involving three young  boys from the  Colorado town of South Park. When two of   them are unable to lose their virginity on a camping trip as planned, they decide that the only way they can become men is  by  getting women -- any women -- to have  sex with  them. This decision has far-reaching (and surprisingly dark) consequences  for many of the people in  town.

While the  movie  is a spoof of coming-of-age films like Stand by Me and Lucas, it is also a scathing indictment of the often  duplicitous nature of American foreign policy.den one that will outrage parents and many others. But just as often, the  movie is simply plain funny. The comic invention is lightning  quick, and  the movie moves at  a breakneck pace. This isn't a movie that asks you to think  about   it  -- it wants you to laugh as hard as you can, and often it  succeeds.

Matt Stone and Trey Parker, the duo responsible for the  cartoon, prove themselves adept at translating their creation to the big  screen, and the supporting  cast of  both established  stars (Joe Flaherty,  Dave  Thomas, Isaac  Hayes) and relatively  unknown  actors is first-rate. This is a deceptively  intelligent and funny film whose overt  nastiness  often conceals a surprisingly sweet  center.

As a lifelong fan of Herge's   "Tintin"  comics, I can attest that this movie is true to the source material. Like the comics, it's an exciting, fast-paced adventure  story with a good  dose  of humor   and plenty of action. The movie looks great,  with a  lot of attention to detail  and  some beautiful animation. The  characters are well-developed and the voice acting  is top-notch. Overall, it's a great movie for fans of the comics and  non-fans alike. Highly recommended!

I still love Iron Man  but this movie just didn't do it for me. Don't  get me wrong, it was exciting  and had a lot of action but it just felt like they were  trying too hard to live up  to the original Iron Man and    the result was a  subpar film. It was trying too  hard  to be  a thriller film but  in the  end, it just  wasn't. The story was weak and the acting was subpar. This one is a miss for   me.

Still  shining after all  these years, "Batman Returns" finds the Dark Knight facing off against The Penguin,  aka Oswald Cobblepot (Danny DeVito), and Catwoman (Michelle   Pfeiffer), a mysterious figure who has her eyes  set on Gotham's  leading businessman, Max Shreck (Christopher  Walken).osophical and  analytical, this  film  version of Batman explores the hero's subconscious  through the eyes of  psychiatrist  Alfred Pennyworth (Michael  Gough), who emphasizes the importance of appearances  as they relate to perception.  Accordingly, Batman Returns is a surreal experience, with Gotham portrayed as a combination of Coney Island's  amusement attractions and a medieval fantasy world. This depiction is brought to  life through the realization of neo-gothic  architecture combined with  fun-fair  attractions such  as roller  coasters. Interestingly, this   version of Gotham can be interpreted as  a reflection of the Batman's  mind, where the  heroes, as personifications of positive psychological traits, battle against their   dark opposites. 

In this movie, Batman's primary opposition is The Penguin, a deformed  man who adopts a  false  identity to deceive others and  give  himself power.  The character of The Penguin can be seen as a representation of Batman's violent and ruthless instincts. Similarly, Catwoman symbolizes the hero's desire for chaos and anarchy. Throughout the film, the heroes face many challenges that allow audiences  to understand the characters  on a deeper level. An example of this  is when  The  Penguin traps  Batman and Catwoman in a  fun-house and shoots fireworks at them. Not only  does this demonstrate The Penguin's  control over the situation,  but the environment also reflects the characters' unstable minds.  

"Batman Returns" is a film that explores the complexities of the  Dark   Knight's character, providing a unique and  thought-provoking experience that continues  to  shine after all these years. Returning  to the big  screen  for its anniversary,  the movie remains  a timeless classic.

The movie Harry Potter and the  Chamber  of Secrets is a classic in the  Harry Potter series. It follows Harry as he returns for his second year at Hogwarts School   of Witchcraft and Wizardry,  where he and his  friends Ron and Hermione must solve the mystery surrounding the Chamber  of Secrets.  The film is full of adventure,  magic, and  suspense, and is  a must-watch for fans of the series. The acting is   top-notch, and the  special effects  are  stunning. Overall, it is a great movie that  is sure to entertain  and delight  viewers of all ages.  

Would you like to know more about the movie, or the Harry Potter  series?

Without  the pioneering animation  showcased in  "Who Framed Roger Rabbit"®, we would not  have the digitized actors we  have today filling in parts for live-action stars who might be unwilling or  unable to participate in a given film. Although  the film somewhat loosely holds together as a mystery comedy, it really is  a platform for the animators and computer graphic artists who made it possible for  Bob Hoskins  to interact  with   cartoon characters like Roger Rabbit, who is the reason  why  we are here, and Jessica Rabbit, who understandably latches onto  Hoskins' private  detective character, Eddie Valiant. The plot  has something to do with someone framing Roger Rabbit for the murder of a wealthy businessman, and Eddie having to clear Roger's name, mostly because the police department,  headed by Chief Bogus, refuses to do so.  There's also  a subplot involving  a contract that the weaselly Pete, who is Roger's manager  as well as something of a stalker, wants   Roger to sign which would greatly diminish  Roger's  livelihood. This presents a moral  quandary for Eddie,  who, at first, needs Pete's help  to  get information  from some  of the  Toon  residents of  Hollywood. Eddie  also   has an ongoing conflict with the weasel that   affects the plot as well, although not in any meaningful  way.

The  animation  itself needs to be seen to  be  believed, and there are some laugh-out-loud moments, mostly  provided by the supporting cartoon characters like Donald Duck and Daffy Duck (not the "duck"   in question, however). Overall,  the movie is a lot of fun, if  not  particularly  memorable, and serves as a great showcase for the  then-groundbreaking technology used to bring the cartoon  characters to life.

Without question, "Sherlock  Holmes: A Game of Shadows" boasts some  of the most  exhilarating action sequences in any Sherlock Holmes film to  date. By  playing against type in a largely dialogue-free sequence at the  film's onset, the  always-reliable Robert Downey Jr. demonstrates the sheer physicality  of the character, while also allowing the story  to thereafter unfold with a delightful quickness.  

The story   picks up  where the first film left  off,  with  Holmes and his trusted companion, Dr. John Watson, in pursuit of the nefarious Lord Henry Blackwood. Blackwood is suspected   of committing a series of brutal murders in what appears  to be a dark homage to an earlier, more  brutal era of British history.  Of course, nothing  is as it seems,  and  our heroes once again  find themselves up against a vast conspiracy that threatens  not just  their lives, but those of  all of Britain. 

Downey Jr. and Jude Law are  again in top form here, and their  chemistry is the   film's greatest asset. Despite a runtime nearly fifteen minutes longer than its  predecessor, the film never  drags,  as a function of a fast-paced  plot and rapid-fire  dialogue. By  returning director Guy Ritchie to his street-level roots, the film  feels both  fresher and    more grounded than  the first, while also benefiting from a significantly larger  budget. 

The true star of the  show is Jared Harris, who manages to  make the villainous Blackwood one of the most compelling characters  in any recent action franchise. He is every  bit as smart as Holmes, and brings an unexpected depth to a character  that could have easily come across as a one-note villain. The scenes  between Harris  and Downey Jr. are  electrifying, and easily  the best sequences in the film.  

The supporting performances are also strong, with  Stephen  Fry memorable as Holmes's older brother, Mycroft. The   always-great Rachel McAdams is  unfortunately underused as Watson's wife, Mary, while Kelly Reilly manages  to make the most of  a  underwritten role as Watson's former love interest. 

The action sequences are remarkably well-done, with a  delightful mixture  of practical and computer-generated effects. A particular highlight  is a dizzying fight sequence inside a blazing building that feels  as  if it were  lifted straight from the  pages  of  the original Holmes  novels.  

In  a summer  dominated by  super-heroes and lighthearted fun, "Sherlock Holmes: A Game of  Shadows" is a  welcome addition to the action genre,  and a strong  successor to the first film.

The finale  of the "Harry Potter"  series is a  satisfying end to a decade-long journey. The film is packed with thrilling action and emotional moments as the  gang tries  to destroy the evil Horcruxes once and for all. Daniel Radcliffe, Emma Watson,  and Rupert Grint are all  excellent  in their final outing as Harry, Ron, and Hermione, and they are supported by a   strong cast including Alan  Rickman, Tom Hanks, and Helena Bonham Carter.  The film's visual effects and score  are also top-notch. Overall, "Harry Potter and  the Deathly Hallows:  Part 2" is a  fitting  end to one of the most popular film  franchises  of  all  time.

Without giving away   any spoilers, Jordan Peele has done it again. ''Us'' is another thought-provoking, suspenseful, and scary film from the mind of the  former  Key & Peele star.  Its success rests on the  strong  shoulders of its two leads, Lupita Nyong'o and Winston Duke, who manage to keep the audience engaged through a combination  of horror,  comedy,  and love. The twists and turns of the plot will keep  you on the  edge of  your  seat,  and the  film's message will stay with you long after  the credits  roll. A must-see for horror fans and anyone  looking for a thought-provoking night at the  movies.

Carefully  crafted visuals showcase an accurate portrayal of the events that took place on December 7, 1941. Despite a few historical inaccuracies, the film effectively conveys the shock, anger, and sadness that ensued  in the wake  of the attack. The portrayal of the three   main  characters, Rafe,  Danny, and  Sam,  offers a  relatable human  perspective to ground the audience and draw  them  into the events  of the   day. 

The film depicts the attack on Pearl Harbor through the  eyes of a  bystander,  a lover, and a friend.  It shows the  chaos and destruction of the event and the aftermath. The acting is  superb and the special  effects are top-notch. While the historical inaccuracies can  be distracting, the  film is a must-see for its emotional impact and its portrayal of a pivotal moment  in history.

dreaded drawings and insistently haunting music signaling that terrible things  are about   to happen woods stroll  transitioning  from  benign to bizarre no indication of what's  about to happen  except for the mounting terror filmmaker dutifully telegraphs when to be scared Tierney's portrayal effective even though it  mostly consists of running, screaming,  and crying minimally effective performances  around her  contractual appearance by ForsterDalton's villainy too understated to be  convincing convoluted plot no explanation provided for  the  town's  cursed existence key details of the  story   confusing  logic flaws throughout undermining the effectiveness of  the scares symbolism  and  style over substance  effectiveness of  the horror dissipates over time tedious ending no closure provided for the characters or  the story intensely frustrating film overall showing flashes of the creativity and terror that might have been

The movie starts  off with a  group of people trapped in a mall during a zombie  apocalypse.   They struggle to survive  and to escape  the mall. The movie  is  full of thrilling action and suspenseful moments. There  are also some  funny moments  throughout the movie. The acting was well done and  the plot was well written. This is a great movie for anyone who enjoys zombie  movies  or action-packed movies. Make sure to check this  one out if you haven't seen it already!

Watching South Park: Bigger, Longer & Uncut again after so many years since I first  saw it in the theater with my brother,  it's  held up as a classic satire of religion, organized religion,  and  commercialization of  the same. Filled with funny  gags throughout, though cartman and friends dabbling in adult activities doesn't feel as  revolutionary and groundbreaking as it once  was, with  Kinder Surprise being    swapped    out for TikTok and  also in the post-weinstein  era,  the portrayal  of  a  victimized mistress doesn't have the same bite, though there are still  many memorable moments and lines, Overall, the movie gets a lot right, and while maybe not as fresh and boundary-pushing as it once  was, it's still a  funny movie with a lot of heart  and a powerful anti-religious message.

The  Adventures of Tintin is a classic  movie based on the beloved comic book character Tintin. This film follows Tintin and his  loyal dog  Snowy  as they embark on a journey to find a priceless treasure. Along the  way, they encounter  a variety of colorful  characters, including the villainous Ivan Ivanovitch Sakharine. The movie is full of action and adventure, and it is sure to keep  viewers entertained from beginning  to end.  

The animation in The Adventures of Tintin is truly  impressive. The characters are brought to life  with a mix of traditional animation and computer-generated  imagery, creating a unique and  visually appealing style. The movie also features   a memorable score and a host  of catchy songs  that are sure to get stuck in  your head.

Overall, The  Adventures of Tintin is a fun and   exciting  movie that the  whole family can enjoy. It is a must-watch for fans   of  the comic book character, and  it is sure  to  become a classic  in its own  right.

This  film  is not  only one of  the  best movies ever made, but also one of the  most entertaining and enjoyable films I  have seen in   my life.  The story is  simple enough; Jack  Sparrow (Johnny  Depp)  has been  captured by the Spanish and taken to their island fortress on Tortuga. There he  meets Elizabeth Swann (Gwenyth Paltrow), who is a  member of the infamous Black  Pearl pirate crew. Together they must  fight against  the Spanish  forces that are trying to capture them.  This is a great adventure with some very funny moments. It is a shame that this film  was never released theatrically because it  would be an amazing addition to any collection.

I  am going to give this movie 4 out of 5 stars.

The  second film from the highly anticipated new horror anthology, "Room" is a thrilling psychological horror-thriller  that combines the best elements of John Carpenter's  work with David Fincher  and David Fincher's previous  film, 'The Social Network", to produce  a truly  disturbing and  suspenseful movie that will keep you  on the edge of your seat!

Synopsis: "Room"  is  an original thriller about a young journalist that takes  a seemingly innocuous meeting  with  a mysterious woman  (Isla Fisher), only   to find  herself in the deep end of a  psychological thriller. Her only hope to survive this  "room"  scenario? Escape the "room" before the "room" kills  you.

The Director: David Fincher — "The Social Network" & "Zodiac"

Based on the novel by  Michael C. Hall

This film is an action-packed, high octane, and  very  entertaining film that  will have  you cheering on your favorite characters as they fight to  save their lives. The story follows two brothers who are hired  by a  wealthy family to kill their father in  order to inherit  his fortune. They soon find  themselves fighting against a group  of   mercenaries led by a ruthless leader  named Ivan Reitman (Bruce Willis).  This film has some great action scenes with lots of explosions  and  gun fights. It also features some great  performances from Bruce Willis, Sylvester Stallone, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Jason Statham,  Jet Li, and many more. The cast  does a good job at making this film  feel like it's real life. There are  plenty of memorable   moments throughout the film that make  this one worth watching.

I'm not sure if I would recommend  this movie to anyone else  but I think it's definitely worth checking out. If you're looking for  something  different then check out my other  reviews here.

This is an  action film  that attempts to get you to   care  about a superhero's  origin story. It is a superhero  origin movie where one  of his  origin stories, if not the main story, is the most interesting one. It attempts to add a bit of emotion and  complexity to the villain of the piece, but then does not stick to it.  It makes the  movie feel  like it is treading water and then gets to where  it wants  to get. It tries to do  too many things at once and ends up not doing  enough of them.

This is a fun  little  movie but a bit confusing when  you   come to the end for the first  time.

This film was  made in 1994 and stars Tom Cruise as an astronaut who wakes up  on a  deserted Earth, where  he finds that his fellow astronauts have been killed by aliens. He  must now fight to survive against the alien invaders while trying   to find out  what happened  to  his wife and daughter. The  story follows the astronaut's journey through   space and time, with some  scenes  being shot in outer  space. This film has  a lot of action sequences, but it also has a good amount of humor. It  is not very long, so  you can  watch this movie in one  sitting. There are many different endings, which makes it hard to decide which  ending you should see.  Overall, I think this  is a great movie.

The Departed was  directed by Martin  Scorsese  with Leonardo DiCaprio starring. The film begins with a robbery at a jewelry  store and is told by a gang  member (DiCaprio) that this is the third robbery.  It continues to a bank in the middle of the  night  where  there is another robbery, although this  time the jewelry  store manager tries to stop the  robbers who   escape. The main protagonist, Jonah Hill plays a  bank teller named Nicky Parsons who at the  time, has a kid (Jared Leto) with  him. It  is assumed that Nicky has an alibi that night,  but  after a  week of  not getting close to him, he decides to find out whether he may the victim.

The  movie is about the lives of a group of people  when a bank  robbery happens. There is  a man named Martin Scorsese  (Jonah Hill)  who has left  the movie world and has to take care of his brother (Leonardo   DiCaprio) who is a  doctor in  the same hospital.  The main characters are also a woman who loves her husband and her son but  is  too tired to  talk to him, the husband  who loves but  can't  trust his wife, the son who is sick and  has a secret  he  keeps inside of him, and the bank manager (Jared Leto). The main  plot point is that if you  find the right person,  you may be able to catch the criminal in the  middle of  the film in  a  scene that is so dramatic  that it will make you want to stop and watch it until  the final minute when it actually  happens. It involves a lot of gambling too  that will leave you feeling  tired, but you need to find both the right person  and  the  right place.

The movie took 8 Oscar  Nomination for  its 10 nominations. It was nominated for  Best Picture,  Best Director, Best  Actor, Best  Supporting Actress (Jared Leto),  Best Original Screenplay  (Jared Leto) and Best Music (John Williams).  However the movie  was not nominated for Best  Film and Best Director.

What do YOU think the movie should've  been nominated for? Let us know  below in the comments.

If  you grew up watching baseball, you remember  the old  "ball of fury". This iconic scene happened when one of the teams was chasing an undefeated streak, and they reached the field at the bottom of a  long  hill. Everyone stood there, looking   up at that hill -  as if witnessing the grandest sporting event around. A man with giant balls of rubber on both sides, he  would  leap from one  side  of  the hill to the other like a madman. The whole  crowd would cheer him on - this man was so  amazing  he  could make  anything swing. He  was   unstoppable. The story goes that the first person to hit him got their hands broken, and another couple got  crushed. Eventually, the entire  team was able to get  on the ball  and knock the man down. But that was  not the end of him, he just  started  screaming, and the  game turned  into a wrestling match. The  ball of fury got  up with the whole team and began  stomping on everyone. The teams turned on each other until  the rubber  stopped moving. It  was quite an eye-opener, I remember it  fondly,  and I suspect  the same could  be said of  you. The second time you see it you may   get chills,  and the third time you may wonder if  you were actually feeling yourself.

When a strange anomaly happens on  the lunar surface, a space scientist, played by Russell Crowe, discovers a dead body and tries  to recover the body. It is now  up to a group of Russian scientists  played  by Alec Baldwin and Bradley  Cooper, an American astronaut,  played by Matt Damon, to find out what happend. A  film that uses many genre elements, including  a NASA-type mission with  some science thrown in, the main point seems to  be the survival of the Russian  astronauts.  It is still up  for debate how well this film will do over the long run because it  is based  on  a novel.

There are some pretty  cool concept pictures for  "Moon" on the IMDb  page. Here is a pic on the right  of a young child on the surface on a moon tree:

A picture for the moon on the left:

And here is  how  the moon  might look to a tourist:

I don't feel that  the film is too heavy handed on  the science. The  characters  are  believable and all the characters show some signs of actual character development. I can't see  this  having any real impact  on the film world. It  gives off  the feel of a  more light science fiction action film. That being said, I did  enjoy the book "All You Zombies" and  thought it was okay. And,  it's the   way it looks  and  has its  story that  I was most interested in watching it.

This is the story of an American general who fought on the North European front during  World War II  (his son wrote it about  his father and they  won an Oscar),  in which  he was nearly killed by  the enemy. It's also a satire of government corruption, military contractors, corporate control over media, corporate greed  and   the   national security state, all  the while revealing that the people you are paying  to do your dirty work  are most likely not as altruistic as you make them out to be – if any of  this seems implausible  to you then perhaps you may take another look at where  our tax dollars really  go.
