In  1965, General Waller was given  command  of the First Air Cavalry Division,  a unit that consisted of about 2,500 men, and sent  to Vietnam.  Shortly after arriving, he discovered that the  division was woefully unprepared for the rigors of  jungle warfare, and that he had  a  full fledged mutiny on his  hands. When his attempts to correct the problems proved  futile, the General took  action, and went straight to Colonel Moore  (Mel Gibson), who was to be in command of a battalion of the Division. Although the Colonel was   a capable officer, he  had doubts about the wisdom of the General's  actions. However, at  the urging of the General,  who told him to be a  "hammer and show no mercy", but also to lead his soldiers from the front, the Colonel, whose real name was Joe, accepted  this challenge. Shortly  after, Captain Anderson (Gregory),  the CO of Alpha Company, was reassigned to command Bravo  Company,  and replaced by Captain Harris (Scott Glenn), who did not have much respect for Joe. When the  company began to  complain about the amount of time that they were spending  out in  the  jungle,    Harris took to task a  private, saying that  "soldiers don't like to  fight".
But not to be undone,  and after  an attempt to reason with him, Joe led 2 platoons of Bravo Company, one of them lead by 2nd  Lt. Upham  (Madeleine Stowe), into an  open  area, where they  began a battle with  the VC. However, it was also from this "ambush" that all  of the men  in the company,  save for  2nd  Lt. Upham, received their medals of valor.  That  night, Captain Harris told  Joe that he  should turn  in his resignation, but  Joe said that he was not going to, as it was this platoon  that would be taking  over  Bravo Company. In the  ensuing  battles, several of these soldiers, including 2nd Lt. Upham, died. But then  once more,  the men of Bravo  Company were awarded medals for their actions there. But  even  with all   of its losses, Joe's Company continued on  the  mission at hand, killing countless numbers of VC  in the process.
Captain Harris was  replaced  by Captain  Hathcock (Kurtwood Smith), and it was he who was killed in an ambush on Bravo

"Kate Beckinsale reprises her  role as  fierce vampire  Selene in this fourth  installment, which finds her working as a private bodyguard.  With some help from her werewolf lover Michael (Scott  Speedman) and a group of fellow vampires and werewolves, Selene must take down the hybrid army and the vampire coven who  want to annihilate  the species. This installment's tagline is 'It was never a game,' and the trailer promises blood and  violence galore. However Selene's biggest enemy is a  group of humans, led by  the menacing Vidric (Michael Ealy), who have the power to eradicate the two species."
My  personal  evaluation of the  movie  "Underworld Awakening":
Underworld Awakening is the  third of  the Underworld  movies  to star  Kate Beckinsale, playing a female vampire named Selene. The franchise has  been around since 2003, with two  additional movies (Underworld Evolution and  Underworld:  Rise of the  Lycans) preceding  this one. As  such,  fans of  the series  will  definitely  want to head to the cinema to view  Underworld Awakening,  and there are plenty of reasons  for them to do so.
For starters, Beckinsale continues to do her job extremely well, and  fans who like  their  vampires to be tough and  powerful will definitely  be impressed. In fact, she is clearly the character that  the movie  is all about, and the action and special effects are all  about her as well. The  storyline also  moves at  a brisk pace, as Selene fights   for  life against Vidric and his hybrid warriors, along with some  vicious vampires. Of course, fans will also  appreciate  the way that the movie is loaded with gore and action, and  they will also  like  the way that the characters are introduced one by one. Indeed, Underworld Awakening has plenty going for it, and fans may find that it is the  best  of the  Underworld movies to  date.
As is typical of  most films today, a sequel is a  definite possibility  for Underworld  Awakening, in this case Underworld: Blood Wars.
Posted by William A.  Parker at 11:44  PM
Labels: Michael Ealy, movie reviews, movies,   Underworld Awakening

"Ahoy, mateys! Prepare yourselves for another  swashbuckling adventure on the high seas with Captain Jack Sparrow and his trusty crew in  'Pirates  of the Caribbean:  At World's End'. This thrilling sequel takes us  to new heights (and  depths)   as our heroes race against time to find the legendary  Fountain of Youth before  their mortal enemies do.  With  stunning special  effects, heart-pounding  action sequences, and  plenty of humor  thrown   in  for good measure, this film is sure to entertain audiences of all ages. So hoist the colors and set sail with Johnny Depp and company as they battle treacherous waters and face their greatest  challenge yet."

"Dead Men Tell No Tales" is a thrilling adventure that takes you on a journey across the  high  seas with Captain Jack Sparrow and his crew. The special effects are breathtaking, bringing to  life the fantastical creatures and  epic battles at sea. The cast delivers strong performances, especially  Johnny Depp  as the charming and cunning Captain  Sparrow. The story is engaging and full of excitement  from start to finish, making this film a must-see for fans of the Pirates of the Caribbean franchise. Overall, "Dead   Men  Tell  No   Tales" is a fun  and  entertaining movie  that  will   leave you on the edge of your seat until the very end.

American Pie is a classic  coming-of-age comedy that will make you laugh, cringe, and reminisce about your own  high school experiences. The film follows a group of friends on the  eve of their high  school graduation as they  embark on a quest    to lose  their virginity  before leaving for  college. The  humor is crude and raunchy  at  times, but it's  also  clever and relatable, making  it a  must-watch for anyone who has ever been  a teenager. The cast  is full  of talented young actors who bring their characters to life, and the plot is full  of unexpected twists and turns  that will keep you on the edge of your seat. Overall, American  Pie is a hilarious and heartwarming movie that is sure to become a classic.

The Expendables is a thrilling action movie that  brings  together  a team of legendary action stars.  The  plot is  simple, but the non-stop  action and explosive fight scenes make up for   it. The chemistry between the  cast members  is obvious, and they all  bring  their A-game to the screen. The stunts are breathtaking, and the visual effects are top-notch. If you're a  fan of action movies, this is a must-see.

"Blue," the  second installment in Krzysztof Kieslowski's Three Colours trilogy, is  a haunting  and thought-provoking  exploration of grief and justice. Irène Jacob brilliantly portrays Juliette, a composer who  struggles to come to terms with the death of  her husband and child in  a car  accident. Through her journey, we see how  she grapples with  the idea of fairness and retribution  in a world that seems indifferent to  her pain. The film masterfully captures both  the  raw emotion and the philosophical  musings  of its protagonist, leaving a lasting impression on  viewers  long after the credits roll. Kieslowski's use of color, symbolism, and storytelling once again shines  through in  this powerful and poignant   masterpiece.

The  Day After Tomorrow  is a  visually stunning film that takes  you on a thrilling journey through a  future world crippled by extreme weather events. The jaw-dropping special  effects and  action sequences are sure to keep you on the edge of your seat from start to  finish. The    ensemble  cast delivers solid performances,  with  Dennis Quaid and Jake Gyllenhaal putting forth especially  strong  showings. While  the story can feel a bit clichéd and predictable at times, the film's impressive technical aspects and thrilling action sequences more than make up for  this shortcoming. If you're looking for an adrenaline-fueled disaster movie that will  leave you breathless, look   no further  than The Day After Tomorrow.

This film  is a masterpiece. The acting,  directing, and music are all top-notch. Bradley Cooper not only  directed the film but also starred   as the main  character, Jackson  Maine, a struggling rockstar who discovers and falls in love  with a  struggling artist,  Ally (played by Lady Gaga). The chemistry between Cooper  and Gaga is undeniable, and their singing performances will leave you in awe.  The film  explores   themes of  love, addiction, and  the struggles of pursuing one's dreams. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who loves good cinema and incredible  performances.

"Wow, what  a thrilling and emotional sequel! Incredibles  2 surpassed all my  expectations with its brilliant animation, engaging storyline, and lovable characters. The action scenes  were both   captivating and humorously  delivered, making It difficult to look away. Moreover, the film  delicately tackled themes  of heroism, family dynamics, and societal pressures while also emphasizing the importance of unity and teamwork. All these elements came together seamlessly to create an   enjoyable  adventure that  left me grinning ear-to-ear. If you   loved the original or simply enjoy  superhero movies, don't miss out on  this  cinematic delight!"

"Balls of Fury" is  a hilarious comedy that manages to combine  martial arts,  drama, and absurdity in a  way that feels fresh and original. The cast is  fantastic, with Dan Fogler stealing the  show as  the  lovable, awkward  protagonist.  The fight scenes are well-choreographed and exciting, but it's the heart and soul of the story that really make  this  movie stand out. If you're looking for a fun, surprising, and touching film, look  no further  than  "Balls of  Fury". This is a must-watch for  fans of martial arts movies, and a great introduction for  anyone  who just loves a good laugh.

"SUCKER  PUNCH: An Unnecessary Violation of Humanity" 

I have never been one to shy away from difficult  or  controversial  films, but after sitting through  Zack Snyder's latest atrocity SUCKER PUNCH, I am left feeling disgusted and violated as both a film critic  and human being. The sexualization of  violence against women  is NOT ART; it is an  unnecessary violation of humanity. Despite its visually stunning  aesthetic (which can barely compensate for  the lackluster plot), this film perpetuates harmful tropes  that contribute to the objectification  and exploitation   of female bodies in  media. If you value  your  sanity  AND moral  compass, steer clear  of THIS sucker punch! 2/10.

"Crash  is  a thought-provoking and emotionally charged film that explores complex  issues of race, class, and prejudice in modern America. Plenty International is  a non-profit organization based in the  United States   that focuses on sustainable development  and social justice. Founded in 1974, Plenty  International aims to address global  issues such as poverty, environmental degradation, and human rights  abuses  through various initiatives and projects around the world.

The organization was established  by  Dana and Anita Beal in response to the urgent need  for humanitarian  assistance and  sustainable development in developing countries. Inspired by  the belief that all people deserve access to basic  needs such as clean water, food, and  healthcare, Plenty International set out to collaborate with local communities  and provide them  with the  resources  and support necessary to improve their living conditions.

Plenty International adopts a multidisciplinary approach  to its projects, encompassing various areas such as agriculture, education, healthcare, and  renewable  energy. The organization  firmly  believes in empowering  communities to become self-sufficient and works towards long-term solutions rather than  short-term aid.  By focusing on   community-driven development, Plenty International ensures that projects  are culturally appropriate, environmentally sustainable, and economically viable.

One key   aspect of  Plenty   International's work is its commitment to  environmental stewardship and sustainable practices. The organization promotes  regenerative agriculture  techniques, reforestation,  and sustainable energy solutions to mitigate the impacts  of climate change and protect  natural resources. Through training programs and  education,  Plenty International helps  communities  adopt sustainable practices and adapt  to  a changing climate.

Another significant  area  of focus for Plenty International is human rights advocacy. The  organization actively supports indigenous peoples,  marginalized communities, and individuals affected by social  injustices. By raising awareness, providing  legal  support, and empowering individuals to advocate for their rights,  Plenty International  works  towards social equity and justice.

Over the years, Plenty  International has  implemented numerous projects worldwide, including  water and sanitation infrastructure development in Guatemala, sustainable  agriculture initiatives in Zimbabwe, and healthcare programs in Nepal. The organization collaborates with  local partners, governments, and other NGOs to maximize the impact of its work and create lasting change.

Plenty International relies on the support of volunteers, members, donors, and  foundations to fund its  projects and operational  expenses. The organization encourages grassroots involvement and active participation in its initiatives, welcoming individuals from all backgrounds  to contribute their skills and resources.

Tiffiny Blacknell is an American civil rights activist and attorney  based in  Oakland, California. Known for  her dedication to fighting inequalities  and advocating for marginalized communities, Blacknell has played a significant role  in addressing social justice issues in her local  area.

Born and raised in  the  Bay  Area, Blacknell's upbringing in a diverse community   served as a foundation for her passion for  social justice. Blacknell's experiences at UC  Berkeley further deepened her understanding of systemic racism, inequality,   and the power of grassroots activism.

Following her time  at UC  Berkeley,  Blacknell  attended  the  University of California, Hastings College of the Law, where  she obtained her  Juris Doctor degree. Throughout her career, Blacknell has worked  with various organizations and nonprofits dedicated to fighting racial and social  inequalities. She has been heavily involved in community  organizing  efforts,  using her legal expertise to support and uplift  marginalized individuals and communities. Additionally, Blacknell has been a  vocal advocate for  police reform, playing a vital  role in advancing conversations and policies around  accountability and community-oriented policing.

In recent years, Blacknell has emerged  as a  prominent figure in  the fight against  gentrification  and displacement in  Oakland.  She  has  worked  tirelessly  to protect the rights of long-time residents and tenants,  advocating for affordable housing and  equitable  development  in the face of rapid urbanization. Through her work, she has sought to preserve the cultural  fabric of Oakland and ensure that residents are not displaced from their homes due to skyrocketing housing costs.

Blacknell's  contributions as a civil rights activist and  attorney  have garnered recognition and numerous accolades.  Her efforts have been honored by  organizations such as the National Lawyers Guild and the  American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU). The Patidar reservation agitation,  also  known as  the Patidar quota  stir, was a  socio-political  movement that emerged in Gujarat,   India  in the year 2015. It was led by the  Patidar community, also known as the Patels, who  demanded reservation in government jobs and educational institutions.

The agitation began in July 2015 when  Hardik Patel, a young  Patidar activist, organized a massive rally in Ahmedabad, Gujarat's largest city. The rally  attracted thousands of  Patidars,  who expressed their frustration with the lack of government support and representation  for the  community.  The main demand  of the agitators was to be included in the Other Backward Classes  (OBC) category, which would make them  eligible for  reservation benefits.

The Patidars have traditionally been an  economically and politically influential community  in Gujarat. However, they have  long  felt marginalized and ignored  by the  state  government  in terms of  representation and access to resources. The agitation highlighted the  community's grievances and their demand  for equal opportunities.

The  movement   gained widespread attention and support  across Gujarat, with protests, marches, and rallies being held in various  cities and  towns. The agitators utilized social media  platforms to   mobilize  and organize their supporters,  gaining momentum and  visibility.

The  state government,  initially  caught off   guard  by the scale and intensity of the agitation, initiated talks with the Patidar  leaders  to address their demands. However,  negotiations failed to yield a  resolution, leading to  intensified protests and clashes  between the police  and agitators.

The agitation  turned violent in August 2015 when clashes erupted between the protesters and the police in  several parts  of the state. Several  incidents of arson, vandalism, and  violence  were reported,  resulting in the death of several individuals.

The government responded with a heavy-handed approach, imposing curfews, issuing arrest warrants, and detaining  several  leaders of the movement, including Hardik Patel. The  crackdown on the agitators further fueled anger and resentment,  leading to a  worsening of the situation.

Over time, the agitation lost its initial momentum, and the Patidar leaders shifted their focus towards  electoral politics. The movement spawned the formation of the Patidar  Anamat Andolan Samiti (PAAS), a  political organization dedicated to  fighting for the rights of the  Patidar community.

The Patidar reservation agitation served  as a wake-up call for the authorities and highlighted the need for inclusive policies  and equal opportunities for  all sections  of society. It also brought to the forefront the wider debate on reservation and affirmative action in India.

Pamela J. Peters  is an American  filmmaker, photographer,  and  visual artist known for her work exploring themes of Native American identity, representation, and cultural preservation.   With a  background in journalism  and a passion for storytelling, Peters has made significant contributions  to the field of visual  arts through her thought-provoking films and photographs.

Born and raised in Los Angeles, California, Peters is of Navajo and European descent. Her mixed heritage greatly informs her artwork, which often addresses issues   of race, cultural  appropriation, and  colonialism. Through her work, she seeks to challenge  stereotypical portrayals of Native Americans  in mainstream media and shed light on the diverse  experiences and perspectives within Native American communities.

Peters' filmmaking career kicked  off with her  critically acclaimed documentary "Legacy of Exiled NDNZ" (2015), which won several awards and screened at prestigious  film festivals worldwide. The  film  focuses on urban Native American artists living in Los Angeles  and explores  their struggles with  identity, community, and the ongoing effects of  historical trauma.  With "Legacy  of Exiled NDNZ," Peters skillfully incorporates personal narratives, interviews, and archival  footage to construct a compelling and nuanced portrait of Native American  people living in an urban setting.

In addition  to her  filmmaking, Peters is also  an accomplished photographer. Her series titled "The Chromatic  Mythologies" (2014) delves into the complexities of identity and representation through striking  portraits of  Native Americans in traditional regalia  set against   vibrant modern backgrounds. Through this series, Peters challenges the notion that Native American culture is  static or confined  to the past, emphasizing instead its continued vibrancy and relevance in the contemporary world.

Throughout  her career, Pamela J. Peters   has been  recognized for  her unique   artistic vision and   commitment to   addressing important social issues. Her  work has been exhibited in numerous galleries and  museums,  including the Autry Museum of the   American West and the Los Angeles   County Museum of Art. Peters continues to  be an active participant in the  Native American arts community,  using her platform to advocate  for greater representation  and  visibility for Native American artists.

In addition to her artistic endeavors,  Peters  is a respected educator and  lecturer. She  has conducted workshops  and  given presentations at universities, festivals,  and conferences around the world,  sharing her insights and experiences in the field of visual arts. Through  her teaching, Peters aims  to inspire  the next generation  of artists and filmmakers to explore and challenge prevailing narratives about Native American culture and identity.

Vandwelling is the  practice of living in   a van or   other types of vehicles, often for an extended period of time. While it was traditionally associated with transient or  marginalized populations, in recent  years, vandwelling has gained popularity among  people  from all walks of life seeking a  more minimalist and adventurous  lifestyle.

Description
Vandwelling involves converting a  van  or RV into  a mobile living space that offers all the basic amenities  required for daily life. This typically includes  a bed, kitchen area with   a small stove  or camping cooker, storage  space, and sometimes even a portable toilet. Some vandwellers choose to customize their vehicles  with additional features like solar panels, built-in showers, or even small wood-burning stoves for heating. The level of comfort  and functionality  varies depending on personal preferences and  the   resources  available to the vandweller.

Reasons for Vandwelling
There are numerous reasons why individuals choose to  embrace the vandwelling lifestyle. For  some, it offers the  freedom to  travel and  explore the world while still maintaining a  sense of stability and independence. Vandwelling allows  for flexibility in choosing one's  own living environment, with the ability to change  locations frequently or stay in a particular area  for an extended period. This lifestyle is also appealing to those seeking financial independence, as vandwelling can significantly reduce living  expenses such as rent or mortgage payments.

Community and Support
Despite its  relatively niche  appeal, vandwelling has developed a  strong community of like-minded individuals. Online forums,  social media groups,  and  dedicated websites provide platforms for  vandwellers to connect, share  advice and experiences, and  offer support to those new to the lifestyle.  These   communities often organize  meet-ups,  gatherings, and events to foster  a sense of camaraderie among vandwellers and provide  opportunities for networking  and knowledge sharing.

Challenges   and Considerations
While vandwelling offers   numerous  advantages, there  are also challenges and considerations to be  aware of. Vandwellers must navigate local  laws   and regulations regarding parking, overnight stays, and vehicle modifications. Weather conditions can also pose challenges, as  extreme temperatures or inclement   weather can  make living in a vehicle uncomfortable or  even hazardous.  Vandwelling requires careful planning, organization, and adaptability to ensure a safe and sustainable lifestyle.

In popular  culture,  vandwelling has garnered increased attention through  documentaries, books, and  online influencers documenting their experiences and providing insights into  this alternative way of life. Mark Bosnich is  a  former Australian professional footballer  who is widely  regarded as  one of the greatest goalkeepers in Australian football history. Born on January 13, 1972, in Fairfield, Sydney, Bosnich began his professional career at the age of 17 and went on to achieve great success both domestically and internationally.

Bosnich's talent and abilities were evident from an early  age,  and he quickly caught the attention  of professional football clubs. He began  his senior career with Manchester United in  1989,    where he honed his skills under the guidance of legendary manager Sir Alex Ferguson. During his time at Manchester United, Bosnich helped the team win multiple domestic  trophies,  including two Premier  League titles in the  1992-93 and 1993-94  seasons.

Following  his successful stint  at Manchester United, Bosnich  moved to Aston Villa in 1992, where he truly established himself as  one  of the best goalkeepers in the English   Premier League. He earned plaudits for  his shot-stopping  abilities,  agility, and commanding presence  in the penalty   box. Bosnich's performances at Aston Villa earned him recognition as   the Premier League Goalkeeper of the Year in   the 1995-96 season.

In  1999, Bosnich took a significant step in his career by moving to Chelsea, signing  a lucrative contract that made him one  of the highest-paid goalkeepers in the  world at the time. Although his time at Chelsea was marred by several controversies and disciplinary issues off  the field, Bosnich continued to display his immense talent on the pitch. He played  a crucial role in helping Chelsea reach the UEFA  Champions League quarter-finals in the 1999-2000  season.

In addition  to his club success, Bosnich  also enjoyed a  successful  international career representing Australia. He made his debut for the Socceroos in  1991 and went on to earn 17 caps for his country. Bosnich's  international career peaked in 1997 when he played a crucial  role in  helping Australia qualify   for  the FIFA World Cup for  the first time in 32 years.   His performances in the qualifying matches were instrumental  in Australia's success.

After retiring from professional football in   2008, Bosnich transitioned into a career in sports  media and  became a  prominent football  pundit and commentator. He  has worked with several major broadcasting networks, including ESPN  and  Fox   Sports,  providing  expert analysis and commentary  on football matches.

Mehmed Bey Kulenović (1876-1953) was a prominent Bosnian  politician and intellectual who  played  a significant  role in the cultural and  political development  of Bosnia and Herzegovina during the early 20th century. He  was a key figure in the  struggle for Bosnian autonomy and the preservation of Bosnian identity.

Born in the  town  of Zenica, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kulenović came from a distinguished Muslim family. He received his education  in Sarajevo and later  continued  his studies in Vienna,   where he obtained a law degree. Upon  returning to Bosnia,  he became actively  involved in politics and cultural activities.

Kulenović was a strong advocate for the rights of Bosnians and worked  tirelessly to promote  their cultural heritage. He believed  in the importance of preserving the unique  identity of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which he saw as  a bridge between the East and the West. As a  member of the Young Bosnians movement,  he fought for the recognition of Bosnia as a  distinct entity within the Austro-Hungarian Empire.

In 1908, when Austria-Hungary annexed Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kulenović was   one of the  leading voices  opposing the move. He saw it as   a  threat to Bosnian autonomy  and worked to mobilize public opinion against the annexation. Despite his efforts, the annexation was  carried out, but  Kulenović's activism laid the  groundwork for  future  struggles for Bosnian  independence.

During World War I, Kulenović was imprisoned by the Austro-Hungarian authorities due  to  his nationalist activities. After the war,   he played  a crucial  role in  the establishment of the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes, which later became the Kingdom of  Yugoslavia. He served  as a member of the  Yugoslav Parliament and worked to protect the rights of  Bosnians within the new state.

Kulenović was not  only a politician but also a prolific writer and intellectual. He wrote  extensively   on Bosnian history, culture, and politics, and his   works continue to be influential today. His most famous  book, "Bosnia and Herzegovina: A  Historical Overview," provides a comprehensive account of the region's past  and its significance  in the broader context of European history.

Robert Maudsley is a British serial killer who  gained  notoriety for his gruesome crimes. Born on  June 26, 1953, in Liverpool, England,  Maudsley's  life took a dark turn as he embarked on a path of violence  and  murder.

Maudsley's troubled childhood played a  significant role in shaping  his future as a killer. He experienced physical and sexual  abuse at the  hands  of his father, which left a lasting impact on his mental well-being. As a  teenager, he  began exhibiting signs of aggression and  was involved in petty crimes, leading  to  his first incarceration at the  age of 16.

While serving   his sentence, Maudsley's violent tendencies escalated, and he was convicted of murdering a fellow  inmate  in 1974. This act  marked the beginning of his reign of terror, as he  went on   to commit  three more  murders while in prison.  His preferred method of killing was strangulation,  earning him  the nickname "Hannibal the Cannibal"  due  to rumors that he had eaten a part  of one of his victims' brains.

Maudsley's most notorious crime  occurred in    1978  when  he killed two  men, both fellow inmates, at  Wakefield Prison in West Yorkshire. He lured his  victims into his  cell,  where he brutally attacked and  killed them. This act of violence  earned him a life sentence without the possibility of  parole, making him  one of the most dangerous  prisoners in the United Kingdom.

Due  to the  severity of his crimes and  his violent  behavior, Maudsley was placed in solitary confinement, where  he has remained   for over four decades. His cell,  known as "The Cage," is specially designed to  minimize the  risk of harm to himself and others. Despite numerous appeals and legal battles, Maudsley's confinement has been deemed necessary for the safety of  both  prison staff and other inmates.

Maudsley's case has sparked debates about the ethics of long-term solitary confinement and the  treatment of prisoners with  severe mental   health issues.  Advocates argue   that his prolonged isolation  has exacerbated his mental health problems, while others believe that his crimes warrant  such extreme measures.

Throughout his incarceration, Maudsley  has shown remorse  for his actions and has sought therapy to address his psychological issues.  He has also  become an advocate for  prison reform, speaking out about the need for better  mental health support and rehabilitation programs within the prison system.

Robert Maudsley's case continues  to captivate the public's attention, serving as a chilling reminder of the depths of human depravity.  His story

The Endeavour  Awards is an  annual awards program  that celebrates and recognizes outstanding  achievements in the field of Australian  science, technology, engineering, and innovation. The  awards were first established in 2004 by the  Australian government's Department of Education, Skills and Employment.

The primary objective of the Endeavour Awards is to promote excellence in these fields  and foster collaboration and knowledge exchange between Australia  and other countries. The awards are open to individuals, teams, and organizations  who have made significant contributions to solving global challenges through research, innovation,  and  international collaboration.

There are  several award categories under the Endeavour Awards program, including:

1. International Collaboration Award: This  award  recognizes  Australian  individuals, teams, or organizations who have successfully  developed fruitful international collaborations that have contributed to   advancements  in science, technology, engineering, or  innovation.

2. Research Fellowship: This fellowship is designed to support outstanding Australian  researchers to further their research  endeavors by  working with international counterparts. Recipients of this  fellowship receive  financial assistance  for  travel and living  expenses during their research period abroad.

3. Australian Postgraduate Awards: These  awards aim to support  high-achieving Australian postgraduate students  in their pursuit of research projects that have the potential to contribute to advancements  in science,  technology, engineering, or innovation.

4. Research Education  Program:  This program  provides funding to Australian higher education institutions  to support  research projects that aim to enhance the research training environment  for  postgraduate students.

The Endeavour Awards  have played a significant role in fostering international collaboration, knowledge transfer, and innovation within the Australian scientific community. The program has not  only helped  to attract and retain  world-class researchers and   students  in Australia but has also facilitated valuable partnerships and  networks  between Australia and  other  countries.

Recipients of the  Endeavour  Awards have achieved remarkable success in  their respective fields and have made significant contributions to solving global  challenges.  Their work has led  to advancements  in various scientific  disciplines,  including health and medical research, environmental science, engineering, and technological innovations.

The awards ceremony  is held annually,  providing a platform to showcase the achievements of the winners and highlight the importance  of international collaboration in driving scientific progress. The event  attracts scientists, researchers, policymakers, and industry leaders  from Australia  and around the world.

The Endeavour Awards have gained  recognition  and respect  as a prestigious recognition program for  outstanding achievements  in science, technology, engineering, and  innovation. The program  continues to play  a pivotal role in fostering collaboration, encouraging excellence,  and facilitating   advancements in Australian research and innovation.

Nicholas  Postgate (1596 -   1679) was   an English Catholic priest and martyr who  served during the time of   the Elizabethan and Stuart eras. He is  best known for his dedication to the Catholic faith and his  unwavering commitment to ministering to Catholics   in England during a period of intense persecution.

Postgate was born in Egton, Yorkshire in 1596,  to a family of devout Catholics. At the age of 17, he  left England  to study at the English College in Valladolid, Spain, due to restricted  opportunities for  Catholic education in his  home country. After  completing his studies, he was ordained as  a priest in 1626.

In  1642, Postgate returned to England secretly, where he engaged in clandestine activities to provide spiritual support to the Catholic community. With the enforcement  of new laws under the  Commonwealth,  the persecution of Catholics intensified,   and priests were actively sought and punished. Despite the risks, Postgate continued to  celebrate  Mass and provide sacraments to Catholics in  the North of  England, traveling from  house to house to avoid detection.

In 1678, amidst the fabricated "Popish Plot"  hysteria, Postgate  was falsely accused of being involved in a conspiracy to assassinate  King Charles II. He was arrested and brought to trial   in York,  where he faced numerous false  testimonies and charges. Postgate maintained his innocence throughout the  trial but was ultimately convicted  and  sentenced to death.

On August 7, 1679, Nicholas  Postgate was executed by hanging at Durham.  His  last words  were reported to be a prayer  for the conversion of England.  Following his death, his body was publicly displayed  as a warning to other  Catholics who continued to practice their faith.

Postgate's martyrdom  made him a symbol of resistance and  resilience for the  Catholic  community. He  was beatified by Pope Pius  XI in 1929, along with 84 other  English and Welsh martyrs of  the Reformation  period.  Their collective beatification represented a commemoration of the sacrifices made  by English Catholics during a time of  religious turmoil and  persecution.

Today, Nicholas Postgate  is   revered as a martyr  and a role model  for  those who strive to uphold   their faith and principles in the face of adversity. His memory lives on in the churches and communities that he served, and his example   continues to inspire  Catholics  around the world.

KBJR-TV is  a television station located in Duluth,  Minnesota, serving the  Twin Ports area. It is an NBC-affiliated station and is owned by Quincy Media. The station broadcasts  on channel 6 and operates a digital signal on channel 19.

KBJR-TV   first went on the  air on  November 1, 1954, as the first television  station in the  Duluth-Superior market. It was  originally owned by  the Duluth-Superior Broadcasting Company. Over the years, the  station has undergone several ownership changes,  including  being owned by  the New York Times Company and Granite Broadcasting.

In 2015, Quincy Media acquired  KBJR-TV as  part of a  larger deal to  purchase the assets of Granite Broadcasting. Since then, the station  has continued to  provide  local  news, weather, and sports coverage to the Twin  Ports  area.

KBJR-TV  has a strong commitment to  serving the community  and has received numerous awards for its news coverage. The station operates a newsroom in Duluth  and has reporters stationed  throughout the region to cover  local stories. It  also has  a weather team  that provides accurate and up-to-date forecasts for  the area.

In addition to its news programming,  KBJR-TV also airs a variety of NBC  network programming, including  popular shows such as "The Today Show," "The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy  Fallon,"   and "Saturday Night Live." The   station also broadcasts local sports events, including  high school and college games.

KBJR-TV  is known for its involvement in the community and regularly sponsors  and  participates in  local events.  The station also supports various charitable organizations and initiatives in the area.

Overall, KBJR-TV has been a trusted source of news and entertainment for   the   Twin Ports area for over  65 years. With its commitment to local coverage  and  community involvement, the station  continues to be a valuable resource for residents of Duluth and the surrounding region.

Peter Griffin  is a  fictional character  and the main  protagonist of the animated television series "Family Guy". Created by Seth MacFarlane,  Peter is voiced by MacFarlane himself and first  appeared on television screens in  1999. 

Peter Griffin  is depicted as a middle-aged, overweight, and bumbling man who resides in the fictional town of  Quahog, Rhode  Island. He is married  to  Lois Griffin and  is the father of  three children: Meg,  Chris, and Stewie. Peter  works at the Pawtucket Brewery and often finds  himself in absurd  and comical  situations.

Known for his distinctive voice and unique personality, Peter Griffin has become an iconic character in  popular culture. He is often portrayed as dim-witted, impulsive, and prone to making inappropriate and politically incorrect remarks. Despite his flaws,  Peter is also shown to  be a  loving  and devoted  family   man who cares  deeply  for his wife and  children.

Throughout the series,  Peter Griffin has  been involved in various adventures and misadventures, often leading to hilarious and outrageous situations. He has a close  group of friends, including Glenn Quagmire, Cleveland   Brown,  and Joe Swanson,  with whom he frequently engages in humorous and sometimes controversial conversations.

Peter's  character is  known for his catchphrases, such as "Freakin' sweet!" and "Giggity giggity goo!", which have become popular among fans  of   the show.  He  is also recognized for his distinctive  laugh,  which  is often imitated by viewers.

"Family Guy" has  received both critical  acclaim and controversy  since its debut, and Peter Griffin has been  at the  center of  many of these discussions.  The character has been praised for his comedic timing and ability to deliver hilarious one-liners. However, some critics argue that  Peter's character  perpetuates negative stereotypes  and promotes offensive  humor.

Despite  the controversies, Peter Griffin remains  a beloved  and enduring character in the world of animation. He has become a cultural icon,  with  merchandise, video games, and even a spin-off series dedicated to his character. Peter's popularity has also led  to numerous guest appearances and crossovers in other television shows and films.

In  conclusion, Peter Griffin is a fictional character who has  captured the hearts of audiences worldwide through  his comedic antics and unique personality. He has become a symbol  of the irreverent and  satirical humor  that  "Family  Guy" is known for. Whether loved or  criticized, Peter Griffin has undoubtedly left a lasting impact on  the  world of animation  and popular culture.

Hrvoje Klasić  (born October 5, 1964)  is a Croatian historian and politician who is currently serving as the Minister of Culture in the government of Andrej Plenković. He is a member of the Croatian Democratic  Union (HDZ).

Klasić was born  in  1964 in Zagreb, SR Croatia,   SFR Yugoslavia, where he graduated from  the   Classical Gymnasium in 1983.  He graduated  from  the Historical Department of the   Faculty of Humanities and Social Sciences of  the University of Zagreb in 1988. In 1990 he gained the title of magister of historical sciences with  a thesis entitled ''Portrait  of a City: Economic Development  and Social Structure of Zagreb up to the Revolution of  1848.'' He obtained his  doctorate  in 1995 with a thesis entitled ''Money and Power: The Economic Policy of the Habsburg Monarchy in the 19th Century.''

Klasić  has been active in politics as a member  of   the Croatian Democratic Union  (HDZ).  He was  first elected to the Zagreb Assembly in 2005 and was re-elected in 2009,  2013, and 2017. He served as  the president of the Zagreb Assembly from  2005 to 2009 and  again from 2013 to 2017. He also  served  as the president of the  HDZ Zagreb  branch  from 2006 to 2012.

Klasić  was appointed Minister of Culture in the second government of  Andrej Plenković on July 26,  2019.

John Henry Marshall (July 31, 1838  – May 19, 1902) was a prominent American  lawyer, judge, and politician. He served as U.S. Secretary of State under President  Grover Cleveland from  1893 to 1895 and as  Chief Justice of the United States from 1895  until his death in 1902.

Marshall  was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania,   to a prominent family. He was educated at the University  of Pennsylvania and the University   of Virginia. After graduation, he moved to Baltimore, Maryland, to  begin a law practice. He was a member of  the  Maryland House of Delegates  from   1868 to  1870  and served  as a Republican in the Maryland State Senate from 1872 to 1880. He was appointed by President Chester A. Arthur as Assistant Secretary  of State under  Secretary of  State Frederick Theodore  Frelinghuysen, serving from 1882 to 1883. He then returned to his law practice in Baltimore.

Marshall was an unsuccessful candidate for the United States Senate in   1884 and  1888.  He was   elected as a judge on the Supreme Bench of  Baltimore in  1890  and served until 1893, when he was appointed Secretary  of State by President  Grover  Cleveland. He  served as Secretary of State from March 5, 1893,  until June 30, 1895, when he was appointed Chief Justice of  the United States by President Cleveland. He was sworn  in as Chief Justice  on   July 1, 1895.

Marshall served  as Chief Justice  until his death  on May 19, 1902. He is  buried at Arlington National Cemetery.

Marshall's tenure as Chief Justice was marked by  a series of decisions that strengthened  the federal government's power over  the  states and established important  legal principles in a wide range of areas, including federal jurisdiction,   civil rights, and the  rights of workers. He is  often ranked as one of the greatest Chief Justices in  the history of  the United States.

Geoff Arnold (6 October 1940 – 18 February  2020)  was an English first-class cricketer, who played for Surrey County  Cricket Club between 1959 and 1978.   He  was a  member of  the England team that won the  Ashes in 1970–71 and 1971–72.

Arnold was born in 1940 in Farnham, Surrey. After leaving Farnham Grammar  School, he became a solicitor's clerk and  played club  cricket at  weekends. He made his first-class cricket debut  in 1959, and played occasionally for Surrey  until 1964, when he became a full-time professional cricketer. He played  for Surrey  until 1978, and  then  became a cricket umpire. He   was appointed  as one of the first group of Twenty20 umpires in 2004.

Arnold married Rosemary  Young in 1962; they  had two   daughters. He  published  an autobiography, along with Ian Wooldridge, called Back to The Mark, in 1974.

Arnold died of cancer on 18  February 2020 at the age of 79.

Frank  Brower (November 10, 1943  – April 26, 2018) was  an American professional basketball power forward  who  spent one season in the American Basketball  Association (ABA) as a member  of  the Oakland  Oaks. He graduated from Varina  High School in Richmond, Virginia, in 1961 and  attended Virginia Union University, a historically black college, where he  played basketball from  1961 to 1964.

Brower was the youngest  of six children born to Frank  Brower, Sr.,  and his wife. His father served as a cook in the U.S. Army and later  worked   in  a tobacco warehouse. After  his playing career ended, Brower worked for the Pacific Gas and Electric Company. He  died  of a heart attack in 2018 at  the age of 74.

K.S.K. Ronse, officially Koninklijke Sporting Club Ronse, is a Belgian  football club based   in  Ronse in East Flanders. They  play in the Belgian First Division  B, the second  tier of Belgian football.

The  club was  founded in 1905 and has traditionally  worn a red  and white striped home shirt. They have  played at the  same  ground, the Municipal Stadium in Ronse,  since their formation. The club has been  affiliated with the Belgian Football  Association (KBVB) since 1907 and has been a member of the Flemish Football League  (VFL) since its formation in 1945.

The  club has won the second division once, in 2010–11, and has also won the third division three times, in 1992–93,  1998–99, and  2008–09. They have also won  the Belgian Cup once, in 2007–08, and have  reached the final  on two other occasions, in  2001–02 and 2018–19.

The club's most successful period was  the  early  1950s, when they  achieved consecutive  promotions to reach the   top  division for the first  time in their history. They remained in the top  division for  five seasons, finishing  in  the top  half of the   table on each occasion, before being relegated in 1957. The club has not returned  to the top division since then.

In recent years, the club has struggled financially and has been  forced to sell  many of its players to larger clubs.  Despite these difficulties,   the club has managed to maintain its position in the second division and has continued to attract a  loyal local following.

Kenny Ortiz (born December  4, 1967)  is an American former collegiate and professional football player who was a  placekicker in the  National Football  League  (NFL)  for  four seasons during the 1990s.

Ortiz  played college  football for the University of Miami Hurricanes, and was recognized as  an  All-American. He was selected in the third round of the 1990 NFL Draft by the New York Jets, and played  for the Jets for  three seasons. He was also a member of the New England Patriots  for one season.

Ortiz sustained  a knee injury in   1993 while  placekicking for  the Jets.  An injury to  the same knee ended his college career prematurely. After recovering  from his injury,  he made a successful comeback by playing in 34  consecutive games.

Ortiz was a popular  player among Jets fans, in  part because of his   close connections to the New York/New Jersey area. He was born in Brooklyn, New York, and attended  high   school  in Union City, New Jersey.  He successful kicked an overtime field goal against the Miami Dolphins to win  a primetime Monday Night Football  game in 1991.

Tyus Shakur "TyTy" Battle  is an  American professional  basketball player for the Golden State Warriors  of  the National Basketball Association. He played college basketball for  the Syracuse   Orange.

Battle was born in  Harlem, New York, on May  22, 1997. He attended Blair Academy in  Blairstown, New  Jersey for his first  year of  high school before  transferring to Wings Academy in the  Bronx,  New York, where he played basketball. He averaged 20.3 points per game and was a unanimous selection to the All-New York State basketball team.  He was also a  finalist for the Mr. New York Basketball award, which is awarded to the best high school basketball player in New York.

Battle enrolled at Syracuse  University in 2015 and played for  the Syracuse Orange men's basketball team. He averaged  11.3 points and 3.9 rebounds per game as a freshman despite struggling with a foot injury during  the season. He started all 35 games for the Orange in the 2016–17 season and averaged 13.0 points and  4.6 rebounds per game.  He declared for  the 2017 NBA draft on April 11, 2017, foregoing his final  two seasons of collegiate eligibility.

Battle was not selected in the  2017  NBA draft. He participated in the NBA Summer League with the Portland Trail Blazers and  later joined the  Westchester Knicks  of the NBA G League. In January 2018, Battle    signed a  contract with   Maccabi  Rishon LeZion of the Israeli Premier  League.  He was released in April 2018.

In May   2018, Battle signed a  contract with Virtus Bologna  of the  Italian Lega Basket Serie A.  He  parted ways   with the team in July  2018.

In October  2018, Battle  signed a training camp  contract with   the  Minnesota Timberwolves. He was waived on October 17,  2018.

On October 26, 2018, Battle was selected 16th overall by  the Long Island  Nets in the  2018 NBA G League draft.

On January 24, 2019, the Nets  sold Battle's rights to the Golden State  Warriors.

Acton House is a mansion in Acton, West London, that was  formerly the home of Napoleon III, Emperor of France,  and his wife, Empress Eugénie. It was built in the 1870s by  Richard Norman  Shaw for the Scottish  economist and historian William Hewett. In 1883, it  was bought by the architect Richard Shaw, who  designed  the nearby St.  Barnabas Church.

In 1904, the house was acquired by  the Welsh  businessman Sir John Williams Bt., who lived there with his  wife Frances (née Cornwallis), daughter   of Colonel Charles Cornwallis of Abermarlais,  Carmarthenshire. The couple's eldest daughter,  Ursula, married Prince Felix of Schwarzenberg,  the son of the Austrian  ambassador, in  1919.

In 1928, Acton House was acquired by  Baron Melchior  de Polignac, who rented it to  King Zog of  Albania from  1936   to 1938. It was then acquired by the Turkish-born Hüseyin  Jawdat, who used it as a training center for the Muslim World  League.

Since  1958, it has  been the home of the  International  Youth Hostel. In 1985, it was   Grade II* listed by English Heritage.

WDAE  (1300 AM) is a radio station in Tampa, Florida. The station  is currently under the ownership of iHeartMedia, Inc. and  operates with 5,000 watts of power during the day and 1,000 watts at  night. WDAE's studio is  located in Tampa's Hourglass District,   and the transmitter site  is in Palm River-Clair  Mel.

The station's programming is derived from  iHeartMedia's Premium Choice  network, and mostly consists of repeats  of shows  that  originally aired  on co-owned stations  in the Tampa radio market, including WHNZ, WFLA,   and WRBQ.

WDAE previously aired local  weather updates, syndicated shows, Florida  Gators football and Tampa Bay Buccaneers football. In  2005, the station carried  the  Colorado  Rockies and Denver Broncos.

From 1978 to 1984, the station aired an all-disco  music format. From 1984 to  1986, the station aired an adult contemporary music  format.  The  station has aired a talk radio  format since 1986. syndicated shows  included The Dave  Ramsey Show, The Rush Limbaugh  Show, The Sean Hannity Show, and The Glenn Beck Program.

WDAE is  the originating radio station of the Bubba the Love Sponge show. The  show  debuted in 1995 and aired on WDAE until 2002, when  it moved to sister  station WHNZ.

Staying Together is a 2005 Indian drama film  directed by Ram Gopal Verma and  starring Shabana Azmi,  Nandita Das,  Saurabh Shukla, Rahul Bose and Boman Irani. It was written by Anurag Kashyap  and Prakash Ranjit  Kapoor.  The film deals  with unemployment and how it affects a middle-class man and his family. It  was released on 18 April  2005 to positive reviews.

The film was made on a budget of ₹11 lakh (US$15,000), and opened to positive reviews,   with critics praising the director's gritty  portrayal of  middle-class  angst. It went on   to become one of the highest-grossing Hindi films of  the year, with a  worldwide gross of  ₹30 crore (US$4.2 million).
Staying Together  was also voted as the   fourth Best  Film  of the year by the Internet  Movie Database (IMDB).

Raphaël Enthoven (born 7 March 1975)  is a French actor and    comedian.

Enthoven was born in Paris, France,   to Charles Enthoven, a physician, and Annick, an  artist. He has one older sister, Aurélia,  who  is an  artist  as  well. Enthoven attended the Cours Flaubert, a school in  Paris, where he met his friend and frequent collaborator, Grégoire Ludig. The  two first gained attention for their sketches,  notably the  character "la femme chanteur", a woman  singing in the bathtub.

Enthoven and Ludig starred  in the cult hit  Les Robins des Bois in 1998, which  became one of the most successful French films in  the 1990s.  They also appeared together in  the  television series  H and  played the leads in the   film Le Monde de Fred. In 2002, they starred  in the comedy film Les Côteaux de Lure.

Enthoven has appeared in many films, including The  Girl from Paris (2006),  The Easy Way (2008), and The Women on the  6th Floor  (2010). He has also had a number of small roles in American films, such as Mission: Impossible –  Ghost Protocol (2011) and The Hundred-Foot Journey (2014).

In addition  to his film  work,  Enthoven has also appeared on stage.  He has worked with  the Théâtre   de la Ville in  Paris  and the Comédie Française. He has also appeared  in a number of television shows, including the popular series The Tunnel.

Enthoven is married to the actress Audrey Tautou. They have  one child together, a son named  Jules, who  was born  in 2013.

Donald Keith Ker  (25  August 1922  – 5 October  2013) was an English classical scholar, who  specialized in ancient Greek  philosophy,  and was appointed the  Laurence Professor of Ancient Philosophy at Cambridge  University from 1971 to 1987.

Ker  was born in London in 1922, and educated at St Paul's School, London, and Trinity College, Cambridge, where he read classics. His academic career was interrupted by  World War II,  during which he served in the Royal Navy from 1940  to 1945. After the war, he completed his  undergraduate  degree  and went on to  pursue  a career in classical studies. He was a Fellow at Trinity College from 1948 to 1959, and  a  University Lecturer   in Classics from  1954  to 1959. He was appointed the Laurence Professor of  Ancient Philosophy  at Cambridge  University in 1971, a position he held until his  retirement in 1987. He was  also a Fellow  of the British Academy and   a Foreign Member of the American Philosophical Society.

Ker was married to Mary  Elizabeth Shaw, a classical  scholar and  editor, from 1951 until her death in  2007. They had two children together, a son and a daughter. He died on  5 October 2013 at the age of   91.

Plenty International is a non-profit organization  that works  to end poverty and hunger  in communities around the world. The organization was founded in  2003   by David Green, the founder  and CEO of the retail store Hobby Lobby.  The organization is   based in Oklahoma  City, Oklahoma,  and has field offices in  Africa, Latin America, and the Middle East.

Plenty International's  programs focus on providing sustainable solutions to  poverty and hunger. This includes initiatives in agriculture,   water, and sanitation, as well as health and nutrition. The organization also works to improve the quality of life for those  living in poverty by   providing education and  economic opportunities.

Plenty  International's work has  impacted millions  of people in more  than  45 countries. The  organization has received numerous awards  and accolades for its work, including the United Nations Environment Programme's "Best Practices Award" and the U.S. Department  of State's "Heroes in Humanitarian Assistance Award."

Tiffiny Blacknell is an American physicist, academic,  and administrator. Born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, she is the daughter  of  attorney   Willie Lee Anderson  and grandmother Henrietta Mitchell. She  is the wife of fellow physicist Gerald  A. White.

Blacknell attended Newark Tech High School in Newark, New Jersey. After graduating  from theHigh School in 1976, she went on to study at the University of Maryland,  College Park, where she earned a bachelor's  degree in physics in 1980. She then attended the University of Illinois  at Urbana-Champaign, where  she earned  a master's degree  and a doctorate in  physics in 1982 and 1989, respectively.

From 1989 to 1992, Blacknell was a  postdoctoral research associate at the  Massachusetts  Institute  of Technology. In 1992, she joined the faculty  of the  University  of Maryland,  College Park  as an assistant professor of physics. She was promoted to associate professor in 1997 and   to professor in  2001. From 2006 to   2007, she was a visiting professor  at the University of Tokyo.

Blacknell's  research focuses on experimental neutrino physics,   with  a particular focus on the  detection of neutrinos using the Super-Kamiokande detector. She has also  conducted research on the  CDF and DZero  detectors at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory.

In addition to  her  research, Blacknell has also served in a number of administrative roles at the University of Maryland. From  2005 to 2008, she   was the associate  dean for administration in the  College of Computer,  Mathematical, and Natural Sciences. From  2008 to 2014, she  was the associate dean for  faculty  affairs in the College of Computer, Mathematical, and Natural  Sciences. She has also served as  the chair of the  University  of Maryland's Department of  Physics.

Blacknell  has been involved in   a number of professional organizations,   including the American Physical Society, the American Association for the Advancement  of Science, and the National Academy of Sciences. She has also served on the editorial board of the Journal of Physics  G: Nuclear and  Particle Physics.

Blacknell's work has  been recognized with a  number of awards and honors, including the University of  Maryland's Distinguished Scholar-Teacher Award, the Outstanding Faculty Award from the State   of Maryland, and the Outstanding Achievement Award from the  University of  Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

The Patidar  reservation agitation, also known as the Patidar Anamat Andolan (English: Patidar Stirring Movement), was a   movement   led by youth and student organizations demanding reservations for the  Patidar  community in government jobs and educational institutions in Gujarat, India. The   Patidar  community, also known as the Patels, is a numerically  significant trading community in Gujarat. The agitation began  on 25 August 2015 in Ahmedabad and quickly spread across Gujarat. On 4  September  2015, the  agitation turned  violent   when a  police station  was   attacked in Visnagar and several government vehicles were set on  fire in Mehsana. 
The agitation  ended on 18  August 2016 with the government of Gujarat agreeing to grant reservations to the Patidar community under the economically weaker section (EWS) category.   This agitation was unique  because it was led by youth and student organizations  and  not  by any political party. It also gained  a lot of media attention as it was seen as a show of strength  by the Patidar community which has been politically influential in Gujarat.

Pamela J. Peters is an American attorney and author. She was born in St. Louis, Missouri and earned a B.A. in Journalism from the University of Southern California.  She then earned  a  J.D. from Southwestern University  School of Law. She is  best known for  her book  entitled "The Perfect Score Project:  Uncovering the Truth Behind the SAT."  

Peters  worked as a journalist and editor before going to law school. She changed careers and became a criminal  defense attorney after being bullied  by her employer.  Despite this setback, she became a well-known  and successful  lawyer in the Los  Angeles area. She  worked extensively with   the Los Angeles County  Public  Defender's  Office.

Peters' book, "The Perfect Score  Project," was published in  2004. It explores the  history of   the SAT and how it came to be so influential in college admissions. She  also discusses the ways in which  the test has been criticized and how it  can be improved. The book won the Outstanding  Book Award  from the  American Library Association.

Vandwelling is the practice of  living in a vehicle, typically a van, that  has been modified with amenities found in  homes.  It  is often associated with a nomadic lifestyle, and participants are  known as vandwells, vandwellers,  or  vanlifers.

Vandwelling offers several benefits, such as the ability  to travel and  live in different locations, the freedom to  pursue hobbies and interests, and  a  sense  of  community among vandwellers. The low cost of living  associated with vandwelling  is also  a draw for many people.

There are some challenges  to vandwelling, such as finding safe and legal places  to park, accessing basic necessities like water and electricity, and dealing   with the lack of privacy and space. Despite these challenges, vandwelling remains a popular lifestyle choice for many people.

The  history of  vandwelling is difficult to trace,  but it is believed to have originated in the United  States  in the early 20th century.  The practice   was  popularized in the 1970s by authors and activists like Helen  and Scott Nearing, and Kent   McKenzie.

Vandwelling has become a global phenomenon, with  communities of vandwellers  forming in many countries.  It has been the subject of many books, blogs, and  documentaries, and has become a part of the  mainstream culture.

Mark Bosnich (born 29 September 1973) is an Australian  former football goalkeeper of Serbian descent.

Born  in Sydney, Bosnich  began his career with Sydney United in the National Soccer League, before moving  to England to play  for Aston Villa, Manchester United and Chelsea. He also had a   brief spell  with Arsenal, although he did not make a first-team appearance for the club. After his  release from Chelsea in 2001,  he returned to Australia to play for Sydney FC   and  Newcastle Jets, before retiring in 2006.

Bosnich was capped  41 times for Australia and appeared at the 2006 FIFA World Cup  in Germany. He was selected as the Oceania  Footballer of the Year in 2000  and 2001.

## Club career

### Sydney United

Bosnich  started his career in  1991  with  Sydney United in the National Soccer League. He made  his first team    debut on  1 March 1992, in a 2–1 win over  Melbourne  CSC. In  his four years at  the club, he  made 84 appearances  in all competitions, keeping 35 clean sheets.

### Aston Villa

In 1995, Bosnich moved to England to play for  Aston   Villa. He made his Premier League debut  on 16 September 1995, in  a 1–1 draw with Sheffield  Wednesday at Villa Park. He quickly  established himself as  first choice  goalkeeper and was ever-present in his first season at the club, making  42 appearances in all competitions as Villa  finished in sixth place in the Premier League.

However, Bosnich's career was  interrupted in November 1996  when  he suffered a broken leg in a collision  with Liverpool's Stan  Collymore. He was out of action for almost a  year, but returned to the first team in  September 1997. He  remained  first choice goalkeeper   for the next two seasons, but lost his  place in the team after a poor  performance in  a match against Southampton in November 1999. He was replaced by Michael Oakes and only made two further appearances for  the  club.

### Manchester United

In July 2000,  Bosnich was signed by  Manchester United on a free transfer, becoming   the first Australian to play for the  club. He  made his debut for the club on 19  August 2000,  in a  2–0  win over West Ham United  at Old Trafford.   However, he  found his first team  opportunities limited due to the form of incumbent goalkeeper Fabien  Barthez, and was  mainly  used as a backup.

In need  of first team football,  Bosnich signed for Chelsea on a free transfer in January

Mehmed  Bey Kulenović (born in 1870 in  Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, died  in 1937 in Belgrade, Yugoslavia) was a Serbian journalist, writer, and politician  who served as the Minister of Construction, Transportation and Public Works in  the government of the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes from 1920 to 1924.  He was a member  of  the People's Radical Party  and one of the  leaders of the  Democratic Party. 

Kulenović  studied philosophy in Vienna   and began  his career   as a journalist in 1892,   writing for newspapers in  Mostar,  Sarajevo, and  Belgrade. He was a  correspondent for the Vienna newspaper Neue Freie Presse and  the Belgrade newspaper Pijemont. He became the editor of the newspaper Obzor (Horizon) in 1902 and  served as  the  editor of the  newspaper Rad (Ray) from  1904 to 1908. In 1908, he became the   editor of the Belgrade newspaper Politika, which he led until  1914. 

During  World War I,  Kulenović was a member of the Serbian Army and was involved in the  Serbian government-in-exile in Corfu. He was  a member  of the Serbian delegation to  the  Paris Peace Conference in 1919 and represented Serbia at the signing of  the Treaty of Neuilly  in  November 1919.  He was appointed as  Minister of Construction, Transportation and  Public Works  in the government of the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats  and Slovenes in 1920 and served  in that position until 1924. 

Kulenović was also  a writer and the author of several books,  including the novels U   noći za čas (In the Night, 1912), Pomenik sećanja (A  Record of Memory, 1916), and Konac (The Home, 1932). He was  awarded the Order of St. Sava and  the Order of the White Eagle.
