Robert Maudsley (7 April  1830 – 25  September 1895) was an English businessman and politician.  He was born in Hull, the son of  Benjamin Maudsley,  a merchant, and his wife Anne,  daughter of  Matthew Smith.

Maudsley was educated at Hull Grammar School and at   the age  of  fourteen was sent to  work  in his father's office. He was later employed by the North Eastern Railway Company and   by the London and North  Western Railway Company. In 1867  he became  a director of the latter company and in 1876  was appointed   its chairman,  a position he held until his death.

Maudsley was also  a director of the Bank  of England and  of the Great Western Railway.  He was a  member of the London  School Board from  1870  to 1873 and a member  of the Council of the University of  London  from 1877 to 1880.  He was  a Justice of the Peace for Middlesex and for the County of London.

In 1880, Maudsley  was elected  a Member of Parliament for the borough of Acton. He was a Liberal and a strong supporter of William  Ewart Gladstone. He held his  seat until 1895,  when he was defeated by a representative of the Conservative party.

Maudsley died  in London on 25 September 1895.

The Endeavour Awards are annual awards that recognize  the achievements of British  Columbians in the technology sector. The awards are  open to both individuals and companies, and are divided into several categories, including Innovation, Leadership, and Company of the Year.

The Innovation Award is  given   to a person or company that has made  a   significant contribution  to the  technology industry through  the development of a  new product or service. The Leadership Award  is given to  a person  who has demonstrated exceptional  leadership  in the technology  sector, while the Company of the Year  Award is given to a company  that has consistently demonstrated excellence   in the technology industry.

The Endeavour  Awards are presented  at a ceremony held in Vancouver,  British Columbia. The ceremony  is attended by prominent members of the technology industry, as well  as government officials and other prominent figures. The awards are covered  by local and national  media,  and are widely recognized as a mark of excellence in  the technology sector.

Nicholas Postgate (16 August 1925  – 5  November 2019) was an English Catholic priest  and whistleblower.

Postgate was born in  London, the eldest  son of the  Protestant theologian Graham Leonard  Postgate and his wife Gwen, daughter of  Sir Francis John Davis. His grandfather   was  the vegetarian activist John  Postgate and his great-grandfather was the chemist  Edward Postgate. He had two brothers, Edward  and Raymond, and a sister,  Sylvia. All three of his  siblings  became Catholics. He became a convert to Catholicism at the age of 18, against the wishes of  his father.

In 1943, during  the Second World War, Postgate volunteered  for   the  RAF but was disqualified for  being underweight. He then  volunteered for the Navy  and was assigned to the naval air branch as a mechanic, where he rose to the rank of petty  officer.

After the war  ended, Postgate entered the seminary  at lupus College,   Oxford, to train for the Catholic  priesthood. He was ordained  a priest in 1953.   He served as a curate  at St  Mary's Church, Hurst  Green, and as a teacher at Douai School, a Catholic public school in Woolhampton, Berkshire. In 1964, he became head of  the religious studies department at St  Albans School, a Catholic public school  in Hertfordshire. He remained in that position for the next 19 years.

In 1983, Postgate alleged that  a number  of Roman  Catholic priests in the diocese of Arundel and Brighton had sexually  abused children. This was the first  time that  a member of the Catholic clergy in England had made such an allegation. He also alleged that  Bishop Derek Worlock had covered up the abuse. Worlock refused to comment on the allegations. Postgate was interviewed about  his allegations  on  the Channel 4 News  programme Confidential. A few days after the broadcast, Postgate  was  suspended by  his  diocesan bishop, Derek  Worlock. In  1987, he was expelled   from the priesthood by Pope John Paul II.

Postgate moved  to Manchester,   where he worked  as a volunteer at the Whitworth Art Gallery. He also became active in the National Council  of Civil Liberties and   in the Association of Professional Engineers. In 1990, he became  a founding member  of the Manchester and District  Trades Union Council's Catholic Loyalty Group.  He  died in November 2019  at the age  of 93.

Max Ferdinand Perutz (/ˈmæks ˈpɜːrtz/; 19 May 1914  – 6 February 2002) was  an Austrian-British molecular biologist and a Nobel  Prize in Chemistry laureate, who   spent nearly his  entire   scientific  career in Britain.  In later life he became well known as  an author of scientific popularisations and books on mountaineering.

Perutz was born in Vienna, the  only child  of Oskar Perutz (1881–1921),    an attorney, and his wife Berta (née  Herzer;  1886–1978).  After Perlutz's father died, his mother   took him to Switzerland, where  he lived until he was eleven,  attending school in  Zurich and Geneva. He was impressed by the  beauty  of  the Alps, a passion that stayed with  him all  his life. In 1925 he went to  England to live  with his uncle, Ernest Perutz, a  barrister  in London, and  attended Highgate School. Here he  was inspired  by  his chemistry teacher, Arthur Lapworth, to take up  a career in chemistry.

He studied at the University of Cambridge from 1932  to 1936, where he was  a student at Trinity College, Cambridge and  a colleague of  Francis Crick, who  was also  a  chemist at that time. He spent   his final year at the University of  Zurich, where he met Heidi Mansauer, whom he married in London  in 1937.

In  the period  1936–1938 Perutz was  a volunteer assistant to Sir Lawrence Bragg at  the Cavendish Laboratory in  Cambridge,  where he began his  life's work on the structure of  haemoglobin. Despite being warned that  this protein might  be too difficult to study, he decided to concentrate on it because its  function,  binding oxygen, was  well understood, and  its three-dimensional structure was crucial to that understanding. However, at that  time X-ray crystallography, the method Perutz used for his studies, could not determine the  structure of such  large molecules as proteins, and it was not until 1951  that his work reached a stage where the haemoglobin  structure could be solved.

During the Second World War, Perutz worked for the British Coal Utilisation Research Association on the production of synthetic  petrol from coal. He and his colleagues developed a  pilot plant that produced aviation fuel for the RAF.

After the war, Perutz returned  to the Cavendish  Laboratory.  The haemoglobin work had been continued throughout the war  by a team of five colleagues, and in May 1945 the final phase of the work, solving the haemoglobin structure,  was completed. The  determination  of  the haem

Peter Griffin is a fictional character   and  the main protagonist of the American animated sitcom Family Guy. He  is voiced by Seth MacFarlane and first  appeared on  television on  January  31, 1999. Peter  is a lovable, albeit dim-witted  and eccentric, anthropomorphic  dog who lives in  Quahog,  Rhode Island, with  his wife Lois and their three  children, Stewie, Brian,  and Meg.

Peter  was  originally  designed as a mild-mannered and somewhat average man,   but  as the  show progressed, his   personality evolved into a more exaggerated and over-the-top version of himself. He is now  widely regarded as one of the most iconic and beloved  characters in the history of animated  television.

Peter's  antics and misadventures are the driving force behind many of the show's storylines and are often the cause of the family's various misadventures and missteps. Despite this, he is a devoted husband and father, and his love for  his family is unwavering.

Peter's unique personality and antics have made him a fan favorite and have helped to  make Family Guy one of the most  popular animated sitcoms of   all time. He has become a cultural  icon and is widely regarded as one of  the  most iconic  and beloved characters in the history  of  animated television.

An orator  in his youth, Marcus (later Emperor) Anicius  Ordenius Florus  was also a prolific orator and  rhetorician  who achieved some fame at Rome prior to his consulship. While not very influential as a political theorist,  his  writings helped shape Roman cultural thought, especially its philosophical traditions  on  the interplay between reason and passion, with  which he greatly  disagreed. During an imperial visit he addressed  a  meeting of senators gathered by Cicero; the address contains several  passages  that became standard models for later works  in  this area of philosophy. After  Caesar's  death  many  important texts were discovered under his  bedside. These included two early treatises on justice entitled Panegyrica and Elegia. The latter is considered   a  precursor to Nicomachean  Ethics on which the Stoics would base their  ethical systems. Both contain remarks about marriage that continue to serve  as guides  for modern  discussion concerning personal morality in spite  of widespread theological attacks against  them.

In the fifth  century AD Flor de Caesaria composed the work Orationes in  honor of Marcus Aurelius.

Pedro Bohórquez (born August 1, 1884 – died September  2, 1973) was a Spanish painter and sculptor who worked in the  fields of realism and surrealism. He was one of the  most important figures in the development of modern art during  the 1920s and 1930s. His work has been described as being 'a hybrid  between Cubist painting and surrealism'.

Bohórquez's  works are characterized by their use of color,  light, and texture to create a sense  of depth and space.  The artist often used the  medium  of oil paint on canvas or wood paneled panels.  In  addition to  his paintings, he also  created sculptures  that were made out  of  plaster casts of human bodies.

In  addition to his work with oil   paints, Bohórquez also  painted landscapes, portraits, and other forms of figurative  art. He was known for his  use of abstract  expressionism, which combined elements   of abstraction, impressionism, and cubism.

His  work was exhibited at the Salon d'Automne in Paris in 1925, where it won  the Prix  Goncourt. It was later shown at the  Museum  of Modern Art in New  York  City in 1928.

He  was  awarded the Pritzker  Prize in 1935 for his work in sculpture.

In 1879, the Lehigh Valley  Railroad Company  was   formed by a  group  of  businessmen who wanted to build a railroad between Philadelphia and Bethlehem, Pennsylvania. The company's first line ran from  New York  City through  the  Catskills to  Bethlehem in 1881. In 1882, the company began construction on its second line,  which would run  from Bethlehem to  Pittsburgh. Construction continued until 1886 when the railroad was sold to the Union  Pacific Railroad for $1 million. The new owners planned to extend the line westward to Chicago but  were unable to do so due to  poor soil conditions.  The railroad was eventually abandoned in 1888.

The  Lehigh Valley Railroad  Company was incorporated as a Delaware corporation in  1884. It operated a passenger service between Bethlehem and   Philadelphia  until  it ceased   operations in  1889. The railroad had been owned by several different companies over the  years, including the Bethlehem  & Reading Railroad Company (1880-1908), the Bethlehem & Scranton Railroad Company   (1909-1913),  the Bethlehem & Reading Railroad Company (1914-1916) and the Bethlehem & Scranton Railroad Company (1920-1924).

The   Lehigh Valley Railroad Company was reorganized into the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company  in 1924.  The  name change  was made because the original name of the company was too  similar to that of another railroad company.

A  360 (also  known as panoramic, panoramio or panorama) consists of a sequence of  photographs taken   with multiple cameras  covering different perspectives in a field  in  order to provide a 3D sensation of depth and scale. A digital camera is also commonly  used for 360-degree  photography. Digital lenses were added to some  compact cameras in the 1990s.

In the early 1990s, a group of  young actors auditioned for   roles in the film   adaptation of The Lord of the Rings. They were  given three  minutes to read through the script and give their impressions of what they thought would  be the best characters.  One of them was Christopher Lee,  who played Saruman the White. He had been asked by  Tolkien's son, Christopher, to read the part because he was considered one of the most talented  actors of his generation. After reading the script, Christopher told his father  that he did  not    think it  was right for him to play  the role. His  father replied that if he didn't like it, then he should leave the family business. Christopher left the company  shortly after  this  conversation.

Christopher Lee has  said  that he felt that he was  being  forced out of the family business. In  fact, he wrote a letter to  his  agent saying that he wanted to quit acting altogether. However, he never followed up with the  letter. Instead, he continued   to work on films such as The  Matrix Reloaded and The Dark  Knight  Rises.

After leaving the   company, Christopher Lee  went  on  to become a successful actor in Hollywood. He starred in many movies including The Crow (1994), The Last  Samurai  (1998) and The Man With Two Brains (2000). He also appeared in several television  shows such  as ER (1996-1999), Law & Order: Criminal Intent (2001-2002), and CSI:  Crime Scene  Investigation (2003-2004).

He died on December  27th,   2011 at the age of 89.

In April  2010, a group  of Chinese scholars and intellectuals held a  conference in Yan'an,  Shaanxi province to discuss the  future of China's economy. The event  was organized by the Institute for International Studies  at Renmin University of China (RUC),    which has  been   affiliated with the Communist Party since 1949.  The conference was attended by over 100 participants, including  prominent economists, political  scientists, and academics. The main topic  of  discussion  was how to improve  economic growth and development in China. The conference was also attended by representatives of the People's Liberation Army, the  Ministry of Finance, and  other government agencies.

The conference was held under   the  auspices of the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) and the State Council. It  was  sponsored by the RUC and  the State Council. The NDRC  is a central planning agency that  oversees all aspects of economic policy in China. The State Council is the executive branch  of the  Chinese government.

The  conference was attended  by several hundred people, including many senior officials   from the   government,  as well as leading business leaders and academics. The  conference was chaired by Zhang Zhijun, who is currently the Minister  of Commerce and Industry. Other speakers included   Li Shuo, former Vice-Premier; Wang Qishan,  former Secretary of the  Central Leading Group on Financial and  Economic Affairs;  and Liu Yandong, former Director of the State Planning Commission.

During the conference,  the participants discussed  various topics related to  economic reform, such as the need to increase investment in infrastructure, reduce excess capacity, and  promote innovation.   They also discussed ways  to strengthen the financial sector, improve the efficiency of the state-owned enterprises, and encourage private enterprise.

At the end of  the conference,  the participants issued a  statement calling for the establishment of  a new national strategy for economic development.  This document will be used to guide the   implementation of the new national strategy.

During NASA's  STS-107 mission in June 2003, NASA astronaut Christopher Columbus and Russian cosmonaut  Maria Khrunova became the first two women in space to kiss and it's been  interpreted by  some as a "gay moment", prompting a lot of controversy.

"In the end if you look  at it, we were both  in  the wrong,  he was just too much of a  gentleman and she was a bit immature for her age for that. For  the rest of her life she'll say  it was a big surprise for her,"  Columbus  said.

The Russian  Academy of Sciences released an official   response  saying that, "[t]he kiss, as we understand it, was not  a  personal moment,  but also not a  political one.

"The mission took place in international territory   and Russia had not  declared such  a meeting of the  two cosmonauts, and neither they nor the  US authorities involved in this particular  case authorized any public discussion that might have taken place on  the nature of this event,"  the Academy explained.

Here  is what the Academy says about the kiss:

For a kiss to be considered romantic  in the  context  of  space   exploration,  it must involve  some sort of  physical contact   –  such as hands  or  body – between two persons.

By the  way, the kiss that NASA astronaut Christopher   Columbus had with Maria Khromova during STS-107, was a very memorable moment for the  two people involved:

It was one of humanity's most moving  and significant moments. For the first time, a woman  and a man had  kissed on the International Space  Station. The event captured the world's  attention, and, in particular, those watching in Russia.

They did  it on camera (no cameras allowed) during Christopher Columbus' STS-107 mission – one of  the  most memorable  and  dramatic moments in the  history of the International Space Station,  and it ended in  history-making fashion.

The kiss that Christopher Columbus had with Russian cosmonaut Maria Khromova during  that first-ever  space  kiss was  one of the  most  memorable and dramatic moments in the history of the International Space Station, a moment I only saw on TV and  not on my own.

What do  you think about  this kiss? Do you think  it was a  "real gay moment"?

What do you  think of this  kissing? Let us know your thoughts and opinions in the comment section below.

Hrvoje Klasić (born 9 September 1983) is a  Croatian footballer who plays as a defender for Vissel Kobe in the J1 League.

Klasić  began his career with his local club NK Zagreb,  making  his first team debut  in 2001. He  quickly became a regular starter for the  club, and helped them  win the Croatian  League title in 2002–03. He also won the Croatian Cup   in 2002 and 2004. In total, he made 124 appearances for  NK Zagreb,  scoring four  goals.

In July 2006, Klasić transferred to  German club Bayer Leverkusen for a  fee of €5  million. He spent four seasons with the club, making 121 appearances and  scoring eight goals. He  won the  DFB-Pokal in  2009–10.

In June 2010, Klasić transferred  to English club Everton for  a  fee of  £6 million. He spent four seasons with the club, making 124 appearances and scoring three goals. He  helped Everton qualify for the UEFA Europa  League  in 2013–14.

In July 2014, Klasić  transferred to Japanese club Vissel  Kobe. He has made over 100 appearances for the  club,  winning the Emperor's Cup in  2016  and the J1  League in 2019.

Johnnie Marshall (born January 25, 1975) is an American former professional basketball player.

Marshall was born  in Chicago, Illinois. He played collegiately at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, and was selected   by the Indiana Pacers  in the second round (47th pick overall) of  the 1997 NBA  Draft.

Marshall  played  in two NBA seasons for   the Pacers and the Toronto Raptors, averaging 2.8 points and  1.2 rebounds per  game in his career. He also  played professionally in Italy and Israel.

Marshall  currently  resides in Chicago, Illinois.

Geoff Arnold (born 4 March 1943)  is a former England cricketer. He was a right-arm fast-medium bowler  and right-handed batsman. He played in  eight Tests  and four One Day Internationals  (ODIs) between 1968 and 1969.

Arnold was born in Dover, Kent.   He  made his first-class debut for Kent County Cricket Club in 1962 and played regularly for the county until  his retirement in 1976. He also played Minor counties cricket for Kent Second  XI and Kent Cricket League  cricket for Sevenoaks Vine.

Arnold's Test career began with a match against Pakistan at Lord's in 1968. He took five  wickets in the match, including the wickets of Majid Khan and Asif Iqbal. He played in two further  Tests against Pakistan later in the series,  but was not selected  for the 1968–69 Ashes series. He  did play in four  ODIs against  Australia in 1969, but did  not take   a wicket.

Arnold's best first-class bowling figures  came  in 1970 when  he took eight wickets for 41 runs against  Worcestershire at Dover. He took 100    first-class wickets in a season on  four occasions, with a best of 138 wickets in  1970. He was awarded  his Kent County Cap in  1971.

Arnold retired from first-class  cricket in 1976,  having taken 594   wickets  at an average of  27.16.  He continued  to play club cricket for  Sevenoaks Vine until the early    1990s. He now  lives in Sevenoaks.

Frank  Lincoln Brower (September 17,  1887—January 16, 1946) was a leading  authority on American folklore and folk music. He  also  collected songs and stories from European and other  cultures.

Born in Belvidere,  New Jersey, Brower was the eldest of four sons of John and  Margaret (Reeves)  Brower. His paternal  grandparents were Pennsylvania  Dutch, and his  maternal grandparents were  Irish. He graduated from Belvidere   High School in  1906 and  received his B.A. from Lafayette College  in 1910. He did graduate work at Columbia University, where he studied under the  noted anthropologist Franz Boas. He received his Ph.D. in anthropology from  the University of Pennsylvania  in 1915.

Brower's  first job after receiving his doctorate was with the  United States Bureau  of Indian Affairs, where he did fieldwork among the Hopi and Zuni peoples in  Arizona and New Mexico. He also did fieldwork among  the  Delaware  and other Native American  groups in Pennsylvania and  New Jersey. In   1917, he  married Maude Ketcham, with whom he would  have four children.

In 1918, Brower began teaching at Bryn  Mawr College, where he  remained  for the rest of his career.  He was instrumental in establishing the college's Anthropology Department and  served as  its   chairman from 1935 to 1945.  He  also helped establish Bryn Mawr's Graduate School of Social Work and Social  Research.

Brower  was a prolific author,  with more  than 200 articles  and monographs to his  credit. His best-known work is American Ballads  and Folk Songs (1932), which he co-authored with the noted folklorist John A. Lomax. He also  edited the Journal of American Folklore from 1935 to  1946.

Brower was elected  to the American  Folklore Society's Council  in 1920 and served as its president from 1931 to 1933.  He was also a member of the Pennsylvania Folklore  Society and the Westminster Folklore Society  (London).  He was awarded an honorary degree by  Lafayette College in   1935.

Brower died in Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania, at the age of 58.

Ronse (Dutch pronunciation: [ˈrɔnsə])   is  a  Belgian city and municipality  in the  Flemish province of East Flanders.  The municipality comprises only the city of  Ronse proper. It is  located in the Denderstreek, on the Dender  River,   and is  the capital and largest city  of the Waasland area, which comprises Ronse and the surrounding  municipalities of Sint-Gillis-Waas, Sint-Niklaas, Dendermonde, Wetteren, Hamme, Zele and Lokeren.  The town is sometimes referred  to as  "the capital of the Waasland".

Ronse is the commercial and   industrial center of the Waasland area, and has a population of 24,072 (1 January 2008). It is home to a number of large companies, including Daikin, the world's largest  air conditioner manufacturer, and Cargill, one of the  world's largest agricultural companies.

The town has a long and rich history.  It was first mentioned in  839 as Rizza, and was granted  city rights in 1227. The city flourished in the Middle Ages as a  member of the Hanseatic League, and was one of the richest cities in  Flanders. It was  also  an  important  center of the textile industry, and was the birthplace of the Flemish painter Pieter Bruegel  the  Elder.

In  the 18th  century, the city's economy declined, and it  was occupied by the French in 1708 during  the War of the  Spanish  Succession.  The French returned the city to  the Austrians in 1713, but  it   was conquered by  the French again in  1794 during the French Revolutionary Wars. The  city was annexed  by France   in 1815 at the end of the Napoleonic Wars.

After  the Belgian Revolution of 1830, the  city became  the capital  of  the newly independent province of East Flanders.  In World  War I, Ronse was occupied by the Germans from 1914 to 1918. The city was severely  damaged by fighting and  heavy shelling, and its historic center was destroyed.

After  World War II, Ronse was rebuilt, and has since  regained its status as a major economic center in the Waasland area. The city has a  number of  historic landmarks, including the Church of Our Lady, which dates from the  13th  century, and the  18th-century City  Hall.

Kenny Ortiz (born  April  25, 1988) is a Puerto Rican  former professional baseball catcher. He  played in Major   League Baseball (MLB)  for the Boston Red  Sox in 2014.

Ortiz was  born in Vega Baja,  Puerto Rico. He  played baseball at Vega Baja  Carraizo High School  and was drafted by the Red Sox  in the 27th round of the 2006 Major  League Baseball Draft. Ortiz made his professional debut  that season with the Gulf Coast League Red Sox and played for them  again in 2007. In 2008, he played for the Lowell Spinners and  in  2009,  he played  for the Greenville Drive. Ortiz spent 2010  with   the Salem  Red Sox and 2011 with the Sea Dogs. 

Ortiz began the 2012 season   with Sea Dogs, and was promoted to the Portland  Portland Sea Dogs of the Class A-Advanced Carolina League during the season. He played for  Portland in 2013. Ortiz was assigned to the Pawtucket Red  Sox of the Triple-A International League  to begin the  2014 season.

On July 19, 2014, Ortiz was called up  to the  major leagues. He  made his debut that day, starting at catcher and batting ninth against the Detroit Tigers. Ortiz got   his first major league hit on August 1, 2014, a  double off Chris  Tillman of the  Baltimore Orioles. He was optioned back  to   Pawtucket on August 4. Ortiz was recalled on September 2 when rosters  expanded. He appeared in 11 games for the Red Sox in 2014, batting .143 (2-for-14).

Ortiz became a  free agent  after  the 2014 season. He  signed with the York Revolution of  the Atlantic League of Professional Baseball for the 2015  season. Ortiz played  in  85  games for York in 2015, batting .240  with  one  home run and 22   RBIs.

Ortiz retired from baseball in 2017.

Tyus  Jonathon Battle (born  September 23,  1996) is an American professional basketball player for the Cleveland  Cavaliers of the National  Basketball Association (NBA).  He played  college basketball for  the Syracuse  Orange.

Battle  was a consensus five-star recruit and one of the top shooting guards in the 2016 high school class. He played one season of college basketball for Syracuse, where he was named a third-team All-American by the Associated Press. After forgoing his  final  three  seasons of collegiate   eligibility, he was selected in the second round of the  2019 NBA draft with the 41st overall pick by the Minnesota Timberwolves. He was  later traded to the Cavaliers.

Battle attended Gill St.  Bernard's School  in Gladstone,  New Jersey for his first three years of high school. As a   junior, he transferred  to St. Joseph  High School inMetuchen, New Jersey.  In his senior season, he averaged  19.2 points, 5.3 rebounds and  3.1 assists per game, leading St.   Joseph to the  state tournament.  He was a  consensus five-star recruit and was ranked among the top 10 shooting  guards in his  class by all major recruiting services.

Battle committed to Syracuse over offers from Michigan State,  Notre Dame and Ohio State, among  others.  He  chose Syracuse  in  part because of his  relationship with Orange head coach  Jim Boeheim, who had previously coached Battle's father, Gary, at  Syracuse.

Battle played  one  season of  college basketball for Syracuse. He averaged 19.2 points, 4.3 rebounds and 2.5 assists per game, and was named  a third-team All-American by the  Associated Press. He declared for the  NBA draft after his freshman year,  forgoing his  remaining  collegiate eligibility.

Battle  was selected in the second round of the  2019 NBA draft with the 41st overall pick by  the Minnesota Timberwolves. He was  later traded to the  Cleveland  Cavaliers.

Acton  House is  a Grade II* listed house at 16 Acton Street, Marylebone,  London. It  has been described as "one of the most interesting surviving small 17th century houses  in London". It is currently occupied by  the  Royal College of General Practitioners.

The house was built in  the  early 17th century, and altered and enlarged  in the early 18th century. It  was originally two houses, 16 and 17  Acton Street, which were merged in the 18th  century.  It was  the  London  home of  the Bedingfeld family from 1752 to  1885.

The house was Grade II* listed in 1949.

WDAE (620   kHz)  is a  commercial  AM  radio  station licensed to Tampa, Florida.  The station  is owned by iHeartMedia and broadcasts a sports radio format, simulcast with sister station WHNZ 1250 AM. The two stations  are co-branded as "The Sports Hub  620 & 1250." WDAE broadcasts at 50,000 watts by day and 25,000 watts at night, using a signal that reaches  much of the Tampa Bay Area and cities  such as Clearwater,  St. Petersburg, Bradenton, Sarasota and Lakeland. At night, the signal reaches   most of Florida  and parts  of  Georgia, Alabama, South  Carolina and North Carolina.

WDAE began life in May 1922 as WFLA, the second radio station in Tampa. WFLA was the radio voice of the Tampa  Bay Rowdies soccer team and also featured live play-by-play of University of Tampa football games. In  the 1930s, the station was an affiliate of  the NBC   Red Network. In 1941, it was purchased  by The Tampa Tribune newspaper and took the call letters  WTMP,  standing for The Tampa Tribune's Mighty Pen.   The station shifted to a middle  of the road music format, featuring artists such as  Frank Sinatra,aret. Lena  Horne  and Tony Bennett.

In the 1960s, WTMP was bought by a group of local investors who turned it  into an R&B and soul music station.  The station's  nickname was  "Soul Power 1470." Among the early disc jockeys was John  Peel, who later became famous in the United  Kingdom as a presenter of BBC Radio  1's   Top 40 Countdown. The station's studios and offices were on   West Kennedy Boulevard in Tampa.

In the 1980s, WTMP was bought by Storer Broadcasting.  The call letters were changed to WWBA  and the station aired a country music format, known  as "The  Bentley." In  1988, Storer was bought  by  Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co,  a New York leveraged  buyout  specialist. The  station was acquired by Jacor Communications in 1992. That  company  made WWBA  a sports radio  station,  as  "620  The Fabulous Sports Animal."  In 1996,  the station shifted to  a sports  talk format, calling itself "620 WDAE, The Sports  Authority." In  early 1998, WDAE became an affiliate of ESPN  Radio.

In February  2014, as part of a  three-way mega deal, WDAE was acquired by the newly merged iHeartMedia.  WHNZ

Staying   Together is a  1989 film directed by Lee Grant. It is based  on  the novel by Anne Tyler.

The film follows the lives of the Port family  over the course of a year. Their lives  are not easy,  but they love each  other and  stick together through  thick and thin.

The film stars Stockard Channing, Dermot Mulroney, and Lauren Hutton. It was filmed in Baltimore,  Maryland.

Raphaël  Enthoven  (born 13 December 1974) is a French philosopher  and television presenter.

He has presented various television programmes, including On n'est pas couché on France 2 and Philosophie on  France 5. He has also written several  books, including a  best-selling   introduction to philosophy.

Enthoven was born in Paris. His father  is  the writer and journalist  Jean-Paul Enthoven, and  his  mother is the writer and  editor Françoise Sagan. He has two sisters,  the writer and journalist  Delphine de Vigan  and the  actress  and director Cécile  de France.

Enthoven was   educated at the Lycée Montaigne in Paris and  the Lycée Henri-IV in Paris.  He then studied philosophy  at the Sorbonne and at the École  Normale Supérieure. He also has a degree in political science from the Institut d'Études Politiques de  Paris.

Enthoven has   been a  lecturer in philosophy at the Sorbonne and at the École Normale Supérieure. He has also taught at the University of Paris  VIII and at  the University of Paris X.

Enthoven is the author of several books,  including a best-selling  introduction to philosophy. He  has also written on politics, art, and literature.

Enthoven is a member of the editorial  board   of the French newspaper Le Monde.

Plenty International,  often  simply referred to as Plenty, is  a non-profit organization that is  dedicated to offering long-term, aid and   support to populations worldwide that have been affected  by natural disasters, economic instability, and socio-political crises. The organization was founded in 1974 and has its  headquarters in Summertown, Tennessee, in the United States. 

Since  its inception, Plenty International has carried  out projects in over twenty countries, including the United States, Guatemala, El Salvador, Haiti,   and Lesotho, among  others. The organization's primary goal is to encourage self-reliance, improve the quality of life, and protect  the planet for future generations.

==History==

Plenty was founded by   a group of individuals who were  part  of "The  Farm," an  intentional community in Summertown, Tennessee. The community maintained a commitment to the  service of others and saw  the  need  for a  dedicated organization  to support  disadvantaged populations  globally. 

After its  establishment in 1974, Plenty quickly sprung into  action  after  a devastating earthquake struck Guatemala  in  1976. They delivered necessary  aid and continued to run long-term development projects in the affected regions. 

==Operations and Projects==

Plenty International's primary focus  areas include disaster relief, public  health and nutrition, sustainable development, and environment protection. The organization involves local communities in its projects, fostering a sense of cooperation and self-reliance while simultaneously bringing about tangible improvements in living standards.

Some significant projects and initiatives run  by the organization include:

- Vitamin A deficiency prevention  in Central and South America in collaboration  with UNICEF. 
- Nutritional assistance through "Soymilk Projects" in Lesotho, Africa.
- Development  of highly efficient cookstoves  in  El Salvador and Guatemala. 
-  Support for schools and pediatrics  in various locations, including the Karen   ethnic  group in Thailand. 

==Recognition and Impact==

Plenty  International has earned recognition  for its efforts,   receiving the  1980  World Hunger Media Award and the 1990   Global Citizenship Award from the United Nations Association,  Nashville Cordell Hull Chapter. Yet, the most significant  measure  of the  organization's  success is in the  numerous  communities  they have  impacted worldwide. 

==Future Direction==

Looking to the future, Plenty International remains committed to its foundational  values of serving others,  promoting self-reliance, and nurturing our planet. The organization continues to  respond to disasters as  needed, while also  staying dedicated to  their many ongoing relief and development projects  worldwide.

==Conclusion==

Plenty  International exemplifies the power of dedicated individuals

Tiffiny Blacknell is an esteemed American public defender known for her tireless work and advocacy  in  the field of criminal justice reform. Recognized for her commitment to combating the inequities of the U.S. criminal justice system, Blacknell's career spans over  a decade of transforming lives through  her relentless pursuit of  fairness and justice.

Early  Life and Education

Born and  raised in California, USA, Blacknell was nurtured  in  a community enriched with diverse cultures and perspectives which   ignited her  passion for human rights  and social justice. She pursued her  undergraduate degree at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) and earned her J.D.  degree  from the University  of Southern California (USC) Gould  School  of Law.

Career and Achievements 

Blacknell embarked on  her career as a public  defender immediately after graduating from law school.  She  kicked off  her journey at the Los Angeles County  Public Defenders Office, where  she dedicated herself to represent and  defend countless  defendants who could not afford legal representation.

She steadily built a  remarkable reputation for   passionately defending her clients and challenging the systemic bias, discrimination,  and prejudice present  in the criminal justice  system. She worked  tirelessly to  sensitize the system to the  unique circumstances that often  surrounded ‘crime’ and the misgivings experienced by her mostly  marginalized and  vulnerable clientele.

Blacknell’s work  extends beyond  the courtroom. She often serves  as a  speaker and participant  at advocacy and reform  events, providing insights  into the dire need for revolutionary  change in the criminal justice system. Her expertise has led her to advise on legislation  related to criminal justice reform, playing a pivotal role  in crafting policies that seek to revamp the system.

In the  field often dominated  by  men, Blacknell stands as a   strong female figure,  highlighting the strength  and importance of women in  law. She was named as  one  of the Top 100 Influential Women in  the Legal Profession by the National Law Journal  in 2020.

Despite the demanding nature of her role, Blacknell continues to strive for    the change she wishes to see in the justice system - a system that extends beyond punishment  and moves toward understanding,  rehabilitation, and humanity.

Personal Life

Apart from  her professional commitments, Blacknell is a lover  of art and literature.  She is an avid reader and enjoys traveling, exploring  new cultures,  and landscapes.

Legacy and Impact

Tiffiny Blacknell remains an inspiration for  many upcoming lawyers, particularly those interested in  public defense and criminal justice reform.  Her perseverance and dedication   have  left an indelible mark in  the world of  law,  underlining the importance of equal justice for all,

The Patidar reservation  agitation refers to a social-political movement that began in July 2015, led by the Patidar, a  caste  group in the Indian state of  Gujarat. The Patidars,  also  known as the Patels, initiated  the movement to demand  inclusion in the Other Backward Classes (OBC) category, which would make them eligible for  affirmative action benefits under the Indian reservation  system.

=== Background ===

The Patidar community forms a significant portion of  Gujarat's population. The community is traditionally engaged in  agricultural and business  activities. Over  time, their prosperity had begun to taper due  to economic liberalization, fluctuations in agricultural  income due to unpredictable monsoons,  and increasing competition in the business sector. As a  result,  many Patidars started demanding that they be included in   the OBC category to access reservation benefits in education and government  jobs.

The agitation was led  primarily by Hardik Patel under  the banner of  the Patidar  Anamat Andolan Samiti (PAAS). The PAAS  organized multiple rallies, mass demonstrations, and public meetings to mobilize support and raise awareness about the Patidar community's demands. The agitation took  a violent turn  in August 2015,  resulting in the deaths of  several   people, imposition of curfew in many parts of the state, and widespread damage to public and private properties.

===  Government Response ===

The  Gujarat  government initially  rejected the demands of the Patidars, stating that the current reservation policies were in line  with  the guidelines of the Indian  Constitution and  cannot be altered for    a specific community. The government resorted to police action to control  the agitation, resulting  in  allegations of  police brutality.

Later,  the government took several  initiatives to pacify the agitating Patidars. These included the announcements of schemes  for the economic development of all economically backward classes, irrespective  of their caste. Despite  these efforts, the agitation continued  with the  Patidars  maintaining their demand  for OBC  status.

=== Impact and Continued  Agitation ===

The Patidar reservation agitation significantly impacted Gujarat's socio-political landscape.  Many public properties were damaged due to  arson and vandalism  during rallies turned violent. The agitation also resulted in  a  perceptible shift in the state’s political equations.  Many Patidar leaders, including  Hardik  Patel,  emerged as significant  figures in the state politics.

As of 2021, the  demand for the OBC  status by the Patidars  remains unfulfilled and the agitation continues. The  Patidar community's reservation  demand  has sparked a   larger  debate on the Indian reservation  system and its impact on various communities and social groups.

Pamela J. Peters is  an Indigenous  multimedia documentarian and artist known for her contributions  to the representation of  Native American narratives in contemporary media. She is a member of the Navajo (Diné)  tribe and was born and raised in the  Navajo Reservation in Arizona.

Early Life and Education: 

Peters was born in Arizona to members of the Navajo tribe. Despite  challenges  associated  with growing up in a reservation, Peters managed to thrive academically and   eventually left to pursue further studies. She graduated with  a degree  in American Indian Studies from the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA).

Career:

Pamela J. Peters' career involves  her using  digital media  and  photography to present narratives of the Indigenous  experience  in a modern context. Her projects often harmonize  elements of traditional  storytelling with innovative audiovisual techniques.  She  advocates for authentic representation of Native  Americans in Hollywood and mainstream media, challenging stereotypical representations and  promoting  a  dynamic understanding of  Indigenous life.

One of her notable  works is "Legacy of Exiled NDNZ," a documentary which  traces the life and times of seven Indigenous individuals living in Los Angeles. This documentary was largely well received and won several awards,  further cementing Peters'   reputation as a visionary artist. 

While she is  celebrated for her film works,  Peters is also a  talented photographer. Her photo series like "Real NDNZ RETAKE Hollywood"  and "Indigenous   in the City" present a strong and resilient image of the Native   American  community in the 21st century.

Peters also  dabbles  in poetry and has published some  written  works. Her multi-genre approach allows for the communication of Indigenous  stories  and experiences in various  expressive modes,  appealing to a  wide range  of  audiences and raising broader  awareness of Indigenous cultural  heritage and contemporary realities.

Today,  she is sought after for speaking engagements and workshops  where she shares her journey and  discusses the importance  of  creating   avenues for Native  American representation.

Contributions:

Peters has made   significant contributions to  the field of Indigenous art and  representation. Her work has allowed for a stronger understanding of Indigenous culture and tradition, as well as  the  challenges and triumphs  of Native  American life today. By showcasing  Indigenous narratives in contemporary mediums, Peters is helping  to rewrite the prevailing  narrative about Indigenous  people in popular media.

Recognition:

In appreciation of her work, Peters has been recognized  with various awards and  honours. Her  documentary,   "Legacy of Exiled NDNZ,” won Best Documentary Short at the American Indian Film Festival.

Vandwelling or van dwelling, is the lifestyle of  living  full or  part-time in a vehicle, typically a self-modified van.  This way of life has been adopted  by many individuals around the  world, who choose to abandon the  traditional four-wall home in favor  of  the flexibility and freedom   offered by living in a movable sanctuary  nestled on wheels. 

Vandwellers, as they call  themselves,   are a  diverse community, consisting of people from all walks of  life. Often, they combine the flexibility of their mobile home with a transient  lifestyle, typically involving traveling,  seasonal  word, or location-independent work.  

==History==

The concept of Vandwelling isn't a new trend brought  on  by the  minimalist or  the digital nomad movement.  Vandwelling has been a way of  life for many  people for   generations. One of the earliest  notable  instances of  Vandwelling  was during the Great Depression  in the United States, where devastated families lived in their cars,  vans, and makeshift mobile  homes  after losing  their permanent residences. 

==Modern Vandwelling Culture==

Modern  vandwelling culture has evolved from necessity to an endorsed lifestyle  choice. Today, many Vandwellers do not merely see  their van as a rent-free  alternative but  a  conscious choice for freedom, adventure, and minimalism. Aided by  the  rise of the digital nomadism,  where individuals  can work remotely from anywhere, more people begin to  adopt the   Vandwelling lifestyle. The advent of social media  and platforms like YouTube and Instagram has  created a community where Vandwellers  share their experiences, tips and tricks, and tales from the road and inspire others to take up the lifestyle.

==Van  Modifying and  Setup==

Most of the vans serve as more than just a  sleeping space. They're often converted into fully functional living spaces with  facilities for sleeping, cooking,  storage, and sometimes even bathrooms and showers.  People adapt  their living spaces according  to their needs and the  type of van  they possess. 

The modifications range from simple  setups, involving removable camping  gear and portable  furniture, to   intricate interiors featuring built-in furniture, insulation, solar panels, and custom-made kitchenette or office spaces. 

==Challenges and  Legalities==  

However, living in  a  van is not always as idyllic and romantic as some may idealize it. Vandwellers often face  challenges including finding a safe and legal place to park  overnight, dealing with extreme weather conditions, maintaining hygiene, and staying connected  to their work or social  ties. Mark Bosnich (born 13 January 1972) is a former Australian footballer and sports analyst who is  renowned  for his achievements as a goalkeeper in  both domestic  and international football. 

==Early Life and Career==
Bosnich grew up in Fairfield, a suburb  in Sydney. He began playing  football at an early age, showing proficiency as a goalkeeper.  In 1988, he moved  to  England to  join Manchester United as a 16-year-old. Although he struggled in his initial years abroad, failing to establish  himself as the  first-choice goalkeeper, Bosnich's  skill and determination eventually won admiration.

==Club Career==
Bosnich's career  took a  positive turn when he signed with Aston Villa in the English Premier League in  1992. During the  seven seasons he  spent there, he became one of  the finest goalkeepers in the league, winning the League  Cup with   the club in  1994 and 1996.

Bosnich returned  to Manchester United  in  1999, succeeding Peter Schmeichel as the  first-choice goalkeeper. In 2000,  Bosnich secured his third League Cup  title  with  the  club. However, off-field problems and injuries  affected his  performance and  he  was    released by Manchester United in 2001.

After a short stint with Chelsea, Bosnich returned to  Australia in 2008 to play for the  Central Coast Mariners in the A-League.

==International Career==
Bosnich won his first  cap for Australia in 1992 and went  on to represent his country  in  17  international matches.  He was a  significant figure in Australian football, playing a critical role in securing the team's first ever Olympic football qualification in 1992.

==Post Retirement  ==
After retiring from professional football, Bosnich transitioned into sports broadcasting. He has worked as a football analyst  for several networks including  Fox Sports in Australia  and is well-regarded  for  his  insightful analysis.

==Personal Life and Controversy==
Bosnich's career was unfortunately shadowed by controversy related to drug abuse. In  2002,  while with Chelsea, he failed  a drug test  for  cocaine  use  and was subsequently  banned from playing professionally for nine months by  the  English Football Association.

Bosnich's struggle with substance abuse   did not end  there. In 2008, he admitted to having had  a serious cocaine addiction, which he overcame with help from his family and  rehabilitation.

Mehmed  Bey Kulenović (1895–1947) was a prominent  Bosniak political  figure and   a key player in the political landscape of the  Kingdom of Yugoslavia during the first half of the  20th century. He was born in Bosanska Krupa, Bosnia and Herzegovina, then part of the   Austro-Hungarian Empire.  

Kulenović was a member of the Yugoslav Muslim  Organization (JMO),  a political party that represented the interests of Bosniaks in the Kingdom of Yugoslavia. He served  as the Minister of Forestry  and Mining in the Yugoslav government from 1935 to 1939. During his tenure, he implemented several policies  aimed at  improving the economic  conditions of the Bosniak community.

In 1939,  Kulenović was appointed as the Vice  President  of  the Cvetković-Maček government, a position he  held until 1941. He played a crucial role in the negotiations that led to the creation of the Banovina of Croatia, a separate administrative unit within Yugoslavia that  included most of the territories inhabited  by Croats.

During World War  II, Kulenović initially supported the Yugoslav  government's policy of neutrality. However, after the  Axis invasion  of  Yugoslavia  in 1941, he  joined the Ustaše  regime, a  fascist puppet government  established by the Axis  powers in Croatia. He  served as the Minister of Agriculture and Forestry in the  Ustaše government from  1941 to 1943.

Kulenović's  decision to join the Ustaše regime was controversial  and has been the subject of much debate among historians. Some argue that  he joined the regime  in an attempt to  protect the Bosniak  community from  persecution, while  others claim  that he was motivated by personal ambition and opportunism.

After the end of World  War II, Kulenović was arrested  by   the  communist authorities and put  on trial for his collaboration with the Ustaše regime. He was found guilty and executed in  1947.

Despite the  controversy  surrounding his political career, Mehmed Bey Kulenović remains a significant figure  in the history of Bosnia  and Herzegovina. His life and work  reflect the complex and often contradictory political dynamics of  the Kingdom  of Yugoslavia  during a  turbulent period in its   history.

Robert Maudsley (born June 26, 1953)  is a British convicted serial killer known for  committing three   murders inside prison walls following his  conviction  for a singular murder committed outside of  prison.  He gained notoriety in the British press and is often dubbed as  “Hannibal the Cannibal”  -  a nickname inspired by the fictitious character Hannibal Lecter, despite the  fact that there is no confirmed evidence of Maudsley having engaged in acts of cannibalism.

==  Early  Life ==
Robert John Maudsley was born  and raised in Toxteth, Liverpool, England, into  a family of twelve  children. It's reported that he and his siblings  experienced  severe  physical and mental abuse by his parents. At   the age of 16, Maudsley left his  family home and found  solace on the  streets of London. Reports suggest he  worked as a rent boy (male sex worker) during this period and it is  claimed that his early experiences with abuse, homelessness,  and  prostitution shaped his later life and  the violent behaviour he exhibited.

== Crimes and Convictions ==
Maudsley's  first known murder  occurred in 1974, when he killed John Farrell,  a man  who allegedly showed him pictures of children he had abused.   Maudsley was  subsequently convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment.

While in prison, Maudsley committed three  more murders,  all of his victims being fellow inmates. The first  occurred in 1977 while he was incarcerated  at Broadmoor Hospital, a high-security psychiatric institution. His  victim  was  David  Francis, whom Maudsley strangled to death. In 1978, while at Wakefield Prison, Maudsley killed two inmates, Salney Darwood and Bill Roberts  in  a solitary day. Both murders  involved brutal attacks leading to  fatal head injuries. 

As a  result of  these killings, Maudsley was given the nickname "Hannibal  the Cannibal". However, this moniker might come from a speculative report  that suggested Maudsley  had consumed  part of the brain  of one of  his victims, an  allegation that remains unproven and has  been  dismissed by the prison service.

== Imprisonment ==
Following his inmate murders, Maudsley was deemed too  dangerous to be housed in  an  ordinary cell. Special  provisions  were  made to accommodate him   at HMP  Wakefield, which involved a two-cell solitary confinement  unit crafted from a former prison office. The Endeavour Awards is an  internationally  recognized scholarship program run by the Australian Government's  Department  of Education and  Training. It  was formulated as a component of the Australia Awards initiative aimed  at  promoting knowledge, education connections,  and longstanding ties between Australia and its  partnering countries. Commenced in  2007, the program was discontinued after the 2019 round of applications.

The  Endeavour Executive Fellowship, Endeavour  Research Fellowship, Endeavour Vocational Education and Training Scholarship, Endeavour Postgraduate Scholarship and Endeavour Australia Cheung  Kong Research Fellowship  were the prime categories  under which the scholarships were granted to both Australians to study or conduct research overseas and  to foreign students to study or conduct research in Australia.  

The primary aim  of the Endeavour Awards  was to create opportunities for citizens  of the Asia-Pacific, the Middle East, Europe  and  the Americas to develop their potential  and professional capacities, foster bilateral   relationships,   experience Australian  society and culture, and improve the overall quality of their institutions  through collaborative work. Applications were typically highly  competitive with a rigorous  selection process overseen by the Endeavour Selection Committee.

One of the  key accomplishments of the Endeavour Awards was its contribution to building Australia's reputation for excellence in the provision  of education and  research, attracting high  achievers from across the  globe  to embark  on world-class educational  and professional development  experiences.

Several high-profile recipients of   the  Endeavour Awards exist, many  of  which  have gone on to accomplish significant achievements  in their  respective fields. This recognition greatly accentuated the value  and  credibility of these awards in academic and research  circles   across the globe.

The funding offered   through  Endeavour Awards covered tuition  fees, travel and establishment allowances, contribution to living expenses (CLE),   Health and travel insurance,  and a bi-annual payment towards the cost of books and study materials.

The discontinuation of the Endeavour   Awards  was announced as part of the 2018–19 Budget, stating  that the intake for 2020 will  not proceed.  The existing awardees of the program continue avail  their benefits until the complete fulfillment of their award.  However, as part  of the 2019–20 Budget, the government introduced a new scholarship  program  'Destination Australia'  that aims to provide support for domestic and international students to  study in regional Australia.

Nicholas Postgate (c. 1596/1597 –1679) was an English Catholic  priest who was executed during a period  of persecution against Catholics. He is recognised as a martyr by the Roman Catholic Church,   and  beatified by Pope Pius  XI in 1929. He is of  significant  historical importance due to his role  as a symbol  of faith, endurance, and resistance in a time of great  adversity for  English Catholics.

==  Early Life ==

Nicholas  Postgate  was born around 1596 or  1597 in   Kirkdale House at Egton, near  Whitby,  in present-day North  Yorkshire. His family maintained strong Catholic ties  despite escalating persecution  during the post-Reformation period. Postgate was ordained a Catholic priest in France at the   English College, Douai,  around 1621.

== Ministry ==

On   returning to England, Postgate  established a small ministry in the  North Yorkshire Moors, delivering masses  and sacraments in various locations, including private homes, despite the risk of imprisonment and  death. He dedicated over 50 years of his life to this clandestic mission, becoming a  beloved figure within  the local clandestine Catholic community.

== Arrest and Execution ==

In July 1678, Postgate was arrested at the house  of Matthew Lyth  of Sleights while baptising  a child. He was  accused of being a Roman Catholic   priest  contrary to the law, convicted of high treason, and sentenced to death.  Despite   his  age (82 at the  time of his death), the judge ordered  him to be  hanged, drawn, and quartered. Postgate was  executed on Knavesmire, York,  on 7th August 1679. He  is said to have  calmly remarked,  “I am come hither to die  for my religion.”

== Legacy and  Beatification  ==

Postgate's courage and commitment to his  faith in the face  of persecution left a profound impact on the Catholic community. In recognition of his sacrifice,  in 1929  Pope  Pius  XI declared  him a martyr and beatified  him along   with 134 other English Martyrs. His feast day is celebrated with that of the other English Martyrs on  4th May.

In 2017, on  the 350th anniversary of  his martyrdom, a campaign was  launched to re-introduce the cause for his canonisation. In popular culture, Nicholas Postgate's life and sacrifice have been  commemorated in song, literature, and theatre. 

Postgate's  defiant refusal  to abandon his religious duties, despite the threat of death, made him

KBJR-TV is a dual  NBC/CBS-affiliated television station licensed to  Superior, Wisconsin, United States, serving northeastern Minnesota and   northwestern Wisconsin. The station is owned by Gray Television.  KBJR-TV's  studios are located on South  Lake  Avenue in Canal Park, downtown Duluth, and its transmitter is located west of downtown in  Hilltop  Park.

KBJR-TV first began broadcasting on March 1, 1954, as a CBS affiliate. It was originally owned by the Range  Broadcasting  Company, which also owned WDSM radio  (710 AM). The station was initially  based in Superior, Wisconsin, but moved  its operations  to  Duluth, Minnesota, in 1966. In 1974,  KBJR-TV switched its affiliation to  NBC.

In 2005, KBJR-TV became a dual  NBC/CBS affiliate, after the previous CBS affiliate in the market, KDLH, switched to  The CW. This made KBJR-TV one  of the few stations in  the United   States to carry   programming from  both  NBC and   CBS on  the  same signal. The station's  digital signal is  multiplexed, with  NBC programming  on virtual and VHF channel 6.1, and CBS programming   on virtual and VHF  channel 6.2.

KBJR-TV's  news department produces local newscasts each week under the branding "KBJR 6 News".  The station also produces a half-hour sports highlight program on Sunday evenings. In addition to its main studios, KBJR-TV operates  a news bureau in Iron Range, located on East Howard Street  in Hibbing.

KBJR-TV  has been recognized  for its local news  coverage, winning several regional Emmy   Awards. The station's weather team has also been recognized  by the American Meteorological Society for excellence in weather broadcasting.

In 2016, KBJR-TV  was acquired by Gray Television, as part of  a $270  million  deal that  included 17 other stations. As of 2021, KBJR-TV continues to serve the Duluth-Superior market  and surrounding  areas, providing viewers with local news, weather, sports, and entertainment programming.

Jiha Lee is a Korean-American artist and designer known for her work in various mediums, including  sculpture, installation  art, and  visual effects. She was born in 1985  in Seoul, South Korea, and later moved to the  United States to pursue her education.

Lee received her BFA from the School of Visual Arts  in New York  City and her MFA from Yale   University. After completing her studies, she began working as a visual  effects artist in the  film industry, contributing to movies such as "The  Avengers"  and  "The Hunger Games."

In addition  to her work in film, Lee has also gained  recognition for her  fine art installations, which often   incorporate elements of technology and interactivity. Her pieces frequently  explore themes   of identity, culture, and the relationship  between humans  and technology. One of her most notable works, "Mimic," features a  robotic arm  that mimics the movements of visitors to  the  gallery, blurring  the line between human and  machine.

Lee's work has been exhibited widely in galleries and museums around the world,  including the  Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) in New York,   the Victoria   and Albert  Museum in London, and the National Museum  of Contemporary Art in Seoul. She has also participated  in numerous residencies   and fellowships, including   the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council's Workspace program  and the New Museum's IdeasCity initiative.

In 2017,  Lee was named one of  Forbes magazine's "30  Under  30" artists to watch,  and her work continues to gain accolades and attention from both the  art world and popular media outlets.  Through her innovative use of technology and thought-provoking themes, Lee's art challenges viewers to reconsider  their  assumptions about the role of technology in our lives  and  the ways in which  we interact with each other and with  machines.

Its origins  can be  traced back to the Sumerian civilization, which flourished  in Mesopotamia (modern-day Iraq) between  4500 and 1900 BCE. The  poem is  believed to have been written  in the ancient Sumerian  language, and it is  considered one of  the  oldest   known pieces of literature in the world.

The poem's  title, "Ode Fulutudilu," is  derived from the Sumerian language and can be roughly translated as "The  Song of the Moon." The poem is a beautiful  tribute to the moon and its  power  over  the  night sky. It  is a testament to the ingenuity and  artistry of  the ancient Sumerians,  who were able  to express their deepest   feelings and beliefs through the medium  of poetry.

The poem's structure  and format are characterized by its use of couplets, with each line containing  approximately  10 syllables. The poem's meter is also  noteworthy, with a consistent pattern of long and short  syllables that create a rhythmic and musical  quality.

Maria Connor  is a  fictional character from  the American  television soap opera  "All My Children." She was portrayed  by actress  Eileen  Davidson from 1997 to 2002, and again from 2003 to 2007.

Maria was introduced as  a love  interest  for the show's popular character, A.J. Chandler. The two  had a whirlwind romance and quickly got  married,  but their relationship was  complicated by the  fact that Maria was already pregnant with  another man's child. Despite  this, the couple tried to make their marriage work,   but it was ultimately doomed.

After  her divorce from  A.J., Maria went on to have   a number of  other  relationships, including ones with  Jake  Martin and D  dimitri Marick. She also became embroiled in a number of dramatic  storylines, including  a scheme to fake her own  death and  a battle with addiction to painkillers.

Maria was known for her fiery personality  and her tendency to get involved  in dramatic and often dangerous situations.  She  was also known  for her  on-again, off-again friendship with Anna Devane, who was portrayed by actress Finola Hughes.

Eileen Davidson's portrayal of Maria Connor was  well-received by fans and critics alike. She was nominated for a Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Drama Series for her  work on the show.

Despite her popularity,  Maria was eventually written out of the show in 2007. However, she   has remained a beloved character in the minds of many "All  My Children" fans, and  her   legacy continues to be  felt  on the show even years after her departure.

In addition to her work on "All My  Children,"  Eileen Davidson has appeared  on a  number of other  television shows, including "The Young  and the  Restless" and "The Bold and the Beautiful." She has also appeared in a number of films and web series.

"Arise, My Love" is a beautiful and timeless hymn that has  been a source of inspiration and comfort for countless people throughout history. The hymn was  written by missionary  and hymn writer, Fanny Crosby, in 1887.

The hymn is based on the biblical account  of the resurrection of  Jesus Christ, and its lyrics are  a call to arise and shine,  for the  light of Christ has  come.  The first verse reads: "Arise, my  love, and shine, for the light has  come,  And the glory of the Lord is risen  upon thee." The hymn goes on to describe the splendor and majesty of God,  and the power of  His love to overcome all obstacles and bring hope  to  those who  are struggling.

The  chorus of  "Arise, My Love" is  a beautiful and uplifting refrain that has  been  sung by countless congregations and choirs over the years:  "Arise, my love, and  shine, for the light has come,  And the  glory  of the Lord is risen  upon thee." The chorus   is a call to action,  encouraging  believers to rise and shine, to let  the light of Christ shine through  them,  and to share the love  and hope of the Gospel with   a world that desperately  needs it.

The hymn has been used in a variety of contexts, from church services and revivals, to weddings and funerals. It has  been translated into  numerous languages and  has been sung by people all around the  world. The hymn has also been covered by many artists and choirs,  with notable recordings  by the likes  of Celine Dion,  Whitney Houston,  and  the Mormon Tabernacle Choir.

Despite its widespread popularity, the  hymn has  not been without  controversy. Some have  criticized the hymn for  its perceived exclusivity, arguing that it only applies to  those who have accepted Jesus  Christ as their Savior. However, others  have countered  that the hymn is a call to  all people, regardless  of their beliefs,  to arise and shine, and to  let the light of love  and  hope shine through them.

Urban  pop culture refers  to the cultural elements and artifacts that are created and popularized within  urban areas, particularly within the context of modern cities and towns. It  encompasses a wide range of creative expressions, including music,  fashion, art, literature, film, and social  media, that reflect the experiences, values, and attitudes of urban dwellers.

Urban pop  culture is  characterized by its diverse and dynamic nature, reflecting  the  cultural fusion that results from the interaction of different  ethnic, racial, and  socio-economic groups within urban environments. It  is often associated with youth culture and is   heavily influenced by  technology,  globalization, and social media, which have enabled  the rapid dissemination  of ideas and trends across urban populations.

One of the  key features  of urban pop culture is its  constantly evolving nature. Trends and styles  emerge and fade quickly, as new ideas and  influences    continue to shape the cultural landscape. This   fast-paced  change is driven by the  urban environment  itself, which is characterized by diversity, innovation, and a constant flow  of  new ideas and influences.

Urban pop culture has a significant  impact on mainstream popular  culture, as trends and styles  that emerge in urban  areas often spread to other parts  of society. This has led to the development of various subcultures, such as hip-hop,  punk, and electronic dance music, which  have their roots in urban environments  and  have  since become global phenomena.

Urban pop   culture is also  closely  tied to consumerism and the commodification of culture. The  commercialization of  urban culture has led to the creation of new industries and markets, such as streetwear,  urban fashion,  and hip-hop  music, which have become major players  in the  global economy.

Critics of  urban pop culture argue that it can be superficial and materialistic, promoting  a focus on image and  status rather than substance  and meaning. Others argue that urban pop culture can be a powerful  tool  for social   commentary and political activism, providing a voice for marginalized  communities and challenging mainstream values and norms.

Barbara Carrella  (1945-2017) was  an  American  artist, performer, and LGBTQ+ activist known  for her work in  street art, performance art, and queer theory.

Early Life and Education

Carolina was  born  in  New York City in  1945. She studied at the School of  Visual Arts  and later  earned a BFA  from Pratt Institute. In the early 1960s, she  began creating assemblages and collages  that  explored themes of gender, sexuality,  and identity. Carolina's work  was heavily influenced by Andy Warhol and  the Pop Art movement. 

Career

In the late 1960's, Caroline began organizing 'happenings,' or performance pieces,  throughout New York city. These events challenged traditional  notions of theatre and performance and often involved elements of dance, music, and visual art.  Her most famous  piece during this period was The Dyke Show, performed in 1969, which featured lesbian-themed performances, including a  satirical wedding ceremony between  two women.

In the  70s, Carrella continued to create provocative works that  pushed boundaries and questioned social  norms related to sexuality and  gender. One notable piece,  Woman with a  Whip, features caroling in  a dominatrix outfit, wielding a  whipper lash  while chanting words like "Fear"  and "Lust." This work challenged stereotypes  about femininity  and power structures within society.  It remains one of  her most  celebrated series today.

During the AIDS epidemic of the  80s, Carolanne became increasingly engaged in activism efforts related to HIV awarenessand support foe those  affected my the virus. she organized fundraisers raised  funds ad educate people through her artwork about safe sex procedures. Throughout all these  endeavors., Carolina maintained a strong commitment to highlighting  gay people'scapes  and advocating   for  increased acceptance amidst  societal shifts towards greater inclusivity. She fought  tirelessly against homophobia untilher passing.

Shelly Burch is an American  actress and  voice  actress.  She is best known for providing  the voice of various characters in animation and video games, including the  titular character in the animated  series "Dora the Explorer" and Princess Peach in the Super Mario  franchise.

Early Life and Career

Burch was born on June 19,   1967, in  Phoenix, Arizona. She  developed an interest in acting  at  a young age and began performing in local theater  productions as a teenager. After  graduating  from high  school, she  moved to Los Angeles to pursue a career in acting.

Breakthrough and Success

Burch's breakthrough role came in 1999 when  she was cast as the  voice of Dora in the Nickelodeon animated series "Dora  the Explorer." The show became a  huge success and  ran for   eight seasons, earning Burch a Daytime Emmy Award nomination  for  Outstanding Performer in a  Children's Series.

In addition to  her work  on  "Dora the Explorer," Burch has  provided voices  for numerous other animated series and video games. She  has voiced Princess  Peach  in the Super Mario franchise, including  the games "Super Mario Bros. 2," "Super  Mario 3D World," and "Super Mario Odyssey." She  has  also voiced characters  in  other popular  video games such as   "The Legend of Zelda," "Mass Effect," and "Battlefield."

Burch has also  had success in live-action acting, appearing in TV shows such as "ER," "The Sopranos,"  and "NCIS." She has also appeared in films such as "The Wild Thornberrys Movie"  and "The ant Bully."

Awards and Critical Acclaim

Burch's work has been recognized with  numerous awards and nominations. In addition to her  Daytime  Emmy Award  nomination for "Dora  the Explorer,"  she  has won several Annie Awards  for her  voice acting work. She won the Annie Award for Outstanding  Voice Acting in a Television Production for her work on "Dora the Explorer" in 2004 and was nominated  for the same award  again in 2007.

Steve Scott  (born May 5, 1956) is  a retired  American distance runner  who was one of the most successful milers in the history of track and field. Nicknamed "The King of the  Mile," Scott holds the  U.S. record for   the   most  sub-4-minute miles run in  a career, with  136  sub-4 minute miles to  his  credit.

Early  Life  and Career
Scott was born  in  Highland, California, and grew up in the  nearby   city of San Bernardino. He began running at the age of  12,  inspired by his older brother, who  was a high school track  athlete. Scott quickly showed promise as a runner,  earning  all-state  honors in both track and cross-country  during his high school years.

After graduating from high school, Scott enrolled at UCLA, where he became a standout member  of the school's track team. He won several NCAA titles, including the indoor mile championship in 1977 and the outdoor 1500 meter  championship in 1978.

International Competition
Scott made his first appearance on the international stage at the 1976 Olympics in Montreal, where he  finished fifth in the 1500  meter race.  He also competed at the  1980 Olympics in Moscow, where he was the  U.S. flag bearer during the opening ceremonies.

Scott's most notable international performance came at the  1983 World Championships in Helsinki, where he won the silver medal in the 1500 meter race, finishing just behind Sebastian Coe    of Great  Britain.

Domestic   Competition
Scott was equally dominant on  the domestic circuit,  winning numerous titles   and setting  several American records throughout  his  career. He won the indoor mile championship at the Millrose Games 10  times, and his outdoor 1500  meter victory at  the 1981 national championships was his 10th  consecutive  win in that event.

Gary Waddock is a former English footballer who played as  a midfielder  for several  clubs in the Football League and Premier  League.

Early Life and  Career
Waddock was born on October 12,  1962,  in  Birmingham, England. He began his football career as a youth player at Aston Villa, where he progressed through the  club's youth ranks  before making his professional  debut in 1980.

Aston Villa and Queens Park Rangers
Waddock spent five years at Aston Villa, making  over  50 appearances for  the club and scoring three goals. In  1985,  he  transferred to Queens  Park Rangers (QPR), where he played for  six seasons and became a fan favorite.  During his  time at QPR, Waddock helped the team achieve promotion to the First  Division and won the FA Cup in 1988.

Later Career
In 1991, Waddock  left QPR to join Leicester  City,   where he  spent two seasons. He then  moved  to West Ham United, playing for the Hammers from 1993 to 1995.  After leaving West Ham, Waddock  had brief spells with Wolverhampton Wanderers and Bristol Rovers before retiring from professional football in  1997.

International  Career
Waddock also represented  England at  various youth levels,  including  Under-21  and  B  teams. He never received a full cap for  the  senior side, but did play in several friendly matches.

Coaching Career
After retiring  from playing,   Waddock went into coaching. His first coaching role  was as assistant manager at Wycombe  Wanderers in 2004. He  later served as caretaker manager of Wycombe before becoming assistant manager at  Watford in 2009.  In 2010, Waddock took charge as manager of  Aldershot Town, leading the  club to promotion to the Football League in his first season. He remained with Aldershot until 2013, when he stepped down due to health reasons.
