Fadanpura is a  small village located in the Jhunjhunu district of Rajasthan, India. It is situated approximately  20 kilometers south of the  district headquarters, Jhunjhunu, and 15 kilometers north of the  town of  Chirawa. The village is known for its  rich cultural heritage and historical significance, and is home  to several ancient temples  and  monuments.

History

Fadanpura has  a long and storied   history, with evidence  of human habitation dating back to  the 10th century. The village was an important center  of Jainism, an ancient religion that originated in India, and was a major pilgrimage  site for Jain devotees.  The village  is home to several Jain temples,  including the Mahavir Swami Temple, which  is dedicated to  the founder of Jainism, Lord Mahavir.

The village was  also an important center  of learning and education, with several ancient schools and libraries. The village was known for its scholars and poets, who made significant  contributions to the development of Rajasthani literature.

Culture

Fadanpura is  known for its   rich cultural  heritage, which is reflected in its festivals, music, and art.  The village celebrates several festivals throughout the year, including the festival of Holi, which is celebrated to  mark the  arrival of spring, and the festival of Diwali,  which is celebrated to  mark the victory of  light  over  darkness.

The village is  also known for  its  traditional  music and  dance,  which are an  integral part of the local   culture. The villagers are skilled in traditional   instruments  such as the  dholak, nagini, and sarangi, and are known for their folk songs and dances, such as the Ghoomar and the Kachchi   Ghori.

Economy

The economy of Fadanpura is primarily agricultural, with the main crops being  wheat, barley,  and pulses. The  village is also  known  for its traditional crafts, such as pottery, weaving, and metalwork. The villagers  are skilled  artisans, and their wares are  sold in local markets  and beyond.

Jessie Brewer (born 1970) is an American actress. She  is   best known  for her role as  the title character in the 1989 film, The Little Mermaid.

## Early life

Brewer was born in Los Angeles, California. She is the daughter of actress and  singer, Barbara Eden, and  actor Michael Ansara. She has a  younger brother, Matthew Ansara.

##  Career

Brewer began her career as a  child actress, appearing in   several television shows and films. She is  best known for her role as the  title character in  the 1989 film, The Little Mermaid. She also appeared in   the  films,  The Boy  Who Could Fly and  The Boy Who Cried  Werewolf.

## Personal life

Brewer  is married  to  actor, Michael Cudlitz. They have two children  together.

The United  Kingdom and Brazil have had diplomatic relations since 1825,   when the two  countries signed a treaty of friendship and commerce. Since then, both nations  have  maintained close  ties  in various fields such as trade, culture, education, science and  technology. In recent years there   has been  increased cooperation between  the UK and Brazil on issues related to climate  change, sustainable   development,  renewable energy sources among  others. Additionally they share common interests regarding international security matters including counter-terrorism efforts worldwide. Furthermore  they  are members of several multinational organisations like G20 or BRICS which helps them work together towards   achieving  global goals that benefit all humanity alike.

## History[edit]

### Early history (16th century –  19th century)[edit]

In 1534, King  John  III  of Portugal sent Pedro Álvares Cabral  with four ships to explore new lands for his kingdom.^{[1]} On April 22nd he arrived at what would become known as Rio de Janeiro Bay where he  claimed possession over any   land found within  its  boundaries  under Portuguese  rule.^{[2]} This marked the beginning of European colonization in South America by Spain followed shortly after by France  who also laid claim  upon parts of modern   day Brazil during this period.^{[3]} However it wasn't until 1763  when Britain officially recognized Portugal’s sovereignty over most areas  now comprising present  day  Brazil through Treaty Of  Madrid.^{[4]}

During  much of their early interactions  British merchants were involved heavily into trading activities throughout coastal  regions along  Atlantic Ocean coastline while simultaneously engaging local populations living nearby  these ports towns cities villages etcetera…^{[5]} As time progressed however  tensions began rising  due   largely because many Britons  felt unfairly treated vis-à-vis taxes tariffs duties customs regulations imposed upon them by authorities governing territory occupied by Portuguese crown.^{[6]} These grievances eventually led up  revolts rebellions insurrections riots protests demonstrations marches rallies sit-ins  strikes  boycotts picketing blockades occupations sieges sabotage  acts terrorism violence  civil unrest disorder chaos  lawlessness anarchy mayhem pandemonium bedlam  turmoil strife  discord contention  conflict antagonism animosity enmity hostility hatred  malice ill  will

Henry Pike Bowie (1815–1889) was an  American  politician and lawyer. He   was  a member of the United States House of Representatives from 1853  to 1855, representing the 1st District of Arkansas.

## Early life and career

Bowie was born  in 1815  in  Tennessee. He attended the common schools and studied law.  He was admitted  to the bar in 1837 and commenced practice   in Little Rock, Arkansas.  He was  a member  of the Arkansas House of Representatives  in 1841 and 1842. He was a  member of  the  Arkansas State Senate from 1843 to  1845. He was a member  of the Arkansas Secession Convention  in 1861.

Robert William "Robbie"  Wills (born 1968) is  a   British television presenter and  journalist,  best known for his work on BBC News and as co-presenter   of the BBC's flagship news programme, Breakfast with Frost. He has also presented the BBC One current affairs series Inside  Out in  London since  its launch in September 2004.

Wills  was born in Belfast, Northern Ireland, but grew up in England. His father worked at the  BBC World Service. After studying  English Literature at Oxford  University he joined  the BBC  as a trainee reporter  in 1993. In  1995 he became a producer/reporter for  Radio Five Live before moving to BBC Television News in 1997 where he reported for both national  and regional  programmes including Newsnight,  Panorama and South Today.

In   January 2000 he moved to the BBC's Westminster  political unit where  he covered stories  such as the foot and mouth crisis, the    death of Princess Diana and the war against terrorism. During this time he  also appeared regularly on BBC Two's Daily  Politics  show.

He left the  political team in March 2003 to become  one of the main reporters on the BBC's new breakfast  programme  Breakfast with Frost which launched later that year. Since then he has been a regular contributor to other BBC programmes including  Question  Time,  Any Questions?,  Sunday  AM and The  Review Show.

Since April 2004 he has also been presenting the weekly magazine programme Inside Out in  London.

Lyndsay Stephen

Lyndsay Stephen is the owner and founder of  Cake Design, which has been featured  on popular television shows like: Howie Do  It, The Wedding Specialists, MTV The After Show, Much Music,  and CBC  Television.

Stephen lives in Toronto, Canada.

A Canadian born, self taught baker, Stephen has become one of  the  most talented wedding cake designers in North America. Her wedding cakes, which vary in design, size, and price, run from $1000  to $6000.

With over  15  years of experience in the  industry,  Stephen is one  of the  most popular cake  designers  in Canada as well  as  in the United States where her work has been  featured in The Cake Book.

Cake Design also has the option  of taking their designs  to your wedding, for on-site   demonstrations. Stephen  and her team  of cake artists perform  live demonstrations   at various bridal shows, as  well as at weddings and corporate functions.

Pau-Latina is  a Brazilian city in  the state of Minas Gerais. It is located in the northwest  of the  state,  in the region of the Triângulo Mineiro and Alto Paranaíba. Its population was 10,700 (2007) and  its area is  1,000 km².

The city is  located in the valley of the  river Pau-Latina, which  gives the city  its name. The  city is located  in the  northwest of the state of Minas Gerais, in the region of the Triângulo Mineiro  and  Alto Paranaíba.  It is located   300  km  from the state capital, Belo Horizonte.

Muruganantham, popularly known as N.  Murali (born 1968), is a social entrepreneur and inventor who developed low-cost sanitary  napkins in India for women living below poverty line. He was born to a poor  family in Coimbatore district,  Tamil Nadu, India. His father worked  as a farmer and his  mother was  a housewife. Muruganantham dropped  out of school after  completing tenth grade due to financial constraints. After working at various jobs  including selling bicycle  parts, he started a small  business manufacturing agricultural  tools.  In 2005, while visiting his  wife  Shanthi during her menstrual cycle, he noticed  that she used old rags instead of disposable pads because they were too expensive. This led him to  investigate how commercial sanitary napkins are  made. When he asked local manufacturers  about their production process,  they refused to tell him anything.  So he decided  to make them himself by  collecting blood stained clothes from hospitals   and using it to create prototypes. To test these  products on  human skin, he  began wearing one  of the prototypes himself. However, this caused severe  health problems  such as  urinary tract infection and genital ulcers. Eventually, he found a  way to produce  affordable sanitary napkins with  high quality standards.

In 2007, he founded Jayaashree Industries Pvt Ltd., which manufactures  low cost sanitary  napkins under the brand name “Jayashri”.  These  products have  been distributed free of    charge through government schools across India since 2008. As part  of its corporate responsibility program, Jayashree also provides  training courses for rural  women entrepreneurs  interested in starting similar businesses.  By 2013,  over  4  million girls had received free hygiene kits containing  reusable  cloth pads manufactured by Jayashree.  In addition, more than 100,000 women  have attended workshops conducted by Jayashree staff members.

## Early life[edit]

Arunachalam Muruganantham was born into  a middle class family  in Kovilpatti village near Madurai city, Tamil Nadu  state, southern India.^{[1]}  His parents  were farmers who owned less than two acres of land.^{[2

## [edit]    Summer

The temperature varies greatly throughout the year, with a much warmer  summer and winter than New York City, and significantly colder  winters by comparison to nearby cities such as Albany and Boston. Winter lows around 23 °F or −5 °C are recorded more often in Kingston  than  Albany but infrequently compared to the coldest northeastern  major cities. Highest wind speeds reported  at Kennedy Airport have been comparable to Kingston's 60 to  even 74 knots  high winds during the severe nor’easters of  February, March, April and December as   well as Hurricane Gloria of 1985 (category 1 hurricane that came out over   eastern Long Island  killing four people).^{[citation needed]}  Snow events occur roughly three  times per year typically; however,  heavy snow falls  only once  every two  years on average.  Average monthly  precipitation exceeds eight inches  between May and September,  and peaks  in July due to its thunderstorm activity.^{[1]} In winter  heavy rainfall can fall overnight causing flooding when storms originate near Cape Hatteras.

During drought situations the Hudson River may  diminish  leaving  shallow marshy areas where normally the river would meet the harbor tide line. The Rondout Creek also  tends to decrease in flow  so that bridges near it may  become  impassable for  ships that require deep  water draft for passage.

Kingston  has many  parks including one of six of the United States  Military Academy  at West Point on the Hudson River just across the Esopus river valley east of Kingston.^{[}In the mid-twentieth century there was also a United  States Air Force Base named Kingston Airbase which opened a new highway along Lake Katrine connecting Ulster County Route 9W into downtown  Kingstown. However, it fell victim to  the military base cuts under  President  Carter during fiscal   crisis  era. On  weekends, Kingston offers numerous  free and noteworthy art galleries  featuring photography    exhibits within  walking distance next to the main  business area of Wall  Street  called uptown Uptown District also  bordering the college area of Plaza Midtown   campus district called downtown. Both these  districts show  signs of urban revival after long  periods   of disinvestment.^{[2]}

Andrew Meikle (1766 – 8 April  1818) was a Scottish inventor, mechanical engineer, and manufacturer, widely  regarded  as the "Father  of the Steam Engine". He is best known for  his improvements to the Newcomen  atmospheric  engine, which he patented in 1784.  Meikle's inventions and innovations greatly  contributed to the development of the steam  engine, which in turn revolutionized transportation, manufacturing, and mining.

Early life and education

Andrew Meikle was born   in 1766 in the village of Hamilton, near Lanarkshire, Scotland. He was the son of a blacksmith, and his father's brother was a millwright. Meikle received a basic education at a local  school, but he was largely   self-taught in  mechanics and engineering. As a child, he was fascinated  by machinery and  spent much  of  his  free time tinkering  with engines and gears.

Invention of the  improved  Newcomen  engine

In 1784, Meikle patented an improved version of the Newcomen atmospheric engine, which had been invented a decade earlier. The Newcomen engine  was a type of steam engine  that used  a  piston to  convert steam pressure  into mechanical work. However,  it had several limitations,  including  the fact that it could   only be used  to pump  water,  and it  was inefficient at converting steam energy into useful work.

Meikle's  improvements to the Newcomen engine addressed these  limitations. He replaced  the piston  with  a  larger, more efficient one, and he  added a condenser to the engine, which allowed the steam to be cooled and condensed more  efficiently. These improvements greatly increased the efficiency  of  the engine,  making it more versatile and useful for a wider range of applications.

Impact on  industry and transportation

Meikle's  improvements  to the Newcomen engine had a profound  impact  on industry and transportation.  The steam  engine became a key component  of  the Industrial Revolution, powering  the machines that drove  the factories and mills that produced the goods that fueled   the growth of the British Empire.

The steam engine also revolutionized transportation, allowing for the development of steamships and steam-powered locomotives. This

Aveline  de Grandpré (c. 1290 – c. 1345) was  an English noblewoman and patroness, who played  a significant  role in the Hundred  Years' War between England  and  France.  She married Sir Richard de Clare,  7th Earl of Gloucester, one of King  Edward III's most  powerful nobles, in 1318.

Through her marriage to Gloucester,  Aveline became closely associated with the royal court and played  a key role in political intrigue  during  the early years of  the Hundred  Years' War. In 1337, she was involved in a plot to assassinate King Henry II of France, which ultimately failed. However, her  involvement  in  this plot earned her  the  enmity  of both the French king and his advisors.

In  addition to her political activities,  Aveline was  also known for her patronage  of  the arts and sciences.  She   supported several  notable writers and scholars, including Geoffrey Chaucer, who  dedicated his poem The Knight's Tale to her. She also established a convent at Soham in  Norfolk, where she spent much of her later life.

Despite her controversial reputation,  Aveline is  remembered  as an important  figure in medieval English history. Her close association with the royal court and her support of the  arts  and sciences helped to shape the cultural landscape of England during the Hundred Years' War.

Joyce  Alyssa Robertson (born July 7,  1956) is an American television personality and motivational speaker.  She is best known for  hosting  the popular Christian television program Celebration of Faith with Joyce Robertson, which  has  been broadcasting since 2004.

Born in Stamford,  Connecticut, Robertson grew up as  a member  of First Assembly of God  Church in West Haven, where she was baptized at age 8. Her parents were missionaries   to Peru and  Colombia and spent many years   abroad in South America. This  early exposure to missions fostered a lifelong passion for helping others.

Robertson  attended Southern  Methodist University and earned her bachelor's degree in Business Administration  in 1978 and her master's degree  in International Management from Thunderbird School  of Global Management in 2007.

Rafael Montes  is a Brazilian Christian evangelist and founder of  the  Assemblies of  God in  Brazil. He was  born on July 28, 1939, in Recife, Pernambuco, Brazil. As  a child, he attended a Catholic church  with his  family, but he did not feel a sense of  salvation until he attended an Assemblies   of God crusade in 1958. There, he  encountered the  teachings of the Assemblies of God and felt a strong sense of  calling to preach the Gospel.

After accepting Christ,  Montes  began attending a Bible institute in São  Paulo,  Brazil, where he   studied  theology and evangelism. In 1964, he married his first  wife, Vera. They had three children together before divorcing in  1972.  In 1968, Montes met his second wife, Elena, and they  had two children  together.

Montes began preaching  the Gospel in earnest after  his conversion and quickly became an  effective communicator. He started his own  church in São Paulo and soon realized that there were many other cities in Brazil that were in  need of hearing the Gospel. In 1974, he founded the Assemblies of  God in Brazil,  which grew rapidly  and eventually became one of the largest Christian organizations in the  country.

Montes' messages focused on the importance of evangelism and the need  for people to accept Jesus  Christ as their Lord and Savior. He often spoke about the transformative power of the Holy Spirit and encouraged people  to  live their lives in obedience  to God.

Montes was known for  his charismatic leadership  and his ability to  inspire others to become evangelists themselves. He traveled extensively throughout  Brazil, preaching in  churches and holding large crusades in cities  across the country. In addition  to  his work  with the Assemblies of God, he also served as a  board member of  the World Evangelization Council,   an  organization dedicated to  spreading the Gospel  globally.

Montes passed away on  August 31, 2017, leaving behind a legacy of ministry  and  compassion. He was a dedicated  follower of Jesus Christ, a passionate evangelist,  and  a beloved leader  among the people he   helped to bring to  faith

Suzy Whaley (born 1968) is an American politician   from the state of Indiana.  She has been serving as the Secretary of State of Indiana since January 2005, and was previously in  the  Indiana General Assembly for seven terms representing District 33 in Hamilton County.

Whaley attended Ball State University where she earned her Bachelor's degree in sociology and  her  Master's degree in  public  administration. While there, she met and married longtime friend Greg Whaley, who represented District 76  in the   state House before resigning to join his wife  in the secretary's office.  They have  two  children  together,  Jake, named after  Greg's father, and Emily.

Upon entering office, Whaley became the first female Secretary of  State  of Indiana and the youngest elected official in  the country at  age 37. In July  2009, she successfully led  Indiana  through a major  redistricting  process to establish new electoral districts  based on the results of the  2010 census.

The  Savonians (Latin: Savonii,  also  known as  the Savones or Soanii) were an ancient Italianized  Germanic tribe that inhabited  the region that is now the Provence and part of the Languedoc-Roussillon in southern France. They are believed to have been among the  earliest  Germanic tribes to  have been  Christianized, and  their language,  known   as Savonic or Langobardic, survived for many  centuries in their region.

The  Savonians are first mentioned in the mid-2nd century CE  as living on the  coast of the Mediterranean Sea. They appear to  have been the  first Germanic tribe to have been conquered and incorporated into the Roman Empire. During  the 3rd century CE, they played   a  significant role in the Visigothic conquest of the Kingdom of  Aquitaine, defeating the  Roman forces at the Battle of Poitiers. The Savonians are  believed to have  eventually merged  with the Goths  and established the Kingdom of the Ostrogoths.

The Savonians are best  known for their contribution to the history of Roman warfare.  During the time of Caesar,  they were recruited into  the Roman army as legionaries,   becoming known as the Alamanni or "mountain men". They served  in several major military campaigns  and are credited with saving Rome during  the  Siege of the Teutonian Knights  in 50-51.

In 465, the  Visigoths  under Alaric invaded the city of  Narbonne  and laid siege  for ten months. The Savonians, under the leadership of their king, Sarus, were fighting alongside the Romans when the siege was lifted by the arrival of the forces of   Clovis I, king of the Franks. After  Clovis  defeated the Visigoths at the Battle of Chlodio, he conquered the Savonians and  incorporated them into his Franklin realm.

The  Savonians continued    to speak their own   language, known as Savonic or Langobardic, which  eventually evolved into the Romance language of Occitan or Provencal. Some of the most famous occupational names in the Occitan-speaking region, including   Boutin, Beauchamp,  and  Boileau, have their  origins in Sav

Moritz von Auffenberg (18 May 1868  – 25  January 1945) was a German politician of  the Bavarian  People's Party (CSU).

## Early life and  education

Moritz  von  Auffenberg was born on 18   May  1868 in Munich, Kingdom of Bavaria, German  Empire. He  studied  law at the Ludwig Maximilian University   of   Munich and passed the first and second state  examinations in 1890  and 1892. He then worked  as a lawyer in  Munich until 1900.

## Political  career

In 1900, von Auffenberg became a member of the Bavarian  Landtag (state parliament) representing the constituency of Munich-Ost. He was re-elected in 1904, 1908, 1912, 1916, 1919, 1920,  1924, 1928, 1932, and  1936.

In 1906,  von Auffenberg  became a member of the  Reichstag  (federal parliament) representing the  constituency  of Munich-Ost. He was re-elected in  1912, 1916,  1919,  1920, 1924, 1928, 1932, and 1936.

In 1919, von Auffenberg was one of the signatories of the Weimar Constitution, which established the Weimar Republic.

In 1933, von Auffenberg was one  of the 92 members of the Reichstag who voted against the Enabling Act, which  gave Adolf Hitler   and the Nazi Party dictatorial powers.

## Death

On 25 January 1945, von Auffenberg was killed in action while  fighting against the Nazi regime during World War II.

Motto Moriagaro (本庚) is a fictional village featured in  Natsume's Book  of Friends. It is  located  in Hokkaido  and was named  after a legendary king who defeated an evil dragon that terrorized the region centuries ago.

The village  is home  to several influential spirits, including Reimu,  Natsume Takumo,  Touko, and Megumi. It is known for  its beautiful forests, clear lakes, and stunning  mountain ranges. The residents of Motto Moriagaro are friendly and welcoming, always eager to help those  in need. However, they take great pride in  their sense of community and will often band  together to  protect one another.

In terms of  architecture,  Motto  Moriagaro features traditional Japanese-style  buildings made from wood and paper. These structures blend seamlessly with the natural  surroundings, creating a peaceful atmosphere that has made  it a  popular destination for tourists and outdoor enthusiasts alike.  There is  also a  large spiritual energy center in the heart of the  village which serves as the headquarters of  Natsume's organization, called the Yotsuya Shrine (狭谷神社).  This  shrine draws  on  powerful spiritual energies, allowing  users to harness it for various purposes such as exorcising demons or   healing  others wounded by  supernatural forces.

Alfonso Gómez  (born 1960) is a Mexican-American artist and musician. He is best known for his work as a member of  the band  Los Fabulosos Cadillacs, with   which   he has  released numerous albums and toured extensively throughout the world.

Gómez was born  in  Mexico City, Mexico, but moved to the United  States with his  family when he was young. He grew up  in the San Francisco Bay  Area, where he was exposed to  a wide variety  of   musical  styles, including Latin, rock, and jazz.

In  the early 1980s, Gómez  formed Los Fabulosos Cadillacs with his brother  Ricardo and  their friend Gustavo. The band quickly gained a following  in the  San Francisco area, and in 1988 they released their debut album, "Los  Fabulosos  Cadillacs".  The album  was  a critical and commercial  success, and it helped to establish the band as one  of the leading voices in  Latin alternative music.

Over the  years, Los  Fabulosos Cadillacs have  released  numerous albums, including "La Vida Loca" (1991),  "El Cielo" (1993), and "Revolution" (1996). The  band has also toured extensively throughout the world, performing in countries such as the United States, Europe, and Latin  America.

In addition to his work with Los Fabulosos Cadillacs, Gómez has also pursued a solo career. He  has released several solo albums, including "El Cielo" (1993) and  "La Vida Loca"  (1991). He has also collaborated with other  artists, including the band  Tijuana No! and the musician Carlos Santana.

Gómez is known for his unique style, which combines elements of Latin,  rock,  and jazz  music.  He is also  known for  his energetic live performances, which often feature elaborate   costumes and theatrical elements.

Upnor  Castle is  a partial moated castle located  in the  English county of Hampshire, close to the city  of  Portsmouth  and  southwest  of the village of Upnor.  Built on an  island formed by the confluence  of   the  River Test  with the estuary of  the Solent, it has  been described as both a fortress and a palace. The site  occupies approximately 12  hectares (30 acres), is Grade I listed by Historic England, and is owned  by the Ministry of Defence.

History
=======

The origins of a fortification on this site date back at least to  the Roman period; fragments of Roman brickwork have been found within the ramparts, and a coin dating from AD 67  was discovered  nearby. However,  the  first known  structure on  the  site was built during the reign of King John in the late  12th century; its function remains uncertain but may  have served as a royal hunting lodge or a defensive  fortress  against Welsh raiders. If so,  it would  have marked  the western terminus  of what later became the Wall of  King Henry VIII,  which protected the shores   of Portsmouth Harbour  from  invasion threats posed by France.

In the years following  the Norman Conquest of England, the estate fell into  disrepair before  being restored under the guidance of  Prince Richard III toward the  end of his reign. It continued to serve variously as a royal residence and military stronghold until  the mid-17th century when it passed into  private hands. During James II's  unsuccessful attempt to reclaim his lost throne in 1688,  the castle was captured by loyalists supporting William  III. Afterwards, it declined further until its eventual demolition in the early 18th century except   for parts of its outer walls that now form part  of  England's Coastal Defense Line.

Inositol-trisphosphate 3-kinase (ITPK) is an enzyme in the inositol phospholipid  metabolism pathway. It catalyzes the phosphorylation of  inositol-1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3)  to produce inositol-1,4,5-trisphosphate  3-kinase (IP3  3-kinase) and  inositol-1-phosphate. IP3 3-kinase   is then converted  back to IP3  by the  action of inositol  monophosphatase.

ITPK  is a member of the inositol  phospholipid 3-kinase family, which also  includes phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K)  and phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PIKfyve).  ITPK is expressed in various tissues, including muscle, liver,   and brain.  It   plays a  role in regulating cell  signaling and  metabolism.

Mutations in  the ITPK gene have been associated  with various diseases, including  muscle disorders, liver diseases, and neurological disorders. For example,  mutations in  the ITPK gene have been  linked to Duchenne muscular dystrophy, a X-linked recessive  disorder that affects muscle function and leads to progressive muscle weakness and  wasting.

ITPK is  also involved  in the regulation of glucose metabolism. It  has  been shown  to play a role  in the activation  of AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK), which is a key regulator of cellular energy homeostasis. ITPK has  also been shown to regulate the activity of the mTORC1 complex, which is involved in the regulation of cell growth and metabolism.

Overall, ITPK is an important enzyme in the inositol phospholipid metabolism pathway and plays a role in regulating  cell signaling and metabolism. Mutations in  the ITPK gene have been associated with various diseases,  and further research is needed to fully  understand its function and regulation.

In 1797 a group led by John and William Fairfax purchased land in what  was  then Cumberland County  (now Adams) for $1 per  acre to establish their own  community.[2]  The town's name came about  when one member suggested that they call it after  his hometown back east; another  said he  would do so if  someone else named theirs as well—and thus  two towns were  born with identical names on  opposite sides of America! In 1803 this area became part  again within York county  boundaries until 1961 whereupon all three  counties merged into today’s  single  entity known simply “York”. This small village has been  home over time not  only farmers but also many other types including millers who   worked at nearby mills along Big  Spring Run creek which flows through  most parts  hereabouts before  emptying out near Gettysburg battlefield site just south  west across Route  30 highway bridge spanning both  banks together forming natural boundary line between  these neighboring communities now united  under common banner shared among them  –“We Are  One!”[3][4].

In  Christianity, a higher life refers to any Christian experience that goes  beyond what  one might expect in ordinary church membership or attendance.[1] The term was used by Charles Finney  and  others during his time as part of their revivalist  efforts;  it   has also been applied more recently within  Pentecostalism (see Holiness  Movement) where  there    are many different views on how this can be achieved[2]. In some cases these experiences have led people  into new denominations  such those founded around William J Seymour's Azusa Street Revival which began with  black Americans  but  spread throughout North America before World War I  when white  Christians joined them at meetings held outdoors under tents called 'tabernacles'. This  type became known simply because they were often  located  near railroad tracks so trains  could stop nearby while passengers waited for connections elsewhere along its route - hence  our modern word taboo  comes directly outta here too! It all started  back then though not just  among African-Americans either since  whites had already  begun  attending services together long ago even if  only sporadically due mainly  economic reasons rather than religious ones  per  se."

" _Hithi Nimun_ (හිති හින්තො  විමුණ) (also translated  as Two Sips) is a Sinhala short story written by Martin Wickremasinghe and published  in 1962. _Two Sips_ is  a  story which depicts an average day  in the lives  of Sri  Lankan lower middle class families,  where an  argument starts over the milk in the morning, and continues about  what should be  cooked  for lunch and dinner and finally results  in a husband beating up his wife, who  was   found guilty by her  husband for two sips  she took while he was asleep. In the end  the  wife and husband forgive each other. The  story is considered  to be a  classic in the history  of the   Sinhala short stories. Since then the name " _Hithi Nimun_  " has  entered the Sinhala language in the sense of  a very small  argument or disagreement or two  sips."

#

#

HITHI NIMUN

"Do you  want milk or  not?" the  wife asked.

"I'll  just have two  sips. You've had enough."

"It's  your turn to have the milk."

"And have it with my   tea as well."

"The milk gets sour if we keep it  overnight for your tea."

"You do as you feel is right."

"You can take it if you want, but  I take  it only once."

"I'm not interested in milk any more."

"Then there's nothing   to  discuss."

As soon as he heard the sound of the matchbox  lid  snapping, she knew that she had lost the argument. He would have  a smoke and stay up all night. She  took half a glass  of milk. The glass was  left on  the table. The clock ticked for  a while.

"You want some  too?"

"No."

She put her hand on  the glass.  He lit a cigarette and blew out the match.

"You can't even leave  two sips for me?"

"What, after you had milk in the mornings and evenings?"

"There is a huge difference between a girl without her  clothes, and a girl who has clothes but takes them off," says  the character of Sindhu, aka   Shalini, in Kammattipadam, the 2002 Malayalam film written by  M. T. Vasudevan Nair. Sindhu's character, who happens to  be  one of the  several who  strip  to get  into heaven, was  played by Shalini, who  was  just sixteen  at  the time,  but she was no virgin.
It was a character  who went on  to become iconic in a film that made Shalini an instant star. Shalini won the Kerala state film award for best actress in her debut film, and received a National Award the following year for  Innale,  directed by Kamal. Since then, she has  won a number of prestigious awards, and is currently  one  of the most  sought-after stars of  Malayalam Cinema. However, the actress  is well aware that she  should not rest on her   laurels, and has  therefore notched up at least one film a year since she debuted  fifteen years ago. This has earned her the reputation of being a "workaholic", which she claims she  embraces  "with pride."  Indeed, even while writing this  piece she  was supposed  to be shooting for Kavithalayam, another film in  which she is pitted against her long-time rival, Roma—a competition that  continues to be  viewed as a healthy  contest.
The  thirty-four  year old actress, who was born in a middle-class family, was a very studious child.  "I read all the time. I  started  reading a bit  too soon. She never went out with her  classmates, and  used her spare  time to read everything she could lay her hands on. "Reading  has been a  passion of  mine right from  the beginning."

ABDULAZIZ AL-SHUHBAILY
(c. 1948  - )
Abdulaziz al-Shubaily is a  Saudi Arabian dissident journalist best known for having  been imprisoned  for 9  years by  the Saudi authorities for allegedly "undermining Islamic   religious sentiments" and supporting "the Palestinian cause".[1] In 2003, he was briefly released in exchange for Sheikh Ali al-Omari.[2] However, he was rearrested  upon his subsequent return from  a medical trip and  tried again by the Specialized  Criminal  Court in Riyadh. The first sentence for al-Shubaily came in September   2003, when  he was  sentenced to  12 years in prison,   an  additional three in exile,  and a 20  million riyal fine for  having made "denigrating"  remarks  against senior government and   religious officials. He  was also banned from any other media activities for a period of 10 years.[2]
However, the new sentences passed against al-Shubaily were in  addition to three others he had received  earlier, the total  of which is 21 years in  prison, 10 years in exile  and  a fine of  10 million riyals. The new sentences, he said, were harsh "even for murderers, thieves  and molesters."[2] During the third trial, the  judge was replaced. An appeal was expected  to be filed with the Saudi Supreme Court against the verdict of the Specialized Criminal  Court.  Al-Shubaily has since been released.
Al-Shubaily is also known to be the  second son of Saudi billionaire Abdullah Saif al-Shubailly, who  played an important role  in founding the Saudi-US friendship  societies. His older brother, Sultan  Saif al-Shubailly is a prominent Arab  American activist.
Al-Shubaily was born in Riyadh and studied at the  University of Colorado (1970-1971) & University of  Alabama (1971-1972). At  first, he  contributed articles   and short stories to Saudi weeklies, magazines and newspapers. Following the  execution of  one of his  colleagues, Jamal  Idris, Al-Shubaily decided to quit  his job as a television executive at the Saudi Ministry of Information, which has caused much criticism among Saudi activists.
In addition to  the  aforementioned imprisonment, al-Shubaily has also  been subjected  to  numerous  harassments and intimidation

Gordon Hughes is a famous British   actor   and director. After  gaining some recognition with Shakespearean roles in London's  West End, Hughes moved to the United States in 1969. Hughes gained widespread attention  and critical  acclaim  for  his brilliant portrayal of the title character in the film _Ziggy's  Girlfriend_, which was  a landmark film in  the depiction of gays in the  movies. His star shone brightly in the 1980s, when he was given a  regular role  on   TV in the hit series _Just an American_. He received two Emmy awards for his role as gay attorney Jason Cavanaugh. His career cooled  off in the 1990s, but  he  bounced back after  the publication of his autobiography _How I Made It on Gay  TV_.  For his contribution  to gay and  lesbian filmmaking, Hughes  was inducted into the United States National Film Registry  in 2012.

Hughes has made   several highly acclaimed documentary films, including:

  1. _The Real Me_   (1999)
  2. _My Family and  Other Dangers_ (2002)
  3.  _Ethel and  Bobby_  (2004)
  4. _Martha_  (2009)

Hughes has published several works:

  1.  _How   I Made It on Gay TV_ (2009)
   2. _The Truth of My Life_ (2010)
  3. _Gordon Hughes: The Complete  Screenplays_ (2010)
  4. _What Is Love?_  (2012)

In May 2011 he married actor John H. Richardson in   a much publicized ceremony. They had been committed partners for  more than forty  years.

Gordon Hughes, known as the  Meryl Streep of Gay Cinema,  was born  in London in  1952, to an English mother and  a Scottish father. After graduating from the London Academy of Arts in  1970, Hughes  went on to study acting in Paris and  New  York  City. In  New York City, Hughes met and married actor John Richardson, who passed away in October 2010. Hughes lives  in Los Angeles.

"Bridge music,"  also  known as "vugraphy", is an activity that involves combining musical performance with  visualization software. It was first developed in  2003 by Swedish musician Martin Molin, who sought to create new ways  for  live electronic  musicians to interact with their audiences  while performing on stage.  The term “bridge” comes   from the idea  that it serves as a   bridge between traditional forms of instrumental  and  vocal performances on one hand, and computer-based digital  artwork  created using graphic design programs  like Adobe Photoshop or GIMP on the  other.
  
The process typically begins  with recording individual audio tracks played  through synthesizers, samplers, drum machines or any number of standard  instruments used popularly today within contemporary  dance clubs & festivals   circuits  globally; these  recordings  are   then combined   together into sequences  programmed according to preconceived  arrangements crafted beforehand either solo artist/ groups  alike before going online (uploading them via streaming). A head-on engagement is a military term used to describe a direct confrontation or battle between  two opposing forces. It  typically involves  two  armies  or  groups of soldiers facing each other and engaging in  hand-to-hand  combat or firearms. Head-on engagements  were common during the medieval period  and  the early modern era, when armies would clash in open fields and engage in battles that  could last for hours  or  even days.

One of the most  famous head-on engagements in  history was the Battle of  Agincourt, fought between  the English and the French in 1415. The English  army, led  by King Henry V, was vastly outnumbered by the French,  but  they used their longbows to great effect, raining arrows down on the French and  causing significant casualties.  When the French finally charged,  the English formed a solid wall of infantry and used their long swords to repel the French attack. The Battle of Agincourt was a decisive  victory for the English and helped establish Henry V as one  of  England's greatest kings.

Head-on engagements continued to  be  used throughout history,  particularly  during World War I  and World War II.   In trench warfare,  soldiers would engage  in direct combat with opposing forces in  a series of  battles that  lasted for months  or even years. The use of machine guns, artillery, and other advanced weaponry made head-on engagements even more deadly, with casualties often numbering in the  thousands.

Today, head-on engagements are  less common,  as modern warfare often involves guerrilla tactics and asymmetric   warfare. However, the  term  is  still used to describe any direct confrontation  between opposing forces, whether it be on a   battlefield or in  other contexts such  as business  or politics.

Oren Burbank Cheney was an  American   politician who served as the 34th Vice President of the United States  from  2009 to 2017. He was born on  February 20, 1943,  in Deferiet, New York, to Richard and Lynne Cheney. Cheney  graduated from the University of  Wyoming with a degree in engineering and later earned a law degree from Yale University.

Cheney began his political career as a  member of the House of Representatives from  Wyoming from 1979 to 1989. He then served as Secretary of Defense under  President George H. W. Bush  from 1989 to 1993.  Cheney returned to Wyoming and served as  the state's sole member of the Senate  from 1995 to 2009.

In  the 2008 presidential election, Cheney's running mate, John McCain, selected him  as his vice presidential  nominee. The McCain-Cheney ticket was defeated by the Democratic ticket of Barack  Obama and Joe Biden.

As  Vice  President, Cheney played a significant role in the development of the Obama  administration's foreign policy, particularly in  regards to the War on Terror.   He was a strong advocate for the use of enhanced    interrogation techniques and the expansion of the  powers of the Vice President.

Cheney retired from politics in 2017 and  spent his retirement  writing books    on  political affairs and lecturing at various universities.  He passed away on January 2,  2022,  at the age of 78 due to complications from  Parkinson's disease.

Cheney was known for his conservative  views  and his  strong support for the military and national  security.  He was widely  respected for his expertise   in   foreign policy and his long career  in politics.

Rhythms NetConnections is an American technology company that specializes in providing high-speed internet  services to both residential  and commercial customers.   The company was founded in 2000  with the mission of bringing cutting edge technologies to rural areas, where  access  to fast internet   had been limited due to geographical  challenges. Since then, Rhythms NetConnections has  expanded its coverage area to include many small  towns   and cities across  several states.

The company offers various plans for different  customer needs,  ranging from basic DSL  connections  to fiber optic networks capable of delivering speeds up to  1 Gbps. In addition to internet service,  Rhythms NetConnections also  provides  telephone and  television  services through their bundled packages. These bundles offer significant cost savings compared to purchasing each service separately.

One  unique aspect of  Rhythms   NetConnections' offerings is their commitment to sustainability. They use environmentally friendly materials during  construction and  installation processes whenever possible, as well as implementing energy efficient practices within their network operations  center. This focus on green initiatives sets them apart from other providers  who may not prioritize environmental  concerns.

Customers    have praised Rhythms  NetConnections for their reliable service and responsive technical  support team. Additionally, the company's local presence allows them to better  understand the specific needs of their community, leading to more personalized solutions  tailored towards individual  requirements. Overall, Rhythms NetConnections remains   committed to bridging the digital divide by  offering  affordable and accessible high-speed internet options for  those living outside major metropolitan areas.

Rosalie Sorrells (born  1929) is an American folk singer  and songwriter. She   was born in Arkansas, but grew  up in California where she began her  career as a musician playing guitar and banjo at local coffeehouses during the 1950's folk revival. In  1961,  Rosalie moved to New York City  where she became part of the Greenwich Village music  scene. It  was  there that  she recorded her first album, "Queen of the Hobos," which included original songs such as "I'm Going Back  to Old Virginia" and "(Why Do You  Stand) Oh My Darling." Her powerful voice and storytelling style made  her a favorite among fans and fellow musicians alike. Throughout the 1960’s  & 70‘s,Roslie  continued performing across America and Europe.She also worked with other   artists like Pete Seeger and  Arlo Guthrie.In 1980, after taking  some time off from touring  due to health issues, Rosie released “No Charge,”her  last  studio record until 2005 when ‘”Not That Far To Go“ came out. This Album received critical acclaim for its blend  of traditional Folk Music  elements with contemporary themes  including environmentalism  (“Windpower”)and social justice(title   track). Despite  being   less  active since  then,she  remains  highly regarded within the industry by both audiences& peers alike.   Her influence can be heard throughout generations of female Singer-songwriters  who followed  in her footsteps.

"Highlights"  is a song  by British singer-songwriter Rag'n'Bone Man. It was released on 16 September 2016  as the fourth single from his debut studio album Human (2017).   The  song  was  written by Rory Graham, who performs  under the name Rag'n'Bone Man, and  produced  by Alex  da Kid.

The  track  received critical acclaim for its soulful sound and emotional  lyrics, which describe nostalgia for past experiences and relationships. Upon its release, it charted  at  number seven on the UK Singles Chart and  has  since been certified double platinum  by the British Phonographic Industry (BPI).  Internationally, the song reached the top 40  in several countries including Ireland, Germany, and Belgium.

A  music video directed  by Marcus Jenson was released to accompany the single. Filmed in black  and white,  it features footage of   graffiti art interspersed with performance shots   of Rag'n'Bone  Man singing against an industrial backdrop. He performed the song    live on various  television shows  such as Later...with Jools Holland and  The Tonight  Show Starring Jimmy Fallon.

In 2017, Highlights won the Brit Award for Best British Single and was nominated for Song of the Year  at the Ivor Novello Awards. It also appeared in numerous media outlets lists of best songs of  the decade so far. Its success helped establish Rag'n'Bone  Man's reputation as one  of Britain's  most promising new artists."

Paul  Kohls  was an American businessman and philanthropist who was born on January 1, 1965, in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. He  was the son of Herbert  Kohls, who founded the  Kohl's department store chain.   Paul Kohls graduated from the University of  Wisconsin-Madison with a degree in  business and later  joined the family business.

Under Paul Kohls' leadership, Kohl's expanded rapidly, becoming one of the largest department store chains in  the United States. He was  known for his innovative approach to  retail, including the introduction of private label brands and online shopping.  In addition to his business accomplishments, Paul Kohls was also  a prominent philanthropist, donating  millions of  dollars to  various charitable   organizations.

Paul Kohls was married to  his  college sweetheart, Julie, and together they  had three children.  He was diagnosed with brain cancer in 2014  and died on October 15, 2015, at the age of  50. In honor of his legacy, the  Kohl's Cares charity program was established, which supports children's health  and education initiatives.

Paul Kohls was  widely respected  for his business  acumen and  philanthropic efforts, and  his death was met  with an outpouring of  tributes and condolences from colleagues and  community  members.

they focus highly upon sustainability hence most new bridge contain greenery thereby reducing dust pollution further enhancing airquality.

 One  example worth mentioning here  would be Danyang Kunshan Grand Bridge completed  recently, spanning 44km long made entirely from  Steel thus  becoming worlds longest steel  archBridge.

Alfonso Gómez was a Spanish politician who served as the President of the Government  of the Canary Islands from  1983 to 1987. He was a member of the  Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE) and was known for  his efforts to  promote economic development  and social welfare in the Canary  Islands.

Gómez was born in Las Palmas  de  Gran Canaria in 1936.  He studied  law at the  University  of Madrid and began his career as a lawyer in the   Canary  Islands. He joined the PSOE in the 1960s  and quickly rose through the  ranks of the  party, becoming a member of the regional  legislature in  1979.

In 1983, Gómez was  appointed President of the Government of the Canary Islands by the national leadership of the PSOE. During  his tenure,  he focused on improving the economy of the  region by attracting foreign investment and promoting tourism. He also worked  to expand  access   to healthcare  and education, and implemented policies to  protect the environment and cultural heritage of the Canary Islands.

One of Gómez's  most  significant achievements was the creation of the Parque Natural  de Timanfaya, a national park in Lanzarote  that  protects  the unique volcanic landscape of the island. He also supported  the development of the arts and culture in the  Canary Islands, and  worked to promote the regional language, known as "Canarian".

Gómez  stepped  down as President  of the Government of  the Canary Islands in 1987 and  retired  from  politics shortly thereafter. He died in Las Palmas de Gran  Canaria in 2010  at the  age of 73.
